column2: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch arrived at the Capitol, documentary film crew in tow, to press his campaign to reshape the redistricting process.
Karl Rove, the former senior adviser to President George Bush, has a new goal for 2012: raise $120 million to help defeat President Obama and the Democrats.

12:43 p.m. | Updated Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, is no stranger to tough ads. His Republican opponent for governor of Virginia in 2005 once alleged Mr. Kaine would defend Hitler from murder charges (see below).
In news that will surprise absolutely no one, Christian Dior has begun proceedings to terminate John Galliano's employment in the wake of two race-tinged scandals that have emerged in the past week.

Automakers have already put a considerable dent in the 170 product debuts expected at the Geneva auto show, which opened Tuesday to the press. A Wheels correspondent, Jerry Garrett, is on the convention floor and will file news and photos throughout the day. You can check back regularly for the latest.
The Coca-Cola Company announced on Monday that it would buy the rest of Honest Tea, an organic-beverage maker. Coke first purchased a stake in the company three years ago. Read more »

The N.H.L. trade deadline day was relatively quiet. But one team was hard at work: the Washington Capitals. Striving to turn around a rocky season and strengthen their hand for the playoffs, the Caps made the biggest moves of the day, acquiring Jason Arnott from the Devils and Dennis Wideman from the Florida Panthers.

The Treasury Department announced plans on Tuesday to begin unwinding its stake in Ally Financial, the former lending arm of General Motors, which received a substantial taxpayer bailout during the financial crisis.

FutureGen, the Energy Department's on-again, off-again pilot project for capturing and sequestering carbon dioxide from coal-fired power plants, has chosen a place to put this greenhouse gas: in Morgan County, Ill., about 32 miles from a power plant in Meredosia, Ill., that was chosen for the project.

ABC took a break on Monday night from providing a 24-hour platform for Charlie Sheen so it could briefly address the more pressing business of unveiling the next cast of contenders for "Dancing With the Stars." The roster of semi- and never-were-celebs for the 12th season of that popular reality competition may not include anyone as instantly fascinating as, say, Bristol Palin, who danced her way to a third-place finish on the show last fall, and producers were apparently unsuccessful in casting their spell over Christine O'Donnell, the Republican senatorial candidate from Delaware, to take part in the new cycle.

We all know that the top deal makers at the Blackstone Group -- led by its chief executive, Stephen A. Schwarzman -- are among the most well-paid executives on Wall Street. But what about its top lawyer?

The N.H.L. trade deadline is certainly not what it used to be. Many general managers have begun to see the wisdom of making deals when they're not under the gun of filing paperwork by 3:00 pm. After 31 trades were made at the deadline a year ago, only 16 were finalized on Monday.
Goldman Sachs estimates its legal wrangles could "reasonably" cost the firm $3.4 billion, according to a regulatory filing released Tuesday.

In light of Natalie Portman's Oscar win this week for her role as an obsessive ballerina in "Black Swan," A. O. Scott looks back at "The Red Shoes," one of the definitive dance films about an artist who sacrifices herself for her art. The 1948 film, directed by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger, is "a wonderful depiction of an artist at work and a fascinating examination of the obsessive drive to create art," Mr. Scott says. "But what makes it great is how completely it surrenders itself to that obsession."

On Tuesday, The Lede is supplementing coverage of the uprising in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East by our colleagues in the region. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. Readers can also follow some of the discussion of the region on Twitter in this blog's right column.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Via Mark Thoma, the Dallas Fed notes some acceleration even in its core inflation measures, although these remain below target. What should we make of this?

The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision will discuss whether to allow contingent convertible bonds -- CoCo's -- to count toward additional capital requirements for big global banks, Bloomberg News reports. Read more »

The new poll reported in this morning's Times will, I suspect, come as a shock to many political commentators. Quite a few news analyses of the assault on public-sector workers have simply assumed that the move was a political winner, with little if any thought given to the possibility that the general public wasn't actually ready to go along. But whaddya know: while people don't necessarily love unions -- hey, I personally don't necessarily love unions -- most people apparently see them as having a legitimate role.
"You know more than you should."

BERLIN -- For many private equity players, social media is simply an investment opportunity. But as Mideast revolutionaries embrace Facebook and Twitter as a tool, David Rubenstein of the Carlyle Group wonders whether shareholder activists will take their fights online, too.

Monday's taste of spring will vanish on Tuesday, which will be clear and still relatively warm with highs around 45 degrees.

On Tuesday at the CeBIT consumer-electronics show in Hanover, Germany, Alan Mulally, Ford chief executive, introduced a European-spec version of the automaker's Sync Emergency Assistance system. The software should work in 30 European Union and adjacent countries, according to Ford.

FT's Alphaville breaks down the numbers for Egg, the British credit card portfolio that Barclays agreed to buy from Citigroup. Owing to different accounting standards, Barclays reported the group had roughly £2.3 billion of gross receivables while Citigroup reported £1.8 billion. The reason: the United States requires banks to write down accounts that are past due. Read more »

Success in business is the culmination of many decisions, actions and behaviors. Good customer service feeds customer referrals, good management feeds efficiency, and good engineering feeds good products. A less obvious but equally powerful force is the virtuous cycle of money.
The ancient Egyptians had their tombs -- well-decorated spaces that contained belongings for the afterlife. Bob Brier has his three adjacent apartments in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

When Joe Mauer  came up in the Minnesota Twins' minor league system, he stood out with his talent. He also stood out with his height -- 6 feet 5 inches --  a fact that had some people skeptical that he could make it in the majors as a catcher. Mauer, 27, sees those same developmental questions facing the Yankees' top catching prospect, Jesus Montero, who is 6-4, 225 pounds.

We've all been there: you want to get a tattoo, but you'd also love to hear some live music, see some local art and have a piece of cake. Well, there's a spot for you in Paris: Horror Picture Tea, which opened in January, a funky mixture of luxury dessert shop, music venue, bistro, urban art gallery and, yes, tattoo parlor.

For her "Measure of a Woman" project, Hazel Thompson spent six months in 2007 and 2008 in Bahrain and Qatar, documenting women's roles in modern Arab culture. James Estrin interviewed her in New York last week about her experiences in Bahrain. Their conversation has been edited and condensed.

We're inspired to ask this question today by this article, which describes how the Oscar winner Natalie Portman was also a semifinalist in the Intel science competition while in high school on Long Island - and then went on to study neuroscience at Harvard. Though, as the article points out, she is "depressingly impressive," everyone has talents he or she hasn't yet had the ability or drive to bring out. What do you think yours might be? Why? How do you think you could develop them?

German scientists said on Friday that it might be possible to reconstruct the smaller of the two Bamiyan Buddhas destroyed in Afghanistan by the Taliban in 2001, Agence France Presse reported. Conservators at Munich's Technical University have been studying fragments of the statues for the last 18 months and have concluded that the smaller one, which stood 125 feet tall but was only about 6 feet deep, could be reconstructed by reassembling the recovered parts. (They do not advocate trying to restore the Buddha to its original appearance.) Erwin Emmerling, one of the scientists, is to present the group's findings this week at a Unesco conference in Paris on the long-term fate of the statues.

Aronson, former Director of the Group Therapy Training Program. He led the Group Department for more than 30 years, and made extraordinary contributions to the field, as well as to the well-being of his colleagues, students and patients. DAINES--Richard F.,MD. It is with a tremendous sense of sadness that the entire Continuum Health Partners community acknowledges the sudden and untimely passing of our dear friend and colleague, Richard F. Daines, MD, former President of St. Luke's and Roosevelt Hospitals (SLR) and former Commissioner of Health for New York State. Richard leaves behind a tremendous legacy of achievement in advancing healthcare delivery in New York State. As SLR President, Richard strengthened the hospital's clinical programs, broadened its primary care base, and put in motion expansion of emergency services at Roosevelt Hospital. He also developed and led very strong administrative and clinical management teams and cultivated a work environment that positively supported many of these successes. As State Health Commissioner, Richard took bold steps to appropriately adjust the size and scope of the State's health care delivery system. He also served as an advocate for improving the general health and well-being of all New Yorkers, advancing programs and initiatives that targeted our most pressing issues. And he brought back to the Department an environment of openness, collegiality and transparency. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Linda, his sons, William and Andrew, his daughter, Katherine, his parents, his siblings, a large extended family, many grateful patients and countless colleagues, friends and admirers. Richard will be greatly missed by all who knew him and worked with him. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO, Continuum Gail F. Donovan Executive Vice President and COO Continuum Frank J. Cracolici President, SLR Oscar Garfein, MD President, SLR Medical Board

DAINES--Dr. Richard F.,60, passed away unexpectedly February 26th. He was Commissioner of Health for New York State from 2007-2010. He was deeply loved by his family and will be sorely missed. Dr. Daines was born February 17, 1951 to Newel and Jean Daines in Preston, Idaho, and grew up in Logan, UT. He served an LDS mission in Bolivia from 1970-72. He received a B.A. from Utah State University in 1974, and an M.D. from Cornell University in 1978. Dr. Daines and Linda, his wife of 36 years, made their home in New York City and Dutchess County, NY. Dr. Daines worked tirelessly to improve the health and happiness of his patients and all New Yorkers. His devotion to his work was exceeded only by his devotion to his family. Dr. Daines is survived by his wife, Linda, children William, Katherine, and Andrew, grandson Charles Richard, parents, and siblings Pamela, George, Janet, and Peter. A viewing will take place on March 1st from 6-8pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. The funeral service will be held at 11am on March 2nd at the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 217 East 87th Street, New York, NY. Dr. Daines will be laid to rest at Logan City Cemetery in Logan, Utah on March 3rd. In lieu of flowers, the family kindly requests that contributions be made in his memory to the following charities: Weill Cornell Medical College (www.med.cornell.edu), the Leonard J. Arrington Chair of History at Utah State University (www.usu.edu/giving), or the Boy Scouts of America (www.scouting.org).

SCHEIN--Richard, passed away at home on February 27, 2011 at age 84. He is survived by adoring wife, Carol; daughters Jylle, Cristina, Leslie and Audrey; sons-in-law Anthony and Bill; grandchildren Shealyn, Cormac, Olivia and Evan. He made his home in Manhattan, Sagaponack and Longboat Key. He served in the Navy, graduated from NYU, and had a long and successful career as Group VP at Cranston Print Works. He was an avid tennis player, patron of fine arts and lover of film. He touched many with his enjoyment of life's richness, his generosity, graciousness and good humor. He is remembered with admiration and love. Services Wednesday 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in Richard's memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

BATTAILE--Janet White. A memorial service was held at St. Columba's Episcopal Church in Washington, D.C., on Thursday, February 24, to honor a dear colleague and friend, Janet White Battaile, a longtime editor of The New York Times. Ms. Battaile, 63, died on Friday, February 18, succumbing to multiple myeloma after keeping the disease at bay through successful, and at times experimental, drug treatments for nearly 11 years. Throughout a decade since the diagnosis in 2000, Ms. Battaile displayed courage and tenacity, using her journalistic reportorial skills to research and pursue new and innovative medicines. For example, she first volunteered for a clinical trial of thalidomide at the Mayo Clinic, becoming a "data point" in the study that led to approval of the drug as the first new myeloma treatment in many years. It wasn't until this last year that Ms. Battaile was unable to fend off the disease's progression. In her professional life, Ms. Battaile worked for more than 25 years as an editor for The New York Times, in its Washington bureau, and earlier for its News Service. Before she took early retirement in 2005, she worked with The Times's video and multi-media units, after inaugurating the paper's pioneering online video endeavor, Political Points, with ABC News during the 2000 presidential election. During Ms. Battaile's tenure as a deputy editor in the Washington bureau, she shepherded and coordinated significant policy and political coverage. She oversaw national news coverage through parts of four presidential administrations, from Ronald Reagan's through George W. Bush's, and edited countless Page One articles of legislative battles in Congress over domestic issues as well as those on wars, terrorism and numerous scandals. Her colleagues tell tales like this one: She once alerted staff to missile strikes against Iraq by getting a message posted on a billboard at Camden Yards to those attending a ballgame. Throughout the impeachment scandal during the Clinton administration, Ms. Battaile coordinated news coverage of the events, editing major investigative works as well as profiles of prominent officials. She often spent hours into the late nights preparing and perfecting articles for the newspaper. Ms. Battaile was beloved by many for her attention to detail, and her deft touch that improved reporters' copy on a daily basis. She was also appreciated for her buoyant, cheerful personality, someone whose smile and laughter lifted the bureau's spirits time and again. She has been sorely missed in the bureau these last few years. After her retirement from The Times, she also wrote and edited for Politics Daily, the Web site that is part of AOL. Between her stints at The Times's News Service, which began in 1974, and her return to the newspaper's Washington bureau in 1987, Ms. Battaile served as the deputy Washington bureau chief of The Dallas Morning News from 1981-1987. Ms. Battaile began her career with The Associated Press, in Des Moines, Iowa, in 1969. She was transferred to the New York General Desk in 1971, and worked there until she joined The Times. She was born in Winchester, VA, on March 2, 1947. Ms. Battaile was educated at St. Catherine's School in Richmond, VA, and Lake Erie College in Painesville, OH, where she received a bachelor of arts degree in English. While there, she did a semester at the Universite de Nancy in Nancy, France. She is survived by her husband, Jerry Knight, the retired financial columnist for The Washington Post; their three children, Jesse of Salt Lake City, Erin of Yardley, PA, Marc of Parkesburg, PA; her siblings Jeannie Battaile of Winchester, VA, John Battaile of Stanardsville, VA and Lawrence Battaile of Collington, NC, and eight grandchildren.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Friday about Sanford S. Sigoloff, an executive who helped restructure failing companies, characterized incorrectly a company for which Mr. Sigoloff worked. The company, Kaufman & Broad, a Los Angeles home builder, was financially stable; it was not distressed.

MARION--Elliot, former Bride's Magazine Publisher dies one month shy of his 86th birthday. The WWII Veteran began his publishing career in 1955 working for Seventeen Magazine. Moving to Conde Nast Publications in 1962 where he loved his life working at Glamour, Mademoiselle and Bride's magazines. Raising his family in Jericho, NY, he retired to Boca Raton, FL where he became an avid sculptor and was editor of the local paper for 16 years. He loved festivities, singing and dancing amongst family and friends, welcoming all with a big smile and a warm hug. Survived by his adoring wife of 55 years Barbara and their three children Scott, David and Amy, daughter in law Debra Holloway, and son-in-law Douglas Bobley. He will be forever missed by his seven grandchildren, his extended family and his lifelong friends who he touched forever.

And it is the maker of Camel cigarettes; it does not make Marlboro, which is a Philip Morris brand.

(49) ME FACING LIFE: CYNTOIA'S STORY In August 2004 Cyntoia Brown, 16, shot and killed Johnny Allen, a 43-year-old Tennessee real estate agent she said had picked her up for sex. Two years later Ms. Brown -- who had been born to a 16-year-old and adopted as a toddler -- was tried as an adult, found guilty of first-degree murder and especially aggravated robbery, and sentenced to life. In this ''Independent Lens'' presentation, Daniel H. Birman follows Ms. Brown, above, for six years, starting the week she was arrested, in the hope of exposing the reasons for violence among youth. What he discovered was a history, seemingly shaped by heredity and circumstance, that had repeated itself through each generation of Ms. Brown's biological family. 5:30 P.M. (Cinemax) FUNNY PEOPLE (2009) In this film from Judd Apatow, Adam Sandler plays George Simmons, a stand-up comedian turned Hollywood star and jerk, who discovers that he has a rare, potentially fatal blood disease. Seth Rogen is Ira, the fledgling comic George hires as an assistant, who for the time being seems only too content to accept scraps from his employer. Mr. Apatow's wife, Leslie Mann, plays Laura, the love who got away from George, and the one he wants back now that he's dying. (The Apatows' daughters play Laura's children.) Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said there was ''something irritatingly self-satisfied'' about the film, partly stemming from the autobiographical touches. ''Watching 'Funny People,' you get the sense that Mr. Apatow, one of the most successful filmmakers working in Hollywood, is very happy,'' she wrote. ''Bummer.''

The ''go shop'' on Wall Street is quickly becoming a ''no shop.'' After an acquisition is announced, the target company often has the opportunity to solicit higher bids from potential suitors, in what's known as the go-shop process - as in ''go shop'' for a better deal. The buyer is supposed to act as a stalking horse, attracting other, more lucrative offers.

Though the theater has a rich tradition of productions centered around singing nuns, Mr. Beane, the author of ''The Little Dog Laughed'' and the book of the ''Xanadu'' musical, said that ''Sister Act'' was his ''first Catholic piece.''

LONDON -- Fame kills. Or at the very least, it would appear, it destroys your health, your love life, your family and your sanity. The wages of celebrity are being assessed all over this city in productions that should give weighty pause to those who would be stars. Most conspicuously, there's ''Anna Nicole,'' the title character of the new opera about the perils of Ms. Smith (the chest that launched a thousand tabloid covers) and the hardest ticket in town to wrangle. But audiences are cramming into smaller theaters to watch other figures grow, shrink and generally agonize in the spotlight. Among them is one Judy Garland (incarnated with uncanny fierceness by Tracie Bennett), whose calamity-filled visit to London a few months before her death has been re-created in the inevitably titled ''End of the Rainbow'' at Trafalgar Studios.

Do you treat yourself as well as you treat your friends and family? That simple question is the basis for a burgeoning new area of psychological research called self-compassion - how kindly people view themselves. People who find it easy to be supportive and understanding to others, it turns out, often score surprisingly low on self-compassion tests, berating themselves for perceived failures like being overweight or not exercising.

A crucial part of the securitization market - the Wall Street credit machine that helped set off the financial crisis - is kicking back into gear. In the last few weeks, a number of big banks have successfully bundled and sold new securities backed by commercial real estate loans. Morgan Stanley and Bank of America completed a $1.55 billion deal last month that included office and retail properties. So far this year, financial firms have sold about $5 billion of commercial mortgage-backed securities, almost as much as was done in all of 2010.

Harrison, Jr. She is survived by her three stepsons along with grand and great-grandchildren who will all miss her dearly. LUBRANO--David Gordon, died on Wednesday, February 23, 2011 in Boston, MA, surrounded by his family; he was eighty years old. Mr. Lubrano was born on October 19, 1930 in Providence, RI. He completed his secondary school education at Moses Brown School in Providence. He then graduated from Brown University in 1952, where he was a member of Delta Upsilon fraternity, a writer for the school newspaper, a member of the orchestra, and on both the tennis and ski teams. In 1956, he received his Master of Business Administration degree with distinction from The Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College. After college and prior to graduate school, Mr. Lubrano served in the US Army with the Military Police during the Korean conflict, where he was stationed in Seoul for which he received his combat infantry badge. He began his career as a certified public accountant for Arthur Anderson's Boston Office. He left the firm in 1968 and co-founded National Medical Care, a provider of kidney dialysis services, which ultimately went public and was listed on the New York Stock Exchange. During the course of his 12 years of service at National Medical Care, Mr. Lubrano acted as Senior Vice President, Treasurer, and Director of the firm. In 1980, Mr. Lubrano joined Apollo Computer Inc., one of the first vendors of graphical workstations that dominated the corporate landscape around Chelmsford, MA and helped establish Route 128 as the east coast challenger to California's Silicon Valley. He ultimatley served as its Chief Financial Officer. From 1980 to 1987, Apollo was the country's largest manufacturer of network workstations. Mr. Lubrano resigned from Apollo in 1986 to found his own venture capital firm, 21st Century Ventures Inc. Over decades, Mr. Lubrano served on the Board of Directors of numerous corporations including Staples Inc. and Bitstream Inc. He also served on the Board of Trustees of each of the educational institutions of which he was a graduate, including the Moses Brown School, Brown University, and the Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College. At the time of his death, Mr. Lubrano served on the Board of Trustees of the Dana Farber Cancer Institute. Mr. Lubrano was the son of the late Jack and Ruth Lubrano of Providence, RI. Before he was stricken by Mesothelioma in 2010, he fully intended to break their record for longevity (102 and 107 years, respectively.) He was predeceased by his wife of 43 years, Jean Hambleton Lubrano, with whom he raised a family of five. Mr. Lubrano resided in Hingham, MA; Bridgton, ME; and Vero Beach, FL. For a period of time in the mid-1980's, he was the co-owner of the Pleasant Mountain Ski Resort in Bridgton, Maine and helped install the mountain's first triple chair. He was an avid skier, hiker, camper, canoeist, golfer and tennis player. He had a great love of music and was a long-time supporter of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. He married Jean Keyo of Hingham, MA in 2005, and the couple split their time between Massachusetts, Maine, and Florida. In his last years, Mr. Lubrano was happiest piloting his boat, The Satin Doll, on the waters of Moose Pond in Maine with his wife. Mr. Lubrano is survived by his wife, Jean Keyo Lubrano, and his five children: Beth Dwyer (Paul) of Pembroke, MA; Stacy Lamson (Timothy) of Amesbury, MA; Steven Lubrano (Allegra) of Hanover, NH; Jennifer Clayton (Mark) of Hingham, MA; Kathryn Robinson (Kenneth) of Providence, RI; and 11 grandchildren. Mr. Lubrano was a loyal congregant of St. John's Episcopal Church in Hingham, MA where a memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 5, 2011 at 1pm. Donations in his memory may be made to Loon Echo Land Trust for the Preservation of Pleasant Mountain, 1 Chase St., Bridgton, ME 04009 or the Mesothelioma Applied Research Foundation, 1317 King Street, Alexandria, VA 22314. See www.Keohane.com for online condolences and directions.

A little more than a year before I was laid off from my job as an editor of Harper's Magazine, one of my colleagues quit and I was given his office. It was easily twice the size of my previous windowless workbox, with ego-boosting views of lower Manhattan, and ample space for decoration and a few personal comforts. Before moving in I decided to contribute a few dollars to Ikea's global revenue. In short order, I had outfitted myself with a pair of down-market reading lamps, a few modernist picture frames for my family photos, a colorful little area rug and even a ridiculous "lumbar cushion" pillow for my reading chair, all of which, in my humble opinion, suggested a certain sense of permanence and ease.

The wizards over at Politico know that a Marginally Famous Author plus a Specious Comparison of Obama to an Unloved Ex-President equals Web Traffic Gold, and so today they have a predictable essay (picked up by The Drudge Report, of course) by Steve Forbes about how Obama is messing up the environment, just as Jimmy Carter did. I don't want to get into the specifics of Forbes's argument here - it's pretty boilerplate stuff - but I do want to call your attention to a recent Rolling Stone article about Carter. It's not an apologia, far from it. But it complicates our understanding of our 39th president in necessary ways. By the end of the article - and if you have the patience, the end of the essay Carter's old speechwriter Hendrik Hertzberg wrote about him way back when - Carter will feel to you much more like a real man, not just a punching bag who is trotted out every now and again to boost Web stats.

Adele, the British singer who won the Grammy Award for best new artist two years ago, is the big winner on the Billboard chart this week, with a No. 1 opening for her new album and a rebound for her last one. Adele's new album, "21" (XL/Columbia), opened with 352,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Thanks to a blitz of television appearances to promote the album, that was the best opening-week sales of any album in three months. (In the interim, there have been some painfully low numbers.) And her debut album, "19," bolted 34 spots to No. 16, with 18,000 sales. But almost everything else on the chart is a loser. Last week's No. 1, Justin Bieber's "Never Say Never: The Remixes" (Island), fell to No. 2 with 102,000, a 38 percent decline, and Mr. Bieber's "My World 2.0," at No. 5, lost 22 percent. Mumford & Sons' "Sigh No More" (Glassnote), at No. 3, dropped 46 percent; "Now That's What I Call Music!" Vol. 37 is No. 4 with a 38 percent loss; Bruno Mars's "Doo-Wops & Hooligans" (Elektra), at No. 6, lost 40 percent, and so on. Last week's numbers were higher than usual because of the traditional retail boost the week after the Grammys. But that only underlines the scale of Adele's success. On the digital singles chart, Lady Gaga's "Born This Way," which was enormously popular out of the gate, lost 44 percent of its sales in its third week, with 286,000, although that was enough for it to hold at No. 1.

I recently had a citrus fruit-based trifle and it brought to mind a citrus terrine I had eaten years ago at Astier, a restaurant in Paris. I am not sure if it is still on the menu, but it basically was made up of grapefruit and orange segments held together in a mold by their own gelled juice. Was there a thin layer of cake? I don't think so; just fruit, juice and gelatin, and a little Grand Marnier.

Katori Hall, a 29-year-old playwright from Memphis whose work examines the historical and social forces affecting African-American characters, has been named the 33rd winner of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize. The award is given annually to outstanding women playwrights. Ms. Hall received $20,000 and a signed and numbered print by the artist Willem de Kooning for her play "Hurt Village," about the problems of families in a decaying Memphis housing project.

Sophie Morner has been a central figure in what has come to be a new photography movement in and around Brooklyn. As the founder and owner of the widely respected Capricious Magazine and the soon-to-close Capricious Gallery, she has provided exposure for young, up-and-coming photographers, as well as the often marginalized work of people deeply embedded in queer culture. Morner is an avid equestrian as well as an artist, and her simultaneous passions for gender ambiguity and horses weave a curious pair of threads through much of her work and curatorial choices.

Want an easy way to predict the downfall of Arab governments? Follow Amr Moussa. When the former Egyptian foreign minister and longtime general secretary of the Arab League showed up in Tahrir Square on Friday, Feb. 4, I turned to a colleague - I really did! - and said words to this effect: "Amr Moussa never sticks his neck out. Mubarak is finished." Soon history fell in neatly behind.

We lost a lot of brain cells out on the road with the Grateful Dead, but maybe we gained some, too. Witness "The Music Never Stopped," a film adaptation of Oliver Sacks's account of a man who is unable to store new memories after a brain tumor ravages his frontal lobe. It is discovered that music - particularly the Dead's - is able to penetrate the barrier ever so slightly and help the man to reconnect with himself and his family. Some facts (some big ones) from Sacks's essay, "The Last Hippie," seem to have been altered and molded into a workable movie narrative, naturally, and I worry that Sacks's poignantly honest account will have received a Hollywood face-lift. But maybe the film will surprise us, as did the melancholy but still-hopeful ending to "Awakenings."

Imagine the technology that creates real objects like medical implants, lampshades, car parts and mobile phones by hitting "Print" and sending digital files to inkjet printers. It's already happening. The "ink" is actually material that gets deposited in successive layers; after one layer is complete, the next follows, until solid objects emerge. One American company is now trying to print an entire car this way.

The soprano Angela Gheorghiu will be replaced by Hei-Kyung Hong in the role of Juliette in "Roméo et Juliette" at the Metropolitan Opera because she is ill, the Met said on Wednesday. The production opens on Thursday night and Ms. Hong will play the role in performances through March 26. The opera, conducted by Plácido Domingo, also stars Piotr Beczala as Roméo, Julie Boulianne as Stéphano, Lucas Meachem as Mercutio and James Morris as Frère Laurent.

I always thought I was a reader of obscure writers until I found this Tumblr blog, courtesy of GalleyCat. Of 30 Writers No One Reads, I'd heard of 5 and read 3. (Of these, I own a book by one, which I've barely cracked. In my defense, a cursory glance at an E. M. Cioran text gives you a feel for what lies within: "It's not worth the bother of killing yourself, since you always kill yourself too late.") You can nominate your own unread favorite, and if you don't have one, the cover art alone is worth a scroll - there's even a photo of the ever-glamorous Clarice Lispector.

Typography is now a bona fide art form. Some artists and graphic designers are turning typefaces into paintings and even sculpture. Andrew Byrom, a British-born type designer and professor at California State University at Long Beach, is a typographic conceptualist - a sculptor by any other name - who creates "experimental" typefaces out of Band-Aids, drinking straws, steel railings and neon lights. He has also turned them into objects like furniture, bathroom fixtures and kites.

In my article about coconut oil on Wednesday, I mentioned in passing a recipe for popcorn cooked in coconut oil. In my view, I think it is a perfect way to make popcorn. But if you want to get slightly fancier, try this double coconut version. The coconut flakes get brown and toasty and the mustard seeds add zing. If you don't have mustard seeds, leave them (and that step) out and add a pinch of cayenne to the coconut flakes instead.

Frankie Rose may be a little commitment-challenged - she played drums for Vivian Girls, Dum Dum Girls and Crystal Stilts but never hung around long enough to be considered part of any of those bands - but there is no questioning her status as a crusader of Brooklyn's indie-pop scene. Lately, Rose has been fronting her own retro-pop group, Frankie and the Outs. "While it was a scary transition, it was a natural progression for me, too," she says of her move from behind the drum kit to guitar and vocals. "I really did just get tired of playing the drums." And after touring her joyful, self-titled debut album, she is back in Brooklyn, which she calls "the best place in the world," in search of inspiration for her next album.

Updated, 2:20 p.m. | An elevator contractor fell six stories to his death down an elevator shaft in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, this morning, the Fire Department said. The man, who has not been identified, was cleaning cables on top of an elevator car at 988 Myrtle Avenue around 9:30 a.m. when he fell off the elevator car into the shaft, the police said. He was still breathing when emergency crews arrived, but he died at the scene. The building houses the Brooklyn Community Correctional Center, a halfway house for released prisoners.

To paraphrase Cracker, what the world needs now is another computer peripheral connection standard like I need a hole in the head. However, Apple has just put their might behind something they're calling Thunderbolt, a new type of data port that can transfer data at speeds up to 10 gigabits per second. Considering that the fastest USB 2.0 drives can transfer data at about 480 megabits per second (that's 0.46 Gbps or, in layman's terms, really slow), Thunderbolt may be a welcome change.

Greencare Interior Plants is a store in Houston that sells plants to residences and businesses. The N.F.L. players union won a significant legal battle Tuesday. In a reversal of a prior ruling, a federal judge in Minneapolis said that the N.F.L. violated an agreement with the players when it negotiated its latest TV contracts. The judge said the league settled for less money in exchange for the continued flow of cash in the event of a work stoppage. The N.F.L. had a duty to maximize revenue for the players, the judge said.

DAINES--Richard. We mourn the sudden and tragic loss of Dr. Richard Daines, husband of our board member, Linda. He was a great friend to SAB where his daughter studied for many years. TURITZ--Arlene, of Guilford, CT and Boynton Beach, FL, resided always and will forever in the hearts of her family and dear friends. She died March 1st after a brief and valiant battle with cancer, six months to the day after the death of her beloved husband, Phil. Was there ever more vitality or love of life in anyone? Her life was a song written in the key of love, to the beat of a heart that was a magnet for goodness, a dance of generosity. She inspired a very special hold on life in all of us and will be so missed by Danny and Hillary, Bethanie and Giancarlo Alhadeff, and her grandchildren, David Alhadeff, Allison, Andrea and Lexie Turitz. Services will be held on Thursday March 3, 12:45pm at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th St., New York, NY. A Memorial service will be held on March 9, 3pm, at Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 7205 W. Atlantic, Del Ray Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, donations to Hospice of Palm Beach County, in recognition of their extraordinary care.

BRUSSELS -- A push to align European corporate tax systems has emerged as the biggest obstacle to a proposal aimed at imposing more fiscal discipline on the 17 countries in the euro zone. At least five smaller nations voiced reservations about changes to corporate taxation outlined in a new European Union blueprint discussed Monday by governments, officials and diplomats said. They spoke anonymously because the talks were confidential. By contrast, France and Germany were likely to argue that the tax changes did not go far enough, the officials and diplomats added.

KEARNS--David T. The Board of Directors and Staff of the National Child Labor Committee mourn the death of our dear friend and colleague. His contributions to the well-being of millions of children and youth through his incisive and innovative leadership in the worlds of business and education over the past four decades are a beacon for the nation. We are humbled to have honored him earlier this year with the creation of the first annual David T. Kearns Award for Excellence and Innovation in Education, which gave him a great sense of pride, and that Award will now become a permanent legacy to his multi-faceted accomplishments. We send our deepest and most loving sympathies to his wife of more than half a century, Shirley, and to his beloved children Kathy, Elizabeth, Anne, Susan, Todd and Andrew, and his equally beloved 18 grandchildren. Erik Butler, Chairman Jeffrey Newman, President/Executive Director National Child Labor Committee

An article on Tuesday about eye doctors' warnings of hazards from high-powered green laser pointers sold on the Internet misstated the given name of the chief executive of Wicked Lasers, who said his company's products did not violate Food and Drug Administration restrictions because they are not called pointers. He is Steve Liu, not Sam.

Here's a stage revival we didn't expect to see in this or any other lifetime: Harry Connick Jr. will star in Michael Mayer's Broadway-bound reinvention of ''On a Clear Day You Can See Forever,'' one that puts a gender-bending twist on that classic musical by Burton Lane and Alan Jay Lerner. In the original ''Clear Day,'' which opened on Broadway in 1965, Barbara Harris played the irrepressible Daisy Gamble, who discovers with the help of the psychiatrist Dr. Mark Bruckner that she was, in a past life, Melinda Wells, a woman who lived in 18th-century Britain. (Barbra Streisand and Yves Montand played the characters in a 1970 film adaptation.)

Dr. Richard F. Daines, a former New York state health commissioner who espoused politically risky public health initiatives like closing hospitals and banning the use of food stamps to buy soda, died on Saturday at his family farm in Stanfordville, N.Y., in Dutchess County. He was 60. The death was confirmed by his former press secretary, Claudia Hutton.

ASPLEN--Peter, 83, died peacefully on February 21, 2011. Born in England, he emigrated to the U.S. over fifty years ago. Retired in 1989 after a textile industry career in the areas of advertising and design. Survived by niece and nephew-in-law, Maria and Douglas Ramsay, and grandnieces Fiona and Celina Ramsay of Buckinghamshire, UK. Death confirmed by Lawrence Dick, Attorney.

An obituary on Monday about Duke Snider, the longtime star center fielder for the Brooklyn Dodgers, misstated the number of National League players who have matched Snider's accomplishment of hitting 40 or more home runs in five consecutive seasons. There have been four, not two. (Besides Ralph Kiner and Barry Bonds, Sammy Sosa hit 40 or more in six consecutive seasons, from 1998 to 2003, and Adam Dunn did it in five, from 2004 to 2008.)

Joining the art carnival that descends on New York City during the annual Armory Show, the huge contemporary art fair that opens on Thursday, Times Square is transforming itself into a ''whimsical'' sculpture garden. Pieces by Tom Otterness (a huge bronze mouse, looking as if it has outgrown the subway), Niki de Saint Phalle (a 10-foot ceramic and glass female figure) and Kyu Seok Oh, a Brooklyn artist (a flock of sheep handmade from heavy paper) were unveiled on Tuesday along with two other sculptures by Grimanesa Amoros and David Kennedy Cutler. The works, presented by the Times Square Alliance, will remain on view through Monday.

The ancient Egyptians had their tombs -- well-decorated spaces that contained belongings for the afterlife. Bob Brier has his three adjacent apartments in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. ''People ask me what I'll do with all this stuff when I die,'' Dr. Brier said recently. ''I say: 'I'm an Egyptologist. I can take it with me.' ''

MARION--Elliot, former Bride's Magazine Publisher dies one month shy of his 86th birthday. The WWII Veteran began his publishing career in 1955 working for Seventeen Magazine. Moving to Conde Nast Publications in 1962 where he loved his life working at Glamour, Mademoiselle and Bride's magazines. Raising his family in Jericho, NY, he retired to Boca Raton, FL where he became an avid sculptor and was editor of the local paper for 16 years. He loved festivities, singing and dancing amongst family and friends, welcoming all with a big smile and a warm hug. Survived by his adoring wife of 55 years Barbara and their three children Scott, David and Amy, daughter in law Debra Holloway, and son-in-law Douglas Bobley. He will be forever missed by his seven grandchildren, his extended family and his lifelong friends who he touched forever.

SCHEIN--Richard, passed away at home on February 27, 2011 at age 84. He is survived by adoring wife, Carol; daughters Jylle, Cristina, Leslie and Audrey; sons-in-law Anthony and Bill; grandchildren Shealyn, Cormac, Olivia and Evan. Agricultural subsidies have helped bring us high-fructose corn syrup, factory farming, fast food, a two-soda-a-day habit and its accompanying obesity, the near-demise of family farms, monoculture and a host of other ills. Yet - like so many government programs - what subsidies need is not the ax, but reform that moves them forward. Imagine support designed to encourage a resurgence of small- and medium-size farms producing not corn syrup and animal-feed but food we can touch, see, buy and eat - like apples and carrots - while diminishing handouts to agribusiness and its political cronies.

DAINES--Dr. Richard F.,60, passed away unexpectedly February 26th. He was Commissioner of Health for New York State from 2007-2010. He was deeply loved by his family and will be sorely missed. Dr. Daines was born February 17, 1951 to Newel and Jean Daines in Preston, Idaho, and grew up in Logan, UT. He served an LDS mission in Bolivia from 1970-72. He received a B.A. from Utah State University in 1974, and an M.D. from Cornell University in 1978. Dr. Daines and Linda, his wife of 36 years, made their home in New York City and Dutchess County, NY. Dr. Daines worked tirelessly to improve the health and happiness of his patients and all New Yorkers. His devotion to his work was exceeded only by his devotion to his family. Dr. Daines is survived by his wife, Linda, children William, Katherine, and Andrew, grandson Charles Richard, parents, and siblings Pamela, George, Janet, and Peter. A viewing will take place on March 1st from 6-8pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. The funeral service will be held at 11am on March 2nd at the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, 217 East 87th Street, New York, NY. Dr. Daines will be laid to rest at Logan City Cemetery in Logan, Utah on March 3rd. In lieu of flowers, the family kindly requests that contributions be made in his memory to the following charities: Weill Cornell Medical College (www.med.cornell.edu), the Leonard J. Arrington Chair of History at Utah State University (www.usu.edu/giving), or the Boy Scouts of America (www.scouting.org).

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a Supreme Court ruling that a mortally wounded man's identification of his assailant may be used as evidence in court misspelled a word in a phrase used by Justice Antonin Scalia in his dissent. Justice Scalia pondered whether the defendant, convicted by the testimony of a witness he could not face in court, ''has received his just deserts.'' He did not use the often-seen, but erroneous spelling ''just desserts.''

Pierre Lucien, 27, has to learn how to walk again, with no legs, and with new legs. A police officer on medical leave who has lived in New York since leaving Haiti in 1989, Mr. Lucien was running at a police training facility three years ago when he collapsed -- and he has not felt the ground since. He contracted rhabdomyolosis, a disorder in which the breakdown of muscle fiber releases a protein pigment called myoglobin into the bloodstream, causing kidney failure and other organ damage. Mr. Lucien, who lives in Downtown Brooklyn, lost both of his legs. He has had to use a wheelchair, but is determined to master his prosthetics. ''I'm somebody

ABC took a break on Monday night from providing a 24-hour platform for Charlie Sheen so it could briefly address the more pressing business of unveiling the next cast of contenders for ''Dancing With the Stars.'' The roster of semi- and never-were-celebs for the 12th season of that popular reality competition may not include anyone as instantly fascinating as, say, Bristol Palin, who danced her way to a third-place finish on the show last fall, and producers were apparently unsuccessful in casting their spell over Christine O'Donnell, the Republican senatorial candidate from Delaware, to take part in the new cycle. But when the new season of ''Dancing'' makes its debut on March 21, the contestants will include Kirstie Alley, the ''Cheers'' and ''Look Who's Talking'' star; Ralph Macchio, the original ''Karate Kid''; the talk-show host Wendy Williams; the hall of fame boxer Sugar Ray Leonard; and the Pittsburgh Steelers wide receiver Hines Ward. The people we had to Google include Chris Jericho, a professional wrestler; Chelsea Kane, a Disney Channel actor; Kendra Wilkinson, a Playboy model and reality television star; and ''Psycho'' Mike Catherwood, a co-host of the radio program ''Loveline.'' Also competing this season is the rapper Romeo, who was scheduled to be part of the show in 2006, but dropped out because of an injury and was replaced by his father, the rapper Master P.

In a marked shift from his previous statements, Egypt's minister of antiquities, Zahi Hawass, said on Tuesday that his department was unable to protect Egypt's historic sites and artifacts and that he was considering resigning. In a telephone interview he said that thieves on Monday broke into two warehouses near the pyramids of Giza that held artifacts excavated in the early 20th century. It was not yet clear what had been taken. He said that the police were no longer protecting Egypt's monuments and that his own staff was unarmed and unable to stop attacks.

(13, 49) TROUBADOURS: CAROLE KING/JAMES TAYLOR & THE RISE OF THE SINGER-SONGWRITER Forty years ago Ms. King released her song ''You've Got a Friend'' on her album ''Tapestry'' -- the same year Mr. Taylor's version, covered on his album ''Mud Slide Slim and the Blue Horizon,'' reached No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100. Their friendship had been cemented in November 1970, when they performed together at the Troubadour, the West Hollywood, Calif., club that figured prominently in the careers of some of the decade's most significant singer-songwriters. (Ms. King and Mr. Taylor, above, would reunite there in November 2007 in honor of the club's 50th anniversary.) This ''American Masters'' presentation explores that movement through archival film footage and new interviews with Ms. King, Mr. Taylor, Bonnie Raitt, David Crosby, Jackson Browne, Kris Kristofferson, Steve Martin and Cheech Marin and Tommy Chong. The documentary, directed by Morgan Neville and produced by Eddie Schmidt, also features performances from the Carole King/James Taylor Troubadour Reunion world tour last year. 10 A.M. Frank Rich, who over the course of a three-decade career at The New York Times was a theater critic, magazine essayist and Sunday Op-Ed columnist, is leaving the paper to join New York magazine. The rumors were true: Bristol Palin is writing a book. ''Not Afraid of Life'' will be released this summer by HarperCollins, the publisher of Sarah Palin's books, ''Going Rogue'' and ''America By Heart.'' Bristol Palin's book will be ''an inside look at her life, her world, and the things that matter most, including her family and the faith that keeps her centered,'' the publisher said in a statement on Tuesday. She will write about her appearance on ''Dancing With the Stars,'' including the grueling practices and the criticisms she endured, her aspirations and her religious faith. The book, which will have a co-writer who was not identified, will be published by William Morrow, an imprint of HarperCollins. Ms. Palin, 20, spends time touring the country speaking to groups and recently bought a house in Maricopa, Ariz., south of Phoenix.

Backing away from an earlier assertion by their spokesman, the musicians of the striking Detroit Symphony Orchestra said on Tuesday that they in fact would not be going back to work and were only offering to undergo binding arbitration. ''Our offer is to submit to binding arbitration, and if management agrees, we could be returning to work immediately,'' Haden McKay, a cellist in the orchestra said. He said that under the proposal each side would pick an arbitrator and the two arbitrators would then pick a third arbitrator.

He is as much of a celebrity as one can be in a field in which cadavers are the main attraction.Dr. Cyril H. Wecht, a forensic pathologist, first earned national attention in the 1970s when he opposed the single-bullet theory in the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. He has since established himself as an expert in post-mortem science, commenting on television and in court on celebrity cases as varied as Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination, Anna Nicole Smith's death and the O. J. Simpson murder trial. Hiring him to do a private autopsy costs about $500 per hour.

I've always loved the musical "Company," a Broadway show by Stephen Sondheim that opened in 1970. It was about a 35-year-old Manhattan guy, still unmarried even though all of his best friends are married couples. The set, the tone and the score were all ultrachic, ultramodern, ultraurban. Kate and Laura Mulleavy, the two Los Angeles-based designing sisters behind the fashion house Rodarte, have never had a solo exhibition on their home turf. Until now. "Rodarte: States of Matter," which opens this weekend at the Museum of Contemporary Art's Pacific Design Center gallery, treats visitors to an up-close look at 20 Rodarte creations, including six ballet tutus that the sisters designed for the film "Black Swan." "We're really happy to have the opportunity to show our work in an art museum," Laura said. "We're used to seeing our garments on tables in our studio as flat pieces that are kind of lifeless. For the exhibition, we wanted to abstract the clothes, removing them from the human figure, and show them as sculptural objects in the round."

That's what I've been wondering since catching up with Steve Fishman's remarkable jailhouse interview with Bernie Madoff in New York Magazine. I'm not sure what I expected from the mastermind of a $65 billion Ponzi scheme, but it wasn't whiny rationalizing like this: "Everyone was greedy. I just went along. It's not an excuse." Some crimes are so big that they demand full-throated, active voice, nonhedging remorse. (Not with "we participated" language a la Lloyd Blankfein, either.)  If only Madoff were more like Richard Nixon. True, it took hours of pushing and pressing by David Frost to get Nixon to apologize for Watergate - "I let the American people down, and I have to carry that burden with me for the rest of my life" - and he could have apologized for so much more. But watch Nixon's face. Something is there. Could it be contrition?

There are certain things that all creative people share in common - and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitken's 2006 book "Broken Screen," which featured interviews with everyone from Robert Altman to Rem Koolhaas, challenged the convention of the linear narrative. Now, with his latest video project, Patterns & Repetitions [http://www.patternsandrepetition.com], the artist sits down with a whole new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. There's Jacques Herzog on instinct and architecture; LCD Soundsystem's James Murphy on the sound of snow; and Jack White weighing in on Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. This week, The Moment features the artist Mike Kelley talking about Detroit, his hometown. But don't be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesn't do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

The historian Ron Chernow has won the annual American History Book Prize for his biography "Washington," the New-York Historical Society announced on Thursday. Roger Hertog, chairman of the society's board, said the book, published by Penguin Press, would "undoubtedly become the definitive life of our first president." Mr. Chernow is also the author of biographies of John D. Rockefeller and Alexander Hamilton, among other works. The prize, which comes with an engraved medal, the title of American Historian Laureate and an award of $50,000, will be presented on April 8 in Manhattan.

After dinner last night, I ducked into that giant magazine store off Union Square, among the last of its kind. The lighting in there is as flattering as the full-body-cavity-search room at J.F.K. (not that I've been there), but it had the new April issue of Mojo on March 2, the sign of a newsstand that still cares. I rushed home and devoured the 17-page cover package on the Smiths, marking the 25th anniversary of "The Queen Is Dead" (which, interestingly, Mojo ranks as only their second-best album). Though it's largely about the rock music of years gone by, Mojo steers clear of sentimentality and cheap nostalgia by sheer, unabashed devotion to its subject. Also: strong, well-defined sections, loads of vintage rock pictures, graphic design that draws inspiration from classic album covers and wonderful paper stock that feels so good in your hands.

What will Darth Maul's double-bladed light saber, Anakin Skywalker's pod racer and Jar Jar Binks's unyielding floppy ears look like to audiences as they appear to leap off the screen? And more important, when can they buy tickets for the first "Star Wars" movie to be released in 3-D? Lucasfilm and 20th Century Fox answered one of those questions on Thursday, announcing that "Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace," the first of the six space-adventure films that George Lucas and Industrial Light & Magic are converting for 3-D presentation, will be released in theaters next year on Feb. 10. In a statement, the studios said the 3-D conversion is "being done with utmost respect for the source material, and with a keen eye for both technological considerations and artistic intentions." (We assume that means artists won't overemphasize the adorable chipmunk cheeks of a young Natalie Portman.) For science-fiction fans expecting to learn release dates for 3-D versions of the franchise's other films (including the original trilogy of "Star Wars," "The Empire Strikes Back" and "Return of the Jedi"), this isn't the blog post you're looking for.

This past Sunday, Luke Matheny took home the Oscar for Best Live Action Short with "God of Love," a charming twist on the classic Cupid story. In the wake of his win, the former New York University film student took a few moments to speak with The Moment about the excitement of the Oscar experience, what made his crew different from that of, say, "The King's Speech" and what's up next for this rising talent.

James Kirchick has a good piece exploring the divide that's opened between American neoconservatives and many Israelis over the revolutions and protests currently roiling the Middle East - with neocons welcoming the fall of Hosni Mubarak and the promise of democratic change throughout the region, even as the Israeli leadership classes wax more pessimistic about the likely consequences of replacing despots with more popular regimes. "Could there be a starker illustration of just how mistaken the neocon-Israeli conflation always was?" Kirchick asks, and he's right: The last few weeks should bury, once and for all, the foolish idea that neoconservatism's rhetorical commitment to democracy promotion is just a smokescreen for Likudnik dual loyalties or U.S. imperialism.

In my most recent piece on U.S. agricultural subsidies I made the point that the government often makes payments to very wealthy farmers who don't exactly "need" that extra money. To illustrate one of the more head-scratching examples of subsidizing the rich, I singled out David Rockefeller, Standard Oil heir and former chairman of Chase Bank. The idea here was simply to show that our farm subsidies are not doled out as judiciously as they could be: government policy was the target, not Mr. Rockefeller (I suppose I could have just as easily mentioned Ted Turner or Kenneth Lay.)

Believe it or not, Lady Gaga once had trouble getting any designers to lend her clothes. So much trouble in fact that she had her own knockoff-ish pieces made for the stage. That changed around the time Nicola Formichetti styled her for the September 2009 cover of V Magazine. She quickly owned the must-dress list. And now - as the muse for Formichetti's new vision for Thierry Mugler - she's come full circle. Let it be said, Gaga makes for a pretty sick model. Sometimes even the most captivating show can drag on, and rarely does the audience of editors walk out laughing about the good time they just had. Even the models appeared to be having a blast. The clothes - shiny and sexy, with sculptural shoulders sharp enough to be used as weapons - were fun too, and there's nothing wrong with that.

It's a bird, it's a plane, it's a former cast member of "The Outsiders" who we never expected would one day grow up to be the mother of a quintessentially all-American superhero: it's Diane Lane, who is only the second member of the cast to be announced for a new Superman movie that the director Zack Snyder is preparing for next year. On Wednesday night, Warner Brothers Pictures said Ms. Lane, whose more recent movies include "The Perfect Storm," "Unfaithful" and "Secretariat," would play the mother of the film's title character - not the Kryptonian mother of Kal-El, who arrives on earth from a dying alien planet, but Martha Kent, an adoptive parent who raises him in his guise as Clark Kent.

Some day there's going to be a tattoo bake-off between European soccer players and their N.B.A. brethren, right? We can hope. In the meantime, just in time for the start of the Major League Soccer season two weeks from now, when the Seattle Sounders host the L.A. Galaxy, one likely contestant has beefed up his qualifications. David Beckham recently revealed on his Facebook page the latest addition to his body-art collection. It's a Pietà-like image of Christ being tended to by cherubim. Not sure about this, but it's hard to avoid spinning out some exegesis about that whole Beckham-as-savior-of-soccer-in-America business that kicked off four years ago when Beckham took his talents from Spain to the Galaxy - especially now that his final season under contract here is about to begin. At the moment, those cherub wings may also remind many of the poor broken-winged owl that died after being kicked by a Colombian soccer player when it landed on the field in the middle of a match earlier this week. The visiting player who struck the bird, a mascot for the home team, could use some absolution himself: he faces a fine and possible jail time.

If you've been following the Charlie Sheen Self-Immolation World Tour 2011 - during which he has appeared, or is scheduled to appear, on every talk show, radio program and podcast that will have him (which, as of now, seems to be all of them) - you've noticed that we are now in Defcon Three of Celebrity Scandal: The "Whither Society" portion of the meltdown. Defcon Five is the scandal itself. Defcon Four is the all-of-us-watching-with-mouths-agape phase. With Defcon Three comes the clothes-rending: Are we enablers? Should we be egging him on? Is this actually news? And most worrying of all: why do we care?

The Pittsburgh Pirates last had a winning record and made the playoffs in 1992. The Kansas City Royals had a winning season in 2003, but the last time they made the playoffs was in 1985, when they beat the St. Louis Cardinals in the World Series. Chances are the situation isn't that dire for the worst team in your keeper league, but the experiences of the Pirates and the Royals illustrate how difficult it can be for us fantasy leaguers to rebuild a franchise, and we can learn from the mistakes of those franchises. We'll talk about some of the common rebuilding problems here, then discuss a few possible solutions to get out of the rebuilding rut in your keeper leagues.

Later this month, the Federal Reserve is going to let banks know how they did on its most recent round of ''stress tests.'' Banks are eager to bring doctors' notes to their meetings with investors, displaying their bills of health. They want regulators to allow them to start paying, or increasing, dividends to investors or to initiate stock buyback programs.

PARIS -- The regime of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has been badly undermined, but he retains enough support among critical tribes and institutions, including parts of the army and the air force, that he might be able to retain power in the capital, Tripoli, for some time to come, say experts on Libya and its military. They caution that the situation on the ground is both fluid and confusing. But they emphasize that tribal loyalties remain an important indicator, and that there is no clear geographical dividing line between the opponents to Colonel Qaddafi and his supporters.

An art review on Friday about an exhibition of work by Ree Morton at the Alexander and Bonin gallery in Chelsea referred incorrectly to the exhibition. It is the first solo show of her work at a New York gallery in 10 years, not the first in New York in that time. (There was one at the Drawing Center in 2009.)

THE designer Jessie Randall, of Loeffler Randall, known for updating classic looks with a dash of edge, is coming out with a new bridal-shoe line next week, with selections like the three versions shown here. From left to right: the Georgia, a satin and mesh lace-up bootie ($625); the Paige, a metallic stilletto ($595); and the Rowena, a flat sandal ($295). Flats? Available at loefflerrandall.com.

The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday ordered that about 500 prescription drugs used to treat colds, coughs and allergies be removed from the market, saying that the medicines had never gone through a federal review of their safety and effectiveness. ''We don't know what's in them, whether they work properly or how they are made,'' Deborah M. Autor, the director of the office of compliance in the F.D.A.'s drug division, said in a telephone news conference on Wednesday morning.
You feel punched in the stomach. ERIN PARKER, a high school science teacher in Madison, Wis., on verbal jabs against teachers. [A1]

In early 2002, Stephen King said he was written out and was thinking of retiring. Some retirement. He has since published at least four novels, a couple of story collections and has collaborated on a monthly comic book. On Wednesday, Scribner, his publisher, announced that in the fall it will bring out yet another King novel, called ''11/23/63.'' The new book is 1,000 pages long - enormous by most standards, but cruising length for Mr. King - and is apparently a ''counterfactual,'' a novel that imagines what would have happened had history turned out differently. It's the story of a Maine high school teacher named Jake Epping who discovers a portal back to 1958 in a storeroom at a local diner. He travels back there and, while enjoying some sex and rock 'n' roll, finds himself with a chance to thwart the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

It is safe to say that the last thing the computer world needs is yet another connection standard. However, Apple and Intel have just put their might behind something they are calling Thunderbolt, a new type of data port that can transfer data at speeds up to 10 gigabits per second. Considering that the fastest USB 2.0 drives can currently transfer data at about 480 megabits per second (that's 0.46 gigabits per second or, in layman's terms, really slow), Thunderbolt may be a welcome change.

A chart on Feb. 8 with an article about AOL's efforts to remake itself through acquisitions like that of The Huffington Post, using information from comScore, misstated the traffic to SB Nation, a sports Web site. It had 7.3 million unique visitors in December, not 2.1 million.

DURKIN--Evelyn. Born in Washington Heights, daughter of the late Patrick Blaine and Mary Meehan of Killybegs, Ireland. Beloved wife of 45 years of the late Francis. Cherished mother of Laura (Steve), Claire (Rich), Mark (Nanette) and Jenifer. Loving sister of Patrick Blaine and Myra Ruocco. Devoted grandmother of Marisa, Bridget, Nathaniel, Belle, Cara and Declan. Evelyn traveled the Atlantic to and from Ireland before the age of four, then grew to embrace New York and her family, as well as a career in reinsurance. She will be missed.

A money manager whose client roster once included Hollywood luminaries like Martin Scorsese and Uma Thurman was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison on Wednesday for siphoning more than $30 million from his clients. For more than 20 years, the manager, Kenneth I. Starr, cultivated celebrity contacts to amass a fortune. Likened to a miniversion of Bernard L. Madoff, Mr. Starr, 67, used the funds to finance a lavish lifestyle, including a luxury apartment with an indoor swimming pool on the Upper East Side. As part of the sentence, Mr. Starr will have to pay more than $29 million in restitution to his victims, a portion of which will come from the sale of his condominium.

IN this anti-aging age, perhaps it's unsurprising that vampires -- ancient, but with forever-young skin -- are a cultural obsession. Now a cosmetic treatment to fill in wrinkles or to plump up hollow cheeks is being marketed as a ''vampire filler'' or a ''vampire face-lift.'' In fact, it's not surgery, but an in-office procedure that entails having blood drawn from your arm, then spun in a centrifuge to separate the platelets. They are then injected into your face, with the hope of stimulating new collagen production. Selphyl, as the system is called, arrived on the booming facial-rejuvenation market in 2009, and is now used by roughly 300 doctors nationwide in the name of beauty, said Sanjay Batra, the chief executive of Aesthetic Factors, which manufactures the Selphyl system.

If Cameron Crowe could make a memorable scene with just a couple of verses of Elton John - as he did when the ''Almost Famous'' cast sang ''Tiny Dancer'' in the back of that tour bus - imagine what he could do with an entire movie about him? Audiences at the Tribeca Film Festival will be among the first to find out: the festival's organizers said on Wednesday that their 2011 program will open on the night of April 20 with a free outdoor screening of ''The Union,'' Mr. Crowe's documentary about Mr. John, followed by a performance from that best-selling pop performer. ''The Union'' chronicles the making of that 2010 album of the same title, on which Mr. John collaborated with the singer-songwriter Leon Russell, and which also featured contributions from T-Bone Burnett, Bernie Taupin, Neil Young and Brian Wilson, among others. Press representatives for the Tribeca Film Festival said in a news release that the premiere event for the documentary will be held at the North Cove at the World Financial Plaza in Lower Manhattan. The full festival is scheduled to run April 20 through May 1.

ZACHARIUS--Walter, the founder of Kensington Publishing Corp., died on Wednesday March 2, 2011. He was 87 years old. Walter is survived by his loving family; his two children, Steven Zacharius, Kensington's President and CEO and Judy Zacharius, of Fairbanks, Alaska. He is also survived by his two grandchildren, Cori Zacharius Cohen, and Adam Zacharius, and his great-granddaughter, Ava. His first wife, Alice died in 2004, and he is survived by his current wife, Suzanne Zacharius and her daughter, Mariel. Memorial service on Friday, March 4 at 10am at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

The Blue Microphones Yeti Pro is, like its Arctic namesake, heavy, cold, and visually impressive. With a stand seemingly cast out of iron and a body like a soda can, this six-inch tall microphone has three internal microphone capsules for stereo surround-sound recording that allows for podcasters, interviewers and musicians to switch sound recording positions on the fly. Designed to connect to Macs and PCs via USB or to a traditional microphone mixing devices via analog XLR, the Yeti Pro has a large, domelike windscreen on top complete with woven metal protector and gain and volume controls right on the face of the mic.

11:09 p.m. | Updated A Bronx man fatally stabbed his wife Wednesday morning, then set fire to their fifth-floor apartment, killing their 1-year-old daughter and himself, the authorities said. The blaze erupted about 7:50 a.m. in a six-story brick building at 2275 Morris Avenue, off East 183rd Street in Fordham Heights, said a Fire Department spokesman. Investigators said they believed that the father, Vincente Cordero, 34, had stabbed his wife several times after an argument and then set the apartment afire, which killed himself and the baby girl. Mr. Cordero was initially in critical condition after the fire, and had been charged with counts of murder, arson, reckless endangerment and second-degree assault. He died Wednesday evening at Westchester Medical Center.

8:16 p.m. | Updated Doug Morris, a longtime power broker of the record business as the head of the Universal Music Group, is taking over the reins of Sony Music Entertainment, Universal's biggest rival, Sony announced on Wednesday. Granted an early release from his contract at Universal, Mr. Morris will become the chief executive of Sony Music on July 1, replacing Rolf Schmidt-Holtz, whose tenure ends on March 31. Other terms of the deal were not disclosed.

PLAUT--Edward W.,of Westport, CT., husband of Carol (Stern) Plaut passed away Sunday, February 27, 2011. Mr. Plaut was born April 6, 1924 in New York City son of the late Ralph and Gertrude (Weill) Plaut and has been a resident of Westport for the past fifty-seven years. Prior to retiring Mr. Plaut was employed in the Insurance Business for over forty years. He attended the University of Florida and was a US Navy veteran of World War II. Following retirement, Mr. Plaut volunteered delivering meals for the Meals on Wheels program in Westport. He also served as mentor in the Bridgeport Public School System. Survivors in addition to his wife of sixty-one years includes one daughter, Kim P. Sullivan and her husband Joseph of East Dennis, MA. two sons, Wynn Plaut and his wife Robin of Greenwich, CT. and Quentin Plaut and his wife Michelle of Fairfax, VA. and seven grandchildren. The family will receive friends Friday March 4th in the Harding Funeral Home, 210 Post Rd. E., Westport from 9 to 10am. A Celebration of Life will follow at 10:00am in the Funeral Home. Memorial contributions may be made to Home Delivered Meals, 21 Imperial Ave., Westport, CT 06880. To leave an online condolence please visit: hardingfuneral.com.

If your photos don't look as crummy as you'd like, there is new software that will wreck them for you. That's not a bad thing if you are a devotee of the ''lo-fi'' photography movement, which considers the effects achieved by toy cameras, pinhole cameras and other crude photo devices to be artful. There are even contests dedicated to lo-fi work.

KRUEGER--Karen, 55, died February 23, 2011 in New York City. Beloved daughter of Edna Gossel Krueger of Elgin, IL and the late Russell Krueger, sister of Karna (Lloyd) Levitt and aunt of Valery and Jake of Chattanooga, TN. A lyric mezzo soprano, Karen began her career in NY in 1981 touring with the Gregg Smith Singers, New York Vocal Arts Ensemble and NYC Opera National Company. She sang in the Choir of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, where she was choral contractor for their acclaimed Sacred Music series. She was often on the faculty of the Berkshire Choral Festival and she sang in NYC with Musica Sacra, NY. Choral Artists, Voices of Ascension and Temple Emmanuel. Her rich voice, mischievous sense of humor and radiant smile will be missed by all.

An article on Wednesday about the Security and Exchange Commission's insider trading accusations against Rajat K. Gupta, a prominent business executive and former director of Goldman Sachs, misstated the year in which he graduated from Harvard Business School. It was 1973, not 1974.

LEWIS--Marianne H. The Trustees of Usdan Center for the Creative and Performing Arts extend condolences to the family of Marianne Lewis, a lover of music and the arts, and a woman of great strength and character who having survived the Holocaust immigrated to the United States at the age of 15. In 1980, at the age of 59, she was graduated from Yale School of Nursing, and spent much of her life focusing on psychiatric nursing and care for the elderly. She is preceded in death by her husband, Harold. She will be missed by her two sons, Harold (Leslie) and Dale (Debra), our esteemed Executive Director, her loving grandchildren and caring friends.

MUMBAI, India -- Anant Pai, the creator of a popular comic book series that taught several generations of Indian children the country's history and mythology, died here on Thursday. He was 81. The cause was a heart attack, his family said. He was in the hospital at the time recovering from a fall.

CRANIN--Dr. A. Norman, 83, died February 20 in the Cayman Islands. An oral surgeon, teacher, lecturer, author and founder of The Dr. Samuel Cranin Dental Center at The Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, his creativity and tireless work in implant dentistry revolutionized the field. Dr. Cranin was a lifelong resident of Hewlett Bay Park, NY, and spent winters in his beloved Beaver Creek, CO. He was passionate about skiing, sailing, tennis, his many dogs, and philanthropy. He is survived by wife Marilyn (Sunners); Jonathan, Andrew, Elizabeth (Cooperstein) and their spouses; and six grandchildren. A memorial is being planned for late March.
