When the wheels were up on the two Continental Airlines flights from Los Angeles carrying the 64 Staten Island public school students home from their star turn singing the finale at the Academy Awards, the chorus squirmed in their seats with triumphant joy. But on Tuesday evening, they landed with a thump. Lugging their bags through the main terminal at La Guardia Airport, the children were besieged by reporters who had one main question, according to Gregg Breinberg, the chorus director: How did they feel about the fact that Andy Cohen, a senior vice president for programming at Bravo and the network's main public face, savaged their performance of ''Over the Rainbow'' on MSNBC's ''Morning Joe'' on Tuesday?

NEER--Charles Sumner, II. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Charles Sumner Neer II, M.D., a longtime distinguished member of our faculty and a pioneer in the field of orthopaedic and shoulder surgery. Dr. Neer spent his entire professional life at Columbia, having completed his residency in 1949, when he was appointed to our faculty, on which he served until his retirement in 1990 as Emeritus Professor of Orthopaedic Surgery. Dr. Neer founded the first Shoulder Service in the 1970s, and his contributions to the field of shoulder and elbow surgery were truly unparalleled. He helped train generations of surgeons and developed novel procedures and prostheses, as well as establishing a fracture classification system that is now used by orthopaedic surgeons worldwide. We extend our condolences to his wife Eileen, son Charles Henry, daughters Sydney Neer-Rowland and Charlotte Neer-Annis, and the extended Neer family. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that memorial gifts be directed to Columbia Orthopaedics, Columbia University Medical Center, 622 West 168th Street, PH-11, New York, NY 10032.

An obituary on Feb. 22 about the sculptor Roy Gussow misstated the name and location of a college at which he taught. It was the North Carolina State University School of Design (now known as the College of Design) in Raleigh; it was not the North Carolina School of Design near Raleigh.

VALENTINO VETTORI is blunt. Says the Improvd designer, ''I don't like color.'' Then Mr. Vettori (above), corrects himself, pulling dresses from the racks of the label's newly opened first store: ''I like a grayish icey blue or a light purplish gray or a not-nude-not-pink blush.'' Mr. Vettori and Sam Ben-Avraham, an owner of the Atrium store in NoHo, started Improvd a year ago, and now have unveiled an e-commerce site with minimal dresses with a twist, starting at $200. Improvd, 819 Washington Street, (Gansevoort Street); (212) 242-4020, improvd.com.

A picture caption on Feb. 16 with an article about Knicks Coach Mike D'Antoni and his son's high school basketball team in Rye, N.Y., erroneously identified the man sitting next to him at a game as Jack Twyman, the Basketball Hall of Fame member whose grandsons play on the same high school team. The man's identity is not known.

WHAT'S IN A NUMBER? In their annual reports over the last week, the country's big banks for the first time released their potential legal exposure. They were headline-grabbing numbers at most big banks. The revelations, according to executives at various banks, came after the Securities and Exchange Commission sent a note late last year to a number of chief financial officers, reminding them that they are required to make disclosures when there is a reasonable possibility of a loss. The S.E.C. followed up, and one executive said the agency's reminders were forceful. SUSANNE CRAIG MADOFF MONEY White Collar Watch lays out the test facing Irving H. One of the most fascinating figures to emerge from the story of President Obama - his mother, Stanley Ann Dunham - is the subject of a wide-ranging biography to be released in May, the book's publisher said on Wednesday. ''A Singular Woman,'' by Janny Scott, will be published by Riverhead Books, an imprint of Penguin Group USA. The book grew out of an article Ms. Scott wrote for The New York Times in 2008. She spent more than two years conducting research in Indonesia, Kansas and Hawaii, among other places, and interviewing friends, colleagues and relatives of Ms. Dunham, including Mr. Obama and his half-sister, Maya Soetoro-Ng. Ms. Dunham died in 1995. Sarah McGrath, executive editor of Riverhead Books, said the book ''brilliantly captures the full portrait of this extraordinary woman who defied being pigeonholed and lived life on her own terms.'' Ms. Scott was a reporter for The Times from 1994 to 2008.

DAINES--Richard F.,M.D. We join with his family and others in mourning the loss of our dear friend Dr. Richard F. Daines. After graduating from Weill Cornell Medical College and completing his residency at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, Dr. Daines dedicated himself to improving the health of New Yorkers, serving in several leadership roles, most recently as Health Commissioner of New York State. An ally of the Medical College, he advocated for our mission of education, research and patient care. He set the highest standards in medical competence, ethics and integrity. He was a wonderful role model for our students and young doctors and contributed greatly to the health of all New Yorkers. His energy, intellect and compassion will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Linda, his children, and the entire Daines family. Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D., D.Phil, Dean, Weill Cornell Medical College

IN CONCERT ON BROADWAY In this ''Great Performances'' presentation Mr. Connick, above, channels Frank Sinatra, Elvis Presley, Peter Allen and Frank Loesser as he performs a mix of standards, show tunes and jazz classics at the Neil Simon Theater. His accompaniment: a big band supplemented by a 12-piece string section as well as a Steinway grand and an upright honky-tonk piano. The playlist includes ''We Are in Love,'' ''The Way You Look Tonight,'' ''How Insensitive,'' ''Bayou Maharajah,'' ''Light the Way,'' ''Bourbon Street Parade'' and ''Mardi Gras in New Orleans.'' Reviewing the show in July in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said: ''Mr. Connick's rough-hewn, swing-driven aesthetic is ultimately grounded in New Orleans ragtime, blues and boogie-woogie traditions. He may go to Las Vegas, Hollywood and Broadway, but he is finally a proud native son.'' 8:30 P.M. (TV5Monde) SE SOUVENIR DES BELLES CHOSES (2001) Claire (Isabelle Carré), a woman in her 30s whose mother died from Alzheimer's, has a problem remembering things after having been struck by lightning in a forest. Philippe (Bernard Campan), a wine expert, has forgotten the car crash that killed his wife and son. When the two meet in a clinic for memory problems, passion ignites. Zabou Breitman directed this romantic comedy, for which Ms. Carré won the César for best actress, shown in French with English subtitles.

Adele, the British singer who won the best new artist Grammy Award two years ago, is the big winner on the Billboard chart this week, with a No. 1 opening for her new album and a rebound for her last one. Adele's new album, ''21'' (XL/Columbia), opened with 352,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Thanks to a blitz of television appearances to promote the album, that was the best opening-week sales of any album in three months. (In the interim, there have been some painfully low numbers.) And her debut album, ''19,'' bolted 34 spots to No. 16, with 18,000 sales. But almost everything else on the chart is a loser. Last week's No. 1, Justin Bieber's ''Never Say Never: The Remixes'' (Island), fell to No. 2 with 102,000, a 38 percent decline, and Mr. Bieber's ''My World 2.0,'' at No. 5, lost 22 percent. Mumford & Sons' ''Sigh No More'' (Glassnote), at No. 3, dropped 46 percent; ''Now That's What I Call Music!'' Vol. 37 is No. 4 with a 38 percent loss; Bruno Mars's ''Doo-Wops & Hooligans'' (Elektra), at No. 6, lost 40 percent, and so on. Last week's numbers were higher than usual because of the traditional retail boost the week after the Grammys. But that only underlines the scale of Adele's success. On the digital singles chart, Lady Gaga's ''Born This Way,'' which was enormously popular out of the gate, lost 44 percent of its sales in its third week, with 286,000, although that was enough for it to hold at No. 1. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

LONG BEACH, Calif. - Julie Taymor, the director of the new Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' said on Wednesday that she was currently ''in the crucible and the fire of transformation'' as she and her collaborators continue to work on improving the show. Addressing a live audience of more than 1,000 people at the TED2011 conference here, and many more through streaming video, Ms. Taymor was humble as she acknowledged the turbulence surrounding the ''Spider-Man'' project, the most expensive in Broadway history (at $65 million and counting) and technically ambitious. And she graciously praised her cast and collaborators for sticking with the show in spite of the intense media spotlight and the steady negative jabs, particularly from theater critics.''Anyone who creates knows - when it's not quite there,'' Ms. Taymor, a Tony Award winner for the blockbuster musical ''The Lion King,'' said. ''Where it hasn't quite become the phoenix or the burnt char. And I am right there.'' The producers of ''Spider-Man,'' along with Ms. Taymor and her co-creators, U2's Bono and the Edge, are now deciding whether to open the musical as scheduled on March 15, or delay the opening for a sixth time to continue making changes to the script, music, direction, and other elements of the show. Bono attended Tuesday night's performance of ''Spider-Man,'' his first viewing since mid-January, to inform his opinion about opening or delaying. Ms. Taymor is to fly back to New York shortly. The production is expected to announce this week that opening night is confirmed for March 15 or will be delayed.

Katori Hall, a 29-year-old playwright from Memphis whose work examines the historical and social forces affecting African-American characters, has been named the 33rd winner of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize. The award is given annually to outstanding women playwrights. Ms. Hall received $20,000 and a signed and numbered print by the artist Willem de Kooning for her play ''Hurt Village,'' about the problems of families in a decaying Memphis housing project. ''I'm going to buy myself a guitar and an amp,'' Ms. Hall said Wednesday of her plans for the prize money. ''I want to write some country songs. Why not?''

An article on Feb. 20 by The Associated Press about the struggles of the Butler men's basketball team after its appearance in the national championship game last season misstated the number of times a team has reached the title game two years in a row since the N.C.A.A. tournament expanded to 64 teams in 1985. That feat has been accomplished seven times, not three. (Duke returned to the final game after its 1990 and 1991 championship appearances, Michigan did it after its 1992 appearance, Arkansas after 1994, Kentucky after 1996 and 1997, and Florida after 2006.)

It's when you are out of cellphone range and farthest from help when you're going to need urgent assistance. Think of being aboard a boat sinking at sea, or getting lost in the woods, or crashing a motorcycle in the desert while on a camping trip. That's what satellite phones are for - they send a signal directly to a satellite from anywhere with a clear view of the sky without need of a cell tower. But with per-minute fees of $1 or more (sometimes a lot more), you'll still need a regular mobile phone for everyday use. That means you need two phones. Just what you want when hiking - two weighty pieces of hardware to tote.

Bahrain: Protesters marched on the Interior Ministry to demand the release of all political prisoners, The Associated Press reported. Last week, 23 of them were released, but the opposition said at least 200 remained jailed. Egypt: The government-owned newspaper Al Akhbar reported that former President Hosni Mubarak had left his villa in Sharm el Sheik for Saudi Arabia for chemotherapy treatments. The newspaper said that Mr. Mubarak has colon and pancreatic cancer and that he and his immediate family left for the Saudi military complex at Tabuk last week. He and his family have not been seen in public or heard from since he stepped down on Feb. 11. There was no confirmation of the report.

KLAUBER--Roger. We deeply mourn his passing on February 27, 2011. Born in Munich 1924, he escaped the Nazis in 1939. He served in the 10th Mountain Division and then OSS where he met his beloved Hilde. They had two sons Gordon and Mark. Roger was admired as the leader of Klauber Lace founded in 1859. Thanks to his help until his dying day, his company has lasted six generations. After Hilde's passing he found love and support from Roswita. He will be missed by family and friends worldwide. His cour- age and love will never die. Services Friday 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to NY Presbyterian Fund, Inc. In memory of Roger Klauber at Weill Cornell Medical Center, 525 E. 68 St., PO BOX 123, NY 10065.

PHOENIX - The Chicago Cubs have played so poorly this spring training that when two players fought in their dugout Wednesday, it was not even the main reason to schedule a team meeting. The Cubs lost to the Milwaukee Brewers, 12-5, committing five more errors to push their total to 14 in four exhibition games. Three errors in the first were enough to anger starter Carlos Silva, who scuffled with third baseman Aramis Ramirez and left Maryvale Baseball Park without speaking to reporters. Manager Mike Quade said that Silva would not be punished, but that the issue would be addressed in a meeting Thursday.

SATURDAY'S PUZZLE - When you've done enough crossword puzzles, you not only start to recognize bylines but you also recognize styles. Solve even more and it's not uncommon to begin to feel like you're on a certain constructor's wavelength. By wavelength, I mean that you get the constructor's jokes, you understand his or her wording of clues, and it's easy to get into the Solving Zone, where the puzzle falls without too much struggle.

On Tuesday, I wrote about how a health worker named Reynaldo Rodriguez worked with a patient, Joe McManus, to help him stick to his treatment plan to control his AIDS and Hepatitis C. Most of us don't have the multiple serious illnesses and problems that  McManus does, but a lot of us still share his basic challenge: how do we get ourselves to live more healthfully?    We might need to eat better, quit smoking or drinking or exercise more.  Instead of thinking of it as treatment adherence, we might call it keeping our New Year's resolutions.

In 1994, on the last day of a month long stay at the only hotel in Nagorno-Karabakh, a disputed region between Armenia and Azerbaijan, the photographer Bruce Haley took a picture of a woman he had come to know as "Mama." Over the course of his visit, Mama brought him breakfast every day. The two became friends, but she refused to be photographed. When Mr. Haley visited her to say goodbye, though, she let him take her picture under one condition: that he permit her to hold an image of her dead son.

9:08 p.m. | Updated Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, took the first official step toward running for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination on Friday by filing paperwork with the Internal Revenue Service to explore a potential candidacy. The new organization, Newt Exploratory 2012, will report its contributors and expenses to the I.R.S.; it is not required to report to the Federal Election Commission unless Mr. Gingrich becomes an official candidate. Mr. Gingrich is listed as the committee's only officer, and his chief election lawyer, Stefan C. Passantino, as the committee's treasurer.

While it has already been well established that Libya's stocks of portable antiaircraft missiles have been broken into by rebels in the country's east, what is less known is how well the now loose missiles might work. The one bit of evidence so far, a photograph by Tyler Hicks, suggests that at least some of the looted stock was manufactured in 1977. Manpads, as these weapons are commonly called, are perishable items, and can become less reliable with the passage of time, the exposure to elements, and, like many munitions, to heat cycling, or the exposure to swings in ambient temperature over time.

.The loss of the Glory satellite early this morning is another setback for efforts to fill substantial gaps in the understanding of some important aspects of the climate system. Just over two years ago, another important satellite, the Orbiting Carbon Observatory, was destroyed in a failed launch. Components that contributed to that failure (couplings for a clamshell-like shield over the satellite) had been redesigned and three successful launches took place last year, mission officials said at a news conference (video is below).

One more thought on the Hamilton Project chart showing a big decline in men's wages since 1969: it is not depicting the wage history of a typical male worker. The typical 50-year full-time male worker, for instance, is not making 28 percent less than the equivalent man was in 1969.

While Japan's fashion designers (Miyake, Yamomoto, et al) are well know for their time as expats in Paris, the new wave of Japanese transplants in France are more likely to be cooking than sketching. In recent years, in fact, the French capital has become home to an unusual number of classic French restaurants run by Japanese chefs, along with a slew of new Franco-Japanese hybrids. And while the food at Michelin-starred, Japanese-run veterans like Hiramatsu (52, rue de Longchamp; 011-33-1-56-81-08-80) and Stella Maris (4, rue Arsene Houssaye; 011-33-1-42-89-16-22) is very classically French, many of the newer arrivals are letting their Japanese heritage come through clearly.

"We all have our favorite one," Wes Rozen muses, referring to the field of columns in the Brooklyn Museum's Great Hall, which he and his colleagues in the design firm Situ Studio have turned into fabric-covered, warped and twisted versions of their Beaux-Arts originals, complete with integrated seating. The installation, "reOrder: An Architectural Environment by Situ Studio," opens to the public on Saturday and is part enchanted forest and part architectural debutantes' ball, in which the structural elements appear to start dancing through the otherwise static space. (The designers also credit the museum's 19th-century costume collection as inspiration for their crinoline-like structures.)

On Wednesday The New York Times's obituaries included one of Judith Coplon, who in 1949 was tried and convicted of giving secrets to the Soviet Union. The two counts - one for spying, the other for conspiracy - were overturned, because of improper investigative conduct by federal agents, though, as Sam Roberts reported, the evidence against her was solid and reinforced by the release, long afterward, of Soviet documents.

Stumbling upon art that is difficult to categorize is sometimes unsettling and, at other times, simply intriguing. The latter case applies to Gregory Euclide's work which, at a glance, looks like an elegant spill of paint but on closer inspection reveals a carefully executed diorama. Euclide's inspiration is drawn from the land, but that is not to say he paints landscapes. "I know that I am simply using the landscape to reach something more complicated," he says. Two of his pieces - made of a heady blend of plant life (blackberry lily seed, sedum, sagebrush, moss) and other materials (hair, polymer resin, mylar) - are on view this weekend as part of PULSE, the contemporary art fair at the Metropolitan Pavilion. The Milwaukee-born Euclide is anticipating a prosperous year. He is now collaborating with Justin Vernon of Bon Iver on the artwork for the band's forthcoming album and will show more of his work in June at the Museum of Arts & Design "Otherworldly" exhibition. "With these works I often do a painting then crumple it up," he says. "The paper becomes the topography of the land."

One of the great maxims of comic books is that behind every good hero is a really nasty villain. "Nemesis," a mini-series published by Marvel, whose collected edition arrives at No. 8 on our hardcover list, is about the ultimate, unstoppable villain. The concept of the book has been described as "what if Batman were the Joker?" In other words, what if -- instead of fighting for good -- the smartest, toughest, richest man were a champion of evil? "Nemesis" was written by Mark Millar, who was also behind "Kick Ass," and illustrated by Steve McNiven. Mr. Millar and Mr. McNiven were also the creative team behind "Civil War," a pivotal "event" story line that was published in 2006 and had a lasting series of repercussions for Marvel's heroes.

So the season is officially over. (Was it good for you?) Amid the near-radio silence of the last few days, the Bagger has taken some time to ponder the ups-and-downs of the awards circuit. Complaints that the Oscars lacked drama left us stumped; don't follow along if you don't want to know what will happen. Anyway, there was some mystery, and not just surrounding Banksy and the Academy's preference when it comes to directors. Is anyone still wondering why "The King's Speech" took the top prize? Perhaps because, as one awards-watcher put it, it made you feel smart for getting the jokes, just like "Shakespeare in Love" did, while "The Social Network" made you feel comparatively lazy and unambitious.

The Bar Hemingway is a Parisian institution - any night can play host to writers, models and designers. The gatekeeper ensuring patrons have a wonderful evening is Colin Peter Field. His anointment as the best barman in the world, by Forbes and Travel + Leisure magazines, is hardly surprising given his coterie includes Kate Moss, who wrote the preface for his book, "Le Ritz Paris - Une Histoire de Cocktails" (Editions de la Martinière), which was published in October. The model and muse favors the French 76 (a seductive concoction of vodka, lemon juice and sugar mixed with Champagne) whenever she is in town. With Paris fashion week in full swing, Field revealed where to unwind after the shows and where to get the best takeout. And for those not across the pond, he shared one of his favorite recipes for at-home imbibing. Santé!

Pierre Bergé, the old devil, has just a released a new book, "La Revolution de la Mode," about the beginnings of Yves Saint Laurent's Rive Gauche, in 1966, and its impact. Not only are we having a 1960s revival, but  the industry also seems to be waking up with a crushing hangover or a severe case of doubts, and, well, people don't like the feeling. The book is actually a catalog of images - and splendid they are - from the archives of Fondation Pierre Bergé and Yves Saint Laurent, where an exhibition about Rive Gauche and its first boutique will open on Saturday at the foundation's headquarters. (It runs through July 17.)

THE MONTH IN ROMANCE1. Facebook stalking briefly got easier (phew!) with Breakup Notifier, an application that lets you monitor whether a friend is "in a relationship" on the site. According to their slogan: "You like someone. They're in a relationship. Be the first to know the instant they're out of it." (Or, presumably, the third.) But the app died a silent death just days after it began (Facebook shut it down), leaving its reported 3.6 million users to rely on olden methods of stalking that no one had forgotten or even stopped doing.

What will Darth Maul's double-bladed light saber, Anakin Skywalker's pod racer and Jar Jar Binks's unyielding floppy ears look like to audiences as they appear to leap off the screen? And more important, when can they buy tickets for the first ''Star Wars'' movie to be released in 3-D? Lucasfilm and 20th Century Fox answered one of those questions on Thursday, announcing that ''Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace,'' the first of the six space-adventure films that George Lucas and Industrial Light & Magic are converting for 3-D presentation, will be released in theaters next year on Feb. 10. In a statement, the studios said the 3-D conversion is ''being done with utmost respect for the source material, and with a keen eye for both technological considerations and artistic intentions.'' (We assume that means artists won't overemphasize the adorable chipmunk cheeks of a young Natalie Portman.) For science-fiction fans expecting to learn release dates for 3-D versions of the franchise's other films (including the original trilogy of ''Star Wars,'' ''The Empire Strikes Back'' and ''Return of the Jedi''), this isn't the blog post you're looking for. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A newly cast production of ''Black Watch,'' the hit play from Edinburgh about a harrowing tour of duty in Iraq by a legendary Scottish Army regiment, will be performed at St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn for a limited run, April 16-May 8, the theater announced on Wednesday. Earlier productions of ''Black Watch'' had sold-out runs at St. Ann's in 2007 and 2008 and drew critical acclaim for the thrillingly physical choreography by Steven Hoggett and the intense story about a group of young soldiers based near Falluja.

Necmettin Erbakan, the first Islamist prime minister of Turkey, whose attempt to turn his country away from the West led the military to depose him in 1997, died on Sunday in Ankara. He was 84. The cause was heart failure, said Dr. Tevfik Ali Kucukbas of Guven Hospital, where Mr. Erbakan had been in intensive care since mid-January.

LONDON - Antonio Horta-Osorio spent the last four years turning a Spanish bank into one of the biggest retail lenders in Britain. Now, he will have to prove he can do the opposite at the Lloyds Banking Group: shrink a financial firm to make it more profitable. Mr. Horta-Osorio, the former chief of Banco Santander's British unit who took over as Lloyds's chief executive on Tuesday, faces plenty of challenges. In 2010, the British bank posted its first profitable year since taking a bailout during the financial crisis. But the bank is still burdened by bad loans in Ireland and its hasty merger with the troubled mortgage lender HBOS.

Carmelo Anthony's long-awaited arrival in New York was met with predictable fanfare, but the key piece in the deal might have been point guard Chauncey Billups, who quickly proved his worth when he made two key plays to lift the Knicks over the Miami Heat on Sunday night. For Billups, being overlooked and underappreciated is par for the course. Billups's career did not get off to a rousing start. Drafted out of Colorado with the third overall pick in the 1998 N.B.A. draft, Billups played for four teams in his first five years in the league.

It's a bird, it's a plane, it's a former cast member of ''The Outsiders'' who we never expected would one day grow up to be the mother of a quintessentially all-American superhero: it's Diane Lane, who is only the second member of the cast to be announced for a new Superman movie that the director Zack Snyder is preparing for next year. On Wednesday night, Warner Brothers Pictures said Ms. Lane, whose more recent movies include ''The Perfect Storm,'' ''Unfaithful'' and ''Secretariat,'' would play the mother of the film's title character - not the Kryptonian mother of Kal-El, who arrives on earth from a dying alien planet, but Martha Kent, an adoptive parent who raises him in his guise as Clark Kent. Mr. Snyder, the director of previous comic book adaptations like ''Watchmen'' and ''300,'' said: ''This was a very important piece of casting for me, because Martha Kent is the woman whose values helped shape the man we know as Superman. We are thrilled to have Diane in the role, because she can convey the wisdom and the wonder of a woman whose son has powers beyond her imagination.''

GOTTSEGEN--Robert, D.D.S.,Professor Emeritus of Dental Medicine of the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, passed away on March 1, 2011. Dr. Robert Gottsegen was born on June 21, 1919, the son of a dentist. He and his wife Rita (Gillette) Gottsegen had three sons, David, Daniel, and Jonathan. Bob graduated from the University of Michigan in 1939, where his skill as a caricaturist made him the sports cartoonist for the college newspaper. He entered Columbia's School of Dental and Oral Surgery (now the College of Dental Medicine) in 1940 and was in one of the classes that had an accelerated program due to the war, graduating in 1943. After an internship at Mt. Sinai Hospital, he spent two years in the Army and then an additional two years as a Public Health Service/NIH Research Fellow in Dentistry. In 1947, he entered the first class in what was then known as the Advanced Specialty Training Program in Periodontics, also known as the "Certificate" program. He graduated in 1948 and started a private practice limited to periodontics in New York City. Dr. Gottsegen became active in both academic dentistry and organized dentistry almost immediately, holding offices in the American Society of Periodontists, the Executive Council of the American Academy of Periodontology, as Consultant to the National Commission on Diabetes, and as Director and later Co-Chairman of the American Board of Periodontology. He rose through the academic ranks, first to Associate Professor at Columbia, then moving to the University of Pennsylvania, where he was Postgraduate Periodontics Director, and then back to Columbia in 1969 as Professor of Dentistry, Director of the Division of Periodontics, and head of the Postgraduate Program in Periodontics. He held those titles until his retirement in 1988. Dr. Gottsegen rose to become President of the American Academy of Periodontology (1970-71), receiving the Gold Medal Award of the Academy in 1988. He received numerous other awards, including Fellow of the American Academy of Periodontology, Distinguished Alumnus Award of Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, and the Isadore Hirschfeld Award of the Northeastern Society of Periodontists. He was a member of honor societies Omicron Kappa Upsilon and Sigma Xi, Fellow of the American College of Dentists, and Fellow of the New York Academy of Dentistry. He always maintained an interest in research and published on a wide variety of topics, including the relationship of diabetes to periodontal disease and periodontal diagnosis and therapy. In 2006, he was the first recipient of the College of Dental Medicine Lifetime Achievement Award. Above all, Dr. Gottsegen was an educator. His lectures were remarkably well organized and coherent, his clinical demonstrations flawless, his questions of students designed to bring out the best in those he taught, and his knowledge of the relevant literature encyclopedic. He was often in demand as a lecturer, presenting continuing education courses to many local dental societies, dental schools, and regional dental meetings throughout the United States. Bob will be remembered for his prodigious intellect, sharp wit, and his devotion to Columbia. We extend our deepest condolences to his three sons and to members of his family. The memorial service for Dr. Gottsegen will be held on Sunday, March 6, at 2:30p.m., as follows: Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY 10543; 914-381-1809 www.zionmemorialchapel. com. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations in Dr. Gottsegen's memory can be made to: American Academy of Periodontology, Bob@perio.org or the College of Dental Medicine, https://giving.columbia. edu/giveonline Ira B. LamsterD.D.S., M.M.Sc.Dean, Columbia University College of Dental MedicinePanos N. Papapanou D.D.S., Ph.D.Chair, Section of Oral & Diagnostic SciencesDirector, Division of Periodontology

A television review on Feb. 24 about ''Thurgood,'' a filmed version of a play about the life of Thurgood Marshall, on HBO, referred imprecisely to his inability to attend the University of Maryland law school. It did not accept blacks and there is no evidence that he ever applied there; he was not ''denied entry'' in the sense of having an application rejected.

PATEL--Eileen, died peacefully on February 28th. She was surrounded by her loving children; Susan Patel Furlaud, Eric Patel and Sarah Patel Staber. Born on a farm in Ireland, she lived with simplicity, individuality and integrity. She traveled alone to the US at age 17, lived in four countries, and had careers as an artist, fashion retailer, and mother. Eileen was devoted to her husband, Jamshed Patel, her children, six grandchildren and her art. Her quiet grace touched all who knew her. Throughout her last few months she endured extreme pain without complaint. We are deeply grateful to Aging Adult Services at Stanford University Medical Center, Pathways, and all the nurses and caregivers who made her last weeks peaceful.

The Parisian street artist known as JR -- a peripatetic figure who has made a name for himself by plastering urban areas around the world with huge photographs of the downtrodden residents who live there (above, works of his in Clichy-sous-Bois, outside Paris) -- became the unlikely winner several months ago of the 2011 TED Prize (the name stands for Technology, Entertainment, Design). The philanthropic honor gives the winner (past recipients have included Bono and Bill Clinton) the chance to make a grand wish. On Wednesday at the TED organization's annual conference in Long Beach, Calif., the artist revealed his wish -- which the group's backers will help finance. And the wish, perhaps not surprisingly, is to try to turn the entire world into a socially conscious graffiti collective. The artist has started a project called Inside Out that allows people to upload a photo of themselves (or of families or groups of people) free to a Web site, insideoutproject.net. JR and a team of aides then make those photographs into large posters that are mailed back to the senders of the photographs, with the hope that that they will display the posters in public. Whether the posters are displayed with the permission of property owners or are pasted up in a more guerrilla fashion seems to be up the poster owners. ''Posters can be placed anywhere, from a solitary image in an office window to a wall of portraits on an abandoned building or a full stadium,'' says the project's Web site, which already reported 500 uploaded photographs by 6 p.m. Wednesday, just after the project was announced. The goal, JR says, is to transform ''messages of personal identity into pieces of artistic work.'' RANDY KENNEDY

12:39 p.m. | Updated When New York City Center announced this week that it was the first performing arts complex in the city to sell tickets directly to iPhone users via a new app, a whiff of detente was buried in the details. The performances for which one could buy tickets included those by American Ballet Theater. Yet less than a year ago it was unclear when or if American Ballet Theater would return to City Center, its regular fall home. ''I guess the cat's out of the bag,'' Kelly Ryan, a spokeswoman for American Ballet Theater, said in an e-mail message on Wednesday, confirming that the company would be returning for a week's engagement this fall. The plan calls for eight performances between Nov. 8 and Nov. 13. A formal announcement will be made later.

An article on Wednesday about a decrease in bloodstream infections, using information from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, misstated the leading cause of death and hospital stays in people receiving dialysis for kidney failure. It is cardiovascular problems, not infections. (Infections are the second most common cause.) And the article, using information from the C.D.C., also misstated the increase in the number of dialysis patients expected in the next decade. The number, now about 350,000 a day, is likely to increase by about 40 percent by 2020, not to double.

His first wife, Alice died in 2004, and he is survived by his current wife, Suzanne Zacharius and her daughter, Mariel. LIBYA: As rebels in the oil town of Brega celebrated a victory over forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, two working-class neighborhoods in Tripoli that were in open revolt just a week ago were silent and fearful after a clampdown by militiamen and the disappearances of several people who were involved in the protests. That climate of fear suggests just how effectively Colonel Qaddafi's harsh methods to crush dissent in Tripoli, the capital, have sealed off that city. EGYPT: Egypt's ruling military council forced the resignation of Prime Minister Ahmed Shafiq on Thursday, which had long been a goal of the protest movement. Borrowing a tactic from the movement, the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces announced the resignation on Facebook. The generals were evidently trying to head off another huge demonstration on Friday in Tahrir Square by naming a new prime minister, Essam A. Sharaf, who was endorsed by the protesters a day before. Mr. Shafiq seemed to have sealed his fate during a televised confrontation with opponents on Wednesday night when he said that the secret police could be renamed rather than disbanded. Yet even as celebrations ensued, there was a painful awareness that enormous questions remained unanswered for the country. Also on Thursday, Zahi Hawass, Egypt's chief antiquities official for almost a decade and since January a cabinet minister, said that he would not stay on in a newly formed government. On his blog, he posted a list of about two dozen sites that have been looted or vandalized since the uprising.

The historian Ron Chernow has won the annual American History Book Prize for his biography ''Washington,'' the New-York Historical Society announced on Thursday. Roger Hertog, chairman of the society's board, said the book, published by Penguin Press, would ''undoubtedly become the definitive life of our first president.'' Mr. Chernow is also the author of biographies of John D. Rockefeller and Alexander Hamilton, among other works. The prize, which comes with an engraved medal, the title of American Historian Laureate and an award of $50,000, will be presented on April 8 in Manhattan. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

NEMEROV--Shirley. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home at Riverdale deeply mourn the loss of Shirley Nemerov. Predeceased by her husband Arthur, beloved mother of Wendy Maurer and Jeffrey Nemerov, mother-in-law of our esteemed Chairman, Jeffrey Maurer, and Carol Nemerov, Shirley was a humble and gracious woman to all who had the privilege of knowing her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Wendy and Jeffrey, and the entire Nemerov and Maurer families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Shirley will be missed and fondly remembered by all of us at The Hebrew Home at Riverdale. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

Saturday is my day off (no newspaper deadline at least) and so I did what I normally do on Saturday in Paris. I went to the Cafe de Flore. I climbed into a taxi in the Place Vendôme and we puttered across the Seine and down the Boulevard Saint-Germain. It was nearly 8 a.m., the streets were quiet, and as the taxi approached the cafe, I noticed that the metal grilles of the buildings next to Brasserie Lipp shimmered pale pink; and when I looked further down the boulevard, there was a chalky haze. I wondered where the sun was. Then, suddenly, it was there, enormous, rising above the church next to the Cafe Deux Magots.

Motorcycle jackets, couture shapes, tomboys - Junya Watanabe has explored all of these elements in the past. Today in Paris, though, they were in perfect balance in one of his most inspiring collections in a while. Mr. Watanabe didn't overemphasize the 1950s hourglass shapes of his black leather jackets; he eased off the shape just enough to keep them contemporary. There were also capes and loose-back jackets, all in matte black leather that didn't look rigid and wasn't embellished. Another way he kept things contemporary was to put the molded jackets with A-line or softly gathered wool skirts that didn't enhance your rear in a regrettable way. On the feet were updated jodhpur boots with moderately pointed toes.

Two weeks ago Steve Stoute, a marketing executive and music industry veteran, caused a stir by attacking the Grammy Awards in a full-page ad in the Sunday Styles section of The New York Times. In an 850-word open letter, Mr. Stoute criticized the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which bestows the Grammys, for giving top awards to lesser-known artists while booking superstar performances to boost ratings. ''I have come to the conclusion that the Grammy Awards have clearly lost touch with contemporary popular culture,'' Mr. Stoute wrote.

A firefighter rappelled down the side of a 26-story apartment building in Yonkers on Friday evening to rescue two workers dangling from safety ropes after their scaffold collapsed. The workers were trapped 12 stories above the street for more than an hour, secured by only their safety belts, The Associated Press reported. The firefighter who made the descent from the roof, Mike Girous, said afterward, ''It was pretty fun.'' Mr. Girous rappelled after other firefighters raised a ladder from a fire truck, which was about two stories too short to reach the men. The Yonkers fire commissioner, Anthony Pagano, said that the workers were not in danger of falling and that no one seemed to have been seriously injured in the collapse. The cause of the collapse was not immediately known.

A special grand jury in Manhattan has declined to bring charges against four police officers who were involved in a fatal shooting and fired a total of 46 rounds while trying to break up a fight at a block party, according to a union that represents police officers. The grand jury's decision on Friday not to indict the officers came just two days after it declined to indict the man at the center of the chaotic scene last summer in Harlem. ''It is reassuring to see that this grand jury based its decision on the facts of the case and not on fiction from the streets,'' said Patrick J. Lynch, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. ''If we are to do our work effectively, police officers must be reassured that any judgment of their actions will be made on a full and thorough review of facts and nothing more.''
At a host of after-parties for New York City's art fairs on Thursday night, art was oddly absent - at first glance.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the New York Philharmonic included outdated information. In the Hungarian Echoes festival performance scheduled for Thursday, Marino Formenti -- not Pierre-Laurent Aimard -- will play Ligeti's Piano Concerto.

In last weekend's Your Money column, I wrote about all the tax breaks that disproportionately benefit the upper middle class and how many of them were likely to come under the microscope soon. I used 529 colleges savings accounts as a case study, partly because they offered state and federal tax breaks for many investors. But I also think they are likely to invite scrutiny because they can be particularly rich. The plans offer the rare investment account that gives you a tax break on the way in (in the 34 states plus the District of Columbia that offer state tax deductions or credits for some or all contributions) and on the way out (through waiving capital gains taxes for earnings that you use for qualified educational expenses).

A Spare Times entry in some editions on Friday about the Brooklyn Historical Society misstated the admission policy for a screening of a film about the Brooklyn Dodgers scheduled for Sunday. There is no charge in addition to the general admission fee; the screening does not cost $12 for members and $15 for others.

Just recently, I crossed off another task from my changing my name checklist. While I had followed most of the process for changing a name after marriage that I detailed in the Bucks post, ''The Right Way to Change Your Name,'' my name on one of my frequent flier accounts still wasn't the same as the one on my driver's license.

Stephen Sondheim will be honored with the Olivier Special Award 2011 by the Society of London Theater, the society announced on Friday. The society said Mr. Sondheim would accept the award in person at the Olivier Awards on March 13 and that the ceremony - London's equivalent of the Tony Awards ceremony - would conclude with a tribute to him. It said the award recognized the contribution of Mr. Sondheim, the composer and lyricist of musicals including ''Into the Woods,'' ''Sunday in the Park with George,'' and ''Company,'' to London theater. Presenters at the Olivier Awards will include Patrick Stewart, Rupert Everett and the ''Mad Men'' actress Elisabeth Moss, who is currently starring in ''The Children's Hour'' in London with Keira Knightley.

Ewald Groetsch was lonely after his wife died in 2003. Mr. Groetsch, a retired grocery wholesaler who had dementia, struck up a relationship with a broker from Securities America and eventually agreed to put the bulk of his portfolio into a risky security usually reserved for experienced investors. The broker, he said, portrayed the investment as ''safe and secure.'' But the company Mr. Groetsch bought into, Medical Capital Holdings, turned out to be a fraud, wiping out his entire investment.

HOEFER--Dorothy G.,on March 4, 2011 at her home in Bronxville, New York after a long illness at the age of 96. She had a wonderful life. She was preceded in death by her parents Dorothy Micolino and Henry John Gucker of New York City and husband Richard A. Hoefer. Her two sons Robert Waring Hoefer and wife Shannon Brandon Hoefer of Mahopac New York, and Dr. Richard Anderson Hoefer and wife Dr. Elizabeth Ann Harden of Newport News, Virginia survive her. She has two grandchildren Jaime Brandon Hoefer, and David Brandon Hoefer. Dorothy was a native New Yorker and resident of Bronxville, New York, for over 50 years. She was a member of the Reformed Church in Bronxville, and a long time member of Siwanoy Country Club. An avid golfer and reader she had many interests. She was also a Philanthropist, and developed the Dorothy G. Hoefer Comprehensive Breast Center Foundation for Breast Cancer Research, at the center in Newport News Virginia, which bears her name. Funeral Services will be held at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Monday, March 7 at 11am. Interment to followed at The Kensico Cemetery. Memorial gifts may be given to The Dorothy G. Hoefer Comprehensive Breast Center Foundation at the Sentara Health Foundation, 6015 Poplar Hall Drive, Suite 308 Norfolk, Virginia 23502.

One star can only do so much at once on Broadway, even if he's Tony and Academy Award winner Joel Grey. On Thursday the 78-year-old Mr. Grey (''Cabaret'') will begin preview performances as Moonface Martin in the Roundabout Theater Company's revival of ''Anything Goes'' on Broadway; opening night is April 7. This month he is also set to begin rehearsals as director of the first Broadway production of Larry Kramer's ''The Normal Heart,'' the landmark AIDS play from 1985.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. -- After the buzzer echoed through the McCann Center, ending the regular season, 3,000 cheering fans of the Marist women's basketball team stopped and turned their focus to midcourt, where Coach Brian Giorgis held a microphone. His Red Foxes had just beaten Fairfield, 60-45, to finish a perfect run through their Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference schedule, going 18-0 for the second time in four years. The victory gave Marist a 23-game winning streak, the nation's longest and the best in the program's history. Giorgis used his time to lavish praise on his players and their adoring fans.

An art review on Friday about the Salon Zürcher art fair at the Zürcher Studio gallery in the East Village misidentified the artist whose watercolors of mythical creatures are on display at the Proposition gallery booth. He is Balint Zsako -- not Evan Levine, whose painting ''Leopard'' is also at the booth.

LIBYA Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's forces fired on unarmed protesters in Tripoli and Zawiyah, and fought with rebels for control of Zawiyah and Ras Lanuf, an eastern oil town. At least 35 people were killed in Zawiyah. YEMEN Houthi rebels, who had a cease-fire with the government, said the military shelled peaceful protesters in the north, killing two. The government said that its forces fired only after the rebels tried to storm a military post and that no one died.

An obituary on Tuesday about Suze Rotolo, an artist best known for her romance with Bob Dylan, using information from Ms. Rotolo's memoir and from her family, referred incorrectly to her mother's professional background. She was an editor and columnist for L'Unità del Popolo, an American Communist newspaper published in Italian -- not for the American version of the Italian Communist Party publication L'Unità. And although Ms. Rotolo's maternal grandparents were from the province of Piacenza in Italy, her mother was not; she was born in Boston.

An article on Feb. 19 about Hyundai's salutary effect on the economy of Alabama misstated the history of the United Automobile Workers in American plants operated by foreign carmakers. While no such plants are currently unionized, U.A.W. members worked at several joint ventures involving American and foreign carmakers and in a Volkswagen plant in Pennsylvania that operated from 1978 to 1988. It is not the case that the U.A.W. has yet to succeed in organizing American plants operated by foreign carmakers.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about increasing calls for the Obama administration to tap the nation's strategic petroleum reserves referred incorrectly to Bryan Mound, one of the sites where the reserves are stored. It is a salt dome near Freeport, Tex.; it is not a town in itself.
KUGLER--Helen Kugler - Age 93, February 25, at her home in Chevy Chase, MD; Widow of Israel Kugler, Mother of Philip and Daniel, Grandmother of Samuel and Matthew.

The Islanders' Trevor Gillies, who had just returned from a nine-game suspension, was suspended 10 games Friday by the N.H.L. for delivering a blow to the head of Minnesota forward Cal Clutterbuck in a game Wednesday at Nassau Coliseum. Gillies, 32, a combative left wing who has a goal and 220 penalty minutes in 48 career N.H.L. games, received a five-minute penalty and a game misconduct for ramming into Clutterbuck early in the second period of the Islanders' 4-1 victory over the Wild.

SEGALL--Edith Suzanne Besser, 82, of Scarsdale died March 4, three months after the death of her beloved husband, Harold A. Segall. She was the President of the League of Women Voters in Harrison, NY, and the national League of Women Voters' non-governmental observer at the United Nations. She also served as the non-governmental observer for Populations Communications International and Chairman, Conference of UN Representatives, UNA-USA. Earlier, she was religious books editor at Macmillan and an aide to Rabbi Louis Finkelstein at the Jewish Theological Seminary. Survivors include her devoted sons Mark (Karen), Grant (Victoria Belfiglio) and Bruce (Robin Rosenberg); grandchildren Michael, Steven, Rena, Felice, Ruth, David, Anthony and Mario; a brother, Albert Besser, and a sister, Ann Scott. She will be sorely missed. Her funeral will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York at 1:30pm on Sunday, March 6. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

8 P.M. (HBO) ROBIN HOOD (2010) The director Ridley Scott and the actor Russell Crowe, above, -- collaborators on ''Gladiator,'' ''A Good Year,'' ''American Gangster'' and ''Body of Lies'' -- team up once again in what A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called a ''long, bloody, self-serious new version of the legend.'' This Robin is not a ''Hood'' but rather Longstride, an archer in the army of King Richard the Lionheart, on his way home from the Crusades. ''You may have heard that Robin Hood stole from the rich and gave to the poor, but that was just liberal media propaganda,'' A. O. Scott said. ''This Robin is no socialist bandit practicing freelance wealth redistribution, but rather a manly libertarian rebel striking out against high taxes and a big government scheme to trample the ancient liberties of property owners and provincial nobles. Don't tread on him!'' Cate Blanchett plays Marion; Eileen Atkins is Eleanor of Aquitaine; and Matthew Macfadyen is the sheriff. The Times review added that, in true Ridley Scott form, there are enough large-scale action sequences ''to keep you alert and fitfully engaged.'' 8 P.M. (TCM) ON THE CHAIN GANG Five films depict life in shackles, starting with ''Cool Hand Luke'' (1967), starring Paul Newman as a war hero sentenced to jail after cutting the tops off parking meters. Mr. Newman earned an Academy Award nomination for his turn as a prisoner who refuses to break under a brutal system. George Kennedy won the Oscar for best supporting actor for his role as Dragline, the gang's top dog. The evening continues with ''The Defiant Ones'' (1958), at 10:15, with Sidney Poitier as an uneducated convict who goes on the lam with his ''other half,'' a white Southern bigot portrayed by Tony Curtis; ''I Am a Fugitive From a Chain Gang'' (1932), at midnight, in which Paul Muni plays a World War I veteran and drifter sentenced to 10 years of hard labor for a crime he did not commit; ''Hell's Highway'' (1932), at 1:45 a.m., about a convict (Richard Dix) who learns that his younger brother (Tom Brown) will be joining him behind bars; ''Chain Gang'' (1950), at 3, with Douglas Kennedy as a reporter who gets a job as a prison guard to document inhuman conditions; and ''Deep Valley'' (1947), at 4:15, starring Ida Lupino as an abused farm girl who takes in an escaped convict.

It's not exactly Richard M. Nixon going to China, but it is someone who also made some memorable recordings in the 1970s: Bob Dylan is likely to play his first concerts in mainland China this spring, one year after a previously scheduled set of shows there fell through, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Dylan, who has previously performed in Hong Kong, is to play at the Workers' Gymnasium in Beijing on April 6 and the Shanghai Grand Stage on April 8, according to Gehua Live Nation, the Beijing organizers of these concerts. A promoter in Taiwan tried to introduce the gravel-voiced troubadour to China last year but said the Chinese government would not approve the shows. Tickets for Mr. Dylan's Chinese concerts will cost between 280 yuan (about $42) and 1,961.411 yuan (about $300), an amount chosen to commemorate the April 11, 1961, date of his breakthrough show in New York, when he opened for John Lee Hooker at Gerde's Folk City in Greenwich Village. If you're a Dylan fan with a 0.411 yuan coin burning a hole in your pocket, now you know how to spend it.

David Ganek faced two stark choices: try to keep running his hedge fund after a raid by the F.B.I., or shut it down. Mr. Ganek decided to capitulate, not even trying to persuade investors to keep their $4 billion in his hedge fund, Level Global Investors, people close to the fund said. Less than three months after the raid, he told investors he would return their money.

The CBS Corporation said on Friday that it had acquired Clicker, a guide to online television, and installed its chief executive, Jim Lanzone, as the head of its digital media division. The Clicker acquisition strengthens CBS's position in an increasingly competitive area, television on the Web. The purchase price was not disclosed.

GOTTSEGEN--Dr. Robert, born in New York on June 21, 1919, was a pioneer in the field of Periodontal Dentistry. An alumnus of Townsend Harris High School, Dr. Gottsegen graduated from the University of Michigan in 1939. Exhibiting his lifelong passion for art, he was the sports cartoonist for the college newspaper, and also studied set design. He entered the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery (now the College of Dental Medicine) in 1940 in a program accelerated due to the War. He graduated in 1943. After an internship at Mt. Sinai Hospital, he served in the U.S. Army, where he earned a U.S. Army Commendation Medal, European Theatre of Operations. He then spent an additional two years as a Public Health Service/ N.I.H. Research Fellow in Dentistry. In 1947 he entered the first class in what was then known as the Advanced Specialty Training Program in Periodontics, also known as the "Certified" program. Graduating in 1948, he started a private practice limited to Periodontics in New York City. Dr. Gottsegen became active in academics and organized dentistry almost immediately, holding offices in the American Society of Periodontists, the Executive Council of the American Academy of Periodontology, and serving as Consultant to the National Commission on Diabetes and as Director and later Co-Chairman of the American Board of Periodontology. He earned the rank of Associate Professor at Columbia University, then moved to the University of Pennsylvania as Postgraduate Periodontics Director before returning to Columbia to serve as Director of Postgraduate Periodontics. Dr. Gottsegen rose to the presidency of the American Academy of Periodontology (AAP) from 1970-71, receiving the Gold Medal Award of the Academy in 1988. He received numerous other awards, including, Fellow of the AAP, Distinguished Alumnus Award of Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, and the Isadore Hirschfeld Award of the Northeastern Society of Periodontists. He was a Fellow of the American College of Dentists and Fellow of the New York Academy of Dentistry. He was always interested in research, including diabetes as it relates to periodontal disease, systems of health care delivery and metabolic influences on periodontal disease. Above all, Dr. Gottsegen was a teacher and mentor to hundreds of students. His clinical demonstrations were works of dental art, and his knowledge of the relevant literature was encyclopedic. He was often in demand as a lecturer at other schools and in many foreign countries, presenting more than 650 courses over 38 years. Dr. Gottsegen was a connoisseur of fine wines and dining. He had lifelong passion for travel, visual arts, music and theatre. Most of all he loved spending time with his six beloved grandchildren, Jessica, Liza, Sam, Ben, Kate, and Gardner. Dr. Gottsegen was predeceased by his wife of 54 years, Rita Gillette. He is survived by his sons David (wife Shelly), Daniel, and Jonathan (wife Mindy), and his practice partner and devoted friend Dr. Susan Karabin. A Memorial Service in his honor will be held at Zion Memorial Chapel of Westchester, 767 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY (914) 381-1809, on Sunday, March 6 at 2:30pm. Contributions may be made in his honor to the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery or the American Academy of Periondontics.

The British architect Norman Foster has been selected to design the master plan for the 100-acre West Kowloon Cultural District in Hong Kong, his firm, Foster & Partners, announced on Friday. The harbor-front district, known as City Park, is to be a major hub for music, performing and visual arts that includes living spaces, galleries and studios. The project is considered to be the largest current cultural project in the world, Mr. Foster's firm said.

Psychiatrists are talking less and prescribing more. Many of the nation's 48,000 psychiatrists no longer provide talk therapy, the form of psychiatry popularized by Freud that has been a mainstay of psychiatry for decades, writes Gardiner Harris in Sunday's New York Times. Instead, they typically prescribe medication, usually after a brief consultation with each patient.

CRANIN--Dr. A. Norman, 83, died February 20 in the Cayman Islands. An oral surgeon, teacher, lecturer, author and founder of The Dr. Samuel Cranin Dental Center at The Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, his creativity and tireless work in implant dentistry revolutionized the field. Dr. Cranin was a lifelong resident of Hewlett Bay Park, NY, and spent winters in his beloved Beaver Creek, CO. He was passionate about skiing, sailing, tennis, his many dogs, and philanthropy. He is survived by wife Marilyn (Sunners); Jonathan, Andrew, Elizabeth (Cooperstein) and their spouses; and six grandchildren. A memorial is being planned for late March. Donations may be made to the A. Norman Cranin Memorial Fund, Waldorf School, 225 Cambridge Avenue, Garden City, New York 11530, www.gifttrakker.com/ waldorfgarden. NOW who'll wear the shorts in winter?
GAYNES--Martin J. 1/06/33-3/06/07. Always in our hearts and thoughts. Barbara, Brad, Lisa, Carol, Helen, Ben and Maddie

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. -- Rory Sabbatini again shot the lowest score in the field at the Honda Classic on Saturday, deftly working his way through the snares, hazards and Bear Trap holes at the Champion Course at PGA National Resort & Spa for the second straight day. He opened up a five-stroke lead on Y. E. Yang and Jerry Kelly. Sabbatini, a South African who lives in Fort Worth, shot a four-under-par 66 to post a 54-hole total of nine-under-par 201. Yang, whose first PGA Tour win came here in 2009, shot 67 for a 206 total and was tied for second place with Jerry Kelly (68).

CHILDS--Joseph, 82, of New York and Florida, died peacefully following a brief illness on March 4, 2011. Beloved Friend, Uncle, Brother and Son, Joey spent his life as a premier New York City Restaurateur. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel located at 180 West 76th Street in New York City on Monday, March 7, 2011 at 11:30am. Uncle Joey, lovingly know as "the Bear" will be missed everyday by those who loved him
Dance Jack Anderson

Hans Smith has spastic quadriplegic cerebral palsy and a love of baseball. A 24-year-old student at Boise State, he uses a wheelchair and cannot dress or feed himself but appreciates the nuances of sacrifice bunts and cutoff men. Playing baseball on a field with friends is not an option, so Smith enjoys the game on his PlayStation 3. Even that can be frustrating because he does not always have the dexterity to direct his video game players to do what he wants.

''A book itself threatens to kill its author repeatedly during its composition,'' Michael Chabon writes in the margins of his unfinished novel ''Fountain City'' -- a novel, he adds, that he could feel ''erasing me, breaking me down, burying me alive, drowning me, kicking me down the stairs.'' And so Chabon fought back: he killed ''Fountain City'' in 1992. What was to be the follow-up to his first novel, ''The Mysteries of Pittsburgh,'' instead was a black mark on his hard drive, five and a half years of work wasted. That's why you've never read ''Fountain City,'' just as you've never read John Updike's ''Willow,'' Junot Díaz's ''Dark America'' or Jennifer Egan's ''Inland Souls'' -- all abandoned by their authors after years of toil and piles of pages. Chabon, though, has recently published the first four chapters of ''Fountain City'' in the literary magazine McSweeney's, complete with annotations that in turn bemoan and belittle the book that stole so much of his life before he put his misery out of its misery.

To the Editor: It's hard to decide which is more astonishing: that Edward Glaeser glorifies cities in ''Triumph of the City'' while playing down the well-known problems of urban life, or that the book's reviewer, Diana Silver, pays little critical attention to the flaws of such a book (Feb. 13). Glaeser is surely aware of the well-established, widespread existence of such urban pathologies as crime, social isolation, impersonality, anonymity, overcrowding and air pollution. Does he think that all these ills are compensated for by the intellectual and artistic stimulation cities can provide?

Susan Elizabeth Cahan and Jürgen Bank were married Saturday evening in New Haven. Xinia Robles Stein, a Connecticut justice of the peace and a maternal cousin of the bride, officiated in the couple's apartment on the campus of Yale University. Ms. Cahan, 50, is keeping her name. She is the associate dean for the arts at Yale. She graduated magna cum laude from Tufts and received a doctorate in art history from the Graduate Center of the City University of New York.

Vallejo, a city about 25 miles north of San Francisco, offers a sneak preview of what could be the latest version of economic disaster. When the foreclosure wave hit, local tax revenue evaporated. The city managers couldn't make their budget and eliminated financing for the local museum, the symphony and the senior center. The city begged the public-employee unions for pay cuts -- all to no avail. In May 2008, Vallejo filed for bankruptcy. The filing drew little national attention; most people were too busy watching banks fail to worry about cities. But while the banks have largely recovered, Vallejo is still in bankruptcy. The police force has shrunk from 153 officers to 92. Calls for any but the most serious crimes go unanswered. Residents who complain about prostitutes or vandals are told to fill out a form. Three of the city's firehouses were closed. Last summer, a fire ravaged a house in one of the city's better neighborhoods; one of the firetrucks came from another town, 15 miles away. Is this America's future? Cities across America are facing dire financial distress. Meredith Whitney, a banking analyst turned independent adviser who correctly predicted the banking meltdown, has issued an Armageddon-like prediction of mass municipal defaults. Others -- notably Newt Gingrich -- have suggested that state governments as well as cities should be allowed to file for bankruptcy. Congress held a hearing to examine the idea.

DOOLEY--Arch Richard Jr. of Lexington, MA formerly of New York City, suddenly Feb. 22, 2011. Son of Patricia Folts Dooley and the late Arch Richard Dooley and brother of Christopher F. Dooley. Services private. Donations in his memory may be made to Douglas House, Supportive Living Inc., 7 Oakland St., Lexington, MA 02420 or to a charity of your choice.

THE INFINITIES, by John Banville (Vintage International, $15.) Inspired by the myth of Amphitryon, Banville's novel takes place over the course of a single summer's day in the confines of a big, shabby house in the middle of Ireland. With a clan of mischievous Greek gods presiding, the Godley family gathers at the deathbed of Adam, their patriarch and a theoretical mathematician whose work has somehow unlocked the key to infinity. DEVOTION: A Memoir, by Dani Shapiro (Harper Perennial, $14.99.) In her essays and 1998 memoir, ''Slow Motion,'' Shapiro, a novelist, wrote movingly about the tragedies that shaped her life: a family deeply divided about religion, an ill-advised affair, two failed marriages. Here she explores her own spiritual crisis; despite success and a loving husband and son, ''I had begun to quietly fall apart,'' she writes. ''I needed to place my faith in something.''

Dabee Rene Kaye and Andrew Michael Bernstein were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton, Battery Park in New York. Cantor Endre Stamler officiated. The bride, 37, will continue to use her name professionally. She works in New York as the executive beauty/fashion director for Shape magazine and Shape.com, where she sells advertising to beauty and fashion accounts. She graduated from Arizona State University. She is the daughter of the late Judith B. Kaye and the late Herman Kaye, who both lived in Chicago.

Mr. Galioto, 57, is the managing principal of the New York office of HOK, one of the world's largest architecture firms. HOK New York's current projects include LG Electronic's headquarters in Englewood, N.J., and Harlem Hospital. Mr. Galioto joined HOK in 2009, after 30 years with Skidmore, Owings and Merrill, where he helped design One and Seven World Trade Center.

BRENNER--Mary, passed early Saturday morning. Loving wife of Arnold Brenner, mother of Nancy Hilty and Robin Landau, grandmother of Max, Summer, Sam and Bebe. She is survived by her sisters, Rebecca Goldstein, Ruth Scharf and Jeannette Cohn and her brother Arnold Scharf. We will all miss you dearly and carry you in our hearts forever. Thank you for being the most wonderful wife, mother, sister and grandmother which was a blessing to us all. Funeral service at 9:45am on Monday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York.

Life and art stood side by side when the University of Virginia released the transcript of a July 1965 phone call between Lyndon Johnson and Thurgood Marshall. The same day, HBO first broadcast the play ''Thurgood'' starring Laurence Fishburne. Both featured a conversation in which President Johnson called Judge Marshall of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and asked him to become solicitor general of the United States. Art was the more vivid. The play turns the exchange into a two-day affair, with the judge asking for time to think it over because he would be giving up life tenure, the president saying he should take as much time as he needs -- and calling back the next morning. ''Mr. President, I thought you said I'd have time.'' ''You had time.''

JAC HOLZMAN, the 79-year-old founder and former chairman of Elektra Records, might be expected to rest on his laurels. Yet Mr. Holzman, who will be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame on March 14, was in his office at Rockefeller Center, as usual, one recent Saturday morning at Warner Music Group, where he is a senior adviser to its chairman, Edgar Bronfman Jr. Sixty years after starting Elektra as a small, independent folk label and growing it into a rock powerhouse by signing and developing superstars like the Doors and Queen -- he also founded Nonesuch Records as a wide-ranging budget label for classical music -- Mr. Holzman is still looking forward, thinking about how record companies can survive the challenges of file sharing and cyberspace. That no easy solution is evident doesn't discourage him.

LIBYA Militia forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi launched a second day of attacks on the rebel-held city of Zawiyah, 30 miles west of the capital, and the rebels won control of the oil port of Raz Lanuf. The rebels appointed a three-member executive committee, including leaders in charge of the military and foreign affairs. EGYPT The former interior minister, Habib el-Adly, pleaded not guilty to corruption charges. A series of suspicious fires in government security and financial investigation offices has led to speculation that senior officials are trying to destroy evidence that will implicate more of them in crimes like corruption and human rights abuses.

NEWS bulletin from the spirit world: The specter of Edward Gorey, who died in 2000 at the age of 75, is haunting our collective unconscious. In a sense that's as it should be; Gorey was born to be posthumous. His poisonously funny little picture books -- deadpan accounts of murder, disaster and discreet depravity, narrated in a voice that affects the world-weary tone of British novelists like Ronald Firbank and Ivy Compton-Burnett -- established him as the master of high-camp macabre.

An Easy Side Trip from Warsaw? I am a Canadian, and my Polish fiancé and I have decided to get married in Warsaw, where a majority of his family lives. After Warsaw, we would like to go to at least one other city by train, either in Poland or a neighboring country. Do you have any suggestions for a (not too ambitious) itinerary?

THE clamor over ''last in, first out'' -- shorthand for the way union contracts provide for the layoffs of public-school teachers, according to seniority -- is anything but an esoteric political debate for the young teachers at the Academy for Language and Technology, a small high school that opened in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx in 2007. According to a list released by the city, the school stands to lose as many as 9 of 29 teachers if the predictions of 4,675 layoffs before the next school year come true. Many newer schools and those in poor neighborhoods, which tend to hire newer teachers, would lose a particularly large share of their staff members. The Academy for Language and Technology, which was created for native Spanish speakers, fits into both categories.

GOLDREYER--Leonard. You were sweet, kind, and generous, with a curious and open mind. You were interested in our stories and asked the best questions. Uncle Lenny, we will miss you more than words can say. Justis, his big brother Jake, Sally and Michael

Backing Out of a Lease QI recently signed a lease and sent in my first month's rent and security deposit. I haven't moved in yet, but I would now like to get out of the lease. Is it possible to recoup my rent and security deposit?

THE BASICS Vieques, a small island just off the eastern coast of Puerto Rico, has seen big changes in the last decade. Until 2003, most of its 52 square miles were occupied by the United States Navy, which used the base as a bombing range. Almost immediately after the military's withdrawal, travelers began flocking to this untamed paradise of turquoise waters and white powdered sand beaches. In a clear sign that Vieques is no longer off the radar, the first W Retreat and Spa in North America opened its doors there last March. The brand designed a sprawling property that's both luxurious and rustic, filled with unpolished wood and colorful details. It also manages to blend in with the lush nature that surrounds it.

SHARING and communicating are essential components of being human. But as celebrities like Britney Spears and Charlie Sheen have shown us lately, there is such a thing as over-sharing. Still a new generation of Web sites like Dscover.me, Sitesimon.com and Voyurl.com is banking on our willingness to take that next step toward taking our lives public: namely, by automatically tracking personal browsing histories for public viewing.

ASBURY PARK, the first stop in New Jersey for the Smithsonian traveling exhibition ''New Harmonies: Celebrating American Roots Music,'' is putting together six weeks of concerts, workshops, lectures and films to commemorate the occasion. The exhibition, which runs from next Saturday to April 17 at the Asbury Park Public Library, will also be seen in West Deptford, Eastampton, Trenton, Newton and Millville; its tour in the state is sponsored by the New Jersey Council for the Humanities. The 800-square-foot show will offer kiosks with displays about roots music, sacred music, blues and the folk revival of the 1950s and '60s, as well as interactive listening stations and instruments. The curator is Bob Santelli, executive director of the Grammy Museum in Los Angeles.

One morning in early January, David Murdock awoke to an unsettling sensation. At first he didn't recognize it and then he couldn't believe it, because for years -- decades, really -- he maintained what was, in his immodest estimation, perfect health. But now there was this undeniable imperfection, a scratchiness and swollenness familiar only from the distant past. Incredibly, infuriatingly, he had a sore throat. ''I never have anything go wrong,'' he said later. ''Never have a backache. Never have a headache. Never have anything else.'' This would make him a lucky man no matter his age. Because he is 87, it makes him an unusually robust specimen, which is what he must be if he is to defy the odds (and maybe even the gods) and live as long as he intends to. He wants to reach 125, and sees no reason he can't, provided that he continues eating the way he has for the last quarter century: with a methodical, messianic correctness that he believes can, and will, ward off major disease and minor ailment alike.

COHN--Julian Lionel, (June 21, 1921 March 6, 2010), on the first anniversary of his passing. Born and died in New York City. Beloved husband of Ruth with whom he is now reunited; cherished father of Harvey, David, Barbara, Jeremy, and Joel; dedicated grandfather of Douglas. Navy veteran, architect, engineer, developer, playwright and poet. Fondly remembered for his caring devotion to his profession, to the world of art and ideas, and to family

Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. was the lone dissenter in a Supreme Court case last week that ruled the First Amendment protects hateful protests at military funerals. The case was brought by the family of a Marine killed in Iraq whose funeral was the target of protestors carrying signs with messages like ''America is Doomed'' and ''God Hates Fags.'' ''Speech is powerful. It can stir people to action, move them to tears of both joy and sorrow, and -- as it did here -- inflict great pain. On the facts before us, we cannot react to that pain by punishing the speaker.'' -- Chief Justice John G. Roberts, writing for the majority.
