Mike Repole and Todd Pletcher were a long way from the sunny skies of Florida, the glamour of Gulfstream Park and their big horse Uncle Mo, whom they are counting on come Triple Crown season. Instead, the owner, Repole, and the trainer, Pletcher, were hunched against a cold wind here at Aqueduct as a colt named Stay Thirsty shrugged his shoulders as his saddle went on. Stay Thirsty is Repole and Pletcher's second-string horse. His real home is Barn 11 in Boynton Beach, Fla., but he had come north to run in the Gotham Stakes and perhaps prove that he, too, belonged in the Kentucky Derby. Repole, a Queens native, had thought the trip would do the colt good.

THE NEWS Private Eye, a British magazine, said Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, called its editor to complain that the magazine had joined a ''Jewish conspiracy'' bent on smearing his organization. BEHIND THE NEWS When the Private Eye editor told Mr. Assange that the plot's supposed ringleader, Alan Rusbridger, editor of The Guardian, was not Jewish, Mr. Assange reportedly said he was ''sort of Jewish'' because he had a Jewish brother-in-law, then said, ''Forget the Jewish thing.'' Mr. Assange said the Private Eye report was another smear.
INSTRUMENTS OF DARKNESS By Imogen Robertson

WASHINGTON -- When Wisconsin's governor, Scott Walker, began his crusade against collective bargaining by public employees, his state's unions seemed woefully outmatched. But Wisconsin's beleaguered labor movement woke up and mobilized, through e-mail blasts, phone trees and Facebook, getting tens of thousands of supporters to rally in Madison against the legislation and surprising itself that it could muster such a show of force so quickly. For now, the two sides are at a stalemate, with protesters still swarming the Capitol and Democratic senators hiding in Illinois to deny the Republican majority the quorum needed to pass Mr. Walker's bill. Meanwhile, governors in other states, most notably New Jersey and Ohio, have gone on the offensive against labor, deriding teachers' unions, tenure and generous pensions.

SINCE it was unveiled at the Geneva auto show in March 1961, the Jaguar E-Type has regularly topped lists compiled by designers and enthusiasts of the most beautiful cars ever made. The Museum of Modern Art in New York ratified the E-Type's significance in 1996, adding a blue roadster to its permanent design collection. It was only the second road car so honored, following a 1946 Cisitalia 202 GT.

LAST Monday night Matt Stone and Trey Parker, the creators of ''South Park,'' regaled the audience of ''Late Show with David Letterman'' with a vivid description of their appearance at the Academy Awards ceremony in 2000. They told the audience how they decided to dress in drag that night -- their hairy chests scantily covered in silk and taffeta -- which they fretted was a mistake even before they left home. ''Then we did some Charlie Sheen-ing and we were fine,'' said Mr. Parker, to a roar of laughter. Added Mr. Stone: ''We were just sheening our heads off.''
MY FATHER'S FORTUNE A Life

PSST. Interested in some hot munis? No one has ever actually asked me that question, but I wish they had, and preferably several months ago. There have been some great deals in the muni market -- including bonds issued by institutions with fine pedigrees and deep pockets, like Cornell and Harvard.

Duke Snider, the center fielder in the Brooklyn Dodgers' glory years, died last Sunday at 84. His career spanned three decades and both coasts. Fans recalled Snider on the Bats blog last week. How do you say goodbye to your boyhood hero? To the person you modeled yourself after, complete to batting left-handed and throwing right-handed to the bafflement of your parents? To the guy who beat (well, he had some help) the hated Yankees in 1955? To the kind man who gladly signed a ball for a 15-year-old who waited for him in the parking lot after a game he played for the 1963 Mets in which his team lost and he went hitless?

HALLANDALE, Fla. -- Sony Michel is still a high school freshman, yet he has shown flashes of Hall of Fame potential. A tailback for American Heritage in Plantation, Fla., Michel has rushed for 39 touchdowns and nearly 3,500 yards in two varsity seasons. ''He's on par to be Emmitt Smith, on par to be Deion Sanders, on par to be Jevon Kearse,'' said Larry Blustein, a recruiting analyst for The Miami Herald who has covered the beat for 40 years. ''He'll be one of the legendary players in this state.''

As a reporter, I covered two of the greatest losers of the last century. The superlative ''greatest'' applies both to the scale of the loss -- Mikhail Gorbachev lost Russia and all of its colonies, F. W. de Klerk lost the richest country in Africa -- and to the manner in which they lost it. Our hearts understandably thrill to the courage of those who stand up to power -- from Tiananmen Square to Tahrir Square and all the streets that now teem with the young and freedom-hungry. But there is another heroism, scarce and undervalued, that accrues to those who know how to stand down.

HOEFER--Dorothy G.,on March 4, 2011 at her home in Bronxville, New York after a long illness at the age of 96. She had a wonderful life. She was preceded in death by her parents Dorothy Micolino and Henry John Gucker of New York City and husband Richard A. Hoefer. Her two sons Robert Waring Hoefer and wife Shannon Brandon Hoefer of Mahopac New York, and Dr. Richard Anderson Hoefer and wife Dr. Elizabeth Ann Harden of Newport News, Virginia survive her. She has two grandchildren Jaime Brandon Hoefer, and David Brandon Hoefer. Dorothy was a native New Yorker and resident of Bronxville, New York, for over 50 years. She was a member of the Reformed Church in Bronxville, and a long time member of Siwanoy Country Club. An avid golfer and reader she had many interests. She was also a Philanthropist, and developed the Dorothy G. Hoefer Comprehensive Breast Center Foundation for Breast Cancer Research, at the center in Newport News Virginia, which bears her name. Funeral Services will be held at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Monday, March 7 at 11am. Interment to followed at The Kensico Cemetery. Memorial gifts may be given to The Dorothy G. Hoefer Comprehensive Breast Center Foundation at the Sentara Health Foundation, 6015 Poplar Hall Drive, Suite 308 Norfolk, Virginia 23502.
JAY LENO Well, the price of gas near my house went up to nearly $4.50 a gallon today. And that's while I was pumping it. It started at $3.85.

ARTISTS with a toe in commercial fashion are hardly news today, but Sonia Delaunay caused a stir in 1925 when she created her Boutique Simultané. Managing to evoke Picasso's harlequins as filtered through Paul Poiret, Mrs. Delaunay's designs, with their rhythmic patterns and jarring color juxtapositions, will be shown in ''Color Moves: Art and Design by Sonia Delaunay,'' opening March 18 at the Cooper-Hewitt. She is better known today for her paintings, but her clothes were not without fans: Gloria Swanson and Nancy Cunard loved them, as did the wives of modernist architects like Marcel Breuer and Walter Gropius. But ultimately they were a loss leader for her shimmering textiles. And yet, recent shows by Missoni and Prada make it clear that Mrs. Delaunay belongs to the ages. ERIC GRODE
The ''Living In'' article last Sunday, about Park Avenue South, referred incorrectly to subway service at 33rd Street and Park. While the No. 6 stops there, the Nos. 4 and 5 express trains do not.

NO one likes to argue that the world needs more wickedness. What with despots, Charlie Sheen and rail riders who feel that quiet-car restrictions apply to everyone but them, it seems we already have plenty to go around. And yet advocating for more wickedness is exactly what I am forced to do after watching Season 1 of ''Dennis the Menace,'' which is being released this month on DVD by Shout! Factory. Dennis, who arrived on television screens on Oct. 4, 1959, and stayed for 146 episodes over four seasons, was evil incarnate, and he worked hard at it. He wasn't bad just once an episode so that he could receive some tidy life lesson in the final five minutes. He crammed as much wrongdoing into a half-hour as Lindsay Lohan manages in a year. Watching him in action, all I could think was: ''This kid is way more entertaining than the small fry on TV today. Nothing around in the last few decades but cutesy quip spewers like the Olsen twins. What the heck happened?'' The television ''Dennis the Menace,'' of course, was based on the comic strip by Hank Ketcham, and young Jay North, who had just turned 8 when the show had its premiere, memorably brought the character to life. Mischief making, it turns out, is something that needs to be heard and felt, not just sketched. Forget the comics-art purists; this was a television adaptation that ended up being far spunkier than its print-medium inspiration.
Theater Steven McElroy
TIGER, TIGER By Margaux Fragoso

THE world's leading economies are facing crises related to their vulnerability to booms and busts, rising income inequality, unsustainable government obligations, climate change and a widespread erosion of public trust, according to Diane Coyle, an economist and consultant. In ''The Economics of Enough: How to Run the Economy as if the Future Matters'' (Princeton University Press), Ms. Coyle adds a knowledgeable and earnest voice to the discussion about how to face these global challenges.
I WAS A DANCER A Memoir

DHAKA, Bangladesh -- In the last days of the bloody war that created this nation out of the eastern half of Pakistan in 1971, a gang of men abducted Dr. Alim Chowdhury, an eye surgeon and independence activist, from his home. Three days later, his battered body was found in a mass grave, his eyes gouged from his head. His killers, members of a pro-Pakistan militia, were never punished. Moulana Abdul Mannan, the man who confessed to orchestrating the killing, according to a government investigation, went on to become a cabinet minister and member of the Bangladesh Parliament. He died in 2006.

The Ethicist column on Feb. 20, about intellectual property, misstated a phrase from the Constitution related to copyright. It is ''to promote the progress of science and useful arts,'' not ''the sciences and useful arts.''

MARCHI--Dr. Lorraine June Fastie. Died in San Francisco on February 20, 2011 surrounded by family. She is survived by her five children Gene, Jeffrey, Deborah, Beth and Laura; their spouses Travis, Gail, Steve and Reuf; her grandchildren Jessica, Sara, Melissa, Alyson, Jay, Ashley, Carey, Ben and Margo; and her great-grandchildren Jacqueline, Jody and Jamison. Dr. Marchi was a fourth generation San Franciscan whose great-grandmother crossed the plains in a covered wagon from New York City. She was an Alumna of Lowell High School, Stanford University and UC Berkeley. "To Rest is to Rust" is the title of her upcoming memoirs as Founder and CEO of National Association for Visually Handicapped (NAVH). In 1948, Dr. Marchi discovered the need to address the gap of services for people who were not classified as blind but did not have normal vision. For over 55 years, Dr. Marchi tirelessly dedicated herself to ensure that a wide variety of services would be available to clients with low vision, whom she trademarked "Hard of Seeing." Her mission in life was to help the "Hard of Seeing" overcome their challenges of vision impairment through educational materials, support groups, and counseling individuals, their family members and doctors. Through the support services offered, the clients would share their renewed hope and ability to continue their lives with dignity and independence. Recognized by 3M as an award-winning master printer, she used her acquired expertise to educate major publishers on the standards required to meet the needs of the "Hard of Seeing." In many large-print books printed today, publishers proudly display the NAVH Seal of Approval. Dr. Marchi has been the recipient of numerous awards and honors. In 1957 she was awarded the San Francisco Examiner's Phoebe Hearst Award. In 2006 she received the Special Recognition Award from the American Academy of Ophthalmology, whom she joined as an exhibitor displaying NAVH material and educating members for over 50 years. She is also the recipient of the 2009 Jefferson Award. Over the years she has received many personal congratulatory letters from distinguished politicians including many Presidents of the United States from Lyndon Johnson to Barack Obama, Mayors of San Francisco and New York, along with various United States and State Senators. In 2010, Lighthouse International, located in New York City, acquired NAVH and expanded their social services program with the addition of the Dr. Lorraine Marchi/NAVH Client Assistance Program. On January 11, 2011, Dr. Marchi made her final public appearance at a Lighthouse International event honoring her and dedicating the opening of the new program to her legacy. A private celebration of Dr. Marchi's life will be held in the spring. In lieu of flowers, memorials can be made to: Dr. Lorraine Marchi/NAVH Client Assistance Program, c/o Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th Street, New York, NY 10022
AEROTROPOLIS The Way We'll Live Next

Steak, lobster, McDonald's: Ask students in New York City's public schools what their cafeterias should be serving, and those are the top three answers. Their parents have a lot of suggestions, too, which are rarely any more realistic. Eric Goldstein, the Department of Education executive who oversees school food, fields those suggestions. Frequently, he says, they start like this: ''I just ate in this really great restaurant for $100 a person and this cafeteria food doesn't compare with that.'' Everyone seems to have an opinion about school lunches these days. Michelle Obama has pointed to them as a battlefield in the fight against childhood obesity. Nutrition advocates have led a charge against the presence of fast food. Individual districts have kicked soda and candy vendors to the curb.

WASHINGTON -- Cuban state television announced Saturday that the argument phase of the trial of an American government contractor, Alan Gross, charged with crimes against the state, had ended. A verdict is expected in the coming days. If convicted, Mr. Gross faces up to 20 years in prison. The ailing Mr. Gross, 61, was detained in December 2009 when, according to Cuban authorities, he was distributing satellite telephone equipment to Jewish groups on the island that would have allowed them access to the Internet, which is widely restricted by the Cuban government.

It seems hard to believe that one year ago the Philadelphia Flyers were clawing for a playoff berth, part of a season-long struggle in which they had fallen as low as 14th place. Today the Flyers are the class of the East, despite the kind of slump - they have won 7 of 14 since the All-Star break - plenty of teams would be happy to endure. They have held the top spot in the conference since Jan. 8, and the tribulations of the 2009-10 regular season are a distant memory.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. -- Frank Chirkinian lifted his game for one final performance. Close friends of Chirkinian, a longtime CBS producer, gathered Feb. 22 at Emerald Hills Golf Clu in West Palm Beach, Fla., called together by John Haas, who was, until the club's recent sale, its co-owner with Chirkinian. It had become clear to Haas and others that Chirkinian, who was dying of cancer, would not live long enough to attend his World Golf Hall of Fame induction May 9 in St. Augustine, Fla. They agreed that if Chirkinian felt up to it, he would tape an acceptance speech for the ceremony.

For months, New York City brokers have been saying that sales in luxury real estate, the last segment of the market to back away from the edge of a cliff, were rebounding. But one week sales were up, one week they were down. One month they were down, one quarter they were up. And even the most Pollyanna-ish real estate watchers usually added a mouthful of caveats to any declaration of victory.

With everyone talking about the Knicks and their newest star acquisition, Carmelo Anthony, not much attention has been paid to the Philadelphia 76ers, who are a half-game behind the Knicks for the sixth seed in the East.

Chiang Mai, Thailand, Jan. 6, 2011 This is a picture of me taken by my husband, Thomas, at an elephant sanctuary where individuals ride bareback, wash and feed the elephants. This is a sanctuary where elephants are being rescued from harsh abuse and to preserve them. I would never have guessed how sensitive elephants can be. Mammals are simple creatures, especially the ones that have not acquired language; people should listen to them more, then maybe the world could be a better place. Tiffany Adams, New York
PARIS IN the rarefied realm of Bernard Arnault, the grand master of the world of luxury, the talk is usually of beautiful things.

Arnost Lustig, an acclaimed Czech author who drew on his own harrowing experiences as a teenager in World War II to produce novels and short stories laced with tales of young people who survive the Holocaust, died on Feb. 26 in Prague. He was 84. The embassy of the Czech Republic in Washington confirmed his death.

For the last three years, Gallup has called 1,000 randomly selected American adults each day and asked them about their emotional status, work satisfaction, eating habits, illnesses, stress levels and other indicators of their quality of life. It's part of an effort to measure the components of ''the good life.'' The responses are plugged into a formula, called the Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index, and then sorted by geographic area and other demographic criteria. The accompanying maps show where well-being is highest and lowest around the country.

THE call for clean lines and bold colors was broadcast loud and clear last week in Milan. If the new Prada collection is any indication, Mondrian-esque geometry and Mod color-blocking are certain to have a place in every woman's wardrobe come fall. For those who are impatient to achieve such sartorial clarity, there is the Billie shoulder bag by Chloé ($1,560 at net-a-porter.com). Crosshatched in chunky neutral stripes of leather and linen and highlighted with black patent trim, the bag is a structured statement piece that plays well with solids and patterns alike. What's more, you'll already be squared away for the next season. KAVITHA SURANA

GARDNER--Sylvia, passed away on March 1, 2011, 94 years old. Adored and beloved wife of Murray, mother of Dr. Gerald Gardner (Emily), loving grandmother and great-grandmother. You lead a life of quiet dignity, sacrifice and loving kindness. You are forever in our hearts. Donations to a charity of your choice.

Miriam Jenny Udel and Adam Zachary Newton are to be married Sunday at the Metropolitan Building, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Stephen S. Friedman is to officiate, and Wendy A. Amsellem, a teacher of the Talmud and Jewish law, is to give a blessing. The bride, who is 34 and is keeping her name, is an assistant professor of German studies and Jewish studies at Emory University in Atlanta. She graduated from Harvard, from which she also received a Ph.D. in comparative literature. Her previous marriage ended in divorce.

Last Monday's trade deadline provided the final opportunity for teams to make changes in advance of the playoffs. But for those teams out of the hunt, like the Florida Panthers, it was also a chance to rebuild and prepare for next season.

A JAR of rainwater is not the sort of sentimental keepsake newlyweds usually take home from their ceremonies. The bride's bouquet, absolutely. The cake topper, likely. A few monogrammed napkins, sure. But some couples do buck tradition and save unusual mementos. As Rebecca Tompkins recalled, ''It rained heavily the afternoon of our wedding,'' in Columbia, S.C., just as it had at her mother's wedding. ''I remember my mother saying, 'Rain on the wedding day is good luck.' ''

Lori Berenson has always loved to walk. When she was a high-school student in Manhattan in the mid-1980s, she walked home at night from her job at Pasta & Cheese, on the Upper East Side, to the apartment where she grew up, on East 25th Street. When she began her prison sentence in Peru, in 1996, for collaborating with a terrorist group, convicted terrorists had to spend 231/2 hours a day inside their cells. Even then, Berenson walked in the 6-by-9-foot space she and another woman shared -- two steps forward, two steps backward -- for hours. ''People ask, what did you miss most?'' she said in August, two and a half months after she was released on parole, having served nearly 15 years of a 20-year sentence. ''This was definitely it.'' It was after dark, and we were taking a rapid, circuitous walk through a park that clutches the crumbly cliff tops in the Miraflores district of Lima, where Berenson and her 15-month-old son, Salvador, had been living since her release. (Berenson's parole requires that she remain in Peru until 2015.) They were sharing an apartment with a family friend and, temporarily, Berenson's parents, who were visiting from New York. Berenson had recently separated from her husband -- Salvador's father -- whom she'd met in prison while he, too, was serving a sentence for terrorism. Soon after his release in 2003, they married, and Salvador was conceived during a conjugal visit. The boy spent his first year of life with Berenson in the women's prison in Chorrillos, Lima.

LAST Wednesday evening, Blake Lively, the star of ''Gossip Girl,'' arrived at Le Grenouille in Midtown, where Chanel had organized a dinner to introduce her as the new face of the French fashion house's Mademoiselle handbag ad campaign. Wearing a white Chanel minidress that contained -- at least, to a degree -- her famously curvaceous torso while still showing off her long, perpetually tanned legs, the 23-year-old Ms. Lively seemed, at times, to have trouble believing that she was the focal point of the room. After greeting the designer Tory Burch and Vogue's event director, Sylvana Soto-Ward, and hopping up and down in wobbly heels upon seeing John Galantic, the president of Chanel, Ms. Lively eventually made her way to a table. ''I was just having a conversation and I looked down and saw 'Chanel: Dinner in Honor of Blake Lively' '' she said, pointing to her menu. ''It's crazy.''

A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405. Comedy

FOR more than a decade, the American real estate market resembled an overstuffed novel, which is to say, it was an engrossing piece of fiction. Mortgage brokers hip deep in profits handed out no-doc mortgages to people with fictional incomes. Wall Street shopped bundles of those loans to investors, no matter how unappetizing the details. And federal regulators gave sleepy nods.

SAN FRANCISCO -- As the proprietor of Chung Chou City, a packed-to-the-gills dried seafood emporium in Chinatown here, Anna Li presides over barrels full of coveted ingredients like dried shrimp eggs and scallops and fried fish stomachs. The Rolls-Royce of the sea is her shark's fin, the pricey pièce de résistance of traditional Chinese banquets. ''No shark's fin soup, you're cheap,'' said Mrs. Li, summing up the prevailing ethos toward the steamy glutinous broth, for centuries a symbol of virility, wealth and power.

WASHINGTON -- For President Obama, who told Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi last week that it was time to quit, the bloodshed and terror in Libya have posed a dilemma that sooner or later confronts every modern American president: whether, and how, to intervene with military force in a distant conflict. This time, the choice has been made even tougher by history, geography and the peculiar circumstances of Libya's upheaval: a famously ruthless and unpredictable leader willing to do anything to cling to power, in a conflict that seems as much an African civil war as an Internet-fueled youth revolt of the kind that forced out Arab dictators in Egypt and Tunisia.

LITOFF--Ronald, passed away on March 4, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Carole. Adored father of Hope (Todd) and the late Ruth. Cherished grandfather to Charlie and treasured friend to many. Funeral service at 11:30am on Sunday at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 W. 76th Street, New York.
UPPER EAST SIDE STUDIO $495,000

THE first thing you notice is the scale of everything. The unending distance between towns, the unfathomable stretch of land between you and the horizon, the vast expanses of sky. The next thing you notice is the landscape -- or, more accurately, landscapes. In one spot, you're surrounded by low, scrubby desert pocked with thorny bushes. And you think: this could be the Australian Outback, or maybe the American Southwest. But then you approach the ocean, the navy blue Atlantic with its frigid whitecaps and craggy coastline, and your mind calls up images of Nova Scotia or Ireland. Then from some point to the south: a flock of hot pink flamingos flies by, so close you could almost pet them. You picture South Florida, perhaps, or the Bahamas. But, in fact, you're thousands of miles from any of those places.

CORVALLIS, Ore. -- For years, Tyler Jones, a livestock farmer here, avoided telling his grandfather how disillusioned he had become with industrial farming. After all, his grandfather had worked closely with Earl L. Butz, the former federal secretary of agriculture who was known for saying, ''Get big or get out.''

MANY gifted cooks have a vivid memory of their first experience in the kitchen. For Marisa Robertson-Textor, a 36-year-old freelance writer who grew up in the Bay Area of California, that memory involves making dinner for her family when she was 6. ''It was some riff on tacos, my favorite meal,'' she recalled. ''Preformed packaged tacos, as best I remember.'' Not to mention, as her mother reminded her, Minute Maid pink lemonade. Ms. Robertson-Textor has come a long way since packaged tacos and frozen lemonade. She has traveled the world and become skilled at entertaining a crowd. Her Thanksgiving dinners -- Gobble Gobble Night, as she calls the event -- are especially memorable, with recipes drawn entirely from Gourmet, where she worked as research chief until the magazine closed in 2009.

To the Editor: Regarding ''An Up- scale Refuge Near Mexico City'' (Feb. 20): I am a native New Yorker who stumbled across Valle de Bra- vo, Mexico, a few years ago, and be- cause of all the charms described in the superb portrait of the town, I ended up moving there. There was just one omission, however. All you have to do is look into the sky on any afternoon: the town is a mecca for paragliders and hang gliders. The town has some of the best flying conditions in the world. Indeed, Valle de Bravo hosted the paraglid- ing world championships in 2009. On weekends, it looks like we're being invaded. JAMIE ROSEN Valle de Bravo, Mexico
Art Carol Vogel

A chart on Feb. 6 showing record single-event snowfall amounts for 44 cities gave incorrect amounts from AccuWeather for several cities. Some records listed were for midnight-to-midnight snowfall totals and others were for multiday snowfall events. A corrected chart, giving the single-event snowfall for all the cities, can be found at nytimes.com/weekinreview.

TAMPA, Fla. -- All around him, corks flew and beer flowed, but Andrew Brackman was in little mood to party. He stood alone in a far corner of the visiting clubhouse at Rogers Centre, watching his quasi teammates celebrate a return trip to the playoffs. During his 11 days with the Yankees last fall, Brackman did not throw a pitch. He observed, tried not to stand out -- not so simple for someone nearly 7 feet tall -- and committed to memory how it felt that September night in Toronto when he dodged a Champagne bath he thought he did not deserve. ''It just felt awkward,'' Brackman said. ''I'd been there only a few days and I obviously didn't have anything to do with it. I was happy for the guys, but I was also jealous. I wanted to be part of it.''

WHEN Peter J. Sheldon boards a plane to any destination, his safety routine extends well beyond buckling his seat belt and noting the nearest exit. Once at his seat, he meticulously wipes down the cushions, armrests and tray table with disinfectant wipes. He refuses to touch the in-flight magazines and avoids using the restroom if at all possible. Since he began his in-flight cleansing routine he says he has weathered countless stares from other passengers but has never gotten ill from a flight. ''I've become a cautious germ freak,'' said Mr. Sheldon, an executive at a commercial cleaning company. As someone who thinks about germs for a living, Mr. Sheldon may be more neurotic than most, yet a look at the growing number of products catering to traveling germaphobes suggests he's not alone.

GLEICH--Shirley Ringelheim. Passed away peacefully on March 3, 2011 at the age of 87 surrounded by her family at home in Tamarac, Florida. She is survived by her adoring, devoted husband of 64 years, Joseph Gleich, and their three children, Linda, Gerry, and Helene, and their families, including ten grandchildren, and one great grandchild. Shirley was an active philanthropist both in Long Beach, New York and Tamarac, Florida where she lived for many years. She touched many lives, and will be missed by all who knew her. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice By the Sea of Boca Raton, Florida, and The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

To the Editor: In Michael Belfiore's review of Sam Howe Verhovek's ''Jet Age'' (Feb. 6), no mention was made of Aeroflot's introduction of jet service in 1956 with the Tupolev 104, two years ahead of Pan Am, TWA or United. There must be some good stories here: Why were the Russians so far ahead? And in the long run, how did the Tu 104 compare with the Boeing 707 and the Douglas DC-8?

Mary F. Oey and Prem Ganesh Kumar were married Friday at the Superior Court of the District of Columbia. Geneva Murphy, the chief of the domestic relations branch of the family court, officiated. On May 1, the couple are to have a Hindu ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Pandit Swaminath Shastrigal is to lead that ceremony.

GENEVA THE 81st Geneva Motor Show is being promoted as a window into the future of a more environmentally responsible and sustainable auto industry. But should a 1,115-horsepower supercar that runs on ethanol be counted among the 40 or so new ''green'' machines at the show? If so, then what does green really mean?
AND FURTHERMORE By Judi Dench as told to John Miller

THE designer Dror Benshetrit of Studio Dror recently unveiled QuaDror, a space truss geometry that he invented and patented. Its interlocking load-bearing members function at several scales, from the small (a table base or room divider) to the large (a bridge support or structure for a house). But the application about which Mr. Benshetrit is most excited is emergency housing. The QuaDror Home is a kit that includes instructions, tools and QuaDror universal joints -- to which structural members (of wood, bamboo, etc.) can be attached. Because they take up so little room, about 1,750 of the kits can be shipped in a single 40-foot container. Small, sturdy houses can be built with whatever local materials are available, making them cost-effective, not to mention sustainable. PILAR VILADAS

DAVIS--George. The Officers, Board of Directors, shareholders and staff of 570 Park Avenue Apartments Inc., mourn the passing of their former President, friend and neighbor. His unstinting service to his neighbors, his kindness and unfailing courtesy earned him the respect and affectionate regard of all who worked with him. Heartfelt condolences to his wife Mary, their children and family.

SEGALL--Edith Suzanne Besser, 82, of Scarsdale died March 4, three months after the death of her beloved husband, Harold A. Segall. She was the President of the League of Women Voters in Harrison, NY, and the national League of Women Voters' non-governmental observer at the United Nations. She also served as the non-governmental observer for Populations Communications International and Chairman, Conference of UN Representatives, UNA-USA. Earlier, she was religious books editor at Macmillan and an aide to Rabbi Louis Finkelstein at the Jewish Theological Seminary. Survivors include her devoted sons Mark (Karen), Grant (Victoria Belfiglio) and Bruce (Robin Rosenberg); grandchildren Michael, Steven, Rena, Felice, Ruth, David, Anthony and Mario; a brother, Albert Besser, and a sister, Ann Scott. She will be sorely missed. Her funeral will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York at 1:30pm on Sunday, March 6. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

THAT distant rumble you hear is the sound of yet another approaching cultural shift, accompanied by all the shouts of joy and gnashing of teeth that come with such upheaval. The DVD isn't dead yet, but it's definitely looking a little peaked, at least in the eyes of the home-video industry. Sales continue to decline (volume is down about 40 percent from this time last year for the Top 20 titles, according to Home Media Magazine), the formerly ubiquitous neighborhood rental shops have all but vanished (Blockbuster, once the dominant franchise, has plunged into bankruptcy), and the major studios have drastically cut back on full-scale releases of library titles.

Caffeine's Cafe is not easy to categorize. Housed within a large shopping plaza in Unionville, it has a curbside appeal that is predictably minimal, but a comfortable interior that encourages lingering. And though the establishment sells a large selection of coffee drinks, it also offers full breakfast, lunch and dinner menus. Seating (for about 50) is mixed, too, with four booths, a handful of small round tables and three game tables for checkers, chess and backgammon. One long wall is a painter's palette of colors (overlapping patches of purple, red, blue, yellow and green), with small oil paintings hung against it. Balancing that insouciance is the refinement of a cherry wood floor and red tulip-shaped drop lights.

A review on Feb. 6 about ''The Magnetic North,'' by Sara Wheeler, included a quotation from the book that contained an erroneous summary of research conducted by the Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme (AMAP). While the group has hypothesized that unusual sex ratios in the newborns of some Arctic populations might in some way be connected with pollutants, it has repeatedly stressed that causality has not been determined and that further studies are needed before conclusive statements can be made about any such connection. AMAP has not maintained that ''endocrine-disrupting chemicals handed up the food chain have triggered changes in the sex of unborn children in the first three weeks of gestations, resulting in the birth of twice as many girls as boys in some villages in Greenland and among the Inuit nations of eastern Russia.''

THE Jaguar E-Type can tick all the boxes for almost any car collector. Beautiful, fast and descended from a line of Le Mans-winning racecars, only their lack of rarity -- more than 72,000 were built from 1961-74 -- keeps them off the A-list of collectible European sports cars. But accessibility has always been part of the Jaguar equation: even new, the cars offered performance and looks on par with European exotics that cost much more. As one would expect of a car produced for more than a decade, some models are far more desirable than others. Collectors prize the Series I cars, made in 1961-68, because they are the most faithful to the original design, with attractive features like covered headlights and the elliptical front grille opening that became a Jaguar hallmark.

GREENBURGH, N.Y. -- Mike D'Antoni looked straight ahead for a moment Saturday as he flipped through a mental calendar for the next date that his team could have a full practice. He finally settled on next Saturday. Yes, he said, the Knicks could have a good practice then. Despite an abundance of talent, the reconfigured Knicks will have to get through another week of jelling on the fly, especially on defense. But D'Antoni had already offered a reality check: He said he did not expect the Knicks to be cohesive until the N.B.A. playoffs begin next month. ''It just takes a while,'' he said. ''I know everybody's anxious. I'm anxious. The players are anxious. But there's just no way you can throw four new guys into a rotation, and they're all on the same page and going to play great every time. That's not happening.''

Hotels have been on a health kick in the past year, offering hypoallergenic rooms, free workout gear and now special menus for discerning eaters. Last month, Casa del Mar (hotelcasadelmar.com) in Santa Monica, Calif., introduced a gluten-free menu at its restaurant Catch (a striped bass offering, above). Both celiac disease sufferers, who cannot process gluten, found in cereals like wheat, and unrestricted diners have shown interest, according to staff members.

Donovan Hohn's ''Moby-Duck'' tracks a fleet of some 29,000 bath toys that fell off a container ship in 1992 and then drifted into unexpected geographical and metaphysical territory. Elizabeth Royte, who reviews the book this week, is herself no stranger to the pleasures and perils of chasing errant pieces of plastic and other castoffs to surprising (and often disgusting) places. What advice would the author of ''Garbage Land'' and ''Bottlemania'' offer aspiring environmental writers who want to avoid drowning in a vortex of phthalates, parts per million and other eye-glazing technical details? ''Don't wax abstract,'' Royte said via e-mail. ''Minimize interactions with policy wonks and lawyers. Try to put yourself in unusual places and situations. Ask dumb questions and hope that some readers may identify with your skepticism and confusion. Suspense is helpful; so are humor, dialogue and visceral descriptions of skanky stuff.''

MORE than 87,000 Americans suffering from end-stage renal disease are on dialysis and awaiting a kidney transplant. Fewer than 17,000 of them are likely to have new kidneys by the end of the year. The United Network for Organ Sharing, the nonprofit group that manages the nation's organ transplant system, wants to change the system for allocating kidneys from deceased donors. While organs from living donors are usually directed to a particular person, kidneys from the deceased are distributed under a formula devised by the network. The proposal is supposed to provide deceased-donor kidneys of higher quality to healthier, younger patients instead of to elderly ones who presumably have fewer years to live.

IT was a craze, a fad, just like Art Deco, Permastone and swoopy titanium-skin buildings. The mansard mania of 1868 to 1873 swept over New York with a peculiar incandescence, but then went out like a guttering candle. Traces of the mansard bubble somehow survived, and that on the 1868 Grand Hotel, at Broadway and 31st Street, is getting a particularly loving restoration. The mansard roof, where the topmost stories pitch back at an angle, takes its name from François Mansart, the 17th-century French architect who used it extensively.

Since the mid-19th century, Santa María la Ribera, a residential area northwest of Mexico City's historic center, has been a gathering spot for well-known cultural and political figures. Today, vestiges of its former grandeur survive; belle-époque mansions in need of face-lifts sit side by side with cantinas and modernist '50s-era apartment buildings. ''It's quintessential Mexico City,'' said Jim Johnston, longtime resident and author of ''Mexico City: An Opinionated Guide for the Curious Traveler,'' ''a crashing mix of high and low, old and new, ugly and beautiful.'' The neighborhood may have an even brighter future, as a new generation of artists and would-be bohemians have moved in, enticed by cheap rents and quirky living spaces. A host of cafes, art galleries, boutiques, bars and restaurants have followed. NICHOLAS GILMAN

In the dozens of versions for the big and small screens, opera, theater and even ballet, artists have tried to make ''Jane Eyre'' their own. Some succeed -- the 1973 mini-series is ''almost the same as reading the novel for me,'' said Charlene Cruz, who runs the Enthusiast's Guide to Jane Eyre Adaptations at eyreguide.awardspace.co.uk -- others have gone far afield. Would Charlotte Brontë recognize her creation? STEPHANIE GOODMAN

We only have to consider some of the nation's greatest achievements to appreciate what's possible when we coordinate efforts rationally. At its peak, for example, the Apollo program, which put a man on the moon, involved 400,000 people and 20,000 companies and academic organizations. The Manhattan Project, which produced the first atomic bomb, coordinated the work of 130,000 scientists, engineers and others. The Los Angeles Olympic Games were successful because of unprecedented cooperation among civic groups, government agencies and businesses.

TUESDAY'S PUZZLE - One of the formative moments of my childhood was being taken to the movies to see the theatrical release of The Ten Commandments starring Charlton Heston and watching him stretch his staff over the roiling waters of the RED SEA, parting them like it was nothing. It was a scenery-chewing moment that wasn't helped by the cheesy visual effects of 1960s cinema, but to a young mind it was pretty heavy. I remember hoping that the Egyptian soldiers who were being swallowed by the closing of the sea might be able to TREAD WATER.

In his new book, "Philosopher Kings? The Adjudication of Conflicting Human Rights and Social Values," law professor George C. Christie notes that with respect to the conflict between privacy rights and free expression rights, the United States and Europe seem to be going in different directions. European jurists will try, as one court put it, to strike "a fair balance . . . between the competing interests of the individual and of the community as a whole"; American courts are likely to come down strongly in favor of the individual's right to free expression even when an expressive activity arguably pollutes the community's conversational space or is intentionally hurtful to other individuals.

What do you do after your party wins an election? In a forthcoming study for the journal Computers in Human Behavior, Patrick Markey and Charlotte Markey compared Internet searches in red and blue states after the 2006 and 2010 elections. They found that the number of searchers for pornography was much higher right after the 2010 election (a big G.O.P. year) than after 2006 (a big Democratic year). Conversely, people in blue states searched for porn at much higher rates after 2006 than after 2010. One explanation is this: After winning a vicarious status competition, people (predominantly men, I guess) tend to seek out pornography.

This week's Critics Pick video looks at the Walter Hill's drama "The Warriors." The film takes place in a dystopian version of New York City run by gangs jockeying for control.

It's often said that America doesn't make things anymore, that our manufacturing base has been decimated. In a column in the Boston Globe, Jeff Jacoby has an interesting statistic. In 1990, the U.S. accounted for 21 percent of the world's manufacturing output.  In 2009, it accounted for 20 percent.

Feeling re-energized after a brutal season on the field and an off-season full of change, Texas Coach Mack Brown sat down for an interview in his office last week. He also talked about how YouTube aided his hiring process, how Texas' new ESPN channel will impact the program's future and how he re-evaluated the program's recruiting philosophy last year.

American Ballet Theater is no stranger to "The Firebird": the troupe already has in its repertory several versions of the ballet set to Stravinsky's 1910 score. But none of those were by its artist in residence, Alexei Ratmansky. That oversight is about to be rectified: Ballet Theater announced Monday that Mr. Ratmansky would be creating a new version, with scenery by Simon Pastukh and costumes by Galina Solovyeva, to have its premiere next March during the company's Costa Mesa, Calif., engagement. New Yorkers will get to see the production during the spring 2012 season at the Metropolitan Opera House. For those keeping score at home, this will be Ballet Theater's fourth production of "The Firebird" and the choreographer's second -- he created a version for the Royal Swedish Ballet in 2002.

When I was younger, I wondered who bought new Rolling Stones albums. I now know, because I am the descendant of that man: I can't help buying - in physical, compact-disc form, no less - every new R.E.M. album. Tomorrow we get another one: "Collapse Into Now." NPR is streaming it free until then.

Lincoln Center on Monday announced the third pillar of what is shaping up to be an especially high-profile festival this summer: the Mariinsky Ballet. The company will give eight performances at the Metropolitan Opera House in July, joining the Cleveland Orchestra and the Royal Shakespeare Company as major presences at the Lincoln Center Festival. The Mariinsky will present two works receiving their first United States performances, "Anna Karenina" and "The Little Humpbacked Horse," full-length ballets choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky and set to the music of the contemporary Russian composer Rodion Shchedrin. A third program includes Alberto Alonso's "Carmen Suite," choreographed to Bizet's music as arranged by Mr. Shchedrin, and "Symphony in C," the George Balanchine work. Valery Gergiev, Mariinsky's artistic director, will conduct.

Yesterday there were tears in the locker room again. The setting wasn't a championship, however, but a regular-season game in the N.B.A., a loss by the home-team Miami Heat to the Chicago Bulls. We know this because the Heat's coach, Erik Spoelstra, said so in his postgame comments: "This is painful for every single one of us to go through this, there are a couple of guys crying in the locker room right now, it is not a matter of want." As you'd imagine, the general reaction hasn't been one of extending gestures of comfort (for example). And you have to wonder what Spoelstra was thinking when he went all confessional, even if he didn't name names - didn't he learn anything from all that grief John Boehner recently had to put up with over his weepiness? As Spoelstra and the Heat are finding out, crying just doesn't make for good "optics" most of the time. (You might find some exceptions - or confirmations - in today's gallery from Sports Illustrated, "Athletes in Tears.")

My column today makes what I hope is a non-utopian argument for why social conservatives are right to welcome the recent evidence that American teens and twenty-somethings are waiting somewhat longer to have sex. And it pivots, in part, off this post from Dana Goldstein, in which she argues 1) that premarital sex has always been with us, 2) that even if people are sleeping together more casually than they did generations ago, it's just because they're marrying later, and 3) that anyway, there's no need for anyone to feel "anxious about 50-year macro social trends that have brought about unprecedented gender equality and personal fulfillment."

KABUL, Afghanistan - As some members of Congress and rebels fighting the forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi press the White House to intervene militarily in Libya, President Obama's top general and defense secretary joked Monday about the unlikelihood of American airstrikes on the country.

Senators John McCain and Mitch McConnell were out on the Sunday shows to push for more forceful American involvement in Libya. They were joined (with caveats) by an increasingly assertive Senator John Kerry, who insisted that a no-fly zone did not necessitate a military attack per se, contradicting Defense Secretary Gates's statement on March 2. The question of American policy on intervention in Libya has been murky; Hillary Clinton seemed a bit more hawkish than the president for a while, as did Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain. Obama has been getting real results on Libya at the United Nations - in the Security Council, at the General Assembly and even in Geneva at the Human Rights Council. But in American politics, successes at the U.N. are not to be spoken of. Americans may have lost their taste for unilateral actions, but they haven't gained one for multilateral actions either.Then how about some Special Forces sneaking about, as a sop to pride or at least an outlet for the national sense of adventure? Britain's experience last week suggests caution is in order. A report in The Guardian this morning says a fellow named only Tom, whom the paper believes to be a British intelligence agent, had been working at the Al-Khadra Farm Company - which raises wheat southwest of Benghazi, Libya - for five months, until last Thursday, when he drove off into the desert at 3 a.m. with another foreign national, later returning with "large bags" and six armed Special Air Service men. Guards at the farm arrested them. That must have had a wilting effect on the S.A.S. men's spirits. But farm personnel gave them a good hot breakfast and packed them off, and by Sunday the little band was safely away to Malta.

Perhaps on the assumption that everyone enjoys a mildly psychedelic experience from time to time, the Web editors at Rhizome - a nonprofit with ties to the New Museum that maintains an online archive of more than 2,500 new media art projects - posted a video by the artist Brenna Murphy last week called "yingyyangyhuman." Murphy calls it a "cosmic disc resonancy exercise." And maybe, aside from admitting that from time to time I really do enjoy this kind of mildly psychedelic experience, nothing else needs to be said.﻿

The trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the co-founder of the Galleon Group hedge fund, begins in Manhattan on Tuesday. As the unprecedented prosecution unfolds, DealBook takes a look at some of the potential legal strategies and what the case could mean for Wall Street.

Henry Taylor is rarely seen without a smile on his face. A visitor feels immediately comfortable in his presence - a good quality for a painter whose practice includes a plenty of portraiture. When I stopped by his studio in L.A.'s Chinatown recently, within five minutes, I was offered a beer, a cigarette - and my last name was being added in chalk to a new sculpture intended for his solo show at Blum & Poe. He's a professional charmer. Or as he puts it, "I don't want to not like something. I look for redeeming qualities and anything that resonates with me ... like humans ... I want to like them all. It's easier to get along that way when you try to embrace till you find any little thing you like about anything."

The LearnMeProject is for anyone who has ever contemplated the idea of educating his kids at home, or wondered about the relationship between rigor and learning, say, or laziness and creativity. It's about a lot of other things, too, sports and faith and music and marriage, written by a Brooklyn-based author and teacher and his terrifically smart and funny and frustrated-by-traditional-schooling son.

The Teva, that multistrapped mid-'80s fashion disaster beloved by Deadheads in dreads, is having a moment. Created to keep rubber flip-flops on board while white-water river rafting, the sandal, formerly just functional, has achieved some fashion notoriety. The designer Richard Chai says its carefree attitude and eclectic fans have inspired his quirky urban version, which pairs patent leather with canvas in unusual colors like ultramarine and moss green. Lanvin's take looks like Transformers, with straps crisscrossing every which way. And Tomas Maier at Bottega Veneta took his jewel-toned leather Tevas on a trip, sporting gray dress socks for a high-luxe touristy look. I wouldn't recommend giving those a dunk in the deep end.

Proving that it is possible for the star of a CBS comedy to take a break from his series without mortifying the network or his co-stars or burning all of his bridges in the entertainment industry, Jim Parsons, the "Big Bang Theory" star, will join the cast of the coming Broadway production of "The Normal Heart," the play's press representatives said Monday. Mr. Parsons, who in recent months has won an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe for his portrayal of the physicist Sheldon Cooper, will make his Broadway debut in "The Normal Heart," playing Tommy Boatwright, a Southerner in a nascent group of HIV/AIDS activists in the early 1980s. Also joining the cast is Lee Pace, a star of the late, lamented ABC series "Pushing Daisies," who will be making his Broadway debut in the role of Bruce Niles, a closeted fellow activist.

Despite her meticulous frosting efforts, she threw it against the window when she learned that Heather's unloading to the bishop was what led to all the legal heat now roasting the Henricksons to such an unsavory crisp.

Today, the auction house Phillips de Pury & Company is opening a shop at its 450 Park Avenue galleries. Designed by Markus Bergström and Joe Nunn of the London studio Glass Hill, the 600-square-foot space will feature a flexible, modular shelving system of black lacquered dowels and shelves. The shop builds on the success of two pop-up retail installations - Connectors and the Projectory - that Phillips opened last year in its (now closed) temporary quarters at the Saatchi Gallery in London. (Those installations were also designed by Glass Hill.)

Whether they're nebulae, star formations, supernovae or planetary landscapes, images from space fascinate the designer Christopher Kane. "They're breathtaking to look at," he says, plus "they translate well on fabric using digital printing. These haven't been tweaked." The space-print shirt Kane wears here is part of his new men's line. The basic pieces - T-shirts, tank tops, knits and hoodies - are adapted from the themes and fabrics of his main collection, though with an easier, sportier feel. Pretty much anyone can be a customer. "The oldest I know of is Ronnie Wood," he says. "And the youngest is probably my 7-year-old nephew."

With gasoline averaging $3.50 a gallon, as I wrote in Monday morning's paper, Washington is slipping back into one of its intermittent debates about whether it is time to raid the national piggy bank, the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. But the administration looks at the oil as not just as a rainy-day fund but as something that should be preserved for real emergencies.

I didn't know enough about Ancient Greece. I picked up a book published by Penguin that promised me, "the reader who is not a student or expert in classical literature," the chance to be swept along "from the days of Mycenae to the splendors of Athens." I would finally understand how Sophocles revolutionized dramatic history by introducing a third speaking actor. Never again would I mix up the "laughing philosopher" Democritus with democracy. Like any history book, the Penguin might help me comprehend our own history, in a vague way - they had slavery and freedom at the same time, too! But then I came to the plight of the vase painters, and I realized that I might as well be reading the Penguin Foretelling of the Fate of Newspapers in the Internet Age. Novelists, musicians, politicians and many others should also recognize themselves.

There's prolific, and then there's Takashi Miike. Since 1991, the Japanese director has made more than 80 feature films, plus some television, music videos and a kabuki drama. With that kind of work schedule, not all Miike films are going to be masterpieces. Not-so-good Miike films have zombies, sadomasochistic yakuza love stories, decapitated body parts turned into blood fire hoses, lengthy scenes of torture and musical numbers. Good Miike movies have those things, too, so it can be hard to tell which is which. For many fans, the difference is a matter of polish, but disagreements about whether more "polish" is desirable are frequent.

At the beginning of the 2000s, Rachel Millward and Pinny Gryllis were making low-budget short films in London, but had no peer network. In an effort to change this, they decided to buy out London's Curzon Soho Cinema on a November night in 2002 to debut one of their films. That same night, they asked for submissions of other short films made by emerging women filmmakers. They took five of the submitted films, created a program, and the annual Birds Eye View Film Festival was born.

Behind the numbers politicians use to wage budget battles is the clash of values. So as members of Congress begin hard bargaining with the Obama White House over spending cuts, the life experiences that shape their values represent critical determinants of the outcome. The Lens feature in some editions on Wednesday, about Pierre Lucien, a police officer on medical leave who lost both his legs, misspelled a condition from which Mr. Lucien suffered. It is rhabdomyolysis, a breakdown of muscle fibers -- not rhabdomyolosis.

NUSSBAUM--Moses, MD. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with profound sadness the passing of our dear friend, dedicated surgeon and respected colleague, Moses Nussbaum, MD. Moe's career at Beth Israel spanned an amazing 56 years. He held many important positions at the Medical Center, most notably Chairman of the Department of Surgery from 1993 to 2000. In addition, Moe was a longtime member of the Beth Israel Medical Board, and led and served on many of its committees and subcommittees. He also was honored throughout his career by grateful patients who supported Beth Israel philanthropically in appreciation of the care he provided. In recognition of his life's work, Beth Israel established in 1999 the Moses Nussbaum, MD, Memorial Lecture, which is given each year by a prominent speaker on an important topic in the field of surgery. Moe also was incredibly dedicated to the education and training of our medical students, interns and residents. To his beloved wife, Esther, his children, Judy, Gabriel and Tamara, the entire Nussbaum family and all who knew him and loved him, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees Harris M. Nagler, MD President Sheldon Simon, MD President, Medical Board Martin S. Karpeh, Jr., MD Chairman Dept. of Surgery Mark Persky, MD Chairman, Dept. of Otolaryngology-Head & Neck Surgery

SIMON--Sophie, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Manhasset Hills, NY. Beloved wife of the late Harold Simon. She is survived by her children, Douglas and Nancy Simon, Stuart and Marcia Simon, and Edward and Lori Simon; her grandchildren, Heather and Kim, Jonathan and Eli, and Ari and Daniel; and her great-grandson, Quinton. Sophie was a loving wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend. She was a successful business woman, excelling in the area of real estate management and development. Memorial service in Florida on Friday, March 11 at 1:30pm at Temple Torah of West Boynton Beach. Donations may be made to Hadassah.

Gregg Gillis, a musician who performs under the name Girl Talk, creates a unique style of music using a laptop computer to chop up and reuse mainstream pop songs. His work, which is heavily influenced by mathematics, manages to pair divergent genres of music, mixing Madonna and Black Sabbath. His work has also questioned copyright law and fair use with respect to digital music. The following is an edited version of an interview with Mr. Gillis. Nick Bilton: How did you start creating music using a computer?Gregg Gillis: I actually went to school for biomedical engineering. While I was in college I played around with music on the side, mostly just for fun. When I graduated I just kept making music, playing small shows and art galleries, and after two or three years things just took off with the style I had created.

CAPLAN--Korda. Our mother, just shy of her 93rd birthday got what she wanted..a quick, peaceful ending to a wonderful life filled with family, friends, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, whom she adored. Her exquisite sense of style, zest for life, love of fine foods, wine, Paris and Chanel kept us alert on current events and fashion. She combined joy with generosity to friends as well as the many charities she supported. All who knew her hope to age as she did. Predeceased by her parents Sarah and Morris Cohen of Winnipeg, Manitoba, her sister and brother, her two husbands Arthur Herskovits of New York and Leonard Caplan QC of London. Survived by her son Albert Herskovits of London, daughter and son-in-law Jean and Armand Lindenbaum of New York. Grandchildren Felice Lindenbaum, Amiel and Jessica Lindenbaum and Ariel and Albert Sebag. She was the greatest great-grandmother to Aaron, Jonah and Samuel Lindenbaum and Jordan, Jack and Noah Sebag. May her memory be for a blessing. For contributions kindly consider UJA-Federation 130 E. 59 St. New York, NY 10022.

Charlie Sheen, who jumped onto Twitter this week to earn some extra cash and now has more than 1.4 million followers, might want to take note: Yes, celebrities can make money from advertisers by endorsing products on Twitter. But celebrity rants on Twitter can cost them, too. As part of a legal settlement, the musician and actress Courtney Love agreed to begin paying $430,000 this week to a fashion designer who claimed that Ms. Love had posted multiple defamatory 140-character remarks about her on Twitter in March 2009, ruining her reputation and her business.

When Raj Rajaratnam was a hedge fund baron managing billions of dollars and being lionized as one of Wall Streets savviest investors, he was asked what made him so successful. ''It is pride, and I want to win,'' said Mr. Rajaratnam, the co-founder of the Galleon Group hedge fund, according to the 2001 book ''The New Investment Superstars,'' by Lois Peltz. ''I want to win every time. Taking calculated risks gets my adrenaline pumping.''

DAVIS--Alfred Herman "Al" Davis died on March 6, 2011 at the age of 88. Son of the late Celia and Harry Davis and brother of the late Sherry Harris, he was the beloved husband of the late Harriet Davis and the late Gail Glow Davis. He is survived by daughters Ellen Davis and Mona Davis, son-in-law Rafael Cuevas, and beloved granddaughter Eliza. He was a devoted stepfather to Sari Lada, Heidi Glow, Cathy and Howard Allen, and loving step grandfather to Rebecca, Danny, Brenna, Benjamin and Lauren. A U.S. Navy veteran of World War II and graduate of CCNY, he had a long career as a publicist, with clients including The Improv comedy club in New York. He also worked closely with many of the noted newspaper columnists of his time. A published author in his own right, he was a lover of music, literature, art and people. Loved by many, he will be dearly missed. Funeral services will be held at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Tuesday, March 8, 2011 at 11:30am.

The drugs that scored the highest in BrandIndex's perception ranking in the latest four-week period included allergy medications like Zyrtec, medications for heartburn like Zantac, and the world's top-selling drug, Lipitor, which treats high cholesterol. All are heavily marketed in direct-to-consumer campaigns. Some are already sold over-the-counter, like Zantac, and generics are available online for some prescription drugs, like Boniva, for osteoporosis. Two changes in 2011: over the counter sales of Allegra began on March 4, and the patent for Lipitor will expire. SHELLY FREIERMAN

HESS--Carl B.,Founder and Chairman Emeritus of AEA Investors, died peacefully at his home in New York City on February 15, 2011, age 98. He was born in Chicago, Illinois, October 28, 1912, and attended the University of Chicago Lab School. He went on to Dartmouth College, where his many college activities included serving as editor of Daily Dartmouth and as President of The Arts, The Round Table, and The Junto, and membership in Palaeopitus and Casque & Gauntlet. He graduated with honors in history in 1934. His business career led to his becoming a partner in Cresap McCormick & Paget, Management Consultants, and then vice president and director of American Securities Corp. In 1963, Mr. Hess conceived and created a new form of private investment firm which, in 1968, became American Euro pean Associates. Thus began his legendary career as a pioneer in private equity. Known since then as AEA Investors Inc., AEA, initially with financial support and endorsement of S.G. Warburg & Co. and shortly thereafter from senior members of the Rockefeller, Mellon, Harriman, Du Pont and other major families, was the first privately funded organization devoted solely to direct equity investment. From the outset and still today, its ownership and direction has been dominated by the chairmen and chief executive officers of many of America's leading corporations. The firm is now global in its reach with shareholder/participants of the same prominence and achievement in Europe, Asia, South and Central America, and the Middle East. As Chairman Emeritus, Mr. Hess remained active in the firm and was a regular presence in the AEA offices until shortly before his death. Ever loyal to Dartmouth College, he was a member of the Dean's Council and the President's Leadership Council. He was a member of The Rockefeller University Council and served on its Executive Committee. He was also on the Oversight Committee for Preservation of Objects at the Metropolitan Museum. He was predeceased by his beloved brother and friend, John D. Hess. He is survived by: his wife, Ludmila Schwarzenberg Hess; his son, Eric Hess and his daughter-in-law, June Hess; his daughter, Safiya Bonaventura; five grandchildren: Arden Hess Rowland and her husband Walter, and Aram, Joachim and his wife Kisha, Fleur and Claire Williams; one adored great-granddaughter, Wyatt Rowland; two nephews, Anthony and Oliver and his wife Leslie Hess; and two grand-nephews, John and Carl Hess. He is also survived by his first wife, Juliet Forbes. He was predeceased by his second wife, Desanka Pavlu, in 1990. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held on Monday, March 7, 2011 at 4pm at the University Club. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Academic Venture Fund at Dartmouth College or to the Academic Venture Fund at The Rockefeller University.

Some of the earliest and most raw reports of the revolution in Egypt were published on Twitter. Now an enterprising publisher, OR Books, has gathered many of those Twitter messages for a book, ''Tweets From Tahrir,'' a narrative of the revolution told in snippets of 140 characters or less. In a feat of nearly real-time publishing, the book will be released on April 21, a little over two months after the revolution unseated Egypt's president. It will be sold for $12 in paperback form and $10 in e-book form.

Rough Boy: Still rough after all these years. If many another male has been obliged to apprehend at least the basics of sensitive, modern sharing-and-caring guyness over these past several generations, Rough Boy isn't having it. Here he is yet to this day, all 22 marble tons of him, heroically stationed outside Queens Borough Hall with weapon in hand, quite unmistakably beating up on a couple of women who are cringing at his feet. And still to this day he remains sourly unloved by assorted indignants who deem him rude at the very least and want him gone. Now Representative Anthony D. Weiner has become the latest in a long parade of public scolds calling on the city to toss Rough Boy out. ''Ugly and offensive,'' declaims the art-critic congressman. ''It's time for him to go.'' For nearly 90 years now this has been going on. Rough Boy has never much enjoyed welcome-wagon hospitality, not since the day he was first unveiled in 1922. But perhaps he has found his home at last, now that the keepers of Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn -- recognizing that he is, of course, the last masterwork of the American sculptor Frederick MacMonnies -- are offering to salvage him from the pit and the abyss and give him shelter in their bosky glades.

LIBYA Troops loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi defeated rebels at Bin Jawwad, pushing them east and stalling what rebels had hoped would be a steady march to Tripoli. A standoff continued in Zawiyah. In Tripoli, government supporters celebrated after state television falsely reported that Colonel Qaddafi's forces had regained the entire country. EGYPT A new caretaker cabinet was appointed, eliminating most ministers with links to the former president. Soldiers and plainclothes police officers, armed with knives and rocks, dispersed protesters at the Interior Ministry who were angered by reports that incriminating documents were being destroyed.

The president of Nintendo told video game developers Wednesday that smartphones were driving a trend toward lower quality, and economically unsustainable, video games. ''I fear our business is dividing in a way that that threatens the continued employment of those of us who make games,'' Satoru Iwata, the Nintendo chief, said in a keynote address at the Game Developers Conference in San Francisco. ''Is maintaining high value games a top priority, or not?''

A reporting credit with an article on Thursday about the disputed dismissal of Muhammad Yunus, the Bangladeshi economist and Nobel laureate, from his position at the bank he founded misidentified the city from which Vikas Bajaj contributed. It was New Delhi -- not Mumbai, India.

1:40 a.m. | Updated LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the French luxury conglomerate, said Monday that it would take control of Italy's Bulgari in an all-share deal, adding another high-end brand to its formidable stable. Bulgari's eponymous controlling family has agreed to exchange its 51 percent stake in the jeweler for 16.5 million LVMH shares, making it the second-largest family shareholder in the group. The family will also gain two seats on LVMH's board, the company said.

The ability to buy products strategically placed on television programs - a handbag clutched by the actress Blake Lively on ''Gossip Girl'' or a suit worn by the actor Jon Hamm on ''Mad Men'' - with the click of a button has always been talked about as something that the future of marketing would deliver. But like flying cars or robot companions, it has never materialized. Glamour is taking a stab at the concept with an original reality series produced exclusively for the iPad that allows viewers to pause the program and buy clothing worn by the characters, directly from Gap.com.

The particular challenges of feeding 9 billion people without destroying the planet seem both overwhelming and endlessly complex. Trying to peek into the future, however thrilling and terrifying it might be, is usually a failure. But it's not, of course, unprecedented. (In fact, we've been here before, and in my adult-ish lifetime, too.) To that end I've been reading New York Times articles from the 1960's (I was a teenager then) about food crises, and the challenge of feeding 6 or 7 billion people in the year (gulp) 2000. (I'm only permitted to link to the abstracts of these archived articles, but I'll give you some highlights.)

The oldest and most common dig against organic agriculture is that it cannot feed the world's citizens; this, however, is a supposition, not a fact. And industrial agriculture isn't working perfectly, either: the global food price index is at a record high, and our agricultural system is wreaking havoc with the health not only of humans but of the earth. There are around a billion undernourished people; we can also thank the current system for the billion who are overweight or obese.
Some of the legendary British music icon’s guitars and amps, including some replicas, are being auctioned for charity.

The New York State Senate unanimously confirmed Joseph Martens on Tuesday as commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Conservation. He will face challenges like deep budget cuts and a brewing controversy over hydraulic fracturing, a form of natural gas drilling. As Leslie Kaufman noted in a blog post in January, Governor Cuomo won plaudits for his choice.

For the fourth time in 12 years, the Federal Trade Commission plans to study the effectiveness of the voluntary guidelines followed by most marketers of alcoholic beverages. The guidelines are intended primarily to reduce the exposure of advertising to those under the legal drinking age.

European airlines will spend nearly $2 billion on carbon dioxide emissions permits next year as European Union rules on emissions take effect, financial analysts estimate. Under the rules, the number of free carbon permits allocated to airlines will shrink considerably beginning in 2012. By 2020, the cost of permits to the industry could climb to almost $10 billion annually. [Guardian]

Via FT Alphaville, an interesting indicator of what's going on in the world: the oil-copper spread. Copper is basically about the prospects for world economic growth: strong growth means lots of copper demand. Oil is partly about growth, but also about chaos in the Middle East.

Kelly, happened to be serving as grand marshal, ended up being given an exemption from the new rules (the Police Department said the parade had not been given enough advance notice).

Prosecutors have called it the biggest insider-trading case in United States history. On Wednesday, a jury in federal district court in Manhattan found Raj Rajaratnam guilty of 14 counts of securities fraud and conspiracy. He had been accused of making $63 million trading on illegal information scoured from a network of sources that spanned Wall Street and corporate America. The trial highlighted an array of aggressive tactics the Justice Department used in its long-running investigation into insider trading, including confidential informants, wiretapped phone conversations and top executives as witnesses.

No, I did not have surgery today. The surgeon's verdict is that the ankle is still far too swollen, so I get to spend another week with it elevated and icing. Which means I have plenty of time (between drug- induced naps, I guess) to blog.

In pursuit of imperfection, Yohji Yamamoto changed the course of fashion. Now, 30 years after his first show in Paris, which was greeted by astonishment, pro and con, the avant-garde designer is having his 30th museum exhibition, his first in London. The catalog that accompanies the show opening Saturday at the Victoria and Albert Museum (on view through July 10) reflects not just the heart-stopping beauty of the clothes, as photographed by Yamomoto's longtime collaborators Nick Knight, Max Vadukul and Paolo Roversi, but also, in his own words, the designer's enigmatic stance. So we learn, almost poignantly, that from the beginning: "I wanted to protect the clothing itself from fashion, and at the same time the woman's body from something, maybe from men's eyes or a cold wind."

His deep pockets of oil revenue, combined with his ambitions to be a regional power broker, spiced with his on-and-off role as supporter of nationalist movements elsewhere, has made him a prominent and persistent figure in an often shadowy game.

It was a crude, new beast of animated television in its discourse and its social commentary. Shows like "South Park" have since raised/lowered the bar considerably, but "Beavis and Butt-Head" was the Elvis's pelvis of its day.

Overview | What can we learn about life and culture in the ancient city of Pompeii by examining preserved artifacts and structures? What new strategies are being employed by museum curators to help people not just find information about the past, but virtually experience it too? In this lesson, students research and develop their own 21st-century exhibits on the  eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 A.D. and the resulting destruction of the city of Pompeii, in what is now Italy. They then compare their installation with a new exhibition on Pompeii by reading an article about it.

The withdrawal of Angela Gheorghiu from next season's Metropolitan Opera production of "Faust" by Gounod continued to cause ripples on Tuesday. The Met announced the cancellation on Monday, with Ms. Gheorghiu's management blaming her dislike of the production's updated 20th-century setting. But the director, Des McAnuff, said on Tuesday that when he met with Ms. Gheorghiu in November to discuss the production she voiced no objections. "We had a meeting where ideas were shared with enthusiasm," he said in a statement.

The last winter test session for the Formula One teams began Tuesday in Barcelona and Mark Webber set the fastest time in his Red Bull. Jenson Button was second fastest in the McLaren Mercedes, but he said that the Red Bulls and the Ferraris are faster than his car.

I knew something was up in Egypt last fall, long before the first protesters entered Tahrir Square. That was when I first saw a series of Egyptian TV commercials for the Panda brand of food products. The first one felt like pure allegory: Dad and son in Egyptian supermarket. Dad tells son to put a package of Panda-brand cheese back on the shelf. Cut to the panda, now in the same aisle, who is very, very angry. Panda tips over shopping cart. Was the panda Mubarak? Or did the panda represent the aspirations of the Egyptian people for a normal, consumer society?

Nancey Murphy of Fuller Theological Seminary has an interesting and challenging essay in a recent book called "Neuroethics." She argues that the dominant conception of a soul, a spiritual essence separable from the body, is the result of a mistranslation. The Hebrew word "nephesh," which was translated into "soul," was actually just a way of referring to the whole living person, body and mind together. That's closer, I guess, to what we would call "the self."

As much as N.B.A. fans and analysts have made an effort to appreciate individual and team defense, nothing on that side of the ball quite measures up to the sex appeal of scoring. The game itself is structured around made field goals, and basketball observers largely fall into the trap of glamorizing that straightforward act of goal attainment while diminishing the appeal of lock-down defense.

In my new book, "You Are What You Speak," I devote an early chapter to the notion that "our language is in decline."  Perhaps most famously in recent years, Lynne Truss wrote a little book about punctuation, "Eats, Shoots & Leaves," which sold in the millions (to Ms. Truss's own surprise) and made her a household name (at least in language-nerd circles).  What sold so many books, I imagine, was Truss's tone, never less than urgent and sometimes downright furious: nobody knows how to punctuate anymore, and if we don't stop the rot we're doomed!
