The Long Wharf Theater of New Haven has lost its fourth managing director in less than a decade with the departure of Ray Cullom, whose resignation was accepted by its board, the theater said on Tuesday. Mr. Cullom came to the Long Wharf Theater, whose recent critically acclaimed productions include a revival of "The Glass Menagerie" starring Judith Ivey (which transferred Off Broadway to the Laura Pels Theater) and the American premiere of Simon Gray's "Old Masters," in May 2009 under what was supposed to be a five-year contract. But in a news release the theater said that Mr. Cullom was "leaving to pursue a professional opportunity in the producing and presenting theatrical world," and that the board would soon announce a transitional management plan. Mary Pepe, chairwoman of the board, said in a statement that the theater was "very grateful to Ray for his leadership of Long Wharf during a period of unprecedented economic challenge." Mr. Collum said in a statement that the theater "is an incredible place."

Libya's opposition seems to have surfaced online. NTCLibya.org was registered as a domain on March 6 for the Libyan Interim Transitional National Council. Among the tabs across the top of the site's English-language home page are some you rarely see: Allegiances, Map of Revolution. A WhoIs search turned up Identity Protect as the administrator. This is a British company that manages domains while concealing the identity of the actual owner.

"Getting extra height is something women want, right?" the designer Chris Benz asks slyly about his spring platforms. It's a fresh spin on the standard wedge and what we expect cool girls to be wearing.

Try to phone the British-born bootmaker Julian Imrie and you'll probably get his voice mail, which begins: ''I'm in the jungle right now.'' Actually, on a recent weekday, Imrie, 39, was aboard a sailboat anchored somewhere in the French West Indies, when he was prompted, via e-mail, to recount his life thus far - a life that has been so peripatetic, romantic and unlikely that it's almost obnoxious. Imrie quit college to assist Bruce Weber, went on to work on a horse farm in Montauk, N.Y., then movedto Amish country, where he salvaged crumbling barns. He spent a year studying the New Testament (in Greek). Then he biked from Los Angeles, his current home base, to Brazil. At one point, he decided to start Julian Boots, his stylish take on 19th-century footwear (from about $700, at Barneys New York), but first he learned how to make molds in the English Midlands and to tan leather in a 250-year-old Swiss factory. Now he's an amateur boot historian, able to slip easily into a disquisition on what a 19th-century Cornish miner might wear. What his boots share with their fuss-free forebears, Imrie says, is that ''you can use them in your garden and then rub them off and go to a wedding.''

It really is worth repeating: no matter how much the right-wingers may like to claim that the US government is "broke", it's not, in any normal sense of the term. Investors, putting real money on the line, are willing to lend funds to the Feds long-term at an inflation-adjusted interest rate of only 1 percent. There is nothing in the markets or the cash flow requiring immediate austerity.

Starting at 10 a.m., a subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee will hear testimony about climate change from some of the nation's most prominent climatologists and from two scientists who have raised questions about whether the data supports broad conclusions about rising temperatures and other changes. The hearing is part of the House's consideration of a bill sponsored by two Republicans that would limit the Environmental Protection Agency's authority to impose regulations on greenhouse gases; it could come to a committee vote as early as the end of this week. In a recent post about the sometimes contentious issue of protecting seniors who are losing the ability to manage their finances, I wrote about a daughter who was able to intervene in her mother's financial exploitation because she was a co-signer on her bank accounts. That's typically a first step taken when, or before, family members suspect problems. ''The joint bank account is everybody's default estate-planning tool, because it's widely known and commonly used,'' Charles Sabatino, a lawyer who is director of the American Bar Association's Commission on Law and Aging, told me in an interview. ''But it's less than ideal.''

IGOE--Ruth Gelfer, of White Plains, on March 5th at the age of 79. Born August 18, 1931 in New York City to Louis and Ethel Ditchik. Survived by her children; Janet (Edward) Gorman of White Plains, Lynne (Jon) Rose of White Plains, Susan (Lawrence) Ginsberg of Barrington, RI and Diane (Joseph) Suppa of Port Chester, NY. Stepmother to Kathy Krier, Cyndi Koppany, Nancy Weats, John Igoe and Jeff Igoe. Also survived by her sister Grace Oshin of White Plains and seven grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. She is predeceased by her husbands Monroe Gelfer and John Igoe and her brother Philip Ditchik. She touched the lives of all who knew her. In lieu of flowers, make donations to the charity of your choice. The family will be sitting Shiva at 8 Susan Court White Plains, NY 10605 Tuesday and Wednesday from 1-4 and 7-9pm.

HOLZER--Philip, 92, passed away peacefully on March 7, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Ann. Adored and cherished family patriarch, survived by sons Marc (Madeleine) and Stuart (Rhoda); grandchildren Matthew (Wendy), Benjamin, Brooke (Chris), Craig and Leah (Ethan); great-grandchildren Alison, Natalie, Brooklyn and Charles. His wisdom and quiet generosity significantly enhanced the lives of five generations. Born on the Lower East Side, at age 19 he graduated from City College in 1938. Prior to enlisting in the Navy during WWII, he devised a novel ration coupon system for the wartime Office of Price Administration (OPA), conserving significant amounts of fuel and work hours for the war effort by mailing ration books directly to homes, thereby avoiding long lines. Time Magazine described him as "the little man who broke through bureaucracy, red tape, you-can't-do-that rules, and forced OPA to mail ration book No. 3 to U.S. householders." For four decades he was an avid and insightful collector of 18th Century American antiques, and was widely recognized as one of the premier collectors in that field. The printing company that he founded in 1955, and which provided employment to hundreds over more than fifty years, continues to thrive. Contributions in his honor may be made to the City College Fund at the City College of New York.
HETHRINGTON--Nelson, 76. Our deepest sympathy to his wife Harriet, his two step-daughters Jodi and Deborah (Ralph) and grandchildren. We will miss him. Arlene and Bob Hall

CONYERS--Eileen C.,on March 7, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Horace J. Devoted mother of Dennis, Diane, Steven, David, Gregory and Liza. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Brooklyn Botanic Garden for preservation of the local Flora Garden in her memory appreciated.

Prosecutors have called it the biggest insider-trading case in United States history. On Tuesday, Raj Rajaratnam goes on trial in the federal district court inManhattan, accused of making $45 million trading on illegal information scoured from a network of sources that spanned Wall Street and corporate America. Mr.Rajaratnam is fighting the charges, 14 counts of securities fraud and conspiracy. The trial, expected to last six to eight weeks, will highlight an array of aggressivetactics the Justice Department has used in its long-running investigation into insider trading, including confidential informants, wiretapped phone conversationsand possibly top executives as witnesses. -- AZAM AHMED and GUILBERT GATES

MARGOLIS--Kate L. Born September 9, 1960. Survived by devoted husband, Jay Friedman, loving father, Karl Margolis, step-daughters and best friends Alyssa and Rachael Friedman, siblings Laurie, Seth, Jane and Dan, aunt Ruth Gladstone, many close nieces, nephews, cousins, in-laws and friends. Donations in Kate's memory to Gilda's Club New York City. Rest in peace, our angel.

WINOGRAD--Betty, suddenly on March 5, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Col. Alfred A. Winograd, USAF (retired). Devoted mother of Gloria and Steven. Adoring grandmother of David. Dear mother-in-law of Josette. Loving aunt of Barry, Marcy, Lloyd, Ann and Susan. Also survived by many family members and friends. As a lifelong New Yorker, Betty enjoyed a successful career as an owner of the Gourmet Liquor Shop with her husband, Alfred Winograd. She was loved and admired by her friends and family for her outgoing personality, sense of humor and vibrant energy. Until the very end, Betty was an active bridge player and museum lover. At 87, she enjoyed her independence, kept an active social life and still found reasons to marvel at New York City. Betty was a treasure who will be dearly missed and remembered by the many people whose lives she graced. Rabbinical service to be held Wednesday 11am at John Krtil Funeral Home, Inc., 1297 1st Avenue (70th Street), New York City. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY.

An article in some editions on Saturday about a decision by a special grand jury not to bring charges against police officers in a Harlem shooting that resulted in a man's death quoted incorrectly from comments by Peter Neufeld, the lawyer for the deceased. He said of the verdict, ''We're terribly disappointed that once again, a non-transparent'' -- not ''transparent'' -- ''police friendly prosecutor and grand jury investigation resulted in no charges of officers who engaged in excessive conduct given the number of shots that were fired.''

SCHEIN--Richard. The friends and neighbors of Richard Schein, a long time resident of 3 East 71st, send their sincere condolences to his wife Carol, and their children. Mr. Schein, 84, passed away Sunday, February 27, 2011. He will be missed by all.

8:51 p.m. | Updated Throughout his recent rants about CBS, Warner Brothers and his own drug use, Charlie Sheen insisted that he was ready to return to work on the hit sitcom ''Two and a Half Men.'' On Monday, Warner Brothers disagreed, firing Mr. Sheen from the show, claiming the actor's ''statements, conduct and condition prevented him from performing his essential duties.''

An article on Feb. 28 about the Academy Awards ceremony, at which the co-host James Franco appeared in drag as Marilyn Monroe, misidentified, in some editions, the movie in which she wore a similar dress. It was ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,'' not ''Some Like It Hot.''

A City Room article on Monday about renewed criticism of the ''Rough Boy'' statue at Queens Borough Hall included descriptions of the historical background very similar to material the same author had published in The Daily News in 2000. And a Feb. 18 City Room article by that writer, about the naming of the George Washington Bridge, also included passages similar to an account he wrote for The Daily News in 2000. Had Times editors known of the earlier articles, those passages would not have been used.

Legislators often see their e-mail addresses publicized by various groups asking New Yorkers to write them in support of their causes. Dealing with the correspondence that ensues is simply part of the job. But most of the time, the people soliciting support do not have tens of millions of Facebook fans and Twitter followers who can be mobilized with the posting of a single message - and, say, a portrait featuring a leopard-print thong.

GREENSPAN--Ethel DeHaan, passed away March 3, 2011 in Manchester, NH. She was born September 21, 1914 in Manhattan to Eva and Roland DeHaan, married Saul Greenspan in 1939, and moved to Manchester. She was predeceased by her husband in December of 2006. Mrs. Greenspan is survived by her daughters, Jill Schiffman of Hanover, NH and Barbara Jacobson of Menlo Park, CA, and their families. A memorial service will be held in Manchester at a later date.

PEDONE--Arlene Ruth. The AHRC New York City Board of Directors, senior staff and membership mourn the untimely passing of Arlene Pedone, President of the AHRC New York City Board of Directors, and extend sympathy to her beloved and bereaved family. Over the last 35 years, Mrs. Pedone devoted her time, spirit and energy to not-for-profit organizations specializing in the areas of education, drug treatment, healthcare and the well being of people with developmental disabilities. She was a force to be reckoned with -- a powerful voice for those who could not speak for themselves. Her leadership and willingness to stand up passionately for what she believed will be greatly missed by her "AHRC family." Her contributions to our organization will be remembered for many years. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband of more than fifty years, Paul Pedone, her daughters Michelle, Stacey and Allison, her sons-in-law Rocky and John and her granddaughter Elizabeth. She was so proud of the work you all do on the many projects of your choosing in the effort to make the neighborhood, city, state and country a better place for everyone. Melvin Gertner, 1st Vice-President; Michael Goldfarb, Executive Director

Documentaries on Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova, the Academy Award-winning musicians from the hit indie feature ''Once'' and the band the Swell Season, and Genesis P-Orridge, the gender-bending performance artist of the groups Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV, are among the 44 feature-length films announced for the Tribeca Film Festival on Monday. This year, the Tribeca organizers said, the festival's Viewpoints program will include ''The Swell Season,'' a documentary by Nick August-Perna, Chris Dapkins, and Carlo Mirabella-Davis, chronicling Mr. Hansard and Ms. Irglova during the dissolution of their romantic relationship while on a two-year world tour. The lineup for that film program also features ''The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye,'' directed by Marie Losier, which documents the love story between Genesis P-Orridge and Lady Jaye Breyer, whose physical features Genesis P-Orridge duplicated through cross-dressing and plastic surgery.

GREEN--Pear. Passed away on March 7, 2011. Beloved wife of Leon, mother of Gloria and Charles. Mother-in-law to Jeffrey and Ellen. Devoted grandmother to Paul (Jeanne), Cheryl and Andrew. Great-grandmother of Lane and Jackson. We love you; Rest in peace!

MARINO--Michael. Mike's legions of friends mourn his untimely passing. A cherished friend and confidant, Mike was hilarious, generous, wise, loyal, loving, and an indispensable part of our lives. Words cannot do justice to his memory or convey what his loss will mean to us. Wake: Thursday, March 10, 7pm to 9pm, Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue at 70th St., Manhattan. Funeral Mass: Friday, March 11, 10am, Holy Family Church, 47th Street between 1st and 2nd Avenues, Manhattan. Robin Germany, Nora Donoher, Howie Cherpakov, Howard and Judy Saffan

American Ballet Theater is no stranger to ''The Firebird'': the troupe already has in its repertory several versions of the ballet set to Stravinsky's 1910 score. But none of those were by its artist in residence, Alexei Ratmansky. That oversight is about to be rectified: Ballet Theater announced Monday that Mr. Ratmansky would be creating a new version, with scenery by Simon Pastukh and costumes by Galina Solovyeva, to have its premiere next March during the company's Costa Mesa, Calif., engagement. New Yorkers will get to see the production during the spring 2012 season at the Metropolitan Opera House. For those keeping score at home, this will be Ballet Theater's fourth production of ''The Firebird'' and the choreographer's second -- he created a version for the Royal Swedish Ballet in 2002. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about an evangelical Christian campus group, Greek InterVarsity, that is trying to expand Bible studies and Christian recruiting in fraternities and sororities at mainstream universities misidentified the city in Indiana that is home to DePauw University. It is Greencastle, not Greenville.

LIBYA Government warplanes repeatedly bombed rebel positions near an oil refinery in the coastal city of Ras Lanuf, seeking to drive them back farther to the east, as the country's apparent slide into civil war continued. TUNISIA The interim government disbanded the State Security Department, which had been accused of human rights abuses under the ousted president, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, The Associated Press reported. The prime minister also named a new cabinet, retaining ministers in significant agencies like defense, interior and justice, and selecting new leaders for six other ministries.

Grandfather of Christopher, Michael, Charlotte and Katherine. Great-grandfather of Sydney and Olivia. Service at the Funeral Home of Dodge-Thomas Glen Cove, Saturday, March 12 at 1pm. ww.DodgeThomas.com

RUSSELL--Marie Hamilton, beloved sister of Aimee Russell Corsini, the Rev. William Hamilton Russell, the late Joan Russell Low, cherished aunt of Desideria Corsini, Immacolata Corsini Bland, Alessandro Corsini, Marchese di Laiatico and the late Allegra Corsini Poccianti. After an enlightened European childhood and later graduation from Yale University, Mariette passionately shared and promoted her love of art, architecture and literature as well as her affiliation with the Vedanta. As forward-thinking as she was she was still devoted to carrying on traditions, she will be remembered for her generosity. She touched all those she met with her kindness, thoughtfulness, inner peace, her love of beauty and nature. Included in their love are besides Malcom Low, Gerald Bland and Guido Poccianti, Titi's Bland, Poccianti, Low, Russell and Corsini nephews and nieces.

It was at an organic produce farm in Amado, Ariz., called Agua Linda; it was not held at the synagogue, Congregation Chaverim, to which Ms. Giffords belongs.

A federal judge late Monday rejected a request for him to immediately order Exxon Mobil to pay more than $100 million to help Prince William Sound recover from the oil spill caused by the 1989 wreck of the Exxon Valdez. A marine biologist said the government, which first demanded the money in 2006, had failed to follow up its claim. The government said it was still studying how to proceed. Judge H. Russel Holland asked for a status report by Sept. 15.

As the Green Day song in Broadway's ''American Idiot'' goes, ''give me novacaine'' - please. In its first week of performances without the band's frontman, Billie Joe Armstrong, as the special guest star in the cast, ''American Idiot'' saw a painful drop in its box office grosses, falling from $1.3 million to $395,275 for its standard eight performances through Sunday. While many musicals and plays also sold fewer tickets in what is typically a poor-selling week on Broadway's calendar, ''American Idiot'' declined the most and ran to only half-full houses. That sort of steep fall-off, with no obvious turnaround strategy in sight, usually leads a Broadway show to post a closing notice. Asked on Monday if one was coming for ''American Idiot,'' a spokesman for the show declined to comment. The lead producers were not immediately available for comment.

LEVY--George Harold, 86 of Great Neck, NY. Passed away Sunday, March 6, 2011. Loving husband of Joan (nee Liebowitz). Wonderful father of Richard (predeceased), David (Jennie), and Robin (Richard). Funny and adored grandfather of Alex and Eliana. Predeceased by his brother Bob. Survived by his brother Mike. A lover of opera, music, movies, and most of all singing. He was handsome, he was wise, and he sang well too. Contributions can be made to the Great Neck Senior Center, 80 Grace Avenue, Great Neck, NY 11021. Funeral Services Tuesday, March 8 at 9:30am at Nassau North Chapel in Great Neck.

SILVER--Dr. Arnold, 89, of Tenafly, NJ, beloved husband of the late Leah Silver, died on March 6, 2011. He is survived by his children, Robert, Steven and Deborah; and his seven grandchildren. Born March 17, 1921, in New York City, he graduated from Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood, NJ and Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster, PA. He joined the Army In 1944 and rose to 1st Lieutenant. He married Leah Victor, his high school sweetheart, before serving in Europe in WWII, where he earned a Bronze Star and Purple Heart. Upon returning, Arnold worked as a textile chemist. He realized his ambition to be a doctor when he entered the University of Louisville School of Medicine in 1961. He graduated with honors and, starting in 1971, practiced medicine in Fort Lee, NJ. He also was Associate Director of Medical Education at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, NJ where he was a beloved educator. Arnold had a magnetic personality, an insatiable curiosity, and a sharp wit. He loved reading, theater, good deli, beachside vacations, and entertaining on his deck. Most of all, he adored his wife Leah, his partner of more than 70 years. Funeral Services are at 11:30am, Tuesday, March 8, at Robert Schoem Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ.

MORALES--Jose ("Pepe"), Jr. Born August 12, 1928, died at home surrounded by his family on March 5, 2011. He was the beloved husband of Josie, father of Susana, Jose, and Daniel, Abuelo of Danilo and Mateo, adoptive Dad to Lourdes and Dad-in-law, cousin, uncle, padrino. Born in New York City to Rita and Pepe, brother to Jorge, he attended Stuyvesant and City College and served in the US Army. He was a community organizer and health administrator devoted to social justice, civil rights, public health, and the advancement of the Puerto Rican/Latino community. He directed various community and health organizations, was an HEW official and a VP at St. Barnabas Hospital. His Board memberships included the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, El Museo del Barrio, Community Service Society, Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor, Promesa, Latino Commission on AIDS, and Boricua College. He was a Freethinker, arts and gardening aficionado, beer connoisseur, mobile-maker, avid tennis player and eight-time New York City marathon runner. He traveled with Josie around the world, loved adventure, Wellfleet and Puerto Rico. He was a man of integrity, a force of nature who loved life, his family and friends. Viewing March 8-March 9 at Williams Funeral Home, 718-548-1100. In lieu of flowers, donations to Latino Commission on AIDS (www.latinoaids.org); and Marble Hill Senior Center, 5365 Broadway, Bronx 10463.

Lincoln Center on Monday announced the third pillar of what is shaping up to be an especially high-profile festival this summer: the Mariinsky Ballet. The company will give eight performances at the Metropolitan Opera House in July, joining the Cleveland Orchestra and the Royal Shakespeare Company as major presences at the Lincoln Center Festival. The Mariinsky will present two works receiving their first United States performances, ''Anna Karenina'' and ''The Little Humpbacked Horse,'' full-length ballets choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky and set to the music of the contemporary Russian composer Rodion Shchedrin. A third program includes Alberto Alonso's ''Carmen Suite,'' choreographed to Bizet's music as arranged by Mr. Shchedrin, and ''Symphony in C,'' the George Balanchine work. Valery Gergiev, Mariinsky's artistic director, will conduct. The participation of the Cleveland Orchestra and Royal Shakespeare Company was previously announced. Lincoln Center on Monday said other festival offerings would come from the Royal Danish Opera; Peter Brook, directing a fully staged adaptation of ''A Magic Flute,'' his version of the Mozartopera; and the Druid Theater Company performing ''The Silver Tassie'' by Sean O'Casey.

An article on Monday about the effect of patent expirations on profits at pharmaceutical companies misstated the status of clinical trials involving a blood thinner that was Merck's top acquisition from its merger with Schering Plough. One of two major trials of the drug was stopped -- not all testing -- because some patients experienced dangerous bleeding. (The second trial is continuing, though some patients have been removed from the study.)

LEVINE--Abe, DDS.,87, Aventura, FL. Beloved husband of Sylvia for 65 years. Loving father of David, Sharon and Harris. Doting grandfather of Heather, Lara and Ron, Natasha, Courtney, Jennie and Jamie, Matthew and Rachel. Adoring great-grandfather of Raphael, Gus, and Theo. He will be missed by every life he touched.

The director David Cromer (Off Broadway's acclaimed ''Our Town'') will reunite with the Tony Award nominee Jessica Hecht as Blanche DuBois for a scaled-down version of ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' as part of this summer's lineup on the Nikos Stage at the Williamstown Theater Festival, the festival's artistic director, Jenny Gersten, announced on Monday. The season includes several prominent New York actors and directors, in part a reflection of Ms. Gersten's years working at the Public Theater and the Naked Angels theater troupe before taking over the festival last fall. -This ''Streetcar'' will build upon Mr. Cromer's widely praised mounting of the Tennessee Williams play last year at the Writers' Theater in Glencoe, Ill., with the same designers but new cast members. Sam Rockwell (''Confessions of a Dangerous Mind,'' Broadway's production of ''A Behanding in Spokane'') will play Stanley Kowalski; other casting will be announced later. ''Streetcar'' is set to run June 22-July 3.

A music review on Monday about a concert of two works by the composer Annie Gosfield, at the Kitchen, misstated the given name of the guitarist in ''Daughters of the Industrial Revolution'' in some editions. He is Roger Kleier, not Jeff.

Proving that it is possible for the star of a CBS comedy to take a break from his series without mortifying the network or his co-stars or burning all of his bridges in the entertainment industry, Jim Parsons, the ''Big Bang Theory'' star, will join the cast of the coming Broadway production of ''The Normal Heart,'' the play's press representatives said Monday. Mr. Parsons, who in recent months has won an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe for his portrayal of the physicist Sheldon Cooper, will make his Broadway debut in ''The Normal Heart,'' playing Tommy Boatwright, a Southerner in a nascent group of HIV/AIDS activists in the early 1980s. Also joining the cast is Lee Pace, a star of the late, lamented ABC series ''Pushing Daisies,'' who will be making his Broadway debut in the role of Bruce Niles, a closeted fellow activist. This latest production of ''The Normal Heart,'' Larry Kramer's semi-autobiographical work about AIDS, friendship and love in 1980s-era New York, will be directed by Joel Grey (with some help from George C. Wolfe), and is to begin previews at the Golden Theater on April 19 with an opening night planned for April 27. Previously announced cast members include Joe Mantello as the protagonist, Ned Weeks; Ellen Barkin as Dr. Emma Brookner; and John Benjamin Hickey as Weeks's lover, Felix Turner.

The fact pattern looks bad, very bad. Seconds after Rajat K. Gupta, then a director of Goldman Sachs, finished up a board call during which he learned that Warren E. Buffett had agreed to invest $5 billion in the firm, he picked up the phone and called his friend Raj Rajaratnam, regulators contend. Minutes later, Mr. Rajaratnam placed bets on shares of Goldman Sachs that netted his firm, the Galleon Group, $900,000.

Western Digital announced on Monday that it would buy Hitachi Global Storage Technologies for $4.3 billion, in a deal that will further expand the company's reach in data storage. The acquisition, which has been approved by the boards of both companies, is expected to be completed during the third quarter, and is expected to immediately increase earnings per share, excluding certain deal-related costs.

JONES--Foxhall Parker, 85, of Salisbury, CT.,died February 27th. Beloved husband of his wife of 36 years, Kitty C. Benedict, cherished father of L. Parker Jones and her husband James Baker, children Howland Jones, Molly Jones, Brian Jones and Dylan Jones, and adored grandfather of Lily Baker and Sam Foxhall Jones. "Foxy" served in the USMC during the campaigns on Guam and Iwo Jima, wounded twice. A graduate of The University of Virginia, he was legendary as a publisher's representative in New England for Harper Publishers for 35 years (always with his golf clubs ready to hit the links - and he was good)! The light of his wit, his tender love, his noble heart, will live in our hearts. He must be among the angels, for he was an angelic man.

The Bulgari family's long quest to figure out the future of its 127-year-old jewelry and watch business ended last Thursday at a dinner overlooking the Roman skyline. The leaders of the Bulgari clan - Paolo and Nicola Bulgari and their nephew Francesco Trapani - sat down with Bernard Arnault, the chairman and chief executive of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, who had desired their company for years. The meeting was so important that Mr. Arnault, whose aggressive deal streak had stocked LVMH with 60 of the world's most exclusive brands, even skipped part of Paris Fashion Week to attend.

The coming hearings on Islamic radicalization, to be presided over by Representative Peter T. King, the Republican from Long Island who is chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee, have already prompted much protest. The committee should instead "examine all forms of violence motivated by extremist belief."

The New York-based band Caveman recently took the home front by storm with a rolling set, thick with animalistic drums and swooning guitar riffs, at the Bowery Ballroom. The instrument-laden group of boys looked as though they had walked in off the street, picked up their instruments and casually strummed out nearly an hour of seamless musical beauty. From first glance, Lauren Remington Platt appears to have it all. Statuesque, poised and intelligent, the 26-year-old looks more Westport, Conn., than West Village. Graduating from Columbia University in 2006, Platt became a research analyst at a hedge fund. Swapping out her Chanel jackets for chaos theory, long hours at the office left Platt only minutes and a mascara wand before hitting the benefit circuit post-work. This prompted the platinum-haired beauty to start Vênsette.com, a members-only Web site that allows its users to select from pre-styled hair and makeup options, starting at $250 for in-home visits by professional hair and makeup artists. Makeup options range from a natural, sun-kissed look to red-lipped Grace Kelly regalness, while hair styles run the gamut from a slicked-back ponytail (The Tribeca) to a classic, iron-straight middle part à la Gwyneth Paltrow at the Oscars. With an international gaggle of good-looking clients that include the model Anouk Lepere and Monaco royal Charlotte Casiraghi, who better than Platt to tell you how to put your best face forward.

For the millions of blind people living in the United States, paying for something in cash can pose major challenges because there is no difference between the size and shape of a $1 or $100 bill. To tackle this problem, many blind people set up systems to identify a bill's value by folding the notes into different sizes and shapes, which then make them easily identifiable later.

The start of Lent today will offer many of us yet another opportunity to renew that resolution we made at the start of the year (and abandoned by the time February rolled in), to lose the extra poundage. But before you vow to give up your glasses of Cabernet and your plates of pasta primavera, you might want to consider H.A.E.S., or Health at Every Size, a new "peace movement" that one of its proponents, Linda Bacon, a nutritionist in the Department of Nutrition at the University of California, Davis, says was designed to halt "the collateral damage" - food and body preoccupation, self-hatred and eating disorders - that has resulted from the failed war on obesity. H.A.E.S. is based on the idea that "the best way to improve health is to honor your body," and it supports the adoption of good health habits simply for the sake of health and well-being rather than weight control.Bacon and Lucy Aphramor, a National Health Service specialist dietitian and an honorary research fellow at the Applied Research Center in Health and Lifestyle Interventions at Coventry University in England, published a paper in Nutrition Journal earlier this year. It argues that a weight-focused approach geared toward losing weight is - surprise! - not especially effective in either reducing the weight or creating healthier bodies. In fact, they say, such an approach can unintentionally lead to weight gain and worse health.

"Maira Kalman: Various Illuminations (of a Crazy World)," which opens Friday at the Jewish Museum, will be catnip to fans of the artist, whose books, New Yorker covers and illustrated online columns for The New York Times are beloved for their humor, whimsy and insight, and rendered with an irresistible eye for color and composition. The exhibition, which was curated by Ingrid Schaffner for the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia, features 100 of Kalman's paintings, drawings and sketches, along with photographs, embroidery and other works, including her fabric and digital wall covering for Maharam. The paintings take up two of the show's three galleries; the third is filled with objects that regularly find their way from Kalman's life to her art, like a jar of buttons, a Slinky or the pink-wrapped gift package from India that she deemed too beautiful ever to be opened. (Kalman's painting of that package can be seen in the first gallery.) An early version of the unforgettable "New Yorkistan" cover that she and Rick Meyerowitz did for The New Yorker is particularly fascinating, but then so is a broom that hangs - from a hardware-store clip - on the bright red wall that introduces the show. Next to it, Kalman wrote that when the broom was missing, viewers could find her sweeping the sidewalk on the park side of Fifth Avenue, a task she performs regularly as a volunteer for the Central Park Conservancy. Her accumulations of stuff, including chairs and ladders made by her children, Alex and Lulu, look oddly at home in the galleries, with their high ceilings and elaborately carved woodwork, and her decision to put two tufted poufs, covered in the Maharam fabric, in the middle of the second gallery adds to the show's hospitable air, as if Kalman might appear at any moment with tea and cookies. She will, however, be at the museum on March 11 and 18 from 2 to 4 in the afternoon, to sell (with the proceeds going to charity) some of her signature subject matter (like egg slicers or cans of mushy peas) as well as pieces from her own collection that, she said, "no longer need to be owned by me." The exhibition runs through July 31.

What do a 2,000-year-old Egyptian mummy and a spin painting from Damien Hirst have in common? Hirst haters might argue that they're both overpriced artifacts from eras of dramatic cultural decline, but they also happen to be strange bedfellows at the Museum of Old and New Art, which is perched on the edge of nowhere, a k a Hobart, Tasmania. The owner, David Walsh, a Howard Hughes-like eccentric whose fortune (made as a professional gambler), lifestyle and character are the perpetual subjects of local gossip, has spent the past four years and more than 75 million Australian dollars to build the approximately 65,000-square-foot secular temple that, for its opening show, "Monanism," houses only a part of his 2,210-piece collection of antiquities and ethnographic, contemporary and modern art.

Now, under the control of the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, its beaches are scarred and filthy, and the former resort area has become a haven for the homeless and other hanger-outers. POPOLATO--Alfonso. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alfonso Popolato, associated with The New York Times from November 8, 1975 until retiring on July 1, 1989.

''The Method Gun'' can seem like a revue made up of experimental theater acts. There's a short, silly one-man dance; some audience participation; multimedia inside jokes hinting at classic plays; and, of course, nudity. For laughs. But this playful show gradually endears itself to an audience, and not just because it has an ambling charm and a theme -- the importance of teachers -- that suddenly seems timely. ''The Method Gun,'' mounted by the Austin, Tex., ensemble Rude Mechs at Dance Theater Workshop, is not more than the sum of its parts so much as it reveals that one part can be much more than you think.

KRAUSZ--Adrienne Friede MD. Renowned Surgeon, she was decorated for Lifetime Achievement Award by the Association of Women Surgeons. She practiced in New Jersey at Robert Wood Johnson Hospital. She was a clinical associate professor of surgery at Rutgers University. She also had a Second Surgical opinion practice in Westport, CT. Adrienne was born in 1923 in Cluj, Rumania to a famous family of doctors and surgeons. Adrienne was the sole survivor in her family of the Holocaust. It was her joy and mission to tell her story, and to be affiliated with the U.S. Holocaust Museum where she was able to honor the memory of her parents and little sister who were murdered during the Holocaust. Dr Krausz is survived by her daughter Mariette Klein and granddaughter, Melissa. Services will be held on Wednesday, March 9th at 11am at the graveside Judean Memorial Gardens 16225 Batchelors Forest Road Olney Maryland, 20832. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to her favorite charity, the U.S. Holocaust Museum in Washington, DC.

DIKER--Rhona Lillian, passed away in the afternoon of March 7, 2011. Although only 78 years young, Rhona led a full and valued life. Born in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, she went on to graduate from the University of Pennsylvania and later became an accomplished interior designer. Family was the keystone of her life. Rhona was the loving daughter of Leo and Pearl Barnett of Hamilton, Ontario and the beloved wife of over 44 years of the late Bertram J. Diker of New York. Rhonda is survived by her loving and devoted daughter, Susan Diker Levine; her son-in-law William M. Levine; her adored and loving grandchildren Alexandra and Matthew Levine of New York, NY and her sister, Barbara Brickman of Greenwich, CT. A Funeral Service will take place Wednesday, March 9th at 12:30pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, with the interment to be at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Memorial donations may be made to the American Lung Association.

He began as a child actor and later went on to enjoy enormous commercial success, both as a member of the progressive rock group Genesis and as a solo artist. But after nearly 50 years as a performer, the drummer and singer Phil Collins has announced his retirement. Or maybe he hasn't: it all depends how you interpret a statement Mr. Collins, one of the most popular performers of the 1980s and '90s, has posted on his Web site explaining why he is ''stopping'' his creative activities. Mr. Collins, who turned 60 in January, was responding to a flurry of reports over the weekend, mostly in the British media, that he was officially retiring, with the reasons supplied ranging from medical problems to his supposed disappointment with the performance of his last CD, ''Going Back,'' a Motown covers record released last year, which went to No. 1 in Great Britain. Many of those articles, ''have ended up painting a picture of me that is more than a little distorted,'' in which he ''sounds like a tormented weirdo,'' Mr. Collins writes, so ''I would like to add my comments and explain again why I am calling it a day.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

HEALY--Robert (Bob) E. of Vero Beach, FL died on February 27. Born March 6, 1928 to Martin and Marie (Davy) Healy in New York City. Graduated from Fordham University; Fordham's Alumni Man of the Year in 1968. Joined Price Waterhouse in 1953. Partner in the National Office 1966; Policy Board member 1976; Managing Regional Partner New York Area 1978; Retired 1988. Co-authored Valuing a Company, 1971. Board of Trustees Member for: St. Vincent's Hospital & Medical Center; St. Vincent's Hospital Westchester; Christian Brothers University (Memphis); Greenwich Country Club (CT); and John's Island Club (FL). Knight in Sovereign Military Order of Malta. Predeceased by wife, Gloria Cavoti Healy in 2000. Surviving children, Robert Healy, Jr. (Paoli, PA), Eileen Healy Ford (Franklin Lakes, NJ), Katherine Healy Slaughter (Baltimore, MD), Gloria Jean Healy Hazelwood (Lafayette, CO) and Kevin Healy (Scottsdale, AZ). Surviving wife, Mary Salisbury Healy (Vero Beach, FL). Mass will be 10:00am Saturday, March 12, 2011 at St. Michael's the Archangel, 469 North Ave., Greenwich, CT.

OBITUARY An obituary on March 1 about the actress Jane Russell misidentified the newspaper to which she gave an interview in 2003. Although the interview was reprinted in The Sunday Mail, an Australian newspaper, it originally appeared in The Daily Mail of London. The obituary also misstated part of the plot of ''The Outlaw,'' her first movie. Her character, Rio McDonald, was the object of a romantic rivalry between Doc Holliday and Billy the Kid; she was not the girlfriend of Sherriff Pat Garrett, another character in the movie.

RIKER--Harriet Appel, was the beloved daughter of Gustave and Tillie Appel, devoted sister of Jack Appel, and the wife of the late I. Jerome Riker. She passed away on March 7, 2011 at Hospice by the Sea in Boca Raton, Florida, having suffered a hemorrhagic stroke. Harriet was a graduate of New York University Class of 1946. She worked in real estate, and her last position before retiring was with Union Oil of California as their East Coast investor relations representative. She was born in Brooklyn, New York, on February 8, 1927 and moved with her family to Manhattan in the early fifties. She lived at Park Avenue and 70th Street prior to relocating to Boca Raton, Florida, in 2006 to be with her brother. Funeral Services will be held on March 11, 2011 at 10am at the Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at West 91st Street), in New York City. Contributions may me made to Hospice by the Sea, Inc., 1531 W. Palmetto Park Rd., Boca Raton, FL 33486-3395

FRONT PAGE A capsule summary on Tuesday for an article about reinventing silk misstated the process for recreating the properties that make spider silk useful. As the article correctly noted, the efforts involve reconstituting the silk of silkworms and producing analogues of spider silks. They do not involve making spiders more productive.

MENDEL--Joseph C. (Buzz), died at home in Greenwich, CT on March 6, 2011 after a valiant battle with prostate cancer, his wife of 35 years at his side. His many friends will greatly miss his courage, sense of humor, and energy. Born in Atlanta on November 14, 1940 he graduated from Notre Dame in 1963 with a BS in Engineering, most recently serving on the Engineering Advisory Council. He received his MBA from Harvard in 1969. Buzz enjoyed an extensive career both as executive and entrepreneur. In the 1970s he worked for the White House and was later appointed to the management advisory committee (OAMAC) of the U.S. Dept. of Commerce by President G. H. W. Bush. He was a Partner at Booz Allen & Hamilton, and later served as Director of Corp. Development at International Paper Co. He also served as CFO of International Technology Corp., and was Chairman and CEO of Site-Blauvelt Engineers. The son of the late Felix and Kathleen Mendel, Buzz is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Browne Mendel, daughter Ashley Mendel Fox, son-in-law Charles Bailey Fox, twin grandchildren Elizabeth Stewart Fox and Charles Browne Fox (born hours before their grandfather's passing on March 6, 2011), and two sisters Gayle Peters and Kathleen Moore. A funeral Mass will be celebrated March 11, 2011 at St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th St, New York City at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to Notre Dame Haiti Program, 1 Galvin Hall, Notre Dame, IN 46556 or Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, Dr. Howard I. Scher's Cancer Research, 1275 York Ave, NY, 10065.

The Long Wharf Theater of New Haven has lost its fourth managing director in less than a decade with the departure of Ray Cullom, whose resignation was accepted by its board, the theater said on Tuesday. Mr. Cullom came to the Long Wharf Theater, whose recent critically acclaimed productions include a revival of ''The Glass Menagerie'' starring Judith Ivey (which transferred Off Broadway to the Laura Pels Theater) and the American premiere of Simon Gray's ''Old Masters,'' in May 2009 under what was supposed to be a five-year contract. But in a news release the theater said that Mr. Cullom was ''leaving to pursue a professional opportunity in the producing and presenting theatrical world,'' and that the board would soon announce a transitional management plan. Mary Pepe, chairwoman of the board, said in a statement that the theater was ''very grateful to Ray for his leadership of Long Wharf during a period of unprecedented economic challenge.'' Mr. Collum said in a statement that the theater ''is an incredible place.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

TEMKO--Stanley Leonard. In the early hours of Monday, March 7, 2011, passed away peacefully at home at the age of 91. Warm, loving, witty, wise and wonderfully life-enhancing father of Rick, Ned and Bill Temko; beloved father-in-law of Rita, Astra and Sarah; and always treasured grandfather of Peter, Christine, Danny, Jamie and Jack. He was predeceased by his wife of 54 years, Francine Salzman Temko, in 1998, whom he first met when they were attending Columbia University in their native New York City. The family will welcome friends at a memorial tribute at the Metropolitan Club, 1700 H Street NW, Washington, DC, beginning at 4pm on Sunday, March 13. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be sent to The Legal Aid Society of the District of Columbia, 1331 H Street NW, Suite 350, Washington DC 20005 the legal access charity to which his wife devoted time, energy and her legal expertise and experience during her final years and which he continued to support after her death.

Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will hold a confidential strategy session with leading gay activists on Wednesday to discuss how to legalize same-sex marriage in New York, the latest sign that he is preparing to put the weight of his administration behind legislation that has divided lawmakers and voters across the country. Aides to Mr. Cuomo have invited about a dozen of the state's prominent same-sex-marriage advocates to the Capitol for the brainstorming session, according to people told of the meeting, which the governor himself will attend.

10 P.M. (Investigation Discovery) NOTHING PERSONAL Steven R. Schirripa, above, who played Bobby Baccalieri (until he was whacked) on ''The Sopranos,'' hosts this six-part series, which investigates the real-life world of murders for hire and the hit men behind them. This premiere episode tells the story of Larry Carrozza, known as Champagne, of the Colombo crime family. To prove his loyalty to the family, Mr. Carrozza accompanied Salvatore Miciotta, a notorious hit man called Big Sal, on what he thought would be an illicit yet routine errand in Brooklyn in 1983. It turned out to be a very different kind of illicit errand. Mr. Miciotta talks about what happened to Mr. Carrozza. 8 P.M. (CBS) SURVIVOR: REDEMPTION ISLAND Secrets are revealed on Redemption Island, and Matt and Russell duel to stay alive in the game. At 10 p.m., on ''Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior,'' a serial sniper taunts Mick (Matt Ryan) as he and the team try to track down the killer.

Hold onto your avant-garde hats: David Lynch is back on the Web. On Thursday, ''sometime between 1:23 and 1:38 p.m. Pacific time,'' Mr. Lynch, the celebrated ''Twin Peaks'' creator and director of films like ''Mulholland Drive,'' will reintroduce davidlynch.com as a digital music store and ''sensory experience.'' There will be sound experiments from the past (some unreleased from his film and television projects) and new music.

THE ARTS Schedule information on Monday with a review of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company at the University of California, Berkeley, referred incorrectly to the company's program at the Joyce Theater in New York later this month. It will perform ''Antic Meet'' from the program that was reviewed, along with other works; the same program will not be performed at the Joyce.

PARIS -- As Phil Vickery, a British television chef, prepared cottage pie last week, viewers got a taste of the future of television in Britain -- a future that arrived long ago in the United States and many other countries. It was not easy to spot, but there on a shelf behind Mr. Vickery was a coffee maker, the kind that spits out espresso or cappuccino from individual portions of grounds. In this case, the machine was not actually doing anything other than earning a reported £100,000, or about $163,000, for ITV, the British network that aired ''This Morning,'' the show on which Mr. Vickery demonstrated his recipe. But it was still a groundbreaking moment: the first paid product placement on British television.

GARDNER--Stephen, 93, died peacefully at home surrounded by his loving family, wife Jackie of 49 years, children Sarah (Steve Beede), Tom (Alina Vogelhut), Lawrence (Katie Sanders) and adored grandchildren, Ezra, Charlotte and Evie. Steve, a veteran of the Army Air Force during WWII, was an actor, stage manager, and writer. He was the "Twofer King," and founded the Hit Show Club. Memorial service at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St., at 1pm on Wednesday. Donations can be made to New Dramatists or the Actors Fund.

When Rosanne Olken walks into a new cafe, it is her vision that is on overdrive. She cannot take her eyes off a juicy hamburger. The details on the menu are more intriguing than the food itself. For as long as she can remember, Ms. Olken, 34, has not been able to taste or smell. While many people wonder how she feels about it, she does not miss what she has never known. She considers New York's restaurants, bakeries and food trucks to be atmospheric experiences. ''For me,'' she said, ''the excitement is about the company.'' Ms. Olken, a native of Manhattan, now works in market research. If there is a positive side to her sensory deprivation, it might be an absence of temptation. Food, for her, is functional. At new restaurants, she feeds on the excitement of others. But there are times when gastronomic trends do not translate. ''Truffle oil,'' she said. ''What is that all about?'' This series presents multiple-exposure portraits of perceptions of the city described by New Yorkers missing one or more senses. Earlier in the series: nytimes.com/lens.

The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Tuesday morning announced its 2011-12 season, which will include a festival celebrating the music of Budapest, Prague and Vienna; a production of the Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart musical ''Pal Joey,'' with a new book by Terrence McNally; and the Sydney Theater Company's production of ''Uncle Vanya,'' starring Cate Blanchett. There will also be a series of free performances throughout Washington called ''Look Both Ways: Street Arts Across America.'' The center also announced a $10 million gift from its chairman, David M. Rubenstein, half of which will go to programming. The rest will go to education and programs aimed at increasing access to performances. One initiative, MY-TIX, will offer free and discounted tickets through the center's Web site and through community groups. Another, called the Millennials Project, aims to attract young audience members by, among other things, programming popular artists and bands like John Legend,the Roots, OK Go and Nellie McKay.

ALBANY -- One of New York State's leading Roman Catholic bishops said on Tuesday that it was not appropriate for church officials to comment on whether specific elected officials should be allowed to receive holy communion. Bishop Howard J. Hubbard, the leader of the Albany diocese and a member of the executive committee of the New York State Catholic Conference, made his comments at a news conference after meeting with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo at the Executive Mansion to discuss the state budget, same-sex marriage and other issues.

EASY DOES IT Federal regulators are running out of time to write hundreds of new rules for Wall Street. Yet Republican lawmakers -- and even some regulators -- want to slow the pace. Representative Scott Garrett of New Jersey, above, is the latest prominent Republican to rebuke the speed at which the Commodity Futures Trading Commission is writing rules. In a letter to the agency chairman, Gary Gensler, Mr. Garrett complained that a ''rapid pace'' prevented the financial industry from fully digesting proposed rules for derivatives trading. BEN PROTESS

MORALES--Jose ("Pepe"), Jr. Born August 12, 1928, died at home surrounded by his family on March 5, 2011. He was the beloved husband of Josie, father of Susana, Jose, and Daniel, Abuelo of Danilo and Mateo, adoptive Dad to Lourdes and Dad-in-law, cousin, uncle, padrino. Born in New York City to Rita and Pepe, brother to Jorge, he attended Stuyvesant and City College and served in the US Army. He was a community organizer and health administrator devoted to social justice, civil rights, public health, and the advancement of the Puerto Rican/Latino community. He directed various community and health organizations, was an HEW official and a VP at St. Barnabas Hospital. His Board memberships included the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, El Museo del Barrio, Community Service Society, Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor, Promesa, Latino Commission on AIDS, and Boricua College. He was a Freethinker, arts and gardening aficionado, beer connoisseur, mobile-maker, avid tennis player and eight-time New York City marathon runner. He traveled with Josie around the world, loved adventure, Wellfleet and Puerto Rico. He was a man of integrity, a force of nature who loved life, his family and friends. Viewing March 8-March 9 at Williams Funeral Home, 718-548-1100. In lieu of flowers, donations to Latino Commission on AIDS (www.latinoaids.org); and Marble Hill Senior Center, 5365 Broadway, Bronx 10463.

Maine has received a waiver to federal rules in the 2010 health law that would have required health insurers insurers in the state to spend at least 80 percent of premiums on patient care, the federal government said Tuesday. Maine insurers who sell policies to individuals will have to spend only 65 percent of premiums on patients, with the rest going toward profits and administrative costs. The exemption will last through 2013. (BLOOMBERG)

BUSINESS DAY An article on Feb. 19 about Hyundai's salutary effect on the economy of Alabama misstated the history of the United Automobile Workers in American plants operated by foreign carmakers, and a correction in this space on Saturday misstated the current union status of such plants. U.A.W. members have worked at several joint ventures involving American and foreign carmakers and in a Volkswagen plant in Pennsylvania that operated from 1978 to 1988; it is not the case that the U.A.W. has yet to succeed in organizing American plants operated by foreign carmakers. One plant in Normal, Ill., started as a joint venture involving Mitsubishi and Chrysler, continues to operate under Mitsubishi's control alone. It is thus not the case that no plants operated by foreign carmakers are currently unionized.

Loving brother of Hugh (Hank) Friedman of Taos, NM and Mark (Aracelly) Friedman of Port Orchard, WA and the late Trudy Friedman-Bell and her surviving husband Dr. Richard Bell of New Haven, CT. Loving uncle of Lucy and Hannah Friedman-Bell of CT and Judah Friedman of WA. Extraordinarily devoted father of Evan and Elliot Chase of White Plains, NY and stepfather of Brooke Ganes of Katonah, NY. Former husband of Ann Chase of White Plains, NY, and wife Judith Ganes Chase of Katonah, NY. A celebration of his life will be held on March 12. When the New York Police Department announced early last year that all parades would have to be shortened to reduce police overtime costs, several parade organizers cried foul. The 2010 St. Patrick's Day Parade, for which the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, happened to be serving as grand marshal, ended up being given an exemption from the new rules (the Police Department said the parade had not been given enough advance notice). But this year, the luck of the St. Patrick's Day Parade has clearly run out.

INTERNATIONAL An article in some editions on Tuesday about President Obama's plans to nominate Gary F. Locke, the commerce secretary, to be ambassador to China misstated the year Mr. Locke began the first of two terms as governor of Washington State. It was 1997, not 1996. (He was elected in 1996, sworn in in January 1997 and left office in January 2005.) The article also misidentified, in some editions, the location where the current ambassador, Jon H. Huntsman Jr., served as a Mormon missionary. He was in Taiwan, not in China.

GILLESPIE--S. Hazard Jr.,died on March 7th of Pancreatic Cancer. Born July 12, 1910 in Morristown, New Jersey, he graduated from the Hill School, Yale College (32), Yale Law School (36) and spent his legal career, as a litigator, at Davis Polk. He served in WWII, was President of the NYS Bar Association (58-59) and US Attorney for the Southern District of NY (59-61). He is survived by his wife, Adelma Park; children from his first marriage to Ruth Reed, Jane Brown Grimes and Samuel H. Gillespie III; step children, Adelma Lilliston and Leonard T. Lilliston III; brothers, Stuart and David; seven grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers the family suggests a donation to the Lustgarten Foundation or the Hirshberg Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer. The service will be at St Bartholomew's Church in New York on March 30, 2011 at 3pm.

There are certain things that all creative people share in common — and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitken’s 2006 book “Broken Screen,” which featured interviews with everyone from Robert Altman to Rem Koolhaas, challenged the convention of the linear narrative. Now, with his latest video project, Patterns & Repetitions, the artist sits down with a whole new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. There’s Jacques Herzog on instinct and architecture; the artist Mike Kelley talking about Detroit, his hometown; and Jack White weighing in on Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. This week, The Moment features LCD Soundsystem’s James Murphy on the sound of snow. But don’t be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesn’t do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

Some problems are simply too complex to solve with any single approach. Consider the fact that in the United States, a million students drop out of high school each year. To begin to turn back that trend, we need to work on several fronts - assist vulnerable families when children are infants, improve classrooms from preschool through high school, provide after-school supports and college access assistance, tackle the issue of summer-learning loss and get much smarter about addressing students' social and emotional needs at every stage. In the words of Clay Shirky: "Nothing will work, but everything might."

The Donmar Warehouse, the well-known London theater, has a new artistic director. Josie Rourke will take up the position on January 1, 2012, taking over for Michael Grandage, who will step down at the end of this year after a decade in the role, the theater announced on Thursday. Ms. Rourke's appointment represents a return to the Donmar; she trained in the company's Resident Assistant Director program in 2000 - working alongside Mr. Grandage, Nicholas Hytner, Phyllida Lloyd and Sam Mendes. Her directing work for the Donmar has included "Frame 312," "World Music" and "The Cryptogram."

The rusty cash register at Mendel Goldberg Fabrics cannot register sales above $999.99 without a little tinkering. Large sums must be broken into smaller amounts, which are entered separately. Alice Goldberg Wildes, the fourth generation of the Goldbergs to run the store, insists that they will get a computer soon. She never seems to get to it.

In "Gypsies" (powerHouse Books, $45), out in May, the photographer Patrick Cariou retraced the migration of the Romany people from northern to southern Europe, the Middle East and ultimately India, their ancestral homeland. Along the way, he encountered Gypsies making sausage on the floor of a Romanian hovel and living in weirdly beautiful shantytowns in Slovakia and tents in Afghanistan. In France, he found more prosperous Roma, whose Gypsy caravans now include Ferraris and inflatable kiddie pools filled with ice and Kronenbourg beer. Meanwhile, Iain McKell's "The New Gypsies" (Prestel, $40) zooms in on a group unrelated to the Roma, the anarchic vagabonds known in Britain as "horse-drawns," who coalesced with anti-Thatcherite movements in the 1980s. They have fair skin, and their wagons recall medieval fairs more readily than Romania, but the kinship between these Gypsy tribes, new and old, seems somehow more than contrived.

Archaeologists are criticizing the Smithsonian Institution over a planned show of objects salvaged from a shipwreck in the Java Sea, saying that the company that recovered the objects did not observe professional archaeological standards in doing so, the Web site Science Now reported Thursday. The ship, a ninth-century Arab dhow that carried glazed ceramics and gold and silver vessels from China, was discovered in Indonesian waters in the late 1990s and salvaged by a German company called Seabed Explorations GbR. In 2005, according to Science Now, most of the objects were sold to a company in Singapore for a reported $32 million. (The exhibition is currently on display at the ArtScience Museum in Singapore.)

Overview | In this lesson, students consider the themes and characters of Charlotte Brontë's novel "Jane Eyre," beginning with responding to key lines from the novel. They then engage in one of seven activities designed to guide them to deeper reading of the text. Some of the activities involve considering one or more film adaptations, including a 2011 movie version. Finally, they compare the life of someone they know, or themselves, with Jane Eyre.

With their political status still unclear back in their homeland, members of the Belarus Free Theater will be returning to New York next month for a five-week stay at La MaMa, which, along with the Public Theater, has offered the group an "artistic residency" as a gesture of solidarity. Beginning April 13, the troupe, which fled Belarus in December during a crackdown by the country's authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, will perform three of its original works, including the New York premiere of "Discover Love," a meditation on marriage and political repression. Rounding out the program are "Being Harold Pinter" and "Zone of Silence," both of which were critically praised when performed at the Public Theater's Under the Radar Festival in January.

Mark Morrisroe's biography bears the tenor of a tragic, love- and fame-driven star doomed to fizzle too soon for the likes of those standing awed and breathless beneath it. A teenage hustler and a prostitute, he spent the second half of his years with a bullet in his back, flirting with his spine. Dauntless, he made it to the School of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. He palled around with Nan Goldin and David Armstrong, and eventually moved to New York, in the mid-1980s, where he pursued a brief yet scintillating career as a photographer and an artist. He died of AIDS-related illness in 1989, at age 30. Now, for the first time, his frenzied, critically neglected oeuvre is getting some retrospective attention, with a new monograph and a corresponding gallery show at Artists Space, on Greene Street.

I am not sure I even realized that reindeer were real. I lost them decades ago along with Santa and his elves. I certainly did not know that reindeer and the people who herd them could tell me something new about the ridiculousness and cruelty of Soviet communism. But when I went to see a friend read from her novel earlier this week, she was paired with the English writer and polar nomad Sara Wheeler, who read from her latest book, "The Magnetic North: Notes from the Arctic Circle," and I learned about the Chukchi people. The Chukchi are the "next door neighbors" from the very farthest northeastern section of Russia that Sarah Palin said she could see when she was the governor of Alaska. A local politician, Petr Omrynto, told Wheeler that "reindeer are the glue that binds Chukchi culture and society."

That Perry Jones may have run run afoul of some N.C.A.A. rules, triggering his suspension for Baylor's Big 12 tournament game last night, is, in one sense, not shocking. The television contract for the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament is worth billions - the football Bowl Championship Series, the controversial enterprise dominated by the biggest conferences, is also worth billions - and big-time college coaches make millions of dollars annually, but within this cascade of money the athletes themselves are required to remain amateurs. When athletes and coaches are caught breaking a wide range of rules and regulations, the penalties dispensed by the N.C.A.A. for doing so are wildly uneven. And this is where the Jones situation gets baffling.

With an opportunity to distinguish himself in the competition for a rotation spot, Bartolo Colon merely kept pace Wednesday night, allowing two runs over four innings in the Yankees' 4-2 victory against Pittsburgh in Tampa, Fla. The day after Freddy Garcia worked three perfect innings, Colon struck out seven and walked none, impressing Manager Joe Girardi with the command of his two-seam fastball and how he handled hitters the second time through the lineup.

Somehow the books you bring on vacation aren't usually the ones you want to read, and the randomness of other people's choices seems like as much a relief from real-life obligations as the holiday itself. Daydreaming about traveling south this season, I found myself imagining how great it would be to find a place that had the kind of wildly varied collections of left-behind books that I remember from past trips to small hotels and scruffy rental houses. The Economist's culture magazine, More Intelligent Life, produced this examination of hotel libraries - a little more aspirational and sterile than what I had in mind, but probably someone else's idea of the perfect escape.

In statements circulating on Capitol Hill, senior Republican leaders cast legislation blocking the Environmental Protection Agency from enforcing climate change regulations as action that would help slow the rise of gasoline prices. "This standard does not impact vehicles and would have no impact on gasoline prices." [The Hill]

Social science was right: Eric Clapton raised $2.15 million at a New York auction of 75 guitars and 55 amplifiers on Wednesday, more than triple the pre-sale expectations, Reuters reported on Thursday. The proceeds from the sale at Bonhams - at which every lot sold -- will go to the 65-year-old rock star's Crossroads Center drug and alcohol treatment facility in the Caribbean. The auction - the proceeds of which totaled around $1.8 million without the buyer's premium - also included instruments donated by Mr. Clapton's musician friends Jeff Beck, J.J. Cale and Joe Bonamassa. Among the top lots was a 1948 Gibson L-5P, which was expected to bring $20,000 to $30,000 but raised $82,960; a 2005 Zemaitis S22BP 3S, estimated at $12,000 to $18,000, which sold for $75,640; and a pair of 1997 Fender Twin Amps, estimated at $9,000 to $12,000, which sold for $42,700. The rap artist 50 Cent has made a donation to charity after revelations that he performed for the clan of Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Reuters reported on Thursday. "In light of the ongoing events in Libya, 50 Cent will be making a donation to UNICEF, which is providing vital relief supplies to meet the needs of women and children at risk during this crisis," a spokesman for the artist told E! News. The rapper, whose real name is Curtis Jackson, joined what one entertainment Web site called the "Qaddafi performance regret club" - pop stars who sometimes earned seven-figure sums performing for members of Qaddafi's family at exclusive parties around the world. These include Beyonce, Nelly Furtado, Mariah Carey and Usher, all of whom have issued statements saying they would donate or had already given money to charities. The appearances have become a major source of embarrassment since the Libyan leader's brutal response to a popular uprising against him in Libya. 50 Cent earned an undisclosed amount from a private concert during the 2005 Venice film festival.

So there's a new iPad2. And that's great. But for those willing to put up with last year's model, there's a cheapskate strategy that can help you save big - if you know where to look. One of the nice things the arrival of the iPad2 brings are lower prices for what will soon be last year's model. Sure, the iPad1 is not as flashy as the iPad2 (no camera, slower processor, no cool Smart Cover), but if you really want an iPad and a difference of, say, $150 matters to you, you may want to read on.

GILLESPIE--S. Hazard. The Board of Directors and staff of American Skin Association mourn the passing of its longtime friend, board member and former chairman, Hazard Gillespie. Hazard was an active member of the Board for the past 15 years and his counsel and judgment were invaluable. He served as Chairman of the Board for six years and under his leadership, ASA's award-winning public school program for K-12 was launched. He was the program's staunchest champion--to the benefit of millions of children across the country. He had a distinguished career at the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell and his legal counsel and sound judgment inured to the benefit of ASA. He served the public interest through numerous boards and roles, most notably as a U.S. Attorney under Eisenhower. His dedicated leadership, wise counsel and engaging advocacy for children's education will never be forgotten. He truly made a difference. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Adelma and his children and their families. We will miss him. Howard P. Milstein, Chairman George W. Hambrick, Jr., MD, Founder & President American Skin Association

Do the canvases of Cy Twombly look like finger-painting to you? No matter how you answer, you're probably more an of aesthete than you think. Building on a put-down commonly directed at abstract art - ''my kid (or a monkey/elephant) could do that'' - researchers at Boston College tested whether laypeople and art students could distinguish between abstract paintings by professional artists and those made by schoolchildren and animals. As they report in the journal Psychological Science, even non-experts could tell the difference between finger (or trunk) painting and the real deal.

OTTAWA - The proposed merger between the London Stock Exchange and the holding company that owns the Toronto Stock Exchange has encountered opposition from a perhaps unexpected front, Canada's financial community. On Wednesday, the securities units of three top Canadian banks urged governments to kill the deal in an open letter that was published online by The National Post in Toronto.

An article on Tuesday about the plight of sub-Saharan Africans stranded at the airport in Tripoli, Libya, omitted the location of one of the authors. Scott Sayare contributed reporting from the Choucha Transit Camp in Tunisia -- not from Tripoli, the dateline of the article.

THE ARTS An article on Tuesday about the soprano Angela Gheorghiu's withdrawal from a new production of Gounod's ''Faust'' scheduled for the Metropolitan Opera in the fall misidentified her role in ''Carmen'' when she was replaced during a Met tour of Japan because she refused to wear a blond wig. It was Micaela, not Carmen.

Between the Frederick Wiseman documentary ''La Danse'' and live HD showings, the Paris Opera Ballet has been a frequent presence on New York screens in recent years. But onstage is another matter: the company hasn't performed in New York City since 1996. That absence is now being rectified: The troupe has announced that it will appear in the 2012 Lincoln Center Festival as part of its first American tour in more than a decade. After stops in Chicago (at the Harris Theater) and Washington (at the Kennedy Center), it will take up residence in New York from July 11 to 22 next year, performing ''Suite en Blanc,'' ''L'Arlesienne,'' ''Bolero,'' ''Giselle'' and Pina Bausch's version of ''Orpheus and Eurydice.'' The company last visited the United States -- specifically San Francisco and Los Angeles -- in 2001.
NEW YORK The listing of winning lottery numbers on Wednesday misstated one number for Tuesday's New York Take Five in some copies. The numbers were 5, 22, 31, 39 and 38 (not 28).

7:47 p.m. | Updated Lady Gaga has dissolved a major marketing deal with Target, apparently because of the company's support for political candidates who oppose gay rights. As part of the marketing campaign for her latest album, ''Born This Way,'' to be released in May, Lady Gaga struck a deal with Target allowing the retailer exclusive retail rights to a special version of the album. That deal has been ended and the Target version of the album will not be released, a spokeswoman for Lady Gaga said. But on Wednesday afternoon, Target's Web site was still taking orders for the album.

Some of the world's largest private equity firms are in a tug of war over top talent. But the competition isn't over brand-name executives commanding eight-figure salaries. Instead, firms are fighting for the affections of bankers barely old enough to rent cars. This month starts the private equity recruiting season, an annual Wall Street ritual in which young analysts from leading investment banks like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are wined and dined by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the Blackstone Group, TPG Capital and a handful of other top-flight firms. The industry is gearing up earlier than ever this year, with some firms already making offers for jobs that won't start until the fall of 2012, a full 18 months from now.

Women rule the pop charts this week, with the British singer Adele holding at No. 1 on Billboard's album chart for a second week, and Lady Gaga's ''Born This Way'' the top digital download for a fourth week in a row. Adele's second album, ''21'' (XL/Columbia), sold 168,000 copies last week, easily holding its spot at No. 1 and bringing that album's two-week American sales total to 521,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In Britain, where the album has been out for six weeks, it has racked up a million sales, and done so faster than any album has ever done during the first three months of the year, when sales are usually slow.

FRONT PAGE An article on Feb. 24 about the Obama administration's determination that the 1996 law barring federal recognition of same-sex marriages is unconstitutional misstated the acronym of one of the advocacy groups that has challenged the law in court. It is GLAD (Gay and Lesbian Advocates and Defenders), not Glaad (the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation).

BUSINESS DAY An article on Monday about the end of plans for a merger of Smile Train and Operation Smile, two nonprofit groups that work to treat cleft palates and lips, misstated the collective gifts of donors who signed an online petition opposing the deal. Donors who signed the petition have given a total of $7.9 million, according to Smile Train, not $82 million. (The larger number is the amount from all donors who have expressed opposition to the merger, including two of the organization's largest, which account for more than $70 million in gifts.) (Go to Article)

Smartphones are supposed to make calling easier, but between free calling apps like Google Voice, Skype, Fring, as well as services like Line2, there are a baffling collection of names and numbers remember. You may think the last thing we need is another way of contacting people (and you may be right), but a free service called Go800 is trying to make calling easy by replacing phone numbers with Twitter names.

MEXICO CITY - Telefonos de Mexico, the country's dominant fixed-line phone carrier, plans to carve out its rural lines into a separate company, adding a new layer to a dispute between the company and its competitors. The new company, called Telmex Social, would serve 46 percent of the country where there is no competition, according to announcement released late Tuesday, although it would account for only 12 percent of the parent company's 15.5 million lines. Those lines operate with small profits or losses, the company said.

World premieres of plays by Amy Herzog (''After the Revolution'') and Will Eno (''Middletown''), as well as productions of Chekhov's ''Three Sisters,'' Moliere's ''Doctor in Spite of Himself'' and Shakespeare's ''Winter's Tale'' will be featured in Yale Repertory Theater's 2011-12 season, the theater announced on Wednesday. Ms. Herzog's new play, ''Belleville,'' centers on a young American married couple whose seemingly perfect ex-pat life in Paris is upended by revelations. And Mr. Eno's play ''The Realistic Joneses'' portrays two suburban couples whose similarities go far beyond their same last names.Anne Kauffman, who directed ''We Have Always Lived in the Castle'' at Yale Rep, will stage the Herzog piece in the fall, while Sam Gold (Off Broadway's ''Circle Mirror Transformation'') will direct Mr. Eno's play in spring 2012. The season will begin in September with a new version of ''Three Sisters'' by Sarah Ruhl, a Tony Award nominee for best play last year for ''In the Next Room (or the vibrator play).'' The co-production with Berkeley Repertory Theater will be directed by Les Waters, who mounted ''In the Next Room.''
