SIP Champagne, linger over sumptuous prints and pretend that you're a contessa. The new Etro store in SoHo is a vision of nonchalant decadence. The two-story boutique marries the area's industrial feel (high tin ceilings and exposed brick walls) with old-money luxury (wood paneling and oil portraits of deceased ancestors). A trippy array of men's silk printed ties (pictured, $151) and pocket squares ($89) greets visitors to the men's collection on the first floor. Downstairs is the vibrant women's spring collection (pictured, silk drawstring tribal print dress $1,347; nylon trench, $1,275; beaded necklace, $535). Etro, 89 Greene Street (Spring Street), (212) 343-2054; etro.it.

8 P.M. (CBS) THE BIG BANG THEORY Priya (Aarti Mann), the new girlfriend of Leonard (Johnny Galecki), gives him a choice: Does he want a girlfriend or does he want to continue his friendship with Penny (Kaley Cuoco)? He can't have both. Meanwhile Sheldon (Jim Parsons, above right, with Mr. Galecki) is less than enthused with a magic trick that Howard (Simon Helberg) is eager to show off. At 8:30, on ''Rules of Engagement,'' Jeff (Patrick Warburton) tries to surprise Audrey (Megyn Price) by remembering their anniversary but ends up being surprised himself. And Timmy (Adhir Kalyan) acts as interpreter for Russell (David Spade) on a date. At 9 p.m., on ''CSI: Crime Scene Investigation,'' a former police officer found guilty of killing his wife is murdered in prison. Investigators discover a list in the dead man's cell of those he believed could have been his wife's true murderer. At 10 p.m., on ''The Mentalist,'' the body of a doctor is found on a golf course, and the team searches for the killer in a hospital. When LaRoche (the guest star Pruitt Taylor Vince) is put in charge of the search, his first act is to name Cho (Tim Kang) team leader. 8 P.M. (Investigation Discovery) CHASING JUSTICE WITH DAN ABRAMS The police believe they have a prime suspect when a woman is murdered, but it turns out that the suspect has a solid alibi. Then a second woman steps up, risking her life to make sure there is justice for the victim.

TAMPA, Fla.- With an opportunity to distinguish himself in the competition for a rotation spot, Bartolo Colon merely kept pace Wednesday night, allowing two runs over four innings in the Yankees' 4-2 victory against the Pittsburgh Pirates. The day after Freddy Garcia worked three perfect innings, Colon struck out seven and walked none, impressing Manager Joe Girardi with the command of his two-seam fastball and how he handled hitters the second time through the lineup. Of the four candidates for two starting jobs -- Ivan Nova and Sergio Mitre are the others -- Colon is the only pitcher to have surrendered a run (three).

LIBYA Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi attacked rebel fighters on the outskirts of Ras Lanuf, a strategic refinery town, provoking a response that included the firing of missile fusillades and rocket propelled grenades. In the western half of the country, elite government troops continued to pound the besieged, rebel-held city of Zawiyah. EGYPT Mohamed ElBaradei, the Nobel laureate, said he intended to run for president, although he set conditions under which he would pursue the office vacated by President Hosni Mubarak. Meanwhile, violence began to escalate, with 13 people killed in fighting between Muslims and Christians in the Cairo suburbs.

An article on Tuesday about the return, in virtual form, of CARE packages misstated the original name of the charitable organization that initiated the packages to assist Europeans after World War II. It was Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe -- not Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere, which is the organization's name now. (In the 1950s, ''Remittances to Europe'' was changed to ''Relief Everywhere,'' and in the 1990s, ''American'' was changed to ''Assistance.'')

Grandmother of Jessica and Carolyn Blackman, Lauren, Liza and William Truncellito, Sarah, Kathryn, and William Most; Step-grandchildren, Samantha and Adam Berger; her siblings, Babette S. Gruenberg and Stanley M. Stern. She was a very active woman who enjoyed spending time with her family and friends. A Funeral Service will take place on Friday morning, March 11, 2011 at 10am at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, NY. The family will receive visitors at Jane's home from 4-7pm on Friday.

The trouble began, Theresa Smith said, shortly after she bought a hamster for her 9-year-old son. A few months later, the hamster, Princess Stephanie, was playing in its exercise ball on the floor of their apartment in Bushwick, Brooklyn, when an older son, who is 25, flew into a rage. ''He kicked it deliberately, the ball flew across the room, the hamster flew out of the ball, and it died,'' Ms. Smith said. After he had calmed down, the older son felt terrible, she said.

ZIMMER--Anna "Honey," died at home on March 6, 2011 at the respectable age of 89. Beloved wife of the late Fred Zimmer; mother of Dr. Hal Zimmer and Phyllis Arn Zimmer of Bellevue, WA; Sarah Chapman and Michael Turnacliff of Greenbrae, CA; and Bonnie Zimmer and Jim Ptacek of Cambridge, MA. Adoring and adored grandmother of Allegra and Sabina Chapman and Alex Ptacek Zimmer. Honey also leaves her brother Marvin Schachter and lifelong-friend, turned sister-in-law, Phyllis Held. As the matriarch of her large and loving family, Honey's absence will be deeply felt in Kittery Point, ME, in Arlington and Cambridge, MA and in New York City. A pioneering social worker in the field of aging, Honey created some of the first support programs in the United States aimed at empowering elders and all those who care for them. To the very end, Honey charmed and appreciated her own caregivers, enjoying life to the fullest and "collecting families" wherever she might find herself. Contributions to the Nelson Mandela Children's Hospital Fund, the National Council of Jewish Women, or another cause of your choice are greatly appreciated. A former student will be hosting a memorial service in NYC later this spring.

LASTER--Owen Jacob. Beloved son of the late Harry and the late Yetta Laster. Loving brother of the late Seymour Laster and the late Howard Laster. Devoted uncle, brother-in-law, friend and mentor. He was a deeply admired and respected literary agent. Through 42 years with the William Morris Agency, his wisdom and commitment to writers guided the careers of many authors and agents, young and established alike. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Service Friday, March 11th, 1130am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC. Family will receive friends at 425 East 58th St., Friday, March 11th, 7-9pm, Saturday, March 12th, 7-9pm and Sunday March 13th, 2-4pm. Donations in his memory may be made to The Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or The Gay Men's Health Crisis, Inc.

Survived by her daughter Lois (Martin) Hochberg, son Harvey (Adrianne), sister Jeanette Weinberg, grandchildren Leigh Hochberg, Lauren Benthien, and four great-grandchildren. Service today, 11:30am at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W150 Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ.

HAWTHORN--Robert William, passed suddenly on Sunday, March 6, 2011. A private Family Mass of Christian Burial was held on Tuesday at Ascension Church in New York City. Mr. Hawthorn taught at Fordham Preparatory for 50 years and led the Men's Squash and Tennis Team at the University since 1956 until last year. He was an officer in the Air Force, a Registered Nurse at Rosary Hill and a tree farmer at his family farm in Middletown, NJ. He and his wife Eileen had eight children and 17 grandchildren. Robert's whole life was a quiet example of how to be a good person. He was a true follower of the Ignatian philosophy, "A Man for Others." In the spring, there will be a celebration of his life where all who were touched by his Christian example may pay tribute to this "Giant of a Man."

Any photo buff who wants to know what it takes to shoot award winning images can find out with the new iPad app, ''50 Greatest Photographs of National Geographic.'' The app shows top photos from the magazine's deep well of phenomenal images. Each is accompanied by a story from the photographers describing how they captured the image, sometimes with unpublished, alternate versions of the shot or a video.

FISHER--Terhikki Vuolanne, died on March 4. Born April 29, 1933 to Leonard and Elsa Vuolanne in Riihimaki, Finland. She was predeceased by her husband Aurel Fisher and survived by sisters Vuokko Vuolanne, Sini Tarkela, brother Matti Vuolanne, several nephews and nieces. The memorial service will be held today March 10 at the Finnish Lutheran Church, 83 Christopher Street, NYC.

''I wish I were James Bond, but I'm just a messenger,'' says Sean Cross, the hero of ''Vale of Tears,'' Representative Peter T. King's barely veiled 2004 thriller about a congressman who must thwart a planned ''dirty bomb'' attack by Qaeda operatives working in Brooklyn and on Long Island. Even before the plot of the novel unfolds, it is a tense time for Congressman Cross, Mr. King's alter ego. He has been assigned a police escort ''ever since he had begun receiving vague phone and mail threats from self-proclaimed Islamic terrorists.'' Then a series of explosions rock Long Island and Brooklyn, and Congressman Cross is forced to help ''connect the dots'' to prevent an even bigger attack.
ONLINE

COSTELLO--Evelyn, 83 years old, died on March 8, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Lawrence Costello. Devoted mother of Marjorie Costello, Amy and David Crowley and Donald Costello and his partner Charles Luecke. Cherished grandmother of Michael and Kelly. Dearest sister of the late Florence Hess and the late Irving Polsky. Service 11am, Friday, March 11th at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (Opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Alzheimer's Association, 1-800-272-3900.

ANNA SUI is selling an exclusive line of dresses on Outnet (outnet.com), the lower-priced sister of the luxury online retailer Net-a-Porter, starting today. The dress collection, priced from $193 to $253, covers all girly-girl bases from a crepe little black party dress to cupcake print frocks (pictured, a tier-skirted silk print dress, $196).

RIKER--Harriet Appel, was the beloved daughter of Gustave and Tillie Appel, devoted sister of Jack Appel, and the wife of the late I. Jerome Riker. She passed away on March 7, 2011 at Hospice by the Sea in Boca Raton, Florida, having suffered a hemorrhagic stroke. Harriet was a graduate of New York University Class of 1946. She worked in real estate, and her last position before retiring was with Union Oil of California as their East Coast investor relations representative. She was born in Brooklyn, New York, on February 8, 1927 and moved with her family to Manhattan in the early fifties. She lived at Park Avenue and 70th Street prior to relocating to Boca Raton, Florida, in 2006 to be with her brother. Funeral Services will be held on March 11, 2011 at 10am at the Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at West 91st Street), in New York City. Contributions may me made to Hospice by the Sea, Inc., 1531 W. Palmetto Park Rd., Boca Raton, FL 33486-3395

The AmigoCase combining an iPhone case and backup battery is a clever take on the problem for all phone battery packs. That problem is bulk. People will pay a premium to get a phone that is a centimeter thinner than the prior model. After all, who wants to double the size and weight with a case containing a battery?

When it comes to the race for money, Carlos Slim Helu, the world's richest man, has surged even further into the lead. The Mexican billionaire accumulated an additional $20.5 billion over the last year, bringing his total fortune to $74 billion, according the Forbes annual rankings of the world's billionaires. Mr. Slim has held the top spot since last year, when he pushed aside the two past leaders, Bill Gates and Warren E. Buffett. Still, both men added $3 billion to their wealth since the last Forbes billionaires survey. Mr. Gates, the richest man in the United States, is worth $56 billion, while Mr. Buffett is worth $50 billion, according to the magazine.

MIRZA--Muzzi, 3/2/58-3/10/07 Even four long years have not dimmed your light or our memories of your glorious smile, your thoughtful wisdom and the joy you brought to us and all whose lives you touched. Your generous spirit lives on in all the good works still being done in your name. We miss you Muzzi/Dad! With eternal love, Sue, Alex, Christina and Sean and all your beloved family

Prosecutors have released audio files of three wiretapped telephone calls that Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Group’s founder, had with four other people. The government contends that Mr. Rajaratnam received illegal tips on these calls.
Bank bonuses are not what they used to be, although they could make a comeback once the dust settles from the financial crisis, according to a new report from Moody’s Investors Service.

The story quickly climbed The Times’s “most emailed” list but not just because of the sensational facts of the crime involved. “Vicious Assault Shakes Texas Town,” published on Tuesday, reported the gang rape by 18 boys and men of an 11-year-old girl in the East Texas town of Cleveland.

When I was writing my review of the iPad 2, I was trying to get straight the pricing plans for the WiFi/3G iPad version. As I noted in the column, the beauty of these plans is that there’s no two-year contract needed. You can start and stop the cellular service (and pay for it) on a month-by-month basis, as you need it. I just wanted to find out the prices.

TOKYO -- As I type this at my home here, every television channel here is devoting almost all of its coverage to reports of the staggering damage caused by the earthquake that occurred Friday off the Pacific Coast of northeastern Japan. The shaking itself, and the tsunami and fires caused by the quake, have combined to cause staggering damage. Based on past experience, it will be several days before the scale of the disaster fully emerges, as communication with the most damaged areas is still cut off.

Most of the focus when the N.C.A.A. tournament bracket is revealed on Sunday will be on how teams are seeded and what sort of opponents they're due to face -- and which teams make the field of 68 at all. But there is another factor that can make just as much difference: where the games are played.
GREENSBORO, N.C. -- If Duke fails to defend its national championship this spring, the Blue Devils can blame bad toes and bad timing.

SATURDAY'S PUZZLE - Yes, there are Saturday puzzles, and then there are Saturday puzzles by Joon Pahk. With a puzzle like this, it's not so much a matter of choosing something to like and highlight. It's more a matter of trying to find something I didn't like. It was still a bear, though. I crashed and burned in the south and the southeast, just barely making it out alive. The northeast wasn't much easier.

Onlookers recorded the scene; local television news was full of it.

In a conference call with reporters on Friday, Major League Soccer Commissioner Don Garber, who has a long relationship with the Wilpon family, said the Mets owners "would be great owners in M.L.S.," and expressed hope that the family would get their financial difficulties sorted out in time to be part of the league, which hopes to add a second team in New York. More coverage at the Goal blog.

Writing from Greensboro, N.C., in March 1861, the week after Abraham Lincoln took power, Representative John A. Gilmer sent a rapid-fire sequence of letters to William Henry Seward, the new secretary of state. "I am here in the very midst of the South," Gilmer implored Seward, "and I beg you to weigh well the suggestions which I make to you." He described the nervous impetuousness among secessionists, who were beginning to believe that fighting and bloodshed were necessary to sustain their flagging revolution. Their only hope was to instigate a collision between federal and state forces in the Deep South.
In this edition of Reads and Reactions: a Gingrich run, the Oscars, more unions, more 2012 analyses and hoops. (We are now taking suggestions for this feature via Twitter, just reply to @micahcohen).

TAMPA, Fla. - It was a therapeutic return to the lineup Friday for Braves catcher Brian McCann. He went 0 for 3 against the Yankees, playing for the first time since Wednesday, when he hooked a liner into the Atlanta dugout that struck Luis Salazar, a minor-league manager, in the left eye. The impact caused Salazar, standing on the top step, to fall forward onto his face, and he was unconscious for at least 20 minutes. McCann, shaken, took himself out of the game.

Daniel H. Mudd, the former chief executive of Fannie Mae, may soon face civil charges stemming from his tenure at the mortgage finance company, according to a person briefed on the matter who was not authorized to speak publicly.

It was one of those delicious summer nights in Nebraska when you're blissfully wallowing in vacation. You gulp dinner in order to slip out through the screen door into the dark, into an atmosphere of rustling elm leaves and June bugs, and join up with some friends to play "kick the can" or "ditch" or to raise, if not hell, heck.

Elsewhere in the magazine, we drop in on models who box (seriously), a Soviet cosmonaut who was equal parts boozer and charmer, and a Californian who spent seven years on the shadowy margins in Yemen and the Horn of Africa. Rain-related problems on the No. 7 train line that knocked service for a loop Friday morning will persist throughout the weekend as repair crews work to fix damaged signal equipment, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority says. There will be no service between Times Square and Queensboro Plaza until 10 p.m. tonight, at which point service will be restored on only one track, effectively turning the No. 7 into a very long shuttle train with correspondingly long delays. Customers are encouraged to use the E, F, N or R lines as a substitute.

It is now time for Round 2 in our ongoing weekly social-media blog-fusion smackdown: @Shamblanderson's Sentence of the Week. I'm not sure how (probably some kind of mathematical paradox), but this week I managed to come up with eight sentences. Let's take them one by one.

Paul Sullivan writes this week about investor behavior. Specifically, he discusses new research, based on 17 years of call records at a boutique investment firm, that found that investors tended to wait until a period of greatest volatility in the markets had passed and then sell at the bottom or buy at the top.

WASHINGTON - With the union dissolving itself Friday and owners in position to lock players out, the N.F.L. has embarked on its first work stoppage since the players strike in 1987. Prepare for an off-season with no activity on the field, but plenty of news from courtrooms.

TOKYO -- The first thing I was worried about was where to put my tea. I'd been sitting on the heated carpet in my apartment, working on a blog post about Japanese chewing gum. I stood up few seconds after the room started to sway. The TV was jumping. Buildings outside were swaying. A six-foot tall cabinet full of books was rocking. Things were falling in the kitchen and water was sloshing over the edge of the balcony, spilling from something above. I moved out from under the light fixtures and held onto a small table. I wanted to put down my tea cup, but there were no stable surfaces. Things were sliding around the floor.

The family of the Metropolitan Opera bass Cesare Siepi is holding a celebration of his life at the Bruno Walter Auditorium on Saturday at 6 p.m. The bass, who sang at the Met from 1950 to 1973, died in July at 87. Speakers are scheduled to include the former Met singer Roberta Peters, Walfredo Toscanini (the conductor's grandson) and Siepi family members.

Fashion mavens aren't born, they're made. Little Edit, the latest shopping destination for the under-7 set, is inside Edit, a designer boutique on the Upper East Side. Stocked with labels like Baby Dior, Marie Chantal, Girl and a Mouse and Maloles, it's an ideal place for fledgling fashionistas to cut their sartorial teeth. Young chefs have garnered attention lately. The group's Web site describes the players' style as "combat-disco" -- but judging from Apparatjik's new tour vehicle, the battles are waged onstage, not on the road.

If you find typing on a computer keyboard difficult or painful, the built-in speech recognition functions of Windows 7 or Mac OS X may make things easier by allowing you to speak simple commands to control and navigate the system by voice. You do need a working microphone (included with most machines these days) and a bit of patience to learn and say the specific commands the computer expects to hear.

It's one thing to learn, at age 42, who your biological father is. It is another thing altogether to learn that that person is Ted Nugent, the guitar-, gun- and far-right-rhetoric-slinging Motor City Madman. A Brooklyn restaurateur and bar owner, Ted Mann, had that experience recently, and the blog Brooklyn Based has now told his remarkable story. "I got to his ranch and he was grilling elk he had shot for me," said Mr. Mann, who owns Cubana Social in Williamsburg and No Name Bar in Greenpoint, among other places. Read it and weep.

TAMPA, Fla. - The effects of the devastation in Japan were felt in Yankees camp Friday morning, when the minor league left-hander Kei Igawa left the complex so he could try to locate his family. Igawa is from Oarai, Ibaraki prefecture, which was ravaged by a tsunami caused by the 8.9-magnitude earthquake, the strongest to strike Japan. According to photographs, Oarai is partly submerged. If Igawa wants to fly home, General Manager Brian Cashman said he could, "no doubt about it."

The controversial National Portrait Gallery exhibition "Hide/Seek" may come to the Brooklyn Museum, the museum's spokeswoman, Sally Williams, said on Friday. The show, which examined gay and lesbian themes in American portraiture, won critical praise when it opened in October but later drew attacks from Republicans and religious conservatives over a video that included an image of ants crawling on a plastic crucifix. In response, the Smithsonian Institution removed the video from the show, prompting accusations of censorship and moving dozens of museums across the country to display the video and other works by the artist, David Wojnarowicz, in protest. "Hide/Seek" closed last month, but now the Brooklyn Museum and the Tacoma Art Museum in Washington State are collaborating to reconstitute it, Rock Hushka, the director of curatorial administration at the Tacoma museum, said. Mr. Hushka said that the planning was on a fast track, with an eye to the exhibition possibly opening in Brooklyn before the end of the year, and eventually going to Tacoma.

Well, there we go. Just what we love about winter testing: After weeks of doomsaying - even from the Mercedes team itself - Michael Schumacher set the fastest time during testing in Barcelona on Friday, and his teammate, Nico Rosberg, set the third-fastest time. Fernando Alonso set the second-fastest time, .3 seconds from Schumacher, and Nick Heidfeld had the fourth fastest time in the Lotus Renault.

Mr. Thingué was one of six city employees honored with Sloan Public Service Awards on Thursday.

Tim Lincecum, the diminutive power pitcher known variously as Seabiscuit, Tiny Tim and, most memorably, the Freak, slid behind the wheel of his silver Mercedes-Benz on a recent afternoon, sipping a Red Bull. His hair, which he hadn't cut since leading the San Francisco Giants to their first World Series in more than 50 years - and didn't intend to cut anytime soon unless his manager, Bruce Bochy, ordered otherwise - was pulled back into a ponytail. A mustache, if the underseeded patch of grass beneath his nose could be called that, had sprouted up during the off-season, giving him the aspect of a teenager trying to avoid getting carded.

Hospitals that buy surgical robots end up performing more prostate cancer operations, suggesting that technology has become a driving force behind decisions about men's cancer care, new research shows.

TOKYO - I looked at my co-workers and then dove for cover. I thought that's what one did during an earthquake. But no matter how I contorted my 6'3" frame, my legs jutted out from under my child-sized desk. The shaking lasted a long time. I prayed it would end, hoped it wouldn't get worse. To calm myself, I thought about my niece and nephew back in Maryland.

AUSTIN, Texas  -- Angry Birds, the wildly popular game for mobile devices that challenges players to sling grumpy birds at complex formations of smirking pigs, has close to 100 million downloads and a flourishing line of merchandise like cute plush toys.

Volume 7 of "Scalped," about South Dakota's fictional Prairie Rose Indian Reservation, arrives at No. 3 on our softcover list this week. The series is about Dashiell Bad Horse, who left the reservation as a teenager and returns as an undercover agent for the F.B.I. The mission is to bring down Lincoln Red Crow, a corrupt casino owner. Twisted family dynamics and assorted conflicting loyalties make it all the harder to accomplish. Volume 6 of the series landed at No. 5 on the softcover list in June.

The conductor Valery Gergiev continues to suffer from exhaustion and has canceled yet another performance at the Metropolitan Opera, the company quoted his manager as saying. Mr. Gergiev missed Wednesday's performance of "Boris Godunov" and was to return for Saturday's matinee. But according to his manager on Friday, the conductor was unable to travel to New York "due to exhaustion." His manager added: " He has been resting in St. Petersburg and will remain at home to recuperate. He has been advised by his doctors not to fly." Pavel Smelkov, who took over for Mr. Gergiev on Wednesday, was assigned to conduct on Saturday, the Met said.

The floods that inundated the city's northern and western suburbs also shut down the Bronx River Parkway on Friday morning. It remained closed near East Gun Hill Road at 11:50 a.m. The Henry Hudson Parkway and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Manhattan were closed for a while, too, but have reopened. The Saw Mill River Parkway in Yonkers -- see below -- wasn't looking so hot, either.

Celebrate the local, and then the universal. That is how the Montreal Symphony Orchestra plans to mark the opening of its new concert hall in September. The orchestra late Thursday announced its inaugural concerts at the hall, which is due for completion this spring and has yet to be named. The opening program, to be performed Sept. 7, 9 and 10, will begin with works by three Québécois composers, Claude Vivier, Gilles Tremblay and Julien Bilodeau, and finish with Beethoven's Symphony No. 9. The orchestra's music director, Kent Nagano, will conduct. He will also lead a children's concert as part of the opening festivities. The Borodin Quartet, the New York Philharmonic and the Mariinsky Orchestra are also scheduled to visit in the opening months.

.[1:50 p.m. | Updated below with an excerpt from a post I did about 24 hours before the quake struck, musing on how humans don't do well with several kinds of risk, including the risk attending rare, but potent earthquakes. Japan is a best case because it has three vital things: wealth, technological skill and sufficiently frequent seismic activity to boost political will to invest against the worst case. The Pacific Northwest has two out of three, which isn't evidently good enough.]

The Chinese government has given Bob Dylan official approval to perform in Beijing, The Associated Press reported. Gehua Live Nation, the concert organizers, said last week that Mr. Dylan would perform at the Workers' Gymnasium in Beijing on April 6 and the Shanghai Grand Stage on April 8, while he is on an Asian and Australian tour. The Ministry of Culture, according to The Associated Press, on Thursday gave a nod for the Beijing concert, but there was no word yet on Shanghai. Neither concert was listed as of Friday morning on Mr. Dylan's Web site. A previously planned visit to China, scheduled for last spring, fell through.

Before she died of breast cancer in 1995 at the age of 53, the garden designer and connoisseur Maggie Keswick Jencks helped lay the groundwork for a network of cancer care centers, now called Maggie's Cancer Caring Centers, that put the patient first. Designed by architects like Zaha Hadid, Frank Gehry and Richard Rogers, the centers (which are mostly in Britain) offer free medical and psychological support in settings that are the antithesis of most hospitals' cold and confusing institutional interiors.

Slugging, if you don't know - and I certainly didn't before reading this great Emily Badger article in Miller-McClune, thanks to commentary on it by Felix Salmon - is a type of commuting practiced by suburbanites in Virginia traveling into Washington. Those without a car wait in an orderly line and are picked up by those with a car who need extra passengers to take the speedy H.O.V. lanes. This has been going on for decades - an unplanned, unpaid, grassroots form of quasi public transportation that seems to benefit everyone. What particularly struck me was that, over time and without (apparently) any meetings or votes, everyone involved adopted a unique slugging etiquette.

Alexander Wang is still flying high from the excitement of his newly opened SoHo flagship store. To keep the momentum going, Wang has introduced an exclusive all-leather collection of some of his favorite styles from the past. "We wanted to create special product for the store that felt very classic and representative of our DNA," he says of the reinvented six best-selling silhouettes - the fishtail parka, tank bra, aviator jacket, trench vest, overall dress and tailored shorts. The skillful deployment of leather, the placement of smooth patched pockets and asymmetrical buckles, and the contour seaming reaffirms the young designer's uncanny eye for subtlety.

The text you're reading right now is set in Georgia, one of the most common typefaces used online. You'll see it on countless other sites. It was released by Microsoft 15 years ago and was designed specifically for the screen by Matthew Carter, a legendary typographer and AIGA medalist. Five years ago, Alice Rawsthorn wrote a comprehensive article in The International Herald Tribune about the development of this face and its popularity. Despite vast developments in display technology and typefaces produced for use on screens since then, Georgia still proves to be so reliable and legible that, chances are, you haven't noticed it.

You know that $9 billion in annual N.F.L. revenue we keep hearing about, that the owners and players are bickering over? Tiki Barber wants some of that. The former New York Giants running back, who quit after the 2006 season, has turned in his unretirement papers. The widespread assumption is that the soon-to-be-36-year-old, whose broadcasting career and marriage have both foundered badly, needs the money. And that's a mercenary motive that makes some people mad, apparently, and some people sad. (If you're John Riggins, age 63, it makes you want to throw on the old leather helmet again.) It also prompts one Mike to ask the other Mike on "Mike and Mike in the Morning," on ESPN Radio, if it's even possible for a football player like Barber to succeed in coming back if his primary motivation is money and not a raging love for the game. Mike (the former football-playing one) expresses doubt, says it would be hard. A coach in the N.F.L., Raheem Morris, who happens to coach Tiki's twin brother, Ronde, says you have to have "the heart and the desire and the fire."

Every April, without exception, white asparagus arrives in markets around Germany with much fanfare. Over the next eight weeks, all sorts of eating spots, from Michelin-starred establishments to office cafeterias, will serve the white stalks, usually boiled and drenched in hollandaise sauce, accompanied by Black Forest ham, schnitzel, scrambled eggs or plain potatoes. And Berlin, surrounded by Germany's largest single asparagus-growing region, is not immune to the cult-like excitement.

This week's magazine column is a contemporary chicken dinner that doesn't waste a single part of the bird, at least the way most birds are packed. (It's best to make if you start with a whole chicken, one you take apart yourself: video here.) I make good stock in which I braise thighs and vegetables; on those I roast the breasts; and, for a snack, or salad, I make crispy chicken-skin croutons. I had two inspirations for the piece, both recipes from Minimalist columns I wrote years ago.

"Welcome home," the guitarist Warren Haynes said on Thursday night, not far into the first show of the Allman Brothers Band's 13-night stand at the Beacon. And that was the only direct reference to recent derailments: the fact that the band had to move elsewhere last year on its visit to New York, breaking a 20-year ritual for its annual string of gigs that have become the band's most important live shows, or that Gregg Allman, the keyboardist and principal singer, now 63, had undergone a liver transplant nine months ago. (The band's 2010 concerts took place instead at the United Palace Theater in Washington Heights, after Cirque du Soleil had booked the Beacon through the spring.)

Lil B first hit in 2006, at 16, when his group the Pack and its song "Vans" lionized the eponymous skate shoe that had, until then, most definitely not been associated with hip-hop style. (The song was unsponsored, akin to what Run D.M.C. did in the '80s with their song "My Adidas.") As a solo artist, the Bay Area rapper has continued against the grain. Last year's album "Rain in England" melded ambient with rap, perhaps for the first time. A collaborative track with the goth-y Chicago/Michigan trio Salem in late 2010 demonstrated refreshing cross-genre (or subgenre) knowledge. Without being politically correct, Lil B is adept at playing clever word games to undermine some of the negative tropes inherent to hip-hop; his trademark boast - the constantly recycled lyric "I'm a pretty bitch" - uses egotism to unravel misogyny. In three years he has posted enough clips to his YouTube page - more than 240 songs, videos, remixes, video remakes and rambling commentaries - to create something of a canon. Those who explore it tend to grow obsessed.

The critically acclaimed Broadway musical ''American Idiot,'' which used songs by the punk rock band Green Day for a story about disillusionment among the nation's youth during George W. Bush's presidency, will close on April 24 after 27 preview performances and 421 regular performances, the producers announced on Thursday. The final three weeks of the show will feature an encore performance by Billie Joe Armstrong, Green Day's lead singer and guitarist, as the character St. Jimmy, an impish but malevolent specter who enables the main character Johnny in his worsening drug addiction. He will play April 5 through 24.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about President Obama's plans to nominate Gary F. Locke, the commerce secretary, to be ambassador to China misidentified, in some editions, the location where the current ambassador served as a Mormon missionary. And a correction in this space on Wednesday misstated the ambassador's middle initial. Ambassador Jon M. Huntsman Jr. (not Jon H.) was a missionary in Taiwan, not in China.

The first homicide investigation began with a question to Cain - ''Where is Abel, thy brother?'' - and for thousands of years, confessions and witness testimony were the only ways to overcome the scarcity of physical evidence tying criminals to their crimes. Sure, horse thieves were sometimes found atop other peoples' horses, and stains of gunpowder were sometimes found on murderers' hands. But for much of history, it was the rare burglary scene that presented detectives with a muddy shoe print from a thief with extra-wide feet and singular marking on his soles.

Zenyatta, the 2010 horse of the year, is in foal, according to Zenyatta.com, the Web site run by her racing manager, Dottie Ingordo Shirreffs. The sire is the 2006 3-year-old champion Bernardini, a son of the successful sire A.P. Indy. It was horse racing's second high-profile baby announcement this week: Rachel Alexandra, the 2009 horse of the year, is in foal after breeding with the two-time horse of the year Curlin.

The Donmar Warehouse, the well-known London theater, has a new artistic director. Josie Rourke will take up the position on January 1, 2012, taking over for Michael Grandage who will step down at the end of this year after a decade in the role, the theater announced on Thursday. Ms. Rourke's appointment represents a return to the Donmar; she trained in the company's Resident Assistant Director program in 2000 - working alongside Mr. Grandage, Nicholas Hytner, Phyllida Lloyd and Sam Mendes. Her directing work for the Donmar has included ''Frame 312,'' ''World Music'' and ''The Cryptogram.'' ''Nothing could make me more proud than to return to the place where I began,'' Ms. Rourke said in a statement, adding that she will inherit her predecessors' ''legacy of 20 years of wonderful productions, extraordinary performances and great nights out at the theater.''

Owen Laster, one of the most powerful literary agents of his generation, who ran William Morris's worldwide literary operations and had a long list of best-selling writers that included James A. Michener and Gore Vidal, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72. The cause was cancer, Sally Hudson, a niece, said.

10:11 p.m. | Updated The American International Group offered on Thursday to pay $15.7 billion to buy back mortgage securities held in an investment fund set up as part of its huge government bailout.

Brooklyn Heights, the brownstone and red-brick bastion of families new and old, has seen a crime spree of sorts: four burglaries in the past five days. But none of the burglaries came from a forced entry, a broken window. Instead, the burglars simply let themselves in through windows, or doors that residents, perhaps overly confident, had left open. Police officers from the 84th Precinct alerted the executive director of the Brooklyn Heights Association about the burglaries, and the director, Judy Stanton, sent out an e-mail to 1,200 neighbors on Thursday morning. ''This neighborhood is so safe, but not everybody puts on their city smarts and remembers to do the common sense thing and lock their doors,'' she said. Not everybody thought they had to -- until Thursday.

St. Patrick's day Parade (Thursday) The route of the St. Patrick's Day Parade up Fifth Avenue may be shorter this year -- it will now end at 79th Street instead of 86th -- but the annual procession, which marks its 250th anniversary this year, remains long on spirit and enthusiastic viewers (the crowd from last year's parade, above). It officially steps off at 11 a.m. at 44th Street, with the author Mary Higgins Clark as grand marshal, but there is always a lot of preparade pomp and drama along the side streets to satisfy those who arrive early. Other celebrations of Irish pride can be found well before St. Patrick's Day and beyond Fifth Avenue, with walking tours of historic Irish communities in Midtown and Lower Manhattan, an exhibition at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts and several performances of Irish music; check the Spare Times, For Children and Pop listings. As for what to wear, a smile always looks good on St. Patrick's Day (and you thought the answer was something green). Erin go bragh! (Anne Mancuso)

The rap artist 50 Cent has made a donation to charity after revelations that he performed for the clan of Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Reuters reported on Thursday. ''In light of the ongoing events in Libya, 50 Cent will be making a donation to UNICEF, which is providing vital relief supplies to meet the needs of women and children at risk during this crisis,'' a spokesman for the artist told E! News. The rapper, whose real name is Curtis Jackson, joined what one entertainment Web site called the ''Qaddafi performance regret club'' - pop stars who sometimes earned seven-figure sums performing for members of Qaddafi's family at exclusive parties around the world. These include Beyonce, Nelly Furtado, Mariah Carey and Usher, all of whom have issued statements saying they would donate or had already given money to charities. The appearances have become a major source of embarrassment since the Libyan leader's brutal response to a popular uprising against him in Libya. 50 Cent earned an undisclosed amount from a private concert during the 2005 Venice film festival. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Updated 6:57 p.m. | A Brooklyn high school student attacked a classmate with hydrochloric acid Wednesday morning during a chemistry lesson, telling the authorities that she was trying to burn the classmate's eyes out, officials said. Zhanna Smsarian, 16, was arraigned in Brooklyn Criminal Court on Thursday on charges that include first-degree attempted assault. Prosecutors said that she poured acid on Albina Eshimbaeva's head during a class at Fort Hamilton High School in Bay Ridge. Ms. Eshimbaeva, 15, was taken to Staten Island University Hospital, where she was treated and released from the burn unit.

BIRD LOVERS Who would have guessed that a mobile game based on a group of malcontent birds and sinister pigs could become such a lucrative franchise? Rovio Mobile, the Finnish game company behind Angry Birds, has raised $42 million in a financing round led by the venture capital firms Accel Partners and Atomico Ventures. Felicis Ventures also participated in the round. The game, which had its debut on iPhones in late 2009, now claims 40 million active users and has become a full-fledged entertainment franchise. EVELYN M. RUSLI

Social science was right: Eric Clapton raised $2.15 million at a New York auction of 75 guitars and 55 amplifiers on Wednesday, more than triple the pre-sale expectations, Reuters reported on Thursday. The proceeds from the sale at Bonhams - at which every lot sold -- will go to the 65-year-old rock star's Crossroads Center drug and alcohol treatment facility in the Caribbean. The auction - the proceeds of which totaled around $1.8 million without the buyer's premium - also included instruments donated by Mr. Clapton's musician friends Jeff Beck, J.J. Cale and Joe Bonamassa. Among the top lots was a 1948 Gibson L-5P, which was expected to bring $20,000 to $30,000 but raised $82,960; a 2005 Zemaitis S22BP 3S, estimated at $12,000 to $18,000, which sold for $75,640; and a pair of 1997 Fender Twin Amps, estimated at $9,000 to $12,000, which sold for $42,700. A team of Yale University psychologists studying people's desire to own things once possessed by famous people recently concluded that ''celebrity contagion'' was the most important factor in such purchases. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A federal bankruptcy judge on Thursday approved the sale of the ailing movie rental chain Blockbuster after a marathon day of negotiations among its many creditors, allowing the business to avoid liquidation. A patchwork of parties, including hedge funds, small unsecured businesses, major Hollywood movie studios and the investor Carl C. Icahn, found common ground on the terms of a sale after a day of debate.

Charlie Sheen escalated his war with the creator of his hit comedy ''Two and a Half Men'' and the studio that produces it by filing a suit Thursday demanding more than $100 million in damages for first halting production on episodes planned for this season and then removing him from the show. The suit, which was obtained and posted by the celebrity gossip Web site TMZ, is in response to the decision this week by the studio, Warner Brothers, to fire Mr. Sheen from the comedy, citing both his behavior, which has included drug use and accusations of violence toward women, and his comments about the show's creator, Chuck Lorre, and studio executives.

Contributions in his name may be made to Doctors Without Borders. He was a gentleman whose humanity touched many.

(Current TV) BAR KARMA An interactive feature on the Web site for this show offers viewers a chance to help shape the stories they will watch -- with a chance to win a six-month gig at the network. Here is what the audience has helped create (so far): The billionaire Doug Jones (Matthew Humphreys) has won a bet and become the owner of a special bar where he ends up working with a 20,000-year-old bartender named James Anon (William Sanderson, above) and a waitress, Dayna Rollins (Cassie Howarth). Every episode brings in one customer who is at a crossroads in his or her life. And like the Ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Future the employees help the patron come to a realization. In this episode, Charlie O'Connell (''The Bachelor'') is a football player from the 1960s who is torn between two women. 5:30 P.M. (CNBC) MONEY IN MOTION CURRENCY TRADING Melissa Lee hosts this series premiere about currency trading from the Nasdaq MarketSite in Times Square.

GRANT--Alexander Maxwell, of Briarcliff Manor, New York, died suddenly and tragically at the age of 19, this past weekend. Born in Lake Forrest, Illinois, to Kenneth and Deanna Grant, Alexander graduated with high honors from Briarcliff Manor High School in 2009, and was a member of the Tri-M Musical honors society. His research won him the regional prize for Mathematics in the nationwide Intel Science and Talent Search. Alexander was a sophomore in the honors program at Boston College at the time of his death, was a founding member of the University's first fraternity, Sigma Phi Epsilon, and was recently nominated for induction into the Golden Key National Honors society. Alexander had also worked as a valued member of the team, for the last three years as an intern at Risk Resources, LLC, a financial advisory boutique in New York City. Alexander was particularly noted for his wit and compassion, having engaged in a wide variety of philanthropic activities, including City Meals on Wheels, the Robin Hood Foundation, Doctors Without Borders, and the Friends of the Rockefeller State Park Preserve. A talented keyboardist, he and his band, the Jays, performed in venues in and around New York City, and were particularly engaged in raising funds for cancer research on behalf of his friend Demitri Demeropoulos, who preceded him in death. In addition to his heartbroken parents, Alex is survived by his sister, Brianna Elizabeth Grant, his grandparents, William and Betty Oecshle, Phyllis Warsaw and Stuart Grant, aunts, uncles, cousins and a legion of friends. The family is accepting donations in Alexander's name, through the Alexander Maxwell Grant Foundation, which will fund musical scholarships for talented and underprivileged young musicians. Those wishing to contribute should contact Gina Gill, at Risk Resources, LLC, 646-840-4961. Blessed is he whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered (A Psalm of David). The family will receive family and friends at the Beecher Funeral Home, Inc., in Pleasantville, today, Friday from 49pm. A Jewish Service will take place at 4:30pm at Beecher Funeral Home on Friday. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday at 10am at St. Theresa's R.C. Church in Briarcliff Manor. Burial will follow at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery.

FRIULI--Frank A.,on March 7, 2011. Beloved son of the late Ilario and Josephine (Christopher) Friuli and adoring nephew of his Aunt Edna Christopher. Frank was predeceased by his devoted long-time companion Gilbert E. Page with whom he shared a 40 year loving relationship. Frank was a true and faithful friend and admirer of the late great opera soprano Renata Tebaldi with whom he maintained a close friendship from the moment of her New York debut in 1955 until her death in 2004. The beauty of her singing was the source of great emotional ecstasy for him. Frank leaves behind thousands of wonderful and dedicated students with whom he came in contact during a thirty-three year exhilarating teaching career and for whom he worked tirelessly. KRIFTCHER--Dr. Noel N. After a valiant battle against brain cancer, died at home surrounded by his family on March 10, 2011. He was the beloved husband of Bernadette; father of Eric, Brian, and Dana; father-in-law of Jeannie, Phil, and Betsy; G-Pa of Zachary, Paige, Ryan, Hannah, Charlotte, Sophie, Colette, Sydney, Mackenzie, and Gabrielle. Brother to Phyllis; brother-in-law to Fred, John, and Dan; dear uncle, cousin, colleague, and friend. Born in Brooklyn to Rose and Irving, he attended Samuel J. Tilden High School; and then attended New York University. He later earned a Doctorate in Education from Hofstra University. With nearly 40 years of dedicated service to the children of New York City he rose through the ranks of the public education system from high school English teacher to Principal, and ultimately to Superintendent of the Brooklyn and Staten Island high schools. While serving as Principal of Seward Park High School in Manhattan, he was a central figure in Samuel Freedman's book "Small Victories," which has become a cornerstone in graduate studies in education. As founding Director of the David Packard Center for Technology & Educational Alliances at the Polytechnic Institute of New York University for the 14 years prior to his illness, he developed programs to ensure equity of availability, opportunity, and access for women and underrepresented minorities in the use of computers and information-age technology, and in the study of mathematics and science. The consummate educator, he found "teachable moments" in nearly every circumstance of life. He was committed to diversity, and led by example in championing equal educational opportunities for all. A powerful force among all those who knew him, he was devoted to his family, his faith and his profession. He was a man of extraordinary intellect and energy a prolific reader and writer, an erudite speaker, a quick wit. He appreciated all culture, traveled the globe with Bernadette, and frequented opera, museums, theater, and ballet. An avid athlete and fan, he was passionate about golf which he played all over the world; loved the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Football Giants; and passed his lifelong love for basketball and other sports onto his children and grandchildren. He never quite did get past the pain of Bobby Thompson's home run, however. Immensely proud, protective and faithful to his Jewish heritage, he was an active member of The East 55th Street Conservative Synagogue on whose board he served for many years; and supported the Anti-Defamation League; Maccabi USA/Sports for Israel; and countless other organizations. Service 10am, Friday, March 11th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, New York City. Interment at Montefiore Cemetery, 121-83 Springfield Boulevard, St. Albans, Queens. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Dr. Noel N. Kriftcher Scholarship Fund; the Pediatric Cancer Foundation; and the Brain Tumor Center at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

After Elissa Gootman's article on the Upper Breast Side's fight with a condominium board was published on Thursday morning on NYTimes.com, more than 100 readers shared their comments. Here are a few: I'm all in favor of the rights of breast-feeding mothers, but this is ridiculous. It's obviously a store, in an area that doesn't allow stores. Trying to frame this as some kind of tear-jerky discrimination against lactating mothers is a whine and a stretch. Josh Hill, New London, Conn. I would probably agree with Josh Hill et al. if I were reading this article with no experience of the place. But he's flat wrong. As a new mother, I took the subway an hour to this place because it was the only place where the women will teach you which breast pumps are out there and show you how to use them (you literally pump in the store!), diagnose your mastitis/engorgement, help with your baby's latch and generally make it possible to feed your baby and keep your health intact.

What is it about rock stars and their hair? Since the Strokes burst onto the scene in 2001, reinvigorating rock 'n' roll with an injection of garage rawness, they've spawned as many imitators of their style as of their sound. (Their new album, "Angles," is a welcome return to their signature muddy riffs and aloof vocals.) And even more than their perfect leather jackets and smoking hot girlfriends, their artfully undone manes scream rock hero status. Virtual hairdo deities, the band has no doubt inspired more than a few makeovers in its time. As evidenced by the photographs here, the five musicians have very different relationships with scissors. But all share the same D.I.Y. (or don't do much at all) attitude. There was no primping on set. In fact, they barely looked at themselves. "I don't cut it. I don't wash it," says Nick Valensi, one of the band's guitarists, about his sexy shag. "It looks weird when it's clean, so I only shampoo it about 10 times a year." Instead, he squeezes fresh lemons onto his scalp. "I like to think it helps with the pH balance."

Mark Tansey's 1981 painting ''The Innocent Eye Test,'' a crisply realistic rendering of a bunch of experts showing a live cow a crisply realistic portrait of a couple of other cows, has long been seen as a hilarious send-up of the art world. But the painting is now the subject of an art-world dispute that has none of the combatants amused. A British collector who lives in Monaco, Robert Wylde, filed suit Thursday in federal court in Manhattan against the Gagosian Gallery, contending that the gallery sold the painting to Mr. Wylde in 2009 without telling him that the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where the work had once been on display, already owned 31 percent of it and had been promised by its longtime owners that the museum would eventually get the whole thing.

What was scariest was to look up at the skyscrapers all around. They were swaying like trees in the breeze. WILLIAM M. TSUTSUI, a professor at Southern Methodist Univeristy, who was in Tokyo when the earthquake hit. [A8]

There is an adage among actors: never work with children or animals - they inevitably steal the show. For theater publicists seeking to promote their productions, there should be an addendum: never seat a journalist next to Hugh Jackman. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Spring Theater Gala in Fort Greene on Thursday night, there were many notable things: Guests as diverse as David Hyde Pierce and David M. Steiner, New York State's education commissioner, were served on stage at the Howard Gilman Opera House, under a fanciful awning of paper and colored lights. But to the guests at Mr. Jackman's end of a long banquet table - dowagers transformed into tweens at a Justin Bieber concert by his presence - the actor eclipsed the scene with the heat of a thousand suns.

A man whom some might call a dentist to the stars can - er - smile easy after a judge ruled this week that he can essentially go forward with his business for now. In the ruling in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Judge P. Kevin Castel said that GO SMiLE, a teeth whitening company, did not prove it was likely that consumers would confuse their company with a new one started by the celebrity Upper East Side dentist Dr. Jonathan B. Levine.

The controversial National Portrait Gallery exhibition ''Hide/Seek'' may come to the Brooklyn Museum, the museum's spokeswoman, Sally Williams, said on Friday. The show, which examined gay and lesbian themes in American portraiture, won critical praise when it opened in October but later drew attacks from Republicans and religious conservatives over a video that included an image of ants crawling on a plastic crucifix. In response, the Smithsonian Institution removed the video from the show, prompting accusations of censorship and moving dozens of museums across the country to display the video and other works by the artist, David Wojnarowicz, in protest. ''Hide/Seek'' closed last month, but now the Brooklyn Museum and the Tacoma Art Museum in Washington State are collaborating to reconstitute it, Rock Hushka, the director of curatorial administration at the Tacoma museum, said. Mr. Hushka said that the planning was on a fast track, with an eye to the exhibition possibly opening in Brooklyn before the end of the year, and eventually going to Tacoma. Asked if the Wojnarowicz video would be included, Mr. Hushka and Ms. Williams both said yes. ''We are very keen on making sure that we represent the National Portrait Gallery's presentation as fully as possible,'' Mr. Hushka said.

Both the chairman and chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee were named to two influential commissions of the International Olympic Committee on Friday, a development that indicates their efforts to rebuild relationships with the international body are paying off. Larry Probst, the chairman of the U.S.O.C., was named to the international relations commission, and Scott Blackmun, the chief executive, was named to the marketing commission.

In light of how long it can take to close a refinancing or mortgage these days -- especially considering how many paper documents are involved in the process and could potentially get lost, delaying the process further -- we wondered whether a mortgage cloud of sorts exists at any banks. Specifically, we wondered why banks don't just scan all mortgage documents the minute they get them and then put them into an internal cloud of sorts that any employee could get access to. That would also help prevent lost documents. To find out, we checked with Chase and Bank of America.

An essay on Page 11 this weekend, about how the media reports on itself, refers incorrectly to a reporter who live-blogged a radio show on which the writer, Bill Keller, appeared. The reporter, Zeke Turner, is a man.

SILVERMAN--Henry King. Darling Hank, you have been our guiding light and shining star. You taught us honor, respect, fairness and compassion. Your world revolved around your Steven, Randie, Matt, Jarett, Jenny, Brigid-Ann and recently the joy of a great-grandson, Andrew. No one was more adored than you, my sweetheart of a lifetime. Now your heroic struggle is over and your legacy lives on. Nan (Your Hon)

MAGAZINE The cover article on Page 26 this weekend profiles the Baylor basketball player Perry Jones III and cites him as an example of a player who might jump to the N.B.A. after one college season. After the article had gone to press, Jones was declared ineligible by the N.C.A.A. for the beginning of the Big 12 tournament, for ''pre-enrollment amateurism'' and ''preferential treatment violation'' having to do with three loans from Jones's A.A.U. coach to his mother, which were said to have been repaid in a ''timely'' manner. Baylor is contesting the N.C.A.A. decision and is seeking to have Jones's eligibility restored. For developments on his status, check the magazine's blog, The 6th Floor, at nytimes.com/magazine or reports at nytimes.com/sports.

The fruits of Madison Square Garden's three-year renovation will be apparent to Knicks and Rangers fans next season - and so will the prices they will pay for tickets. Knicks season tickets will jump an average 49 percent and the Rangers' will go up by 23 percent.

Celebrate the local, and then the universal. That is how the Montreal Symphony Orchestra plans to mark the opening of its new concert hall in September. The orchestra late Thursday announced its inaugural concerts at the hall, which is due for completion this spring and has yet to be named. The opening program, to be performed Sept. 7, 9 and 10, will begin with works by three Quebecois composers, Claude Vivier, Gilles Tremblay and Julien Bilodeau, and finish with Beethoven's Symphony No. 9. The orchestra's music director, Kent Nagano, will conduct. He will also lead a children's concert as part of the opening festivities. The Borodin Quartet, the New York Philharmonic and the Mariinsky Orchestra are also scheduled to visit in the opening months. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MEZZACAPPA--Elizabeth, of New York, Southampton, and Palm Beach, FL., died of cancer on March 10, 2011. Born Elizabeth Margaret Kurts in Melbourne, Australia, she was 67 years old at the time of her death. Liz was a remarkable spirit, an accomplished gardener, avid golfer and dog lover. She is survived by her husband Damon, her brother Michael Kurts, step-children Jonathan, Jessica and Benjamin Mezzacappa, step-grandchildren Lily and Damon Friedberg, nieces Sophie Grant, Chloe Coates and Emily Kurts, grandnephews Rupert Grant, Angus Grant and grand niece Poppy Coates. In lieu of flowers, those wishing to may make a donation to the Central Park Conservancy.

WASHINGTON - With the union dissolving itself Friday and owners in position to lock players out, the N.F.L. has embarked on its first work stoppage since the players strike in 1987. Prepare for an off-season with no activity on the field, but plenty of news from courtrooms. Here's a rundown of what a lockout means:Q.What happens to free agency? A.Forget it. There is no free agency during a lockout and no player trades. The N.F.L. prefers not to impose work rules, which means paying players while being sued by them, but the courts may force them to and that would start free agency.

COPLAN--Joyce. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Joyce Coplan and extend sincerest condolences to her family. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and President Kenneth Heitner, Central Synagogue of New York City

A picture caption on Tuesday with the continuation of the 18 & Under column, about the spectrum of hand dominance and brain asymmetry, referred incorrectly to President Gerald R. Ford, who was shown writing while seated at a desk. While Mr. Ford was usually cited as being left-handed, he wrote in his autobiography that he used his right hand when standing; he was not ''fully left-handed.''

STILES--Danny, 87, died on Friday, March 11, 2011 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, New York City. Born in Newark, NJ; resided in Short Hills for the last 40 years. He served proudly in the US Navy during WWII. Graduated from NYU with his Bachelors Degree. He was a radio personality for 64 years in New York radio stations including WNYC, WPAT (WNSW), WEVD and WVNJ. He was a member of the Masons and a member of AFTRA. Beloved husband of the late Barbara Borinsky Stiles. Devoted father of Leonard Russell, Howard Russell and his wife Laura, and Gary Russell. Dear brother of Joseph Silberg and the late Milton and Morris Silberg. Loving and proud grandfather of Alexandra, Blake, and Barbara. Services will be conducted from Temple B'Nai Jershurn, 1025 South Orange Ave., South Orange, NJ on Sunday, March 13, 2011 at 1:30pm. Interment: Beth David Cemetery, Kenilworth, NJ.

The Chinese government has given Bob Dylan official approval to perform in Beijing, The Associated Press reported. Gehua Live Nation, the concert organizers, said last week that Mr. Dylan would perform at the Workers' Gymnasium in Beijing on April 6 and the Shanghai Grand Stage on April 8, while he is on an Asian and Australian tour. The Ministry of Culture, according to The Associated Press, on Thursday gave a nod for the Beijing concert, but there was no word yet on Shanghai. Neither concert was listed as of Friday morning on Mr. Dylan's Web site. A previously planned visit to China, scheduled for last spring, fell through. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article last Saturday about the rise of the Tunisian swimmer Ous Mellouli in international competition misstated the educational background of Mohamed Bouazizi, the food vendor whose self-immolation was the catalyst for the protest movement in Tunisia, which Mr. Mellouli said he followed on Facebook and Twitter anytime he was not competing or training. While Mr. Bouazizi was widely reported to be a college graduate, like Mr. Mellouli, family members said later that Mr. Bouazizi did not have a university degree.

Mudd, the former chief executive of Fannie Mae, may soon face civil charges stemming from his tenure at the mortgage finance giant, according to a person briefed on the matter who was not authorized to speak publicly. The Securities and Exchange Commission sent Mr. Mudd a so-called Wells notice, this person confirmed, an indication the agency is considering an enforcement action against him

With their political status still unclear back in their homeland, members of the Belarus Free Theater will be returning to New York next month for a five-week stay at La MaMa, which, along with the Public Theater, has offered the group an ''artistic residency'' as a gesture of solidarity. Beginning April 13, the troupe (members above, from left: Natalia Kolyada, Vladimir Shcherban, Nikolai Khalezin and Artsem Zhaliazniak), which fled Belarus in December during a crackdown by the country's authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, will perform three of its original works. They include the New York premiere of ''Discover Love,'' a meditation on marriage and political repression. Rounding out the program are ''Being Harold Pinter'' and ''Zone of Silence,'' both of which were critically praised when performed at the Public Theater's Under the Radar Festival in January.

An article on Thursday about the narrow victory by St. John's over Rutgers at the Big East men's basketball tournament misstated the given name of an official who was among the three criticized for missing two late calls that would have given Rutgers possession of the ball and a chance to tie or win the game. He is Earl Walton, not Carl.

12:15 P.M. (Cinemax) TWELVE MONKEYS (1995) From a present overcome by disaster and disease, James Cole (Bruce Willis, above, with Madeleine Stowe) is sent into the past so that scientists can learn how the virus responsible for ravaging the population originated. But once back in time, before the plague has struck, James is considered a lunatic and begins to fear for his sanity. Dr. Kathryn Railly (Ms. Stowe), a psychiatrist in the mental hospital where he has been committed, starts to take his dire predictions for humanity seriously. Janet Maslin, writing in The New York Times, found the movie ''fierce and disturbing, with a plot that skillfully resists following any familiar course.'' 6 P.M. (HBO) THE BOX (2009) Working from a short story by the fantasy writer Richard Matheson, the director Richard Kelly (''Donnie Darko'') has written and directed what Manohla Dargis described in her review in The Times as a ''sincere and sinister and inevitably ambitious'' film that asks questions about the human condition. It is 1976, and a couple short of cash receive an offer: push a button on a curious box and receive a million dollars. There is one pesky problem: in doing so, they will murder someone. Cameron Diaz and James Marsden play the couple to whom a mysterious man (Frank Langella) proposes the deal. In the end, Ms. Dargis said, ''Mr. Kelly is so busy sampling genres and confusing the issue'' that he ''often seems as lost as his characters, trapped in a Pandora's box of his own making.''

The State of the Art column on Thursday, about the new Apple iPad 2, erroneously included a quotation from Bloomberg News in a string of excerpts from negative reviews of the first iPad. That quotation referred to the iPhone, not the iPad. The column also misstated, in some editions, the resolution of the iPad 2 still camera. It is 0.7 megapixels, not 5 megapixels.

Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com. By now you have probably heard about the growingevidence that ''dumb money'' is entering the market. The dumb money is not my term, by the way; it's how Wall Street refers to individual investors who repeatedly sell stocks at a low price, only to turn around later and buy them for high prices.

Updated, 4:57 p.m. | The criminal case has been dropped against a 19-year-old Brooklyn woman who had faced up to two years in prison on charges of killing her little brother's hamster, after family members who witnessed the animal's death recanted their accounts, the authorities said. ''The family members that were witnesses to this are not really supporting the story that she purposely killed the hamster,'' said a law enforcement official.

When people were seeking to contribute money after the earthquake in Haiti last year, the Red Cross offered a simple solution: text-message the word "Haiti" to 90999. That's when it became clear to many that text-messaging could work for commerce.

It was a rough week for the Broadway musical "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark." The producers announced on Wednesday that the director Julie Taymor was stepping aside from the now $70 million production. On Friday, they announced that about three weeks of performances, from April 19 through May 11, would be canceled to provide time for their newly hired creative team to rehearse "significant and exciting revisions" to the show. They also picked a new date, June 14, for their opening night, which has now been delayed six times.

The earthquake hit in the early afternoon off the coast of Honshu, Japan's most populous island, triggering unprecedented destruction. Ninety percent of the houses in a score of seaside towns collapsed in seconds. Passenger trains fell off railway bridges and plunged into the sea. A few minutes later, a 35-foot-high tsunami rolled in, sweeping away cars, houses and thousands of people, and burying entire towns in mud. Then came fires, fanned by winds and fueled by flimsy wooden houses, reducing much of what remained to ashes.

AUSTIN, Tex. - Danny DeVito's career has taken him a tremendous number of places, with varied roles on stage, screen and television. He can add another to his résumé: YouTube. That is where his latest film, "Girl Walks into a Bar," now resides. The film, directed by Sebastian Gutierrez, had its premiere on Friday at SXSW and on YouTube. It features Carla Gugino as the titular girl and connects several stories that take place in 10 bars around Los Angeles. Mr. DeVito plays a character in one of those bars, and he took a moment to talk about working on a film made for the Internet and his attempt, generally, to avoid Italian-American gangster roles.

Selection Sunday is here - the day that we have all been waiting for. Joe Lunardi, the apparent "bracketology" guru, has generously provided us all a foundation of expectations. Everyone has been blogging and dropping Twitter bombs from the sky with their own opinions and predictions. The analysts are matching tournament resumes and trying to determine who deserves to be in and who deserves to be out, calculating R.P.I.'s and often using simply the transitive property - If we beat North Carolina, and North Carolina beat Duke, then clearly we are a No. 1 seed. That would be nice.

Administrivial Update: Earlier, I touched on dropping in to visit the goings-on at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, taking place this Friday, March 18 through Sunday, March 20. I'd like to elaborate on that: Drop-ins are welcomed Sunday morning starting at 11:00 AM. There is a crossword contestants' talent show from 11:00-Noon. Then the playoffs are held (division C, B and A) and the awards are handed out. The whole event is over by about 1:30. The cost for this is $30, which includes copies of all the tournament puzzles over the weekend. People should register ahead of time, if possible. The registration form is here: http://www.crosswordtournament.com/info/onlinereg.htmIt is also still possible for people to register for the tournament. Registration is accepted at the door on Friday up to 8 P.M. as well as on Saturday morning between 9:30-11:00 A.M. Full information about the tournament, including bios and photos of this year's constructors, appears at www.crosswordtournament.com.

Some may think maple-syrup-making can only happen in Vermont or Canada. But if last year's little experiment sugaring in Brooklyn proved anything, it was that fine maple syrup could be made in New York City as well. I recently located a healthy sugar maple in the Stapleton section of Staten Island, and although it was already a little late in the season, I set up shop, hoping for a good run. Temperatures have to be just right for quality sap flow: more than 40 degrees in the daytime, dipping to freezing at night.

Three weeks ago, Arsenal, coming off a thrilling first-leg win over Barcelona in the Champions League, was dreaming of winning as many as four trophies this season. A succession of painful defeats has reduced that number to one, and the team's reservoir of confidence to almost zero.

Top dealers in vintage clothing and knickknacks, from France and elsewhere in Europe, show up annually in Paris to sell their unusual, often one-of-a-kind items at the trendy Salon du Vintage. Running from March 18 to 20, this year's show will feature 60 exhibitors offering everything from street clothes and sportswear to evening finery -- plus the shoes, scarves, jewelry and hats to go with them. And although nostalgia is the theme, eras from the 1930s to the '90s will be represented.

I have long enjoyed the magazine as the must-read component of your increasingly expensive publication. The Feb. 27 issue, however, was for me a barrage of bad news. First I read that this column would be Randy Cohen's last as the Ethicist. Cohen's elegant, understated responses to ethical quandaries were the first words I read in each edition of the magazine, and I am already wondering how Sundays will be the same without his work. Next I read that this would be the final column for Virginia Heffernan and The Medium. As the Internet becomes an ever-more integral part of our lives -- my wife and I often ask each other as we look up a recipe or bit of trivia, ''What did we do before the Internet?'' -- it would seem that such a column would be indispensable. Finally, and perhaps most troubling for a high-school English teacher and lover of language, was Ben Zimmer's announcement that this would be his final On Language column. Zimmer performed admirably in the unenviable task of replacing William Safire. In this time of rapid changes in the development of language -- the redefinition of what is acceptable, the spectrum of global influences and so on -- a column like this is essential. GLEN M. MARTIN Adamstown, Pa., e-mail

The Sports of The Times column last Sunday, about the Polytechnic Institute of New York University cricket team, which gathered on March 4 to watch the Cricket World Cup together, contained several errors. Sricharan Rangarajan -- not Raugarajan Sricharan -- was one team member who watched the matches. One of his teammates is Dhaval Dharaiya, not Dhaval Charaiya. Ricky Ponting, the captain of Australia's World Cup team is 36, not 39. And the name of the college of Ian Carlin, the former football player who won the John Bart King Award for the best American-born cricket player, is The College of Wooster, not Wooster College.

The first sports work stoppage of the social networking era has left N.F.L. players concerned, confused and a little distracted. But they were chatty and -- at least temporarily -- united. Moments later, Rodgers acknowledged that there were more important things happening in the world than a football labor dispute.
