Last summer, when Bruce Pask, our men's fashion director, returned from the European collections, we sat down to talk about what he had seen on the catwalk. There was a double-breasted jacket that had turned up everywhere. There were superskinny suits, which hadn't looked so good and so right since the photographer Hedi Slimane defined Dior Homme. There were black watches, white bucks, Breton stripes and goofy brights. We talked trend, and then we talked men. We weren't just after clothes with character; we were looking for character. Stephen Heyman found it in Yuri Gagarin, the Soviet cosmonaut whose life is brilliantly rendered in Jamie Doran and Piers Bizony's ''Starman.'' Jacob Brown brought in Rockstar Charlie -- a downtown boxing hopeful -- and a daring Californian who had had seven years of living dangerously in Yemen and the Horn of Africa. The entire team went mad for a pitcher with balletic form and skater hair. And a real skater -- the legendary Erik Ellington -- agreed to don double-breasted Tom Ford under the canny direction of Magnus Unnar and David Vandewal. Finally, Mikael Jansson and Bill Mullen, over a period of months and endless air miles, put the shrunken suit on the men who have earned the right to publicly flaunt their forms forever. (In addition to that noir watch and easy espadrilles, the real must-have for spring 2011? Iggy Pop's abs regimen. Tape the picture on Page 115 to fridge door now.)

An article last Sunday about Pat Summitt's pursuit of a ninth national championship with the Tennessee women's basketball team erroneously attributed a distinction to the team in some editions. Tennessee was one of two teams -- not the only one -- to beat second-ranked Stanford in the regular season. (DePaul was the other team.)

A review on Feb. 27 about ''The Secret Soldier,'' a thriller by Alex Berenson, misstated the location in Cyprus where a thug is tossed into a harbor. It is the village of Zygi, on the southern coast, not Nicosia, which is an inland city.

Once a sleepy residential area, the Milan neighborhood of Isola, which translates as ''island'' (thanks, perhaps, to its once being relatively isolated from the rest of the city), is now attracting its share of artists, designers and young, newly married couples. Along with this shift, a homegrown boutique scene is emerging. Via Pastrengo and Via Pepe, two adjacent Isola streets, look unassuming and quiet but are in fact lined with chic stores tucked into apartment buildings. And since most shops do double duty as workshops for their artisan owners, shoppers can get a close-up view of the creative process behind the goods. SHIVANI VORA
Daylight saving time resumed at 2 a.m. Sunday. Clocks were set ahead one hour.

An obituary last Sunday about the former major league baseball player Greg Goossen paraphrased incorrectly from a comment that the pitcher Jim Bouton made about Goossen in his book ''Ball Four.'' He said Goossen was the only one of a group of players released by the Seattle Pilots early in spring training who interested him -- not the only one of all his Seattle teammates. The obituary also gave the incorrect context for a statement by Howard Megdal in the introduction of his book ''The Baseball Talmud,'' about Jews in major league baseball. When Megdal said, ''I am a baseball expert, not a Judaism expert,'' he was referring to what he called the ''expansive definition of Jewish'' he used to decide who belonged in the book, which included ''a player whose father is Jewish,'' as was Goossen's. Megdal was not answering a question about why he included Goossen, a Roman Catholic, on a list of Jewish first basemen.

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Joshua Foer, author of ''Moonwalking With Einstein''; Frank Bruni on the chef Gabrielle Hamilton's memoir, ''Blood, Bones and Butter''; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-/seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. ExcerptsSelections from ''The Tiger's Wife,'' by Téa Obreht; ''Mr. Chartwell,'' by Rebecca Hunt; and other books.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the choice of whether to intervene in distant conflicts referred incorrectly to Margaret Thatcher's official status in 1992, when she suggested limited airstrikes to help curb Serbian ethnic cleansing in Bosnia. She was a former prime minister of Britain then, not the incumbent.

The fashion shows in Paris last week were a profound change from the theatrics and wild exaggerations of the last two decades that had been spearheaded by British designers, some of whose lives ended in tragedy. The Chanel designer Karl Lagerfeld's presentation in the Grand Palais seemed to capture the upheaval. His set of moldering ruins suggested the immolation of the gods in Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle, as did his Gothic palette. The self-destruction of John Galliano, the design director for Dior, intensified the gloom. But like a phoenix rising out of the ashes, the elegant jewel-toned collection of Haider Ackermann (top row) signaled fashion's new direction. Other houses that showed new creative fire include Balenciaga (on the tile floors, far left); Céline (the fantastic princess-seamed dress on the runway, left); Junya Watanabe (motorcycle jackets, left); Gareth Pugh (metallic coat, right), and Rick Owens (coat and blue dresses, far right).

What is it about rock stars and their hair? Since the Strokes burst onto the scene in 2001, reinvigorating rock 'n' roll with an injection of garage rawness, they've spawned as many imitators of their style as of their sound. (Their new album, ''Angles,'' is a welcome return to their signature muddy riffs and aloof vocals.) And even more than their perfect leather jackets and smoking hot girlfriends, their artfully undone manes scream rock hero status. Virtual hairdo deities, the band has no doubt inspired more than a few makeovers in its time. As evidenced by the photographs here, the five musicians have very different relationships with scissors. But all share the same D.I.Y. (or don't do much at all) attitude. There was no primping on set. In fact, they barely looked at themselves. ''I don't cut it. I don't wash it,'' says Nick Valensi, one of the band's guitarists, about his sexy shag. ''It looks weird when it's clean, so I only shampoo it about 10 times a year.'' Instead, he squeezes fresh lemons onto his scalp. ''I like to think it helps with the pH balance.'' This is typical rock-star hair behavior, according to April Barton, who tends to the tresses of Bono, Elvis Costello and Rufus Wainwright at Suite 303, her buzzy salon in Manhattan's Chelsea Hotel. ''The very purpose of rock hair is to be low maintenance,'' she says. ''The minute my guys leave me, they can go on tour for four months and not think about it.'' Barton, who considers herself the master of the rock cut, has been doing it for 25 years. ''I have a philosophy about it,'' she says. ''It all comes from somewhere. Look, the Stones had that great, greasy texture everyone still tries to copy because they were jamming, having sex, doing drugs and sweating for five days straight.''

THE NEWS Vivian Schiller, the chief executive of NPR, resigned a day after the release of a surreptitious video recording of an NPR executive disparaging Tea Party supporters to people posing as Muslim prospective donors. BEHIND THE NEWS Ms. Schiller condemned the executive's remarks, but said ''the buck stops here'' and expressed hope that her departure would ease pressure on NPR. Attacks against NPR from the right have stepped up sharply in the five months since the commentator Juan Williams was fired for remarks he made about Muslims.

While most top toques in Paris sharpen their knife skills at the city's elite kitchens, Inaki Aizpitarte started his career as a dishwasher in Tel Aviv. Today the Basque-born chef continues to defy convention by tweaking traditional bistro food -- pork belly with licorice root, foie gras with sliced radishes, deconstructed pot au feu -- at Le Chateaubriand, his wildly popular restaurant in a scruffy section of the 11th Arrondissement. Recently, Aizpitarte expanded his empire with Le Dauphin. The chic new spot, designed by Rem Koolhaas, offers small plates with big, big flavors that already have the critics and cool kids raving.

A biographical note on Feb. 27 with an article about mothers-in-law gave an outdated name for the school where the writer, Nancy Davidoff Kelton, teaches writing. It is the New School, no longer New School University.

An article in some editions last Sunday about Fish Tales, a seafood store in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, misstated the ownership history of the shop. John Addis became a partner around 1998 and took over as sole proprietor in 2001. He was not the owner when the shop was opened in 1996. (A relative, Larry Tramontano, and his wife, Elizabeth, founded the business.)

MONROE--Mary Rita, 81, passed away on March 4, 2011. Her inquisitiveness and joy of life will be missed. Wife of the late Dr. Daniel Monroe, she is survived by daughter Brenda Greene and husband Michael of Annandale, VA; daughter Pamela Lowy and husband Sam of Signal Mountain, TN; and two grandchildren, Colin Greene and Megan Rohn. A small memorial gathering will be held in the New York area later this spring.

I RECENTLY spent several days darting around in a piccolini-size portion of Italian automotive cuisine: the Fiat 500 that will soon be served from new American showrooms. And, like the bite of Nonna's gnocchi that it resembles, the minicar came drenched in red sauce -- in this case, a paint job the color of Sunday dinner marinara. If you live in the United States, you may not have seen a 500 -- in Italian, the Cinquecento -- in your neighborhood. The first deliveries, 500 copies of a version called the Prima Edizione, are going out to customers who long ago put down deposits.

The Trend: Leopard lace. The stealth tacky runway trend looks intriguingly elegant in small doses. The Guy: Marcelo Burlon, Milan's reigning fashion multitasker and founder of the famed Pink Is Punk parties.

THE tale of Susie Essman and the red couch in her Upper West Side apartment sounds uncannily like an episode of ''Seinfeld.'' Ms. Essman, who plays the feisty, foul-mouthed Susie Greene on ''Curb Your Enthusiasm'' -- created by Larry David, a co-creator of ''Seinfeld'' -- moved into an apartment at the Straus Park Condominium four years ago.

PFUND--Lydia. Theurer Mikell of Highland Beach, FL. Formerly of Alpine, NJ, on March 8, 2011. Born in Manhattan on June 2, 1919 to Minna and John Theurer, predeceased by her beloved husband Ledyard Hale Pfund. Survived by a much-loved stepson, Ledyard Bruce Pfund, sister-in-law Helena Theurer, nephews and nieces Darryl and Sigrid Novak, Wayne and Jane Novak, Ann Mikell and great- nieces/nephews Margo, Yvonne, Emily, Lars, Mari Kim, Todd and Kate Novak as well as great-greats Woods, Emily, Alexander and Grace, cousins Edith Kleineke, Tony Dorfmueller, Henry Jecker and Rita Bishop as well as cherished friends in Florida and New Jersey. Lydia graduated with BA and MA degrees from Stetson University, where she taught briefly. She was proud to have served in Miami, FL as the founding president of The Vizcayans, membership group of the Dade County Art Museum, as well as first woman community member of the Dade County Hospital Advisory Board. On returning to New York she was active in the manufacturing business, which dated to her grandfather's wagon/carriage business founded in 1888, and which had been brought thoroughly into the 20th century by her beloved brother the late John Theurer, Jr. Devoted to traditional jazz, a member of Knickerbocker Country Club, the Garden Club of Englewood, Delray Beach Club and Norton Museum Docents, she also served on the Board of Governors of Hackensack University Medical Center and its Foundation, and was a life member of the Nature Conservancy and the Owl's Head Transportation Museum in Maine, where she had given two of her husband's prize antique cars. A celebration of Lydia's amazing life will be held on Saturday, March 19 at 10:30am at the Presbyterian Church at Tenafly, 55 Magnolia Ave., Tenafly, NJ. In lieu of flowers, gifts to Hackensack University Medical Center or the Nature Conservancy would be valued.

Lin Gathright: I'm performing in a burlesque show, and so I look at the picture, and it's not Lin Gathright, it's a character I play, Bunny Love. I call it my ''Smoking Number'' because I hold the cigarette in my mouth the entire time, and with the feather boas involved, there's a sense of danger, like, ''Is she going to burn herself?'' Or, ''Is she going to catch on fire?'' And you never see anything until the very end, when I drop the boa and pose in all my glory, there with my glitter-covered nipples and my one feather and let the audience take that in. Then I take the cigarette out of my mouth and flick it at them and walk off. It's kind of mean-spirited, and I always feel a little bad about it after, but I think they love to hate me. Pari Dukovic: I was standing at the side of the stage, and you could feel the crowd's attention while she was doing this act. It's almost like the air got thicker. She was drawing them into her world. I've seen a lot of these shows, and people dance and they do all kinds of things. But she was just walking around like: ''I'm here whether you want it or not. I'm here.''

The Teva, that multistrapped mid-'80s fashion disaster beloved by Deadheads in dreads, is having a moment. Created to keep rubber flip-flops on board while white-water river rafting, the sandal, formerly just functional, has achieved some fashion notoriety. The designer Richard Chai says its carefree attitude and eclectic fans have inspired his quirky urban version, which pairs patent leather with canvas in unusual colors like ultramarine and moss green. Lanvin's take looks like Transformers, with straps crisscrossing every which way. And Tomas Maier at Bottega Veneta took his jewel-toned leather Tevas on a trip, sporting gray dress socks for a high-luxe touristy look. I wouldn't recommend giving those a dunk in the deep end. BRUCE PASK

Tim Lincecum, the diminutive power pitcher known variously as Seabiscuit, Tiny Tim and, most memorably, the Freak, slid behind the wheel of his silver Mercedes-Benz on a recent afternoon, sipping a Red Bull. His hair, which he hadn't cut since leading the San Francisco Giants to their first World Series in more than 50 years - and didn't intend to cut anytime soon unless his manager, Bruce Bochy, ordered otherwise - was pulled back into a ponytail. A mustache, if the underseeded patch of grass beneath his nose could be called that, had sprouted up during the off-season, giving him the aspect of a teenager trying to avoid getting carded. ''That desk manager is really sexy,'' Lincecum's agent, Rick Thurman, who had flown up from Los Angeles for the day, volunteered from the back seat as we emerged from the basement garage of Lincecum's apartment building, a 30-story glass tower in downtown Seattle.

GOULD--Karolyn Richman. 80. I lost her after an abiding wedded bliss of 53 years. I know that loss will be eased by our four children, and their spouses: Sarah Kagan and her husband Stewart, Tom and his wife Maura, Roger and his wife Cathy Wagner, Melinda Konopko and her husband Elliot and our nine grandchildren--Andrew, Joan, Ruth, Leo, Penelope, Aviva, Adam, Charlotte and Oliver. She is also survived by her sister, Barbara Elliot. Funeral will be at Riverside Memorial (76th and Amsterdam) on Sunday, March 13 at 11:45am. Donations: InwoodHouse.com Her beloved husband, Bruce J. Gould

MAGAZINE The cover article on Page 26 this weekend profiles the Baylor basketball player Perry Jones III and cites him as an example of a player who might jump to the N.B.A. after one college season. After the article had gone to press, Jones was declared ineligible by the N.C.A.A. for the beginning of the Big 12 tournament, for ''pre-enrollment amateurism'' and ''preferential treatment violation'' having to do with three loans from Jones's A.A.U. coach to his mother, which were said to have been repaid in a ''timely'' manner. Baylor is contesting the N.C.A.A. decision and is seeking to have Jones's eligibility restored. For developments on his status, check the magazine's blog, The 6th Floor, at nytimes.com/magazine or reports at nytimes.com/sports.

MORGAN--Nancy Luebbe of the Upper West Side, Manhattan, NY, died peacefully on March 2, 2011 at age 78. Daughter of the late Ray H. Luebbe, Sr. and Evelyn H. Luebbe. Prior to retiring in 1993, Nancy was Associate Director of Executive Programs at Columbia Business School, where she worked for most of her professional life. She will be missed her brother, Ray H. Luebbe, Jr., his wife Dorothy; nieces Betsy Garrett, Karen Blamick, Melissa Davis; four grandnieces; and many friends. Please send condolences to: NLM3211@gmail.com

KOCH--Lynn & Lizzie. Very remarkable daughter-sister-wife and mother. We miss you everyday never forgetting your values of humanity & devotion. We remain lost without you. With everlasting love, Paul & LJ

KENTLER--Dorothy Neves, 90, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, sister-in-law, aunt, and friend died peacefully Sunday, March 6, 2011 after a long illness. Born in Hoboken, NJ on December 4, 1920 and raised in Montclair, NJ she was the daughter of the late Agnes Patterson Neves a graduate of the Teachers College, Columbia University and Dr. Charles S. Neves, a Harvard educated physician who served during WW I on the USS Mercy, the first completely equipped hospital ship. She is predeceased by her husband Dr. Charles Joseph Kentler Jr., a 1941 Yale University graduate who worked on the Manhattan Project in Oakridge, TN. Dr. Kentler held a Ph.D. in Chemical Engineering from Cornell University, where he later taught. His career included a long stint with Rockwell International and the founding of his own business, Kentler Skilling International, where he was CEO. Mrs. Kentler is survived by her children Charles Joseph Kentler III of Pittsburg, KS and Carol Kentler Reynolds and husband David Linn Reynolds of Manhattan; her sister Carol P. Neves of Sea Girt, NJ and Palm Beach, FL; her brother-in-law Robert Wells of Sea Girt, NJ; her grandchildren Jack, William, Thomas, and Charles Reynolds; and four nieces and three nephews. Mrs. Kentler was a graduate of the College of Saint Elizabeth, Morristown, NJ. Her early career included work as a junior chemist at Hoffman-La Roche and later as a schoolteacher. She touched many lives while pursuing her multiple passions including gardening, bridge, and home design. As the family relocated around the country, she designed and oversaw the construction of five of her family's homes. Throughout her life, the Spring Lake shore area of New Jersey was a constant source of pleasure.
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel heads to Santarém, Brazil, in the heart of the Amazon (above) and discovers a beach and party scene in the rain forest.

9 P.M. (ABC Family) BEVERLY HILLS CHIHUAHUA 2 In this sequel to the 2008 Disney movie, Chloe (the voice of Odette Annable) and Papi (George Lopez) are married and have five troublesome yet adorable puppies. They are doing well, but the parents of Papi's owner are having financial problems and are worried about losing their home. The Chihuahuas, above, try to come to the rescue by entering a dog show that offers a $50,000 prize. The competitive and snobby French poodle, Appoline (Bridgit Mendler), is not at all concerned about possibly losing to the tiny pups. 7 A.M. GOOD MORNING AMERICA Robin Roberts and the program's medical editor, Dr. Richard Besser, report from Cape Town, South Africa, on the battle against devastating communicable diseases.

SHAROFF--Dr. Jerrold L.,Florida and New York, February 22, 2011. Beloved husband of Helene (Pincus); adored father of Nancy Selikoff (Michael) and Aileen Ganz (David); cherished "POP" of Jeff, Julie, Lauren, and Lisa; devoted brother of Helen Felton. You live in our hearts forever.

''I'm a big ugly son of a bitch,'' says the Chicago artist Tony Fitzpatrick, who's not actually ugly, just a bit imposing -- tattooed, tall, gruff and given to profanity. An art legend in the Windy City, Fitzpatrick has a multidisciplinary bent, although he'd probably never use the word ''multidisciplinary.'' ''I never went to college, so nobody told me I had to do one thing or another,'' says Fitzpatrick, who writes poems (''I could feel the/Murderous rumble/Of my dad's Oldsmobile''), plays thugs in action movies (like ''U.S. Marshals'') and paints and draws intricate collages. Many of them look like fin de siècle circus posters made under the influence of mescaline.

ZIMMER--Anna "Honey," died at home on March 6, 2011 at the respectable age of 89. Beloved wife of the late Fred Zimmer; mother of Dr. Hal Zimmer and Phyllis Arn Zimmer of Bellevue, WA; Sarah Chapman and Michael Turnacliff of Greenbrae, CA; and Bonnie Zimmer and Jim Ptacek of Cambridge, MA. Adoring and adored grandmother of Allegra and Sabina Chapman and Alex Ptacek Zimmer. Honey also leaves her brother Marvin Schachter and lifelong-friend, turned sister-in-law, Phyllis Held. As the matriarch of her large and loving family, Honey's absence will be deeply felt in Kittery Point, ME, in Arlington and Cambridge, MA and in New York City. A pioneering social worker in the field of aging, Honey created some of the first support programs in the United States aimed at empowering elders and all those who care for them. To the very end, Honey charmed and appreciated her own caregivers, enjoying life to the fullest and "collecting families" wherever she might find herself. Contributions to the Nelson Mandela Children's Hospital Fund, the National Council of Jewish Women, or another cause of your choice are greatly appreciated. A former student will be hosting a memorial service in NYC later this spring.

PORCELLO--Antoinette (nee Ossite). Lovely daughter of the late Michael and Kaffa. Devoted wife of the late Joseph. Beloved mother of Joseph, Michael, Salvatore and Toniann. Cherished grandmother. Special aunt to Ameena. Loving sister. Mass Our Lady of Lebanon, Monday 12 noon. In repose Raccuglia & Son, 321-323 Court St., Brooklyn. 718-855-7737

The Brooklyn-based jeweler A. Jason Ross is part Indiana Jones, part dandy. His latest venture, the Watch Transformation Project (starting at $5,500), is a service for men who want to give some edge to underused timepieces. Clients supply their own watches -- a Cartier, say -- and Ross swaps the band for rugged straps and then bundles it in a stylish leather case that would look nice on a nightstand next to a fedora. EDWARD BARSAMIAN
WINDSOR TERRACE HOUSE $919,000

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Hockey Brawler Paid Price, With Brain Trauma,'' March 3: What disturbed me most about the picture of Bob Probert accompanying the article about the health risks of hockey fighting was not the sight of two players whaling on each other, though that was grotesque enough, but the adoring and gleeful look on the face of the boy watching them through the glass.

Lil B first hit in 2006, at 16, when his group the Pack and its song ''Vans'' lionized the eponymous skate shoe that had, until then, most definitely not been associated with hip-hop style. (The song was unsponsored, akin to what Run D.M.C. did in the '80s with their song ''My Adidas.'') As a solo artist, the Bay Area rapper has continued against the grain. Last year's album ''Rain in England'' melded ambient with rap, perhaps for the first time. A collaborative track with the goth-y Chicago/Michigan trio Salem in late 2010 demonstrated refreshing cross-genre (or subgenre) knowledge. Without being politically correct, Lil B is adept at playing clever word games to undermine some of the negative tropes inherent to hip-hop; his trademark boast - the constantly recycled lyric ''I'm a pretty bitch'' - uses egotism to unravel misogyny. In three years he has posted enough clips to his YouTube page - more than 240 songs, videos, remixes, video remakes and rambling commentaries - to create something of a canon. Those who explore it tend to grow obsessed. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

DAVISON--Richard. The Board of Directors, staff, and clients of Phoenix House mourn the loss of our dear friend Richard Davison. A wise and farsighted advisor, he played a critical role in the development of the earliest Phoenix House programs. He was a founding member of our Board of Directors, whose real estate expertise was of great help in locating and securing sites for treatment facilities throughout the country. We will remember Dick for his many years of service, his passion for the work we do, and his commitment to our mission and to the individuals and families whose lives have been touched by addiction. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Jeffrey A. McDermott, Chairman, Howard Meitiner, President & CEO, Mitchell S. Rosenthal, M.D., Founder, Phoenix House Foundation

The first cabdriver tells his prospective fare that, lacking GPS and a map, he does not know how to get to Union Street and Third Avenue in Brooklyn, an intersection of two relatively major streets about 1.5 miles, and two turns, from the base of the Brooklyn Bridge. The second flashes a you've-got-to-be-kidding smile as the customer asks to be taken to Liberty Avenue and Lefferts Boulevard in Queens. Then he drives off, as the man calls after him: ''What's the problem? Yo!''
The Boss feature last Sunday, about Paul Yarossi, president of HNTB Holdings, misidentified the college from which he graduated in 1973. It is Manhattan College, not Manhattanville.
New civvies for the weekend warrior.

He was a Soviet hero, a space pioneer (and a bit of a boozehound) who risked it all to save a doomed comrade. An excerpt from ''Starman,'' a new biography on the rise and fall of Yuri Gagarin, featured in the pages of our upcoming Spring Men's issue. April 12, 1961: 108 minutes

WOLFLEY--Alan, of New Canaan, CT died on March 8th at the age of 87. Son of the late Chester E. and Lois K. of Rockford, IL. Educated at Middlebury College ('45) and Harvard Business School ('49). Wolfley met his wife, Joanne Higgins, at Middlebury and they were married for 66 years. He served with decoration in the US Army Air Corp and flew 51 B-24 combat missions in WW2. These wartime experiences stood him well in later business pursuits, which included top positions with five "Fortune 500" companies and also a successful entrepreneurial career, including pioneering work in the Colombian seaborne coal trade. He remained active in business until his final day. Wolfley was also a passionate golfer and a longstanding member of Wee Burn CC and Pine Valley GC. He is survived by his wife, their three children C. Alan, Susan W. Baumgartner and E. William, seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

It is a near certainty that this will be the 20th consecutive season that no player has averaged more than three steals a game. Leading the league entering Saturday at 2.4 steals a game is Rajon Rondo, the Boston Celtics' point guard, who also led the league last season with a 2.33 average.

ROSENTHAL--Barbara, left this world too soon. She died suddenly on March 3rd while traveling in pursuit of one of her many passions - the opera. She loved art, ballet, the opera (especially Wagner's Ring Cycle), good food, fine wine and the entire animal kingdom. She is survived by loving cousins, dear friend, Judy Wolfe, her beautiful cat, Chaplin and step-dog, Benny. A celebration of Barbara's rich life will be held at 2pm, Sunday, April 10th at "The Riverside" 76th and Amsterdam. Donations can be made to the Central Park Zoo's Horticulture Department in her name.

For decades, the connection between Las Vegas and the world of organized crime was a well-known secret. Now, two Sin City museums aim to embrace that history. The Las Vegas Mob Experience (lvme.com), which opened this month at the Tropicana Las Vegas, offers what it calls ''an immersive, highly interactive journey'' into the historical relationship between Vegas and the mob.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Reminder of Why Rules Blur,'' March 10: Would the presidents of the University of Connecticut, Ohio State University and the University of Tennessee give a slap on the wrist to a department chairman who fails to notify the university of cheating and plagiarism, or of improper academic conduct by a subordinate, or would that chairman be summarily fired?

N.H.L. general managers will be under intense public scrutiny when they convene for their annual meeting in Boca Raton, Fla., beginning Monday. Under pressure from medical researchers, owners and even players, the general managers are expected to strengthen Rule 48, the league's bylaw governing checks to the head, which was instituted this season. But they will probably not establish a ban on head contact like the rule in the International Ice Hockey Federation, the Ontario Hockey League and the N.C.A.A. After speaking to all 30 G.M.'s last week, Bob McKenzie of the Canadian network TSN reported that they were likely to stop short of a ban, but the movement toward more stringency is palpable. At last year's meeting, the general managers came up with a draft form of what became Rule 48, which barred blindside hits to the head and checks that take aim at the head. A steady drumbeat of medical evidence from doctors and researchers showed the damage caused to hockey players from repeated blows to the head, and as recently as a few weeks ago, the league seemed satisfied with what it had done. Comments by the managers at the board of governors meeting in December indicated that Rule 48 was having the desired effect: deterring players from taking aim at one another's heads. At the All-Star Game at the end of January, Commissioner Gary Bettman said that although concussions were slightly up this season, the number resulting from head shots was actually down - and he credited Rule 48. At that time, the top agenda item for the Boca Raton meeting was shaping up to be a possible crackdown on checks from behind. But a recent pileup of unusually bad, headline-grabbing news put concussion prevention front and center again. The frightening injury of the Canadiens' Max Pacioretty after he was shoved into a stanchion by the Bruins' Zdeno Chara; a recent study that found concussion-induced chronic traumatic encephalopathy in Bob Probert's brain; and Sidney Crosby's two-month absence because of a concussion caused both by a hit to the head and by a later check from behind have led to a public outcry in favor of more stringent rules governing head shots, or at least stronger disciplinary measures to prevent them. In a letter to the N.H.L., Air Canada said that the airline would withdraw its sponsorship if the league did not improve player safety. And in an op-ed article published in Saturday's Globe and Mail of Toronto and Le Presse of Montreal, Ken Dryden called for the managers to do more to prevent concussions. ''Arguments and explanations don't matter anymore,'' wrote Dryden, the Canadiens' Hall of Fame goalie of the 1970s and a member of Parliament. ''The N.H.L. has to risk taking the big steps that are needed: if some of them prove wrong, they'll still be far less wrong than what we have now. It is time to stop being stupid.''

''MAIRA KALMAN: Various Illuminations (of a Crazy World),'' at the Jewish Museum through July 31, is catnip to fans of the artist, whose books, New Yorker covers and online columns for The New York Times are beloved for their humor, insight and irresistible eye for color and composition. The exhibition features her needlepoint, fabrics and wall coverings as well as her paintings. Of the three galleries, one has objects that made their way from her life into her art, like a pink-wrapped gift package from India that she deemed too beautiful ever to be opened. PILAR VILADAS

The other morning, I went for a grocery run. I parked my car and made a mental note of the aisle number, remembered to take in my reusable shopping bags, and although there was a ''slight hitch in my git-a-long,'' as the old saying goes, I was feeling pretty, pretty good. I started my tour of the store, meeting and greeting along the way: commiserating, congratulating, admiring babies, partaking of samples. And after successfully resisting the temptations of the candy aisle, I finally arrived at the checkout counter.

Mikael Jansson The Swedish photographer Mikael Jansson gushed over all the rock gods in ''Ballad of a Thin Man'' (Page 114), but he feels closest to Lou Reed and Iggy Pop (shirtless, above). ''I was 15 when 'Transformer' and 'Raw Power' came out,'' he says. ''They kind of changed my life.'' (Jansson first shot Reed and Pop, along with David Bowie, when he covered the Stockholm music scene in the 1970s.) Today Jansson is a prolific contributor to Interview, where his past cover subjects have included Eva Mendes, Marion Cotillard, Rihanna, Ryan Gosling and Penélope Cruz.

The Video column last Sunday -- about the future of home video -- misstated Netflix's plans for the mail-order DVD part of its business. While Netflix does intend to become primarily a streaming video company, it does not plan to phase out the distribution of physical DVDs.

''There will be blood tonight. 88 East Broadway.'' The message rang out on Facebook early on Jan. 28. It was one of the few public tip-offs that the underground fights would take place -- and it was quickly deleted by the downtown ''It'' girl who had posted it. This would be the seventh Friday Night Throwdown, and the event's shadowy promoters had learned not to take any chances. Each Throwdown takes place in a Manhattan warehouse space -- this time in one of the weird buildings under the Manhattan Bridge, in Chinatown. A regulation ring is built.

One of the top passing guards in the N.B.A., Jose Calderon of the Toronto Raptors, may want to consider whether he would be willing to pass the ball to himself. After a season in which his prodigious assists average dropped to 5.9 a game, Calderon appears to have righted the ship, averaging 9.2 a game, good for fifth in the N.B.A. But the Raptors must be concerned that Calderon's shooting has been well below his career marks, and he has yet to adjust his game by shooting less.

To the Editor: Regarding your cover article about John Galliano (''Exiting the Way That He Entered,'' Thursday Styles, March 3): Just when our children were learning to maneuver in a world of political correctness, along comes this fashion icon spewing hate. ''It was like summer camp -- we all lived together,'' says the writer-director Max Winkler of the 25 days he spent making his first feature film, ''Ceremony.'' The script, which Winkler says is 65 percent autobiographical, is about Sam (Michael Angarano), a young man in love with a much older woman, Zoe (Uma Thurman), who is about to get married. ''I thought the movie wasn't going to happen'' after Jesse Eisenberg dropped out to star in ''The Social Network,'' recalls Winkler (the son of Henry). Angarano, who originally had a supporting role, read for the part of Sam, and as clichéd as it may sound, the director cannot imagine making the movie, which opens April 8, with anyone else. ''I couldn't believe how good he was.''

CRISIS POINTS When there's a quake, everyone who uses Twitter tends to tweet about it. I waited until the first round of shaking had died down. Then I wrote: ''That rearranged my kitchen.'' It had. Drawers were open. Bottles had hit the floor. A bottle of Captain Morgan's had broken, and the spilled rum left the kitchen floor sticky and smelling of vanilla. The impact worked the cork in the Glenfiddich halfway out, but it stayed intact. I tweeted that, too, and a flurry of messages came from people I'd never talked to before -- from Australia, England, the United States -- with funny comments about keeping the booze nearby.
Art Roberta Smith

In 2007, the Alinea chef Grant Achatz was stricken with Stage 4 tongue cancer and, in a Beethovenian twist, lost his sense of taste. ''Life, On the Line'' (Gotham Books, $28) is the story of how he bounced back. Ben Ryder Howe's memoir, ''My Korean Deli'' (Henry Holt & Company, $25), is about a Paris Review editor who moonlights in a bodega. In Peter Mountford's debut novel, ''A Young Man's Guide to Late Capitalism'' (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $16), a hedge fund trader disguised as a freelance journalist wheels and deals in Bolivia. Carol Benedict explains how 350 million Chinese got hooked on cigarettes in ''Golden-Silk Smoke'' (University of California Press, $50). And one must-have monograph: ''Mark Morrisroe'' (JRP/Ringier, $65), about the Nan Goldin contemporary and former teen prostitute whose most famous photos are X-rays of the bullet that was lodged in his back. It is paired with a current show at Artists Space in New York.

WILLETS POINT, a section of Queens that contains a swath of automobile repair shops and parts-scavenging operations, is the subject of ''Foreign Parts,'' a documentary being shown at the Museum of Modern Art in New York through Wednesday. Frugal New York drivers go to Willets Point to replace a muffler or side mirror cheaply. Enthusiastic, hard-selling workers direct trolling cars to the area's many shops in a loose communal ballet.

Whether they're nebulae, star formations, supernovae or planetary landscapes, images from space fascinate the designer Christopher Kane. ''They're breathtaking to look at,'' he says, plus ''they translate well on fabric using digital printing. These haven't been tweaked.'' The space-print shirt Kane wears here is part of his new men's line. The basic pieces -- T-shirts, tank tops, knits and hoodies -- are adapted from the themes and fabrics of his main collection, though with an easier, sportier feel. Pretty much anyone can be a customer. ''The oldest I know of is Ronnie Wood,'' he says. ''And the youngest is probably my 7-year-old nephew.'' JACOB BROWN

BERMAN--Stanley Merwin, died on February 27 in the Dominican Republic. He was 90 years old and a resident of New York for his entire life. He is survived by his devoted wife Joyce Soman Berman, six children and stepchildren, ten grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for April, the date and location to be announced.
An entry on the hardcover fiction best-seller list on Feb. 27 misstated a plot element of ''A Red Herring Without Mustard,'' by Alan Bradley. A Gypsy woman is badly beaten; she does not turn up dead.

In the first issue of his graffiti and pop-culture magazine While You Were Sleeping, Roger Gastman thanked ''Mom for the loot,'' and then thanked ''everyone who ever told me that graff was a dumb waste of my time.'' Gastman, who was 19 at the time, had already been running a graffiti supply business in Bethesda, Md., for three years and was starting to assemble a valuable collection of graffiti ephemera, sourcing discontinued Krylon paint colors at mom-and-pop hardware stores as though he knew, even as a teen, that his obsession would serve him well. Now 33 and living in Los Angeles, Gastman is still having the last laugh. The Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, is gearing up for the April opening of ''Art in the Streets,'' a major graffiti and street-art survey he's curating along with the museum's new director, Jeffrey Deitch, and the independent curator Aaron Rose. ''The History of American Graffiti'' (HarperCollins), written by Gastman and Caleb Neelon, also comes out next month.

A humanitarian crisis has many faces. In Tunisia now, fleeing immigrants have overrun the border crossing of Ras Ajdir in an attempt to escape the strife in Libya. The travelers are mostly male Egyptian laborers but also migrant workers from Tunisia, Bangladesh, China. They arrive in overcrowded cars and buses and on foot, dragging suitcases. Their numbers keep swelling. The photojournalist Paolo Pellegrin was there until the beginning of March, when, he said, ''they were still pouring out.'' What began as an orderly exodus became chaotic as some 75,000 immigrants, in little more than a week, tried to pass through the checkpoints that separate Tunisia and Libya. Yet Pellegrin notes that while Ras Ajdir is desperate, this ''isn't a panic in the terms of what we saw in Kosovo or the scenes of Congo, with women and children. These are all able men.'' The displaced, Page 46.

LEXINGTON, Ky. - In the seemingly incomprehensible symbolism of alchemy, the copulation of kings and queens is viewed as a marriage of lower-value base elements like copper and iron to produce nature's most precious metal, gold. That such a crude commercial endeavor ultimately pushed the alchemists to the margins of the scientific community and earned them infamy as charlatans has not diverted the breeders of thoroughbred racehorses from undertaking a modern version of this murky, barely respectable and mystical art.

May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to her family. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, Rabbi Andrew Frackman, President

In ''Gypsies'' (powerhouse Books, $45), out in May, the photographer Patrick Cariou retraced the migration of the Romany people from northern to southern Europe, the Middle East and ultimately to India, their ancestral homeland. Along the way, he encountered Gypsies making sausage on the floor of a Romanian hovel, and living in weirdly beautiful shantytowns in Slovakia and tents in Afghanistan. In France, he found more prosperous Roma, whose Gypsy caravans now include Ferraris and inflatable kiddie pools filled with ice and Kronenbourg beer. Meanwhile, Iain McKell's ''The New Gypsies'' (Prestel, $40) zooms in on a group unrelated to the Roma, the anarchic vagabonds known in Britain as ''horse-drawns,'' who coalesced with anti-Thatcherite movements in the 1980s. They have fair skin, and their wagons recall medieval fairs more readily than Romania, but the kinship between these Gypsy tribes, new and old, seems somehow more than contrived.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

Matt Bai and the union leaders he interviewed for his profile of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey gave the impression that Christie is nearly entirely responsible for the sacrifices being demanded of the state's public employees. But he is just the governor of New Jersey, not its dictator. He can't unilaterally force his will on the state. Neither Bai nor the union leaders quoted in this otherwise excellent piece focused on the role of New Jersey's Legislature, which last July approved the proposals that have so infuriated state employees. JOHN C. KATZ Falls Church, Va., e-mail

He is survived by Eunice and his niece and nephew, Lenore Jones and Charlie Haas of California, and his beloved friend of forty years, Irene Petrillo, of New York City. Our family is grateful to Irene, Toni and Frank Prendergast, and Luis Gerarro for their diligence and generosity in making Eli's last year a happy one. We thank Kellena Bedford who started out as an aide to Eli and became a dear friend. Eli, we'll miss you.

LIBYA The Arab League asked the United Nations Security Council on Saturday to impose a no-flight zone over Libya in hopes of halting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's attacks on his people. Fighting continued as pro-Qaddafi forces pushed rebels eastward and strengthened their hold around Tripoli, the capital. YEMEN Fighting escalated between antigovernment protesters and security forces, and four people were reported killed, even as President Ali Abdullah Saleh promised the White House that he would not use violence against the demonstrators. At least three people were killed in Sana, the capital, and a 14-year-old boy was killed in a protest in the south, witnesses said.

Kelly Slater leaves every other surfer in his wake. Any conversation about Kelly Slater begins with the number 10. As in, 10 Association of Surfing Professionals World Championships, the last of which he earned in November. Chop his career in half, and he'd still be both the winningest and second-winningest pro surfer in history. At age 20, he was the youngest world champion ever; at 39, he's the oldest. In other words, there's no point in comparing Slater with those in his own profession. By 2009, when Surfer magazine named him the greatest surfer of all time, it had already become a parlor game to measure his career stats against athletes like Michael Jordan, Tiger Woods and Wayne Gretzky.

''GETTING extra height is something women want, right?'' the designer Chris Benz asked slyly, as if he doesn't already know the answer. The Digital Domain column last Sunday, about ultrafast broadband, referred incorrectly to two aspects of broadcast-quality, high-definition video delivered to the home. That video is compressed, not uncompressed, and the bandwidth it needs is generally in a range of 5 to 20 gigabits a second, depending on the compression used; it is not specifically 23 megabits a second.

SOME may think maple-syrup-making can only happen in Vermont or Canada. But if last year's little experiment sugaring in Brooklyn proved anything, it was that fine maple syrup could be made in New York City as well. I recently located a healthy sugar maple in the Stapleton section of Staten Island, and although it was already a little late in the season, I set up shop, hoping for a good run. Temperatures have to be just right for quality sap flow: more than 40 degrees in the daytime, with temperatures dipping to freezing at night. The sugar maple was in the back of my friends' property, halfway up a hilly incline, and tapping it would require lugged boots, steady legs and the ability to drill while negotiating a fence. Although I had spiles (something like spigots) with hooks from Vermont -- and thoughts of using them to hang my bucket directly from the tree the old-fashioned way -- my ''Little House'' dreams were dashed by the realities of urban tapping (a wire fence). My tapping partner and I resorted to the tried-and-true do-it-yourself approach, involving steel pipes and PVC tubing from the local hardware store.

Beloved husband of Ruth; father, brother, uncle, grandfather and great-grandfather. Loved by many. He will be missed more than words can say.

YOHN--Timothy Mitchell. In Loving Memory of Timothy Mitchell Yohn, 1940-2011, who passed away March 9, 2011. Beloved husband and stepfather, Mr. Yohn was General Billy Mitchell's grandnephew and renowned illustrator F.C. Yohn's grandson. He co-authored "Prime Time & Misdemeanors - Investigating the 1950's TV Quiz Scandal" and was former book editor at McGraw Hill. He is survived by his loving wife Lina Todd and his stepdaughters Alexa Wilding and Sonja Georgevich.

Roger Herman might just be the most important artist you've never heard of. Ceramics is the Rodney Dangerfield of the art world: the medium gets no respect. So why is there such a glittering crowd at the Acme gallery on Wilshire Boulevard for the opening of ''Los Angeles Museum of Ceramic Art''? The women are model-y swans, the men are rugged and fashionable, and this being L.A., there's even the requisite celebrity - John C. Reilly - mingling among the crowd. And everywhere, just everywhere, are the young art stars that twinkle in L.A.'s firmament. They're mostly painters, and they've been drawn here by the gravitational pull of an artist that most outsiders have never heard of: Roger Herman.

FRANKIE ROSE may be a little commitment-challenged -- she played drums for Vivian Girls, Dum Dum Girls and Crystal Stilts but never hung around long enough to become part of the bands. And these days, she's fronting her own retro-pop group, Frankie Rose and the Outs, having recently completed a tour for her self-titled first album. For all her bopping around, though, there's no denying her status as a cool fixture on Brooklyn's indie-pop scene. ''While it was a scary transition,'' she said of her move to guitar and vocals, ''it was a natural progression for me, too. I really did just get tired of playing the drums.'' When she's not tending bar at the Brooklyn club Bruar Falls (a girl has to eat), Ms. Rose is practicing for her April 12 date at the Bowery Ballroom. KATHRYN BRANCH Dolce & Gabbana bodysuit, $1,195. Hair by Roberto Di Cuia. Makeup by Daniel Martin.

Because of an editing error, a chart with the Sky Watch column in some editions last Sunday erroneously indicated two Big Dippers. The large formation of stars that is part of the Ursa Major constellation is the Big Dipper, as the chart indicated. The smaller formation in the Ursa Minor constellation that includes Polaris, the North Star, is in fact the Little Dipper.

MUENSTERBERGER--Werner. Sotheby's New York African and Oceanic Art Department deeply mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague and dear friend Werner Muensterberger. His talents and passions were many and varied, but we knew him best for the knowledge and expertise he brought to the field of African and Oceanic art. A learned and scholarly gentleman, Mr. Muensterberger held three doctorates, in medicine, anthropology and art history. Born in Dortmund, Germany, on April 15, 1913, he began collecting African art at the age of thirteen, having been inspired to do so by his uncle, the late Baron Eduard von der Heydt, and went on to become an expert with an important collection. Best known for "Sculpture of Primitive Man" (1955) and "Collecting: An Unruly Passion" (1994), Mr. Muensterberger's books were major contributions to the literature on African, Oceanic and Native American art and the psychology of art collecting. Through his scholarship and his contagious enthusiasm he played a key role in the appreciation of the art of primordial cultures as world art. Mr. Muensterberger's passing is a great loss to the world of African and Oceanic art. We extend our heartfelt condolences to all his friends and members of his family. We will miss him. Heinrich Schweizer, Head of Department

IT helps to see a lot of clothes over the years to know the ones you like in a new season. That's what I say when people ask how editors and writers can remember what they have seen over nearly a month of shows. I essentially keep two mental lists -- one for the clothes I personally love and the other for looks I think will be relevant. Inevitably, there is some overlap. This time, I want to talk about the things I loved from the fall collections: my favorite individual looks from New York, Milan and Paris. And I want to limit the list to three or four picks because it's more interesting that way. The Cathy Challenge! I anticipate that some of you will be disappointed by my choices and will say, head-scratching: ''Is that it? Is that the best you could pick from all those incredible shows?''

PAPPAS--John G. John George Pappas, 90, of New York and Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, one of the last living physicists of The Manhattan Project passed away in his sleep at home at The Little Wyndham Estate in Bryn Mawr on March 4th, 2011. Born August 7th, 1920 in Manhattan to Greek parents from Asia Minor, Lucy and George Pappas (Papazoglou), he graduated Stuyvesant High School then Columbia University in 1943 with a BA in Physics. In August, 1945 he was recognized by the U.S. War Department for his essential work on The Manhattan Project in Oak Ridge, Tennessee. In 1952, he married his wife Clara Gossett. In the 1970's, as chief chemist at Benjamin Moore and Co, he invented the first commercial exterior latex paint, MoorGard. He was predeceased by his wife Clara (1963) and brother Christo (2003). He is survived by his daughter Dr. Diane Pappas-Sfedu, son-in-law Dr. Emil P. Sfedu, and his grandson Christopher W. Sfedu. Funeral services will be on March 15th at St. Luke's Greek Orthodox Church in Pennsylvania, followed by burial at The Woodlawn Cemetery in New York.

Nobu restaurant has long been known for upscale Japanese cuisine that draws jet-setters to its 25 locations around the world. Now Nobu is bringing its cachet to a different sort of setting: a hotel. The first Nobu hotel, lounge and restaurant will occupy the tower at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas under a tentative deal, Gary Selesner, the president of Caesars Palace, and Trevor Horwell, chief executive of Nobu Hospitality, said last week. The tower is to be transformed by a multimillion-dollar renovation into a 180-room hotel that hews to Nobu's Japanese theme, with a 9,500 square-foot Nobu restaurant and lounge at its base. (The tower is currently occupied by Caesars rooms and its base by retail space.)

Being close to the ocean would be ideal. After two weeks of school, I would like to travel (for one or two weeks) and practice my Spanish.

Contributions in his name may be made to Doctors Without Borders. He was a gentleman whose humanity touched many.

OXFORD, England -- Peering at the post-tsunami devastation in Japan on miniature YouTube windows or video-streaming displays from Japanese news outlets provokes not only great empathy and concern, but an unmistakable feeling of déjà vu. As a scholar focusing on the place of nuclear energy in Japanese culture, I've seen more than my share of nuclear-themed monster movies from the '50s onward, and the scenes of burning refineries, flattened cities, mobilized rescue teams and fleeing civilians recall some surreal highlights of the Japanese disaster film genre.

When the Great Kanto earthquake of 1923 and the fires that erupted along its trail destroyed Yokohama and three-fifths of Tokyo, killing nearly 150,000 people, Akira Kurosawa was in middle school. Kurosawa, the director of "Rashomon" and "The Seven Samurai," never tried to put the wasteland that suddenly overtook the landscape of his childhood on film, but in interviews and an autobiography, he returned to the devastation again and again. Trying to take in the scale of the destruction in the aftermath of the earthquake last week in Japan, particularly the way active coastal towns were suddenly vaporized by the tsunami, I was reminded of what Kurosawa never forgot.

AUSTIN, Tex. - The director Greg Mottola takes comedy seriously. While the filmmaker has been interested in making funny movies ("Superbad," "Adventureland"), he's also concerned about the craft involved in making those films work within specific genres. Mr. Mottola was profiled in this week's Arts & Leisure and was in Austin to discuss "Paul," his film starring Seth Rogen as the voice of an alien who gets himself mixed up with two British fanboys (Simon Pegg and Nick Frost, who also wrote the screenplay). Mr. Mottola spoke about the challenges and rewards of making a film with a CGI alien character at its center.

Minnesota Timberwolves forward Kevin Love's ridiculous streak of 53 consecutive double-doubles came to an end Sunday night against the most unlikely of opponents.  Golden State - which was on the receiving end of a 37-point, 23-rebound game from Love just three weeks ago - held him to 6 points Sunday (and 12 rebounds) in a 100-77 Warriors victory despite an up-tempo game and a defensively inferior frontline. Somehow David Lee was able to do what the league's best defensive bigs could not, and Love's double-double ways hit their first hiccup in 54 contests.

A spending bill passed by House Republicans last month could affect the nation's tsunami monitoring system, which issued warnings in response to last week's devastating earthquake and tsunami in Japan, opponents warn. The plan cuts $126 million from the 2011 budget of the National Weather Service, which runs the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center in Hawaii.

James Frey has avoided traditional publishers with his next novel, "The Final Testament of the Holy Bible," the story of a modern-day Jesus that his publisher, the Gagosian Gallery, predicted would be "the most compelling and provocative work of his career." The book is set in the Bronx, and Mr. Frey's version of the Messiah is a heavy drinker. It is set for release on Good Friday. The Gagosian Gallery, which has never published a novel before, will print only 11,000 copies. The book will include original artwork by Ed Ruscha, Terry Richardson and Dan Colen, among others. Mr. Frey will make an e-book edition available to traditional retailers.

A British jury said on Monday that an Academy Award-winning special effects coordinator was not responsible for the death of a cameraman who was killed in a stunt mishap during the filming of "The Dark Knight," Reuters reported. After less than two hours of deliberation, jurors at Crown Court in Guildford, southwest of London, ruled unanimously that the effects coordinator, Christopher Corbould, was not guilty of failing to ensure the safety of the cameraman, Conway Wickliffe. Mr. Wickliffe was killed in 2007 on the set of "The Dark Knight," Christopher Nolan's sequel to his superhero film "Batman Begins," as he rode in a pickup truck driving parallel to a stunt car; the pickup missed a 90-degree turn and crashed into a tree. Last week, prosecutors argued that Mr. Corbould, who won an Oscar for his work on "Inception" and whose filmography includes several "James Bond" movies, did not follow proper safety guidelines in planning the stunt and that the accident was foreseeable. Mr. Wickliffe was honored in the closing credits of "The Dark Knight," along with the actor Heath Ledger, who died before the film's release.

Carnegie Hall, which is sponsoring a festival of Japanese culture, has followed through on its stated desire to steer patrons toward places to help the victims of Japan's earthquake and tsunami. Routinely, the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament is the greatest sporting event of the year, and in particular, the tournament's first weekend serves up the most entertaining four days in sports. Yet this year, the N.C.A.A. has unwisely decided to step on that Thursday-to-Sunday tradition by beginning the tournament on Tuesday and Wednesday, with a set of "First Four" games. In doing so, the N.C.A.A. has somehow conspired to create a situation in which the first round of a second-tier playoff, the N.I.T. - particularly the Harvard-Oklahoma State game that will be broadcast on ESPN on Tuesday - is more interesting than the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament (broadcast on truTV).

AUSTIN, Tex. - Throughout his film career, the actor Josh Lucas has been more of a supporting player. But in the SXSW competition film "A Year in Mooring," his role couldn't be more central. Directed by Chris Eyre ("Smoke Signals"), the film follows a year in the life of a man who's trying to rebound from a tragedy by buying and spending time on a sailboat. It was a challenging role for the actor, which features Mr. Lucas alone on screen for a good portion of its running time. At the festival he spoke about the film and how he got involved. He also shared some thoughts on the competitive nature of landing roles in Hollywood.

There may be nobody in Washington who has anything good to say - publicly, at least - about the expanded 1099 reporting requirements that became law with the health care overhaul. Republicans and Democrats all want to repeal it. President Obama, in his State of the Union speech, described the provision as an "unnecessary bookkeeping burden." But now that Congress must reconcile two very different approaches to striking the provision, it may be a good time to risk pillory and wonder if perhaps the new law's supposed crippling effects on small business are exaggerated.

"That's the beauty of the game." It's a useful phrase in sports talk. It allows you to sum up - without actually having to say much about - things like comebacks and buzzer-beaters and the unexpected twists and turns of unscripted athletic contests. But I'm going to use it as a way to characterize my reaction to two art installations I came upon the other day online. The first is a sculpture of Muhammad Ali ... made up of speed bags ... strung from wires. It's very cool. (It's probably also some sort of commentary on shifting perspectives and focus and, for all I know, maybe even various Greatest of All Time debates.) Even cooler is this installation connected to another G.O.A.T. candidate, the F1 racer Michael Schumacher. The pictures of his car, taken apart, each piece suspended from an art-gallery ceiling, are rather amazing. And now I'm going to call time on this post, before I start talking about things going down to the wire.

Perhaps you are familiar with Meatpaper: Your Journal of Meat Culture. I was not, but how can anyone resist browsing such an attractive periodical? Especially when it's called Meatpaper? Yet after flipping through the Spring 2011 issue for a a solid three or four minutes, I was still unsure: Is Meatpaper pro-meat? Is it an ironic dispatch from militant vegans? A pull quote under a movie still of Catherine Deneuve didn't clarify matters: "The carcass comes to symbolize the psychosexual malaise by which Catherine Deneuve's character is afflicted." Well, sure - obviously. Which made me wonder whether Meatpaper wasn't an anagram of ''Meta Paper.'' Development in the Caribbean tends to move on, well, island time. But this season, snowbirds were buzzing about a handful of dazzling upgrades. The biggest news is the re-launch of the Four Seasons Resort Nevis, which had been closed for two years following the destruction wrought by Hurricane Omar, which struck the twin island of Nevis and St. Kitts in October 2008. (The faltering economy played a role as well.) Now the resort on a prime stretch of Pinney's Beach is back with a new design, a new spa director (who has come up with a new range of island-y treatments using rum, sugar cane and papaya) and a new chef, Andreas Donnerbauer, who will scuba dive with certified guests to pluck their supper right from the sea. The hotel has also added super-luxe day cabanas on the beach along with a sailing school. But guest favorites like the endangered sea turtle program and the Robert Trent Jones-designed golf course remain - as does Sunshine's, the famous ramshackle bar just down the beach.

This blog isn't really about politics, but sometimes I'll veer into the psychology of politics. For example, when people hold high office they change a zillion different ways. They have power, with all the attendant corruptions. They become the center of every room they enter, with all the attendant narcissism. They also have inside information, and often leap to the conclusion that people who don't have this information are simply not worth listening to.

This week's special issue of Science Times explores why we love animals and the rich relationships between pets and people. Numerous studies show that pets are good for your health. They may lower your risk for heart problems or may simply be a better walking partner than a human.

A division of Warner Brothers said that it would pull the Clint Eastwood movie "Hereafter" from theaters in Japan following the earthquake and tsunami that have devastated the country, The Associated Press reported. "Hereafter," which was released in Japanese theaters in February and was scheduled to be shown there through late March, follows several characters who are affected by death and near-death experiences, including a journalist played by Cécile de France who is caught in Thailand during the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami. On Monday, Satoru Otani, an official at Warner Entertainment Japan Inc., told The A.P. that the tsunami sequences in the film were "not appropriate" at the present time and that the film would no longer be shown.

When Copenhagen's Noma was named the world's best restaurant by Restaurant magazine last year, the gastronomes who think nothing of settling into a four-hour, three-star dinner suddenly developed an interest wild plants. For years, foraged ingredients played an important if subtle role in the multicourse meals that unfurl at restaurants like Michel Bras, the Fat Duck and Coi. But it was Noma's exuberant celebration of what grows wild in the Nordic countryside that turned cloudberries and wood sorrel into culinary stars.

When Harold Richards, 81, arrived at the hospital emergency room in Ann Arbor, Mich., he expected a long wait. After all, he'd been through the emergency room drill before. The patient in the worst condition would be seen first, he knew, and the waiting time could be indeterminable. The rush, the harsh lights, the white walls and bright floors -- everything about the place seemed designed to confuse and frighten elderly patients like him.

I.B.M.'s Watson may have pummeled Jeopardy! champions Ken Jennings and Brad Rutter last month, but last week, a New Jersey Congressman beat the question-and-answer supercomputer. To be sure, it was no ordinary politician. Representative Rush D. Holt Jr., a New Jersey Democrat, is a physicist who spent the nine years before he won his first congressional race in 1998 as the assistant director of the plasma physics laboratory at Princeton University.

LIBYA Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi advanced on the town of Ajdabiya, a strategic linchpin that would thrust them onto the doorstep of the opposition capital of Benghazi and within grasp of a highway crucial to recapturing the eastern border and encircling the rebellion with heavy armor and artillery. After another day of headlong retreat, this time from the refinery and port at Brega, rebels tried to make what some called a last stand at Ajdabiya, taking refuge in military barracks. YEMEN In the capital, Sana, clashes broke out for the second day in a row on the perimeter of an antigovernment demonstration, a continuous sit-in that has lasted for about three weeks. Plainclothes government supporters started throwing rocks and attacked the demonstrators with jambiyas, traditional Yemeni daggers, witnesses said. They then fired at the protesters with automatic weapons. Volunteer doctors working at a makeshift medical clinic in a nearby mosque said that 10 protesters had injuries from live ammunition and about 10 more had other types of injuries.
INTERACTIVE FEATURE Satellite images taken before and after the quake and tsunami in Japan. nytimes.com/world

Leo Tolstoy once wrote, ''Happy N.C.A.A. tournament experiences are all alike.'' He later switched the line to ''happy families are all alike'' when he changed Anna Karenina from a Purdue point guard to a Russian aristocrat. But Tolstoy was on to something. We all enjoy March Madness in much the same way, filling out the same brackets, watching the same games and sneaking out of the office at the same time. Chances are, your schedule for the next three weeks will match the following timeline.

Before arriving at Ohio State, Jared Sullinger was faced with huge expectations. He was the first Ohioan to be named Parade player of the year since LeBron James in 2002 and 2003, and was widely considered the nation's No. 1 recruit. Sullinger, from Northland High School in Columbus, did not disappoint in his collegiate debut on Nov. 12 against North Carolina A&T, scoring 19 points and grabbing 14 rebounds.

LERER--Shifra. The funeral service will be held today, Monday, March 14th at 12:45pm, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. INTERNATIONAL An article on Wednesday about Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates's trip to Sangin, a district in Afghanistan where many Marines have died, misstated the name of the battalion Mr. Gates visited. It is the Third Battalion, Fifth Marines -- not the reverse. (There is no Third Marines, Fifth Battalion.)

Brigham Young's Jimmer Fredette leads the nation in scoring at 28.5 points a game, and one reason for his success was that he honed his skills by playing against prisoners during summers. When he was 18 and living in Glens Falls, N.Y., Fredette and his brother played on weekends against inmates at either the Great Meadow Correctional Facility in Comstock, N.Y., or the Mount McGregor Correctional Facility in Wilton, N.Y. ''They're decent courts,'' Fredette, a senior guard, said. ''They're like big courts for some reason, and it was a lot of fun playing in there, you know, made you immensely tough just playing in front of inmates like that and the things they would say to you. I don't know if I can repeat all the stuff that they would say. But they were just kind of heckling you, and most of the time they didn't like you at first.''

7 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO As a graduate student at the Actors Studio Drama School at the New School, Bradley Cooper earned a bit of fame for peppering ''Inside the Actors Studio'' guests like Robert DeNiro, Steven Spielberg and Sean Penn with questions. Now it's his turn in the spotlight as he becomes the school's first graduate to sit in the chair opposite the show's host, James Lipton (above left, with Mr. Cooper). In this hourlong episode Mr. Cooper talks about starring with Mr. De Niro in the film ''Limitless,'' which opens on Friday, and the coming sequel to his 2009blockbuster ''The Hangover.'' He also takes a moment to introduce his girlfriend, Renée Zellweger, who is seated next to Mr. Cooper's mother, Gloria, in the audience. 8 P.M. (NBC) CHUCK Chuck (Zachary Levi) suspects Casey (Adam Baldwin) of carrying out private missions that could divide the team. Chuck also worries that he's about to be made obsolete by some seemingly perfect new operatives (Isaiah Mustafa and Stacy Keibler). In ''The Event,'' at 9, a shaken President Martinez (Blair Underwood) demonstrates that he's still in charge after the attack in Alaska.

MCMANUS--James William Jr.,70, entered eternal rest March 11, 2011 from the VA Hospital, Charleston, SC. He was preceded in death by parents Marjorie S. McManus Gilmartin and James William McManus, MD. Survived by sisters Mary Ellen Maguire, Brooklyn, NY and Marjorie T. McManus, Mt. Pleasant SC, and brothers Paul M. McManus (Doerte), Charleston, SC, Robert W. McManus, Phoenix AZ, Stephen M. McManus (Karen), Eastchester, NY, seven nephews, four grand nieces, three grand nephews and the Gilmartin family. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, a graduate of The Brooklyn Preparatory and The College of the Holy Cross, Worcester, MA, he served in Vietnam as a U.S. Navy Lieutenant. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered Wednesday, March 16, 2011 at 11:30am at Christ Our King R.C. Church, Mt. Pleasant, SC. Burial at sea at a later date. Funeral services are provided by McAlister-Smith Funeral Home, Mount Pleasant Chapel,1520 Rifle Range Road, Mount Pleasant, SC 29464. Phone: 843-884-3833.

LIPTON--Brian, 35, formerly of Tenafly, NJ and San Francisco CA, suddenly on March 10, 2011. Loving son of Nancy and Dr. Charles Lipton. Dear brother of Dan, brother-in- law of Carrie, uncle of Josh and Chloe; grandson of Evelyn and the late Dr. Irvin and the late Benjamin and Florence Schwartzman. Many relatives and friends loved him and weep over his unexpected passing. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Monday, March 14, 11:45am.

The Aspen Music Festival and School, a rite of passage for many of the nation's leading musicians but an institution fraught with dissension in the recent past, has hired the conductor Robert Spano as its new music director. ''In terms of governance we're very clear on who's doing what and the way it works,'' Mr. Spano said.

KLEINMAN--Hyman J, MD of Greenwich, CT formerly of Westchester, March 12, 2011, beloved father of sons Stuart and Andrew and his wife, Noela and grandchildren Julia and Alexander, widow of Ruth. Loved by his patients as well as by family and friends.

SPORTS An article on Friday about the decision by National Athletic Equipment Reconditioners Association, the trade group that oversees the refurbishing of used helmets, that it would no longer accept helmets more than 10 years old misstated the day Representatives Henry A. Waxman and G. K. Butterfield requested that the House Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade hold a hearing regarding football helmet safety. It was Monday, not Tuesday. And because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the state represented by Butterfield. He is a Democrat from North Carolina, not Michigan. (The error about his state also appeared on Tuesday in a report in the Sports Briefing column about Waxman's and Butterfield's request for the hearing.)

CONCORD, N.H. -- Many aspiring Republican presidential candidates are going to great lengths to avoid the spotlight, but not Tim Pawlenty. He is doing whatever he can to step into it. Few audiences are too small for Mr. Pawlenty, who turns up at Tea Party rallies, church forums and beer and pizza parties with College Republicans. He even hit the ice to play hockey here, with a local television crew following closely along.

Duke guard Nolan Smith is trying to make history -- and repeat history at the same time. Smith, a senior, is trying to lead Duke to a second consecutive national championship. It would be only the third program since John Wooden retired at U.C.L.A. to accomplish that feat. Florida repeated in 2006 and 2007, and Duke did in 1991 and 1992. Smith was the Atlantic Coast Conference's player of the year and the most valuable player of the conference tournament.

CASSELL--Warren. Stellar bookseller, avid tennis player, volunteer, and community activist Warren Cassell died on February 25th, in Portland, Oregon of heart failure. In addition to his wife of 46 years, Melisa, Mr. Cassell is survived by his daughter, two sons, and two grandsons.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Thursday about David Broder, the political reporter and columnist for The Washington Post, referred incorrectly to Jimmy Carter's political status in 1976, when he won the Wisconsin Democratic primary for president. He was the former governor of Georgia -- not the governor, having left office in 1975.

LOS ANGELES - Rutabagas. Rice cakes. Roll 'em? Whole Foods Market, the giant purveyor of wholesome groceries, is planning to stock a half-dozen environmentally themed movies in about 70 cities during a monthlong program it is calling the ''Do Something Reel'' film festival.

LIEBROSS--Harold, age 94. Died peacefully on May 2, 2010, after a long illness. Loving husband of Ruth Liebross, father of Robert Liebross and Diana Steinman, grandfather of Samuel Steinman, and father-in-law of Judith Welsh-Liebross. A very hard worker, always ready to help others and handy with a joke, Harold took very good care of his family, who loved him and miss him.

Somewhere along the line, utility became a bad word at news magazines. And that's where The Week saw an opening. While magazines like Time and Newsweek published heavy essays, distinguished guest columnists and artful photo spreads, The Week embraced magazine journalism at its most functional and stripped down.

On Tuesday, Long Wharf Theater in New Haven announced that Ray Cullom was stepping down as its managing director. On Thursday, Mr. Cullom got a new job: the board of the Queens Theater in the Park announced that he had been appointed executive director. The Theater in the Park, located in the pavilion designed for the 1964 World's Fair by Philip Johnson in Flushing Meadows Corona Park, recently completed a $27 million renovation and expansion. A $2 million capital campaign to support its programming is also nearing completion. Mr. Cullom, who spent less than two years at Long Wharf, has 20 years experience in arts administration.

LEVINE--Charlotte. To the talented, wonderful woman and loving companion to Robert Berkley. May she long be remember for her sage view of the world, adoration of friends and admirers. She will never be forgotten.

Rajat K. Gupta, the former Goldman Sachs director accused by the government of passing insider information about the Wall Street firm, had tried to resign from the Goldman board in the middle of the 2008 financial crisis, only weeks before he is said to have provided the tips to the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam. According to a new audiotape recording released by federal prosecutors late Friday, Mr. Gupta sought to leave the Goldman board to take a job as a senior adviser at Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity firm led by Henry R. Kravis, a friend of Mr. Gupta's.

STONE--Carol Chanin nee Kaplan. On March 13, 2011 of Palm Beach, Fl. Carol was the beloved wife of the late Marvin Stone and previously the late Paul Chanin. Devoted mother of Steven Chanin and Jeffrey Chanin (Karen Lovedahl). Loving grandmother of Seth Chanin and Julia Chanin. Treasured sister Norma Smith (Gordon Smith). The family will welcome friends at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Parlor 1079 Madison Ave. from 5pm-7pm Tuesday March 15, 2011.

A new Web site focused on independent films is hoping to become Netflix for the Sundance Film Festival crowd. Fandor, introduced on Wednesday, is a subscription service with a library of 2,500 films like ''Dogtooth,'' a Greek drama nominated for an Academy Award in the foreign language category.

''Don't worry, we'll keep it clean,'' Mark Roberts said, sounding reassuring right from the beginning.-So much for the really salty language in his exploration of old salts' salty talk. Mr. Roberts, 47, is a tour guide at the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum whose roots as an English major came in handy when he was casting about for new things to tell visitors.-So sometimes, on specially scheduled tours, he lets other guides talk about the Intrepid's past - the night in 1944 when a torpedo smashed into the hull; the day in 1965 when the Intrepid picked up Lt. Cmdr. John Young and Maj. Gus Grissom after the splashdown of Gemini 3. Mr. Roberts focuses on the nautical origins of everyday phrases, and not just shipboard slang.-He stamped his foot. ''This is not a floor, it's a deck,'' he said, explaining that ''deck,'' in English, sounds like a Dutch word for cover. ''So 'deck the halls' means 'cover the halls,' '' he said. He leaned against - well, let him explain the perpendicular structures that run between decks and ceilings. ''These are not walls, they're bulkheads,'' he said.

The biggest difference in this new phase of Barack Obama's presidency: he's not so needy. During 2009-10, President Obama needed a lot from Congress: a $787 billion stimulus package to counter the economic crisis, a financial regulation overhaul to prevent the next one and big health care and energy programs to fulfill his vision for future growth.

A man has been arrested in the stabbing death of a 42-year-old former model on the Lower East Side more than a month ago, the police said on Sunday. The woman, Jomali Morales, 42, was attacked in an elevator at 555 Roosevelt Drive in the Baruch housing project on Feb. 12. The police later said that she had 19 stab wounds.
