The Consumer Product Safety Commission introduced a new feature on its Web site on Friday, allowing users to report unsafe products like toys, furniture, electronics and clothing (safer products.gov). The site is like other government sites, for vehicles (safercar .gov), medicines and food (fda.gov), and meat, eggs and poultry (usda.gov). Recent searches for recalled items include the Mazda 6, above, which had problems with spider webs clogging fuel system vents; the Ford F-150 truck, for air bags; and 500 cough, cold and allergy medications not approved for sale by the Food and Drug Administration. SHELLY FREIERMAN

It was a relatively routine call, the kind that the New York City police usually handle without too much trouble. A frightened woman in Brooklyn telephoned 911 early Sunday morning and reported that her ex-boyfriend was threatening her. ''He said he's going to kill me,'' the woman cried. ''He said he's across the street, and he's going to kill me and 'Don't call the cops!' ''

Space. The Final Four Frontier. These are the voyages of the Starship Office Pool. It's a three-week, 68-team mission: to fuel national obsession, to crown a new champion, and to boldly inspire you to waste time filling out a bracket that's obsolete by Thursday afternoon. Command Center The freshman forward Jared Sullinger piloted Ohio State to the Big Ten championship and has set his course for the N.C.A.A. title game on April 4. The Buckeyes overcame late-February turbulence to win their last four games and rocket through the Big Ten tournament. Sullinger (17.3 p.p.g., 10.1 r.p.g.) doesn't helm the ship alone: three other Buckeyes averaged double-digit scoring.

For the millions of blind people living in the United States, paying for something in cash can pose major challenges because there is no difference between the size and shape of a $1 or $100 bill. To tackle this problem, many blind people set up systems to identify a bill's value by folding the notes into different sizes and shapes, which then make them easily identifiable later. A new application, the LookTel Money Reader, available for $2 on the Apple iOS platform, hopes to help solve this problem by taking advantage of the devices camera to ''read money'' and speak the value of the currency out loud.

LIEBROSS--Ruth, age 91. Died peacefully on August 5, 2010, after a long illness. Loving wife of Harold Liebross, mother of Robert Liebross and Diana Steinman, grandmother of Samuel Steinman, and mother-in-law of Judith Welsh-Liebross. Always looking on the bright side of things with a smile, Ruthie took very good care of her Harold and her family. We will always love our Ruthie.

Kim Hill, whose childhood battle with leukemia inspired the first Ronald McDonald House, the model for an international network of temporary housing for families of sick children, died on Saturday in Orange, Calif. She was 44. The cause was brain cancer, her father, Fred Hill, said. When her family learned she had leukemia at age 3, doctors predicted she would not reach adulthood.

When people were seeking to contribute money after the earthquake in Haiti last year, the Red Cross offered a simple solution: text-message the word ''Haiti'' to 90999. That's when it became clear to many that text-messaging could work for commerce. A company called Zoove contends there is an even simpler way to reach customers than asking them to remember a text-message address of five random digits.

The former chief executive of Freddie Mac may face a civil action as the government ramps up an investigation of disclosure practices at the mortgage finance giant and its sister company, Fannie Mae, people briefed on the investigation said.

I mentioned in my column that in recent weeks politicians in Florida and Iowa have introduced bills that aim to crack down on shooting photographs and videos of agricultural operations. The Florida bill would require anyone wishing to photograph a farm to first secure written permission from the owner. And what if they don't? First-degree felony. The implicit goal here is to deter and criminalize damning undercover exposés like this one. The bill would also make it illegal for an agenda-less passerby to snap a picture of a farm from the side of the road, but my best guess is that those "crimes" might not be prosecuted quite so diligently.

During the secession crisis, no Americans were more trapped between secession and Union, between slavery and emancipation, than middle-of-the-road Virginians. And no Virginia family was more torn than Thomas Jefferson's clan.

Fay met with the marines at McGuire Veterans Administration Hospital in Richmond, Va., to record them in what most would consider the worst possible conditions. In the first post, he met Lance Cpl. Shiho Fukada was born and raised in Tokyo. She is traveling with Michael Wines, a writer from the Beijing bureau of The New York Times, and Mac Bishop, a video journalist for The Times. This narrative is an edited version of her conversation with Kerri MacDonald from her hotel room in Kitakami, in northern Iwate Prefecture.

It's time to take a look at the line between "pet" and "animal." When the ASPCA sends an agent to the home of a Brooklyn family to arrest one of its members for allegedly killing a hamster, something is wrong.

Martin A. Armstrong, who prosecutors accused of running a $3 billion Ponzi scheme, is finally out of jail after 11 years, including a possible record seven years for contempt of court in a dispute over gold and antiquities.

Last night, don't ask me why, I plowed through the full 23-page transcript of Warren Buffett's interview with the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, discovered via Felix Salmon. It was surprisingly light reading; Buffett cracked himself up so many times there could've been a laugh track. He offered plenty of the plain-spoken discernment for which he is idolized - pricing power makes even an idiot C.E.O. look like a genius; investing in your house is a currency play ("really a way to go short on the dollar"); Wall Street profits by fooling its customers with complex risk underwriting ("There's just more money in contracts that people don't understand"); Bank of America's Ken Lewis is the unheralded hero of the financial crisis because he saved the world as we know it by buying Merrill Lynch when he could have had it the next day for nothing.

No two species of iconic American outerwear mate quite so well as the bomber and the varsity letter. One particularly fine specimen can be found in the window of Blackrainbow, a boutique at 68 rue des Archive, in Paris. It has existed online and within the department store Citadium for four years, and this past January opened its first stand-alone shop. In addition to a well-edited selection of street-wear brands like Stüssy, Wood Wood, Woolrich, Barbour and Supra, Blackrainbow produces a small in-house label that includes a yearly limited-edition leather jacket manufactured by hand in France. Editor's Note (slightly overdue). An article on Oct. 21, 1942, about the death of Byron Darnton, a war correspondent for The New York Times, described the death as "accidental" without any elaboration. Two subsequent articles said the boat he was traveling on "was bombed from the air." It was many years before The Times explained further: Mr. Darnton was killed by friendly fire in an attack by an American B-25 bomber on the Australian fishing boat that was carrying the reporter and a force of American troops to Buna, in New Guinea. The circumstances of his death quickly became known to his family and were recounted correctly in Meyer Berger's 1951 history, "The Story of The New York Times: 1851-1951," and in a 1975 article in The Times by Martin Arnold reporting on the discovery of Mr. Darnton's last notebook, the one in which he was writing when he died.

Though exceptional rookies are able to rack up points, assists, or rebounds from Day 1, it's a rare first-year player who begins his pro career as a competent defender. N.B.A.-level defense doesn't only require athletic tools, but also defensive awareness and familiarity with a system that young players often lack. Each player develops on his own curve; some may make significant strides by his second or third season, and others may not be fully comfortable on defense until they settle into the right system or alongside the right on-floor leader.

AUSTIN, Tex. - The horror director Ti West returns to SXSW with "The Innkeepers," his follow-up to the creepy "House of the Devil." But this time, the laughs are almost as plentiful as the scares. His film, about two staffers at a vintage hotel who may have more guests on site than they thought, uses many of the conventions of old-fashioned horror, but adds in characters not usually found in those films. In an interview appropriately conducted at the historic (and sometimes spooky) Driskill Hotel, Mr. West spoke about his goals for the film, including experimenting with jump "jokes," rather than jump scares.

In Germany, where anti-nuke fervor runs high, Chancellor Angela Merkel announced that seven nuclear plants have been shut down for testing as part of a nationwide review. Meanwhile, the German news media have their own way of dealing with the crisis. According to The Guardian, Süddeutsche Zeitung, a Munich-based daily, noted that a novel for young people with a nuclear theme, "Die Wolke" ("The Cloud"), by Gudrun Pausewang, published a year after the Chernobyl disaster, hit No. 2 on German Amazon over the weekend. And though Japan lies nearly 6,000 miles from Germany, Bild, "Europe's biggest-selling tabloid," ran a nuclear meltdown Q.&A. anyway. The queries? " 'Is it O.K. to carry on eating sushi?' (Answer: yes. German sushi restaurants do not usually use Japanese fish); and 'Should I buy a Geiger counter?' (no)."

In last Friday's column, I cited some research to suggest that young people today have a more expanded sense of self than young people a generation ago. The meaner way of saying this is that they are more narcissistic. I hesitate to use the meaner vocabulary because of my sense that people under 30 are a remarkable generation: they volunteer more, hurt each other less and hurt themselves less than previous generations.

Deborah Eisenberg was named the winner of the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction on Tuesday for "The Collected Stories of Deborah Eisenberg" (Picador), a compilation of four volumes of her work. It was chosen from a selection of roughly 320 novels and short story collections, all published in the United States in 2010. Laura Furman, one of the judges, said of Ms. Eisenberg's collection, "From the first to the last of her collected stories, Deborah Eisenberg demonstrates her sharp intelligence, literary inventiveness and her clear understanding of human interconnectedness as it exists in isolation." She will receive $15,000; the four finalists, Jennifer Egan, Jaimy Gordon, Eric Puchner and Brad Watson, will receive $5,000. An awards ceremony is scheduled for May 7 at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington.

That guy who said "The times they are a-changin' " really knew what he was talking about, didn't he? Adding to the itinerary of locations where Bob Dylan has never previously played and where we never imagined he'd someday appear in concert, that ragged counterculture bard is slated to give a performance in Vietnam next month, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Dylan, whose songs like "Blowin' in the Wind" and "Masters of War" were sung at many a Vietnam War-era protest, is scheduled to perform a set list of his own determining on April 10 at RMIT University in Ho Chi Minh City. Rod Quinton, the general manager of Saigon Sound System, a Ho Chi Minh City company that is promoting the concert, told The A.P. that Mr. Dylan "is a very important legend of music, and we think it's important that Vietnamese people, particularly the younger generation, are exposed to his legacy and what he's done for music." The director of Art Performances Department of the Vietnamese government said Mr. Dylan had been granted permission to give the concert, which will come days after his first performances in China, in Beijing on April 6 and in Shanghai on April 8. The A.P. said tickets for Mr. Dylan's Ho Chi Minh City performance would run from about $43 -- just more than Vietnam's monthly minimum wage -- to about $120 for V.I.P. seats.

Imagine you're an editor at The Paris Review, the product of a WASPy New England milieu. Your life entails daily interactions with George Plimpton - editing, writing, looking for the next Philip Roth. Then, for reasons that seemed reasonable at the time, you decide to pour your life savings into a cruddy bodega in the Boerum Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn for the sake of your Korean-American wife's parents. A New York story par excellence, Ben Ryder Howe's "My Korean Deli" is a hilarious account of clashing cultures and backbreaking, soul-squeezing vocational juggling. Here, Howe takes questions on his life post-deli and his relationship with his stubborn Korean mother-in-law ("the Mike Tyson of Korean grandmothers"), and even offers a few pointers on what to avoid at a convenience store.

"Shorts just past the knee somehow felt new and freeing for spring," says Erin Beatty, one of the designers at Suno. "It's time to move past all that was short and tight and into something looser, longer and a bit less overtly sexy." Baggy slackettes may be more similar to men's board shorts than conventional women's shorts, but this season is no stranger to men's-wear-inspired women's wear. If you can wear your boyfriend's brogues, why not his swimwear? While board shorts may evoke images of Venice Beach grunge, the runway counterparts are more metropolitan than boardwalk. Wear a drapey silk blouse and a clunky pair of heels with Stella McCartney's denim shorts or elongate your silhouette by donning a longer cotton blazer with the brightly hued Diane von Furstenberg bottoms to tap in on sport-street culture's graphic and carefree essence. "Surf style never really changes because we don't wear a lot of clothes to begin with," says the professional surfer Malia Jones. "But to see variations of shore style on the runway takes us beyond the beach, and I love that!"

In the wake of President Obama's announcement last week that military trials will resume at Guantánamo Bay and that the prison camp will remain open indefinitely, it's well worth taking the time to read Michael Paterniti's article from the February issue of GQ about the current life of former detainee Mohammad Jawad. Jawad is one of two minors (the other is Omar Khadr) held for years at the prison camp. His precise age is not known, but human rights workers and family members claim he was was 12 when he was detained in December 2002. (The American military says he was at least 16.) He was released from Gitmo in August 2009 after a federal judge ruled the military's case against him was "riddled with holes" and the chief prosecutor of the case resigned in protest of the military commissions. Paterniti, who recently wrote about Haiti for this magazine, also compiled a partial but fascinating oral history of the camps, which accompanies his GQ article online.

And people. We have always been bound together. Humans are animals, after all. And each new bit of scientific research adds weight and complexity to our genetic intimacy, not just with primates, but with distant relatives like fruit flies and sponges. We share behaviors. We share homes and habitats. We consume each other. Mostly we eat them, a moral quandary for many people. But we still do feed multitudes of parasites, mosquitoes and the odd shark. This issue of Science Times is devoted to our many bonds with animals, and also to the distance between us and them. No other animal makes operas or nuclear weapons. How did we become so different? What made us human?

There comes a day in the life of any transportation reporter --ever the impartial observer --when a personal travel experience seems too amusing to resist a mention. Reader, bear with us: today is that day. Last week, City Room plunked down into one of the new blue leather seats aboard the Acela Express, Amtrak's Northeast Corridor high-speed rail service, and settled in for what we expected to be a peaceful, environmentally friendly trip to Washington.

James Frey has avoided traditional publishers with his next novel, ''The Final Testament of the Holy Bible,'' the story of a modern-day Jesus that his publisher, the Gagosian Gallery, predicted would be ''the most compelling and provocative work of his career.'' The book is set in the Bronx, and Mr. Frey's version of the Messiah is a heavy drinker. It is set for release on Good Friday. The Gagosian Gallery, which has never published a novel before, will print only 11,000 copies. The book will include original artwork by Ed Ruscha, Terry Richardson and Dan Colen, among others. Mr. Frey will make an e-book edition available to traditional retailers. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Carol Channing, Ozzy Osbourne and A Tribe Called Quest may not show up together on any iPod playlist ever created in human history, but they'll all have a presence in movies being shown at this year's Tribeca Film Festival. Among the features that Tribeca organizers announced on Monday to round out the festival's 2011 program are ''Carol Channing: Larger Than Life,'' a documentary directed by Dori Berinstein about that ''Hello, Dolly!'' star; ''God Bless Ozzy Osbourne,'' directed by Mike Fleiss and Mike Piscitelli, about the 40-year career of that long-lived heavy-metal singer; and ''Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest,'' directed by Michael Rapaport, about that vintage-1990s hip-hop group. Other films announced on Monday include the comedy ''A Good Old Fashioned Orgy,'' written and directed by Peter Huyck and Alex Gregory, and starring Jason Sudeikis of ''Saturday Night Live''; ''Higher Ground,'' the directorial debut of Vera Farmiga (''The Departed''); ''The Trip,'' a comedy from Michael Winterbottom featuring his ''Tristram Shandy'' stars Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon; and ''Revenge of the Electric Car,'' the director Chris Paine's follow-up to his documentary ''Who Killed the Electric Car?''

CHICAGO - Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi may not yet be a Republican presidential candidate, but his travel itinerary suggests that may be simply a formality, as he visited President Obama's hometown on Monday before flying to Iowa to begin testing themes of a probable campaign.-In a luncheon speech to the Chicagoland Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Barbour delivered a sweeping indictment of the president's economic and energy policies, saying that expanding the size of government would not lead to the creation of more jobs in the United States.-''Let's look at their record,'' he said. ''In the last two years, the federal government spent $7 trillion and our economy lost seven million jobs. I guess we ought to be glad they didn't spend $12 trillion. We might have lost 12 million jobs.''-Mr. Barbour is among the wide field of Republicans who are considering entering the fight for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination. He has said that he intends to make a decision after the Mississippi legislative session ends next month.-In a 30-minute address to business leaders, Mr. Barbour offered a preview to the message of his potential candidacy, with a heavy emphasis on traditional Republican themes of economic growth, job creation and increasing oil production through expanding drilling. He delivered more criticism than specific policy proposals. -''In fairness, the Obama administration arrived in office facing some of the worst economic conditions in decades,'' Mr. Barbour said. ''But for more than two years, this administration and its Congress has pursued policy after policy that created economic uncertainty or directly hurt the economy.''-As the country's energy policy takes on heightened importance with the turmoil in the Middle East and the nuclear disaster in the wake of the earthquake in Japan, he said: ''The Obama energy policy basically boils down to this: increase the price of energy so Americans will use less of it. That's an environmental policy, not an energy policy.'' He stopped well short of declaring his intentions. In a question following the speech, a man in the audience asked if Mr. Barbour was ready to announce his presidential bid.

CAVALLO--Dominick. Adelphi University mourns the passing of our dear friend and esteemed colleague Dominick Cavallo who, for 31 years, served Adelphi with distinction and passion. He was a teacher, a scholar, a leader, a dean, a provost, a close adviser to Adelphi presidents, a writer, and a dedicated student advocate. He generously shared his knowledge and commitment to educational excellence with the Adelphi community. We'll honor his legacy through our dedication to the highest academic standards and active engagement in civic initiatives. Our thoughts are with his partner JoAnn Smith, his sister Jo, and JoAnn's children, Alex and Andrea who loved him as a father. Adelphi University President Robert A. Scott Provost Gayle D. Insler

DAVISON--Richard, of New York City and Kortright, NY, died on Thursday, March 10, 2011, from complications of Parkinson's disease at his farm in upstate New York. Born in New York City on April 15, 1926, he served in WWII as an aerial gunner in the Naval Air Force. While still in his 20s, he started a printing company specializing in the emerging field of offset lithography. After retiring to country life in his 40s, he established a horse farm but eventually returned part-time to city life and worked as a consultant to several international corporations. He loved the sports of horse racing, billiards, and snooker and, as a collector of antiquarian books, spent enjoyable afternoons in the bookshops of Milan and Parma searching for books printed by Giambattista Bodoni. Active in inner-city and urban affairs for 50 years, Mr. Davison helped establish the field of therapeutic communities. In the mid-1960s, he helped found the Phoenix House Foundation and remained an active board member until recently. He is survived by his wife, Abby Kinsley Davison, and his daughters from a previous marriage, Lisa Davison, of Seattle, WA, and Toni Davison of Mesa, CO. He was predeceased by his beloved Cooper.

Ramin Talaie/Bloomberg NewsRobert Greifeld, chief executive of Nasdaq OMX Group8:42 p.m. | Updated In an effort to stay relevant amid a wave of exchange deals, the Nasdaq OMX Group is moving closer to a rival bid for NYSE Euronext, one that could break up the Big Board operator's planned merger with Deutsche Borse, according to people briefed on the matter.

Trying to ramp up pressure on the White House to move forward on a trio of trade pacts, Senate Republicans said Monday that they would block confirmation of a new Commerce secretary or any other trade nominee until President Obama submitted trade deals with South Korea, Colombia and Panama for ratification. Leading Republicans said they had commitments from 44 Republican senators, more than enough to filibuster any nominee for the Cabinet post being vacated by Gary Locke. Senator Rob Portman of Ohio, a former Bush administration trade representative, said Republicans were acting to encourage the administration to advance trade deals the president supports.

RUDIN--Milton Samuel, 94, commercial financier and leasing pioneer, passed away on March 14, 2011. His warm heart, devotion to all, honesty, integrity and dazzling fastball will never be forgotten. Son of the late Jacob and Sarah Rudin, husband of his beloved late wife, Jeanette Rudin, he is survived by sons Dr. Stephen Rudin and Dr. Richard Rudin, and three grandchildren, Gabriel, Ian and Jillian Rudin. A memorial service will be held at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel on Wednesday, March 16, at 11:15am.

PetroChina agreed last month to buy a 50 percent stake in a Canadian gas venture for $5.4 billion. If the deal goes through, it will be the largest overseas acquisition on record for the Chinese oil company. The transaction will also signify a shift in the merger and acquisition strategy of the Chinese energy industry. For decades, major players like PetroChina, Sinopec and Cnooc focused on building out their operations in politically volatile regions like Sudan, Venezuela and Iran. Now, they are competing with the multinational giants on their own turf, striking partnerships and joint ventures in the United States, Canada and Latin America.

A music review on Monday about a performance on Friday by the conductor William Christie and his ensemble, at Alice Tully Hall, misstated the historical timing of ''actes de ballet'' by the composer Jean-Philippe Rameau. They were from the 1700s, not the 17th century.

If you're looking for the latest in home exercise equipment, you may want to consider something with four legs and a wagging tail. Several studies now show that dogs can be powerful motivators to get people moving. Not only are dog owners more likely to take regular walks, but new research shows that dog walkers are more active over all than people who don't have dogs.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about plans by Aufbau publishing house to release a recently discovered unabridged version of the World War II novel ''Every Man Dies Alone'' in Germany misidentified a market where the publisher Penguin is also considering a reprint. It is Britain, not the United States.

On the waterfront in Battery Park, passersby were mirrored on Monday in the surface of the East Coast Memorial, which honors soldiers who died in World War II.

The Department of Education announced on Monday that it would open an elementary school inside its headquarters at the Tweed Courthouse behind City Hall, a move that could chip away at the longstanding problem of school overcrowding in Lower Manhattan. To open the school, the department had to engage in a chess game of sorts. The basement at Tweed has doubled as an incubator for several new schools; it currently houses the Spruce Street School, which will move into its own building in September, where it will expand into second grade and eventually grow into eighth grade.

A British jury said on Monday that an Academy Award-winning special effects coordinator was not responsible for the death of a cameraman who was killed in a stunt mishap during the filming of ''The Dark Knight,'' Reuters reported. After less than two hours of deliberation, jurors at Crown Court in Guildford, southwest of London, ruled unanimously that the effects coordinator, Christopher Corbould, was not guilty of failing to ensure the safety of the cameraman, Conway Wickliffe. Mr. Wickliffe was killed in 2007 on the set of ''The Dark Knight,''Christopher Nolan's sequel to his superhero film ''Batman Begins,'' as he rode in a pickup truck driving parallel to a stunt car; the pickup missed a 90-degree turn and crashed into a tree. Last week, prosecutors argued that Mr. Corbould, who won an Oscar for his work on ''Inception'' and whose filmography includes several ''James Bond'' movies, did not follow proper safety guidelines in planning the stunt and that the accident was foreseeable. Mr. Wickliffe was honored in the closing credits of ''The Dark Knight,'' along with the actor Heath Ledger, who died before the film's release. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Archaeologists are criticizing the Smithsonian Institution over a planned show of objects salvaged from a shipwreck in the Java Sea, saying that the company that recovered the objects did not observe professional archaeological standards in doing so, the Web site Science Now reported Thursday. The ship, a ninth-century Arab dhow that carried glazed ceramics and gold and silver vessels from China, was discovered in Indonesian waters in the late 1990s and salvaged by a German company called Seabed Explorations GbR. In 2005, according to Science Now, most of the objects were sold to a company in Singapore for a reported $32 million. (The exhibition is currently on display at the ArtScience Museum in Singapore.) Three archaeological associations and three of the Smithsonian's internal research organizations have written to the Smithsonian's secretary, G. Wayne Clough, opposing the exhibition, arguing, among other things, that because of the methods employed by Seabed Explorations, valuable scientific information was lost. The Smithsonian has scheduled a panel of archaeologists and other experts to discuss concerns about the exhibition in April.

JONES--Judd. Actor, singer, dancer died peacefully at home March 9. He was 79. Born and raised in Alabama, Judd arrived in New York in 1954 with stars in his eyes. His booming bass baritone voice had been nurtured in the U.S. Army. He was assigned to a USO and fell in love with performing. "But if you want to make it on Broadway, you can't just sing," Chita Rivera told him. "You have to learn to act and dance." Judd toured for five years as Chino in West Side Story. He performed on Broadway, Off Broadway, in regional theater and with the Lincoln Center Repertory Co. His one-man shows celebrated Paul Robeson and Bert Williams. Judd adored his showbiz friends: Stokes, Keith, Martin, Tommy, Jeremy, Whoopi, Ron, Mike, Georgia, Julie, Jack, Brenda, Mary Louise, Christopher, Emily. He worshipped his divas: Leontyne, Renee, Bernadette, Patti, Audra, Betty, Barbra. He taught and mentored Ta'u, Patricia, Morgan, Chico, Christopher. After a moving Black History Month reading from Martin Duberman's slave chronicle "In White America," a sobbing girl apologized to the white-haired Judd for his suffering. "Oh, my dear, I'm not that old," he said. "I am an actor and I have lived a wonderful life in New York City." Judd is survived by his brother Edward. He is mourned by friends, neighbors and the Jones family. A memorial service will be held April 10, 7 pm, Good Shepherd Faith Church, 152 W. 66. Contributions may be made to Actors Fund, NYPL's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, Assn of Tenants of Lincoln Towers.

Bahrain is a very little place - fewer than a million people on one modest island. But Bosnia was small too, and it helped kick off World War I. The risk in Bahrain is that battles there could ignite a broader Shiite-Sunni conflict. As Vali Nasr (currently at the State Department, in Richard Holbrooke's old shop) wrote in his indispensable 2006 book, "The Shia Revival," Bahrain's Shiites, who account for more than 70 percent of the population, "consider themselves to be the salt of the earth ruled by a minority of Sunni settlers who invaded from Qatar in the eighteenth century." Since Bahrain gained independence from Britain in 1970, Nasr writes, "Shias have been heavily involved in every coup attempt, street agitation, uprising and reform movement in the Persian Gulf emirate."

A play about Bernard Madoff that had been slated for production at a Jewish theater company in Washington last summer but was canceled after a legal threat from the author and Holocaust survivor Elie Wiesel, who was depicted as a character, will now go on at that theater in a revised version, The Washington City Paper reported. The play, "Imagining Madoff" by Deborah Margolin, originally depicted a close relationship between Mr. Madoff and Mr. Wiesel, who in real life lost all his and his wife's savings and $15.2 million of his charitable foundation's assets in Mr. Madoff's Ponzi scheme. Before the play's premiere at Theater J in Washington, Ms. Margolin sent Mr. Wiesel a copy of the script, hoping he would like it. Instead, he threatened to have his lawyer halt the production. Ms. Margolin agreed to revise the play, but when Theater J's artistic director, Ari Roth, volunteered to show the revised script to Mr. Wiesel's foundation, she decided to back out of the production entirely. Instead, she took the rewritten version - with Mr. Wiesel's character replaced by a fictional Holocaust survivor and poet named Solomon Galkin - to Stageworks/Hudson, a small theater company in upstate New York, where it was performed last summer. Mr. Roth saw the play there and subsequently renewed a discussion with Ms. Margolin about producing it at Theater J. The play will open on Aug. 31 and run through Sept. 25.

It's now clear that Gerald Wallace was only the most basic of the Portland Trailblazers' trade deadline acquisitions. However, dig deeper and what the Blazers netted was a ridiculous level of lineup versatility. With so many capable players able to swing between positions, Nate McMillan now has a canvas to handle all the free-form painting he can muster. McMillan has never been considered part of basketball's avant garde, but he's not afraid of going small, going big, or going with whatever works, and that makes him a worthy coach to handle such a strange roster.

As the new minority party in the House, Democrats will need to keep their caucus together if they hope to win many votes. But in the early months of the 112th Congress, a clear pattern is emerging that could cause concern for party leaders: some House Democrats are voting against their party more often than ever. An analysis by The New York Times of the first 180 recorded votes in the House shows that 14 Democrats have agreed with a majority of their colleagues less than 70 percent of the time. Six of those are below the 60-percent level, including Dan Boren of Oklahoma, who has voted with a majority of Democrats only 44 percent of the time.

A mandoline seems to be one of the last frontiers for the home cook. Maybe it seems too fussy with all those different blades, or maybe people are under the impression that you have to buy the most expensive model, which can get extremely pricey. But even the cheapest mandoline will make your life so much easier in the kitchen. For example, while I could, with much time and a little effort, thinly slice the potatoes for a gratin (such as in my column on Wednesday), running them through a mandoline takes about three minutes and gives me perfectly even, gossamer slices, which melt into the cream while baking in the oven. I also rely on my mandoline for paper-thin slices of fennel and zucchini for salads, and lovely wafers of beets that I serve carpaccio-style with a walnut-mustard dressing on top. And then there's my recipe for French apple tart, which depends on uniform slices of apple that are a breeze with a mandoline. So here are a few tips for those of you ready to take the plunge. Mandolines range in price based on the sharpness of the blade, the number of different cuts the blades will make and the sturdiness of the base.  I have used the Super Benriner (about $50), but years ago, I had the most basic Benriner ($20) and it served me just fine until the blades grew dull.  If you just want something basic, go for a cheaper model - they start somewhere around $15 (Norpro and Kyocera, for example, make them). And if you want something a bit more substantial (able to handle a more diverse range of fruits and vegetables), go for a sturdier, more advanced model. Oxo and Swissmar Borner (both about $40) are two reliable brands in this price range. And if you are looking to invest in something that will last you a lifetime and give you the widest variety of blades for different cuts, stainless steel professional models go for around $100, but you probably won't ever have to replace them. Mandolines from MIU sell for about $110; Bron has one for $150 and De Buyer's model, $229, allows for left-handed users. Most of the mandolines are compact and collapsible, which is particularly useful if you're in a tiny kitchen and space is at a premium. And if you're worried about cuts and scrapes, consider this glove, which has saved my knuckles from many an injury.

Are new immigrants weakening the social fabric? By one measure they are not. In fact, America seems to be corrupting them. In the journal Addictive Behaviors, Mildred Maldonado-Moline, Jennifer Reingle, Wesley Jennings and Guillermo Prado looked at drunk driving arrests among new immigrants and U.S.-born young adults. The recent immigrants had low DUI arrest rates. Second generation Americans had higher arrest rates than first generation Americans and third generation had higher rates than the second generation. The same pattern applied to arrests for marijuana use.

Riccardo Muti, the Italian maestro and the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, has been awarded the $1 million Birgit Nilsson Prize for his "extraordinary contributions" to the music world, The Associated Press reported. The prize was awarded by the Birgit Nilsson Foundation, established after the death of Nilsson, a renowned Wagnerian soprano, in 2005. The only previous winner, Placido Domingo, was chosen by Ms. Nilsson before her death; Mr. Muti was chosen, as subsequent winners will be, by the foundation and by a jury of at least five members. Mr. Muti, 69, who had surgery last month for facial injuries sustained in a fall from the podium during a rehearsal, was back at work last week conducting Giuseppe Verdi's "Nabucco" at the Teatro dell'Opera in Rome. Mr. Muti's fall was related to fainting because of a heart rhythm disturbance;  he subsequently received a pacemaker.

A new poll by Quinnipiac released on Wednesday shows that Michael Bloomberg's approval rating as mayor of New York has dropped to its lowest level in eight years. Mr. Bloomberg is now in negative territory - with only 37 percent of respondents approving of his performance as mayor and 51 percent of respondents disapproving - for the first time since November 2003. Lounging on a turquoise cotton covered daybed in the large bay window at the new Dar-Hi Hotel in Nefta, Tunisia, I heard the late-afternoon call to prayer echoed through La Corbeille, the hot-springs-fed oasis sprouting date palms nearby. In the distance the large salt lake Chott El Jerid shimmered in a brick-red mist. When I arrived the night before, I'd seen dromedary-crossing signs along the main access road from the airport in Tozeur. This was true North African desert culture.

The 2011-12 season for the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., will include world premieres by John Guare, Danai Gurira ("Eclipsed"), and the Irish playwright Marina Carr, along with productions of Tom Stoppard's "Travesties" and a new musical directed by John Doyle and based on the songs of Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, Playbill reported. The season will open with Mr. Doyle's musical "Ten Cents a Dance," a co-production with Williamstown Theater Festival, in which the cast doubles as the orchestra.  It will be followed by Ms. Carr's "Phaedra," an adaptation of that classical myth. Next up is "The Convert," by Ms. Gurira, a playwright and actress who was one of the creators and stars of "In the Continuum," about women living with AIDS in Africa and Los Angeles. "The Convert" is set in 1895 amid uprisings against colonialism in southern Africa. After "Travesties," the season will close with Mr. Guare's new play, "Are You There, McPhee?"

They say there's no such thing as a small role, but then what do you call a performance in a short film? The 60 short films selected for the 2011 Tribeca Film Festival include turns by actors as, well, big as Campbell Scott, Anthony LaPaglia and Colin Quinn. And some of the animated shorts feature the voices of David Duchovny, Joseph Fiennes and Ian McKellen. The films were chosen out of 2,862 submissions; they represent 20 countries and include 22 world premieres. Documentary subjects include a Haitian community that joins together to build a movie theater, a rock musician who decides to have transgender surgery, and a motivational speaker privately battling bipolar disorder. The narrative films include one in which a character tries to atone for a car accident that left a girl in a vegetative state; one about a man seeking justice after he thinks his son has been sexually assaulted; and - for those in search of lighter fare - a film titled "Mr. Stache" and described as "the awesome adventures of a man and his mustache." The short films will compete for three awards - Best Narrative Short, Best Documentary Short and the Student Visionary Award - with combined cash and value-in-kind prizes totaling more than $15,000. The winner of Best Narrative Short will qualify for consideration in the short-film category of the Academy Awards without the standard theatrical run. The Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 20 to May 1.

AUSTIN, Tex. - In "Hesher," a father and son suffer a tremendous tragedy and struggle to heal. Their mourning period is interrupted by Hesher (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), a long-haired, havoc-wreaking stranger who infiltrates their lives in uncomfortable ways. The film is part drama and part dark comedy. After playing at last year's Sundance Film Festival, the movie made its way to the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., complete with a fiery after-party. The director Spencer Susser discussed his film and what he thinks the character of Hesher represents.

Now that Hyderabad, India, is booming as a business hub (Microsoft, among other tech giants, is here), the city is looking past the stuffed suits and angling for the jet set. Its history rivals that of the more popular Jaipur, with distinct architecture from the Nizam rule and a mining heritage that gave us the Kohinoor diamond. A flurry of new openings - boutique hotels, upscale restaurants and shops catering to stars of the local Telugu film industry, known as Tollywood - is moving the metropolis into the spotlight.

If you could move anywhere in the world, where would you go? In the journal Israel Affairs, Yinon Cohen, Yitchak Haberfeld and Irena Kogan looked at the immigration patterns of Jewish immigrants from the former Soviet Union. They found that the most skilled emigrants went to the United States, where labor markets are more flexible and return on skills are higher. The less skilled moved to Germany or Israel. The U.S. still seems to be attracting the Best and the Brightest.

AUSTIN, Tex. --The grand jury prize for the best narrative feature film at the South by Southwest festival went to "Natural Selection" on Tuesday night. The film, written and directed by Robbie Pickering, is a comedy about a woman who gets to know the eldest son of her husband, who has been a regular donor at a sperm bank. The grand jury prize for a documentary went to the director Tristan Patterson's "Dragonslayer," about the life and love of a youth in Fullerton, a Southern California suburb. "Natural Selection" also received prizes for performances by Rachael Harris and Matt O'Leary, and for its script, editing and score, setting it up as the big winner at a festival that focused heavily on low-budget films with small, personal stories. On Wednesday, by contrast, Jodie Foster was set to appear with "The Beaver," from Summit Entertainment. That film, which she directed and in which she performs, stars Mel Gibson as a troubled toy executive who sorts out his life with the help of a beaver hand puppet. Mr. Gibson, who pleaded no contest on Friday to a misdemeanor count of battering his ex-girlfriend, Oksana Grigorieva, is not expected to attend the film's Wednesday-night premiere. The South by Southwest festival, which explores, film, music and digital culture in presentations and panels, continues here through Sunday.

To help travelers avoid the pileup of indistinguishable black bags on the luggage carousel, Tumi has enlisted the graffiti artist John Matos to decorate a group of its lightweight Vapor cases. Matos, who goes by Crash, started spray-painting walls in the Bronx in 1975 and was showing in galleries and museums by the 1980s. For the Tumi project - which will be limited to 1,000 of each case in the four-piece collection - Matos explains that he "didn't sit there thinking, What would be cool on a Tumi bag?" If he'd thought of himself as just a tagger for hire, he says, "the work wouldn't have come out as good." $445 to $595; tumi.com.

The tragic bus crash last weekend that took the lives of 15 people heading home to New York after a day of gambling at the Mohegan Sun casino in Connecticut brought me back to Dec. 26, the day the blizzard of 2010 buried much of the East Coast in snow. My husband and I were flying home to New York City that day after visiting family in Cleveland for the holiday. When LaGuardia Airport was shut down just as our plane approached the city, the pilot announced that our flight was being diverted to the nearest available airport. We found ourselves in Syracuse - where it was not snowing! - wondering how, and when, we were going to get home. Eventually the airline gave the passengers who were on our flight the option of either checking into a hotel overnight or taking a bus to New York City, for those who were crazy enough to take their chances on the road.

KALATSKY--Judith. The Yad Avraham Institute mourns with profound sadness the untimely passing of Rebbitzin Judith Kalatsky, beloved wife of Rabbi Yosef Kalatsky shlita, Dean of the Yad Avraham. She was dedicated to living a life of Torah and instilling it into her children. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Rabbi Kalatsky, her children, grandchildren, and her entire family. The funeral and interment was in Jerusalem, Israel on March 15, 2011. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Board, officers, members and friends of the Yad Avraham Institute.

MORE VEGETABLES, DEAR? Q. My boyfriend doesn't eat vegetables aside from potatoes, mushrooms and onions. He was never forced to eat his veggies as a child because his dad doesn't like them either. It falls to me to come up with meals that involve minimal vegetables or to have them on the side. I love everything from brussels sprouts to chard to kohlrabi, so making meat-and-potatoes dinners is really tough. And really boring. I've tried asking him for ideas on how he might like to try green beans, for example, and I offer to give him recipes, but I always get the reply that nothing sounds appetizing. He sees right through zucchini bread and will even leave all the carrots behind in a bowl of chicken soup, claiming that he wasn't trying to avoid them but that it just happened. Am I fighting a losing battle with 23 years of ingrained taste?

Last year when the Dallas Museum of Art celebrated the 25th anniversary of one of its largest donations - a collection of some 1,400 works of art, including paintings by Van Gogh, Renoir, and Pissarro - it probably didn't anticipate that it would soon be forced to defend its ownership of the art. But that's what has happened. The collection, amassed by Emery Reves, a writer and publisher who was a close friend of Winston Churchill, was donated to the museum by Reves's widow, Wendy Reves, who died in 2007. The Reveses lived in the South of France in a villa that had originally been built for Coco Chanel.

NATIONAL An article on Feb. 23 about developments in the investigation of a 2008 arson fire at the Texas governor's mansion misstated the role played by an F.B.I. informer, Brandon Darby, in an earlier case in Minnesota. In that case, two men were accused of making and possessing gasoline bombs at the Republican National Convention in St. Paul in 2008. Both men eventually pleaded guilty. Initially, however, one of them implicated Mr. Darby, saying Mr. Darby had persuaded him to make the bombs. He later conceded that Mr. Darby had not entrapped him.

Matthew Whitaker is only 9, but he can play seven musical instruments. He lives with his father, Moses, and his mother, May, in Hackensack, N.J., and has three half-siblings. Every Saturday, he travels to New York City for music lessons at Lighthouse International and the Harlem School of the Arts. Born 23 weeks premature, Matthew weighed 1 pound 11 ounces. The oxygen that kept him alive added pressure that damaged his retinas. He has never had his vision, but other senses -- hearing, smell and touch -- are enhanced. Matthew started playing music when he was 3 and his grandfather gave him a small Yamaha keyboard. ''He hears everything as music,'' his father said. The fax machine sounds like an A. The copy machine is a B-flat. Jackhammers are drum beats. Describing the city, Matthew stands and pivots 360 degrees with his fingers pointing straight in front of him. ''New York City is a circle of sounds,'' he said. ''The subway, the cars, the jackhammers. And everybody has a smile on their faces. It's musical, it's dark and so beautiful. There are no animals.''

BUSINESS DAY An article on Monday about The Week, a news magazine, misidentified its founders. The magazine was started in London in 1995 by Jolyon Connell and Jeremy O'Grady, two British journalists; it was not created by Felix Dennis, who was an early supporter of the idea and a major investor who later purchased the magazine and established an American version.

This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SAFEGUARD A top banking regulator approved a plan to seize and unwind big banks, a proposal that will help address those ''too big to fail'' firms whose collapse could imperil the financial system. The board of Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, led by its chairwoman, Sheila C. Bair, left, voted on Tuesday to approve rules intended to create an orderly process to unwind large institutions. The rules outline how creditors can file a claim and how those claims will be addressed.

Schumer of New York, long admired, and reviled, for his uncanny ability to make it all about Chuck, has worked his way into the party's No. 3 job in the Senate, where he puts his promotional talents to work on behalf of all his Democratic colleagues.

Jeremy Mage hefted the guitar onto his left knee, ran his left hand up the fret board and inclined his chin over the instrument, turning the pegs and strumming until the six strings were tuned. He straightened up and looked out at the crowd -- now was the time when a guitarist would probably call for a throat-moistening beer. ''Can you bring that little yellow box over here?'' he asked the crowd, pointing to a box of tissues, his eyes already damp. ''I'm going to need it.''

Federal and local law enforcement officials raided medical marijuana operations in Montana this week as legislators debated a proposal intended to repeal the law that legalized its use. The state's House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed the repeal bill last month, but in a 6-to-6 vote, it failed to advance past a Senate committee. The United States attorney's office in Montana said 26 criminal search warrants were executed in 13 communities as part of an investigation into marijuana distribution and trafficking.

6 A.M. (TCM) TRIBUTE TO THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART FILM ARCHIVE Founded in 1935 as the Film Library, the archive now includes more than 22,000 films and 4 million photographs. Its collection of international films is considered the strongest in the United States. Acting as hosts for the day's 15 films will be Robert Osborne, who will be joined by Rajendra Roy, the museum's chief curator of film, and Anne Morra, associate curator. The all-day tribute begins with ''Bringing Up Baby'' (1938), Howard Hawks's screwball comedy starring Cary Grant (above, with Katharine Hepburn) as a stodgy paleontologist seeking money for his museum, and Hepburn as an eccentric heiress who throws a wrench into his game. The prime-time portion includes Morris Engel's ''Weddings and Babies'' (1958), a naturalistic study of a New York photographer (John Myhers) struggling to become financially independent, at 8; and Otto Preminger's ''Bonjour Tristesse'' (1958), an adaptation of Françoise Sagan's novel about decadent lives on the French Riviera, starring David Niven, Jean Seberg and Deborah Kerr, at 9:30. At 11:30, ''The Projectionist'' (1971), Harry Hurwitz's portrait of a man (Chuck McCann) living deep within the movies he projects, makes its TCM premiere. 9 A.M. (CUNY) ELDRIDGE & CO. Dr. Nawal El Saadawi, left, an Arab feminist who for decades has fought female genital mutilation, was jailed by the Egyptian government in 1981 before fleeing the country in 1988. She returned to Tahrir Square this year to participate in the demonstrations that lead to the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak. In this interview with Ronnie Eldridge, Dr. Saadawi, who will be 80 this year, speaks about her childhood dreams of a revolution in Egypt, why the country's military protected the people, and why young Egyptian men want equality for women.

LIBYA Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi used tanks, heavy artillery and airstrikes to rout insurgents at Ajdabiya, who were holding the last defensive line before Benghazi, the rebel capital and the country's second largest city. As the shelling intensified, hundreds of cars careened through the streets as residents fled, heading north to Benghazi, about 100 miles away. BAHRAIN The battle for control of the island kingdom intensified, with Iran lashing out at the arrival of Saudi troops to help retake the streets from antigovernment protesters, and the king declaring a three-month state of emergency. Two people were killed by the security forces, and the government said protesters had killed a member of the security forces.

MAGUIRE--John P.,of St. Louis, MO, died on Friday, March 11, 2011. Husband of Mary-Emily (nee Jones) for 64 years. A native of New Britain, CT, Mr. Maguire also lived in Hartford, New York City and Lloyd Harbour, Long Island. Mr. Maguire attended Holy Cross College for one year and graduated from Babson College, Princeton University and Yale Law School. During his career, he served as an associate of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, as a Vice President and Director of Forbes, Inc., as General Counsel of Texas Butadiene & Chemical Corporation and as Vice President and Corporate Secretary of General Dynamics Corporation. After retirement from General Dynamics, he formed J.P. Maguire Investment Advisors. The firm was subsequently merged into Fiduciary Asset Management where Mr. Maguire continued as an advisor until his death. He is survived by a daughter, Joan. A funeral service will be held at Our Lady of Pillar Church, on Saturday, March 19, 2011, 401 S. Lindbergh, St. Louis, MO at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Peter Dunbar Maguire Scholarship Fund at the John M. Olin School of Business, Washington University, St. Louis. Please share your condolences at: kriegshausermortuary.com

If you live in an apartment, or tend to let surplus vegetables die in the crisper drawer, you may think that that the do-it-yourself food movement does not apply to you. Not so. Making some of your own staples -- and a few luxuries, like chocolate-hazelnut paste or better-than-balsamic maple vinegar -- is possible, and enormously gratifying. What follows is a D.I.Y. starter kit: small kitchen projects that any cook can tackle. What they all have in common is that they are simple, seasonless and a clear improvement on the store-bought version. Many books on craft food are daunting: full of advice on how to put up bushels of kale or bury an old washing-machine drum to use as a root cellar. Nothing here requires special equipment, a shed or a backyard; no canning or even freezing is involved.

That guy who said ''The times they are a-changin' '' really knew what he was talking about, didn't he? Adding to the itinerary of locations where Bob Dylan has never previously played and where we never imagined he'd someday appear in concert, that ragged counterculture bard is slated to give a performance in Vietnam next month, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Dylan, whose songs like ''Blowin' in the Wind'' and ''Masters of War'' were sung at many a Vietnam War-era protest, is scheduled to perform a set list of his own determining on April 10 at RMIT University in Ho Chi Minh City. Rod Quinton, the general manager of Saigon Sound System, a Ho Chi Minh City company that is promoting the concert, told The A.P. that Mr. Dylan ''is a very important legend of music, and we think it's important that Vietnamese people, particularly the younger generation, are exposed to his legacy and what he's done for music.'' The director of Art Performances Department of the Vietnamese government said Mr. Dylan had been granted permission to give the concert, which will come days after his first performances in China, in Beijing on April 6 and in Shanghai on April 8. The A.P. said tickets for Mr. Dylan's Ho Chi Minh City performance would run from about $43 -- just more than Vietnam's monthly minimum wage -- to about $120 for V.I.P. seats. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Times's system rewards its participants for picking lower-seeded teams by giving bonus points based on the difference in the two teams' seedings; it does not give the same number of points regardless of which team is picked.

Deborah Eisenberg was named the winner of the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction on Tuesday for ''The Collected Stories of Deborah Eisenberg'' (Picador), a compilation of four volumes of her work. It was chosen from a selection of roughly 320 novels and short story collections, all published in the United States in 2010. Laura Furman, one of the judges, said of Ms. Eisenberg's collection, ''From the first to the last of her collected stories, Deborah Eisenberg demonstrates her sharp intelligence, literary inventiveness and her clear understanding of human interconnectedness as it exists in isolation.'' She will receive $15,000; the four finalists, Jennifer Egan, Jaimy Gordon, Eric Puchner and Brad Watson, will receive $5,000. An awards ceremony is scheduled for May 7 at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Your celebration of the creative mind and soul and of literature and art guided and encouraged us to follow our hearts. Our lives will be forever filled with your bright light. Our lives will be forever changed and we will always love you.

BERLIN -- With the crisis in Japan raising fears about nuclear power, Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Tuesday that she will temporarily shut down seven German nuclear power plants that began operations before the end of 1980 as officials begin a three-month safety review of all of the country's 17 plants. The move came as European energy ministers in Brussels considered the introduction of stress tests in order to see how the bloc's 143 nuclear plants would react in emergencies. Construction procedures too might be reassessed, according to Olivier Bailly, a spokesman for the European Union Commission.

The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday asked the owner of the former Manufacturers Hanover Trust building on Fifth Avenue at 43rd Street to revise its renovation plans for the building's interior, which the commission designated a landmark last month. The commission made its recommendations following public testimony at a hearing during which several preservationists argued that the proposed changes to the interior of the 1954 building, originally by Gordon Bunshaft, would amount to sacrilege.

LEE--Mathew. The trustees, faculty and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of Mathew H.M. Lee, M.D., former chair of the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine and medical director of our Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine. His legacy extends well beyond his scientific achievements as he will be remembered for his extraordinary depth of humanism, clinical expertise and courage. A true protege of Dr. Howard Rusk, he enriched NYU Langone Medical Center with compassion, courage, and leadership in a career lasting nearly 50 years marked by tireless and selfless devotion to people with disabilities. His contributions to our institution and to the field of physical medicine and rehabilitation will live on and continue to shape the care we provide for people with disabilities. Kenneth G. Langone, Chair, Board of Trustees; Robert I. Grossman, M.D. Dean and CEO

Oh, for the wings of a dove. Or an eagle, or even a chickadee. I mean, anything that might help an earthbound actor flap his way off a stage. There's so much flying going on in the theater these days you wonder if an aviator's license won't soon be mandatory for participation in a Broadway or West End production. Then why do I get the feeling that when it comes to matters of flight, many of these shows never achieve lift-off? Most notoriously, there's the ever-beleaguered, ever-in-previews ''Spider-Man: Turn off the Dark,'' a musical that promises aerobic, in-the-air battles will be fought high above our heads. Yet the night I attended the production last month, the poor lug (or lugs, since there are assorted actors and stunt doubles) playing the building-leaping title character kept getting stranded or stuck like, well, a fly in a spider's web.

The Sundance Film Festival is taking its show on the road. Robert Redford, founder of the nonprofit Sundance Institute, and AEG Europe, owner of the O2 entertainment complex in London, on Tuesday said they would collaborate on a four-day multidisciplinary arts festival, with the inaugural installment to be held next year. Sundance London will run April 26 to April 29 at the O2 and include film screenings, live music performances, discussions, panels and other public cultural programming. The Sundance Institute, best known for its annual film festival in Utah, will curate the film component; AEG Europe will stage and promote music events.

A company hoping to build a facility to export coal to Asia from Washington State has withdrawn its permit application and said it would start anew. The company, Millennium Bulk Terminals, which wants to build a facility on the Columbia River, had received a preliminary permit for the project. But documents recently made public as part of a legal challenge based on environmental concerns suggested that the company hoped to build a facility far larger than its initial application described. The company said in a statement on Tuesday that its new application would include a more thorough environmental analysis ''to show our continued commitment as a good neighbor.''

ALBANY - State lawmakers expressed outrage on Tuesday over a news report detailing cases of abuse at state-run group homes for the developmentally disabled, vowing to seek criminal prosecution of workers and to introduce legislation improving oversight. The chairman of the Assembly's Mental Health Committee, Assemblyman Felix W. Ortiz of Brooklyn, called for the immediate resignation of any state officials who were complicit in the abuse cases detailed in an investigation published in The New York Times.

The former chief executive of Freddie Mac may face a civil action as the government ramps up an investigation of disclosure practices at the mortgage finance giant and its sister company, Fannie Mae, people briefed on the investigation said. The executive, Richard F. Syron, a former president of the American Stock Exchange and now an adjunct professor and trustee at Boston College, has received a so-called Wells notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission, an indication the agency is considering an enforcement action against him.

Now certainly feels like one of those moments when the world needs to be explained to us, and Random House believes it has found just the writer to do it: Al Gore, the former vice president and Nobel Peace Prize winner, will write a new book about what he calls ''the drivers of global change,'' that connects the dots among social, economic and political forces shaping our times, Random House said on Tuesday. The book, which is planned for release next year and does not yet have a title, is the first acquisition for the publishing house by Jon Meacham, the author and former Newsweek editor, who was named an executive vice president at the Random House Publishing Group in January. Mr. Meacham, a Pulitzer Prize-winner for his Andrew Jackson biography ''American Lion,'' and, like Mr. Gore a Tennessean, said in a telephone interview that the former vice president's best-selling books ''An Inconvenient Truth'' and ''The Assault on Reason'' had established him as an author who ''has been early and right'' on anticipating global trends.

The N.F.L. lockout is taking a toll on players, who cannot work out or receive treatment at their teams' facilities. Now it may have an impact on incoming players, too. Leaders of the dissolved players union - it's now officially a trade association - are contemplating staging an event concurrent with the N.F.L. draft in April. The idea is to keep incoming players, who will be locked out as soon as they are chosen, from participating in the ritual of walking across the stage at Radio City Music Hall to shake Commissioner Roger Goodell's hand and receive the hat and jersey of their new team.

SMITH--Brian D. Brian D. Smith, a renowned real estate lawyer who led the London office of law firm Goodwin Procter LLP, died suddenly in London after suffering a brain hemorrhage on March 2, 2011. He was 60. He is survived by his partner and soul mate, Josefina Jimenez, and their rescue dog, Stella, who lived with the couple. Brian approached his life and career with an open mind, a giving heart and an adventuresome spirit. He practiced law for 25 years, focusing on the hospitality industry and advising many of the world's leading hotel brands. Prior to becoming a partner at Goodwin Procter, Brian was a shareholder of Heller Ehrman LLP and was affiliated with the firm for 17 years. He began his legal career at Pettit & Martin. Brian provided pro bono counsel to nonprofit organizations dedicated to preserving open space and natural resources, including International Rivers, the Bay Area Ridge Trail and the Nature Conservancy. Born to Fran and Ed Smith in Hartford, Connecticut in 1950, Brian attended junior high school in Daytona Beach, Florida. He returned to Connecticut to attend the Kent School, graduating in 1968. He received his undergraduate degree from Brown University in 1972 and his law degree from the University of Virginia School of Law in 1977, earning Order of the Coif honors. Brian completed his education at Cambridge University in London, earning a Ph.D. in international environmental law in 1986. His thesis, "State Responsibility and the Marine Environment: The Rules of Decision," was published by Oxford University Press. Brian was, according to his many friends and colleagues, a true Renaissance man a devoted scholar, an avid reader and an enthusiastic outdoorsman. "Brian's time with us was all too brief, but in that span he touched many and inspired us in ways that will have a lasting impact," said Goodwin Procter Chair Regina M. Pisa. A memorial service has been planned for June 3, 2011 in San Francisco. In lieu of flowers, donations in Brian's memory may be made to The Brian and Josie Charitable Gift Fund, Fidelity Charitable Gift Fund, PO Box 770001, Cincinnati, OH 45277-0053.

The hearse pulled slowly up a narrow drive of a cemetery in Flushing, Queens, Monday afternoon and stopped in front of a large granite gateway carved with the words Yiddish Theatrical Alliance. The gates open onto thousands of headstones with Hebrew and English and Yiddish. This is Block 67 at Mount Hebron Cemetery, a special section maintained by the theatrical alliance, its plots reserved for those who worked in Yiddish theater in New York.

A music review on Saturday about Esa-Pekka Salonen's conducting of the New York Philharmonic, at a festival at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday, misidentified the cellist who traded decorative phrases with a violinist. It was the orchestra's principal cellist, Carter Brey -- not Colin Carr, a cellist who plays around the world but who is not in the Philharmonic.

Over the past decade, Pittsburgh has been a model of consistency in the Big East. The Panthers have made the N.C.A.A. tournament in all eight of Coach Jamie Dixon's seasons, with a record of 98-38 in Big East play. But in the first seven of those tournament appearances, Pitt, despite several high seeds, has gotten as far as the Round of 8 just once.

Every discussion about foreign aid is a heated discussion.  Readers of Tuesday's column on a new idea for foreign aid - paying for outcomes instead of providing money in advance - had plenty of suggestions about how to fix foreign aid (or why to abandon it).   But before we get to them, we should make sure we know what we're talking about when we say "foreign aid."   "It would be better if the citizens understood that 'foreign aid' is a misnomer," wrote Millie Bea of Washington (25).

In a letter sent directly to every N.F.L. player Thursday, Commissioner Roger Goodell asks the players to press their leaders - he still refers to their group as a union, although it decertified last week - to return to negotiations. The sides are not expected to meet until at least after a April 6 hearing in federal court in Minneapolis on the players' request for an injunction to lift the lockout imposed.

Gadget reviewers have been singing the praises of Apple's new "smart cover" for the iPad 2 ever since Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, showcased them on stage two weeks ago. Late last year I wrote an article about Chinese men and women who were queued up outside of Apple stores in New York with the hopes of buying an iPhone 4 or an iPad. These devices would then be smuggled into China and resold through an underground electronics black market that is largely fueled by the sale of Apple's sleek products.

Today we rise up in defense of traditional values. For example, is it a good idea to have sex with somebody on the first date? Probably not. In the Journal of Family Psychology, Dean Busby, Jason Carroll and Brian Willoughby studied the effect of sexual timing on later marriage relationships. They found that couples who waited before engaging in sex for the first time went on to have higher relationship satisfaction, even after controlling for education, the number of sexual partners, religiosity and relationship length.

This is the second in a three-part series.Before leaving McGuire Veterans Administration Hospital, after our first day of sketching two battle wounded Marines, Richard Johnson and I go by the Wounded Warrior Detachment office and thank Gunnery Sgt. Alain Frederique for setting everything up for us. The "gunny" says there's another Marine who would really love to participate, Lance Cpl. William "Kyle" Carpenter. It's pretty late in the day, and we ask if we can set up a time to meet and draw him tomorrow. The Gunny tells us no - Carpenter will be at Walter Reed all of the next day for medical appointments. Carpenter's face was virtually blown off and his right arm shattered by a grenade blast and after no less than 30 surgeries in nine weeks, he wants to tell his story. We don't want to miss this opportunity.We find Lance Corporal Carpenter relaxing on his hospital room's La-Z Boy lounger. His still-boyish face is a crazy quilt of scars. Kyle, as he prefers to be called, is resting his heavily bandaged right arm on a pillow across his lap. Both upper thighs are bandaged, and his right eye is a milky ghost of its former self.

Scott Burgess, the automotive critic for The Detroit News, resigned on Wednesday after a local Chrysler dealer complained about his review of the Chrysler 200 -- the centerpiece of the company's "Imported from Detroit" advertising campaign. There are certain things that all creative people share in common - and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitken's 2006 book "Broken Screen," which featured interviews with everyone from Robert Altman to Rem Koolhaas, challenged the convention of the linear narrative. Now, with his latest video project, Patterns & Repetitions, the artist sits down with a whole new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. There's LCD Soundsystem's James Murphy on the sound of snow; the artist Mike Kelley talking about Detroit, his hometown; and Jack White weighing in on Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. This week, The Moment features Jacques Herzog discussing instinct and architecture. But don't be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesn't do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

Hope is alive for the revival of an orchestra in Honolulu. A group of local business people and prominent citizens paid $210,000 at auction on Thursday for the assets of the Honolulu Symphony, which declared bankruptcy in October and was forced to liquidate.

The Bolshoi Ballet, with a major tour to Paris planed for the spring and the opening of its theater set for the fall after a long renovation, is facing leadership turmoil. Its artistic director, Yuri Burlaka, left after his contract expired on Tuesday, according to Reuters, and no successor was named. Also on Tuesday, Gennady Yanin, the company director, abruptly resigned; on Wednesday, a 37-year-old Bolshoi soloist, Yan Godovsky, was named director in his place. News reports, referring to an article in the Russian daily Izvestia, said Mr. Yanin resigned after an e-mail with a link showing erotic pictures of someone who resembled him was sent to hundreds of people. Efforts to reach Mr. Yanin on Thursday were unsuccessful.

In 1949, the African-American painters Charles Alston and Hale Woodruff covered the lobby walls at a Los Angeles insurance company headquarters - a trapezoidal Moderne building designed by the African-American architect Paul Williams - with murals of early black Californians including explorers, cowboys and oil riggers. Now the original owner, the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company, is being liquidated, and the Smithsonian's National Museum of African American History and Culture is planning to buy the works for $750,000 and remove them from the lobby. (They have been appraised for up to $5 million.)

I thought I'd share with you some of his tips.

There is an almost clinical sobriety to the photos in Todd Eberle's new book, "Empire of Space" (Rizzoli, $85). Culled from Eberle's 30-year career and presented in pairs, the pictures force you to consider the visual kinship between disparate subjects: a Jeff Koons sculpture begins to look like a tomato; Granny's plaid sofa becomes a Frank Lloyd Wright ceiling; and an old I.B.M. computer morphs into the United Nations Secretariat tower. Eberle says that after making this book, he finds such parallels everywhere: "It's incredible to have a new way of seeing the world."

When it comes to the complex science behind food preservation, recipes don't answer every question. In researching and writing this week's D.I.Y. handbook, I was lucky -- when the bacon looked too wet, or the kimchi appeared to be bubbling -- that I was able to call up the authors and ask why. When my cheese didn't set because I used the wrong kind of rennet, Robin Mather -- who keeps goats, chickens, and writes about self-sufficient living from her house in rural Michigan, diagnosed the problem. Are you thinking about trying out a D.I.Y. food project (from our guide, or elsewhere) this weekend? Send questions, concerns, and preliminary results by Monday, and I'll consult the experts.

Now that we all know high is low and sophistication may be disguised as pork belly sliders, I began a year or more ago considering the Jell-O shot as a Platonic concept pregnant with possibility.

AUSTIN, Tex. - Greta Gerwig is no stranger to SXSW. Her new film, "The Dish & the Spoon," marks the sixth time she has had a movie in the festival in an film career that has stretched the same number of years. This new film, directed by Alison Bagnall, about a woman and a young man (Olly Alexander) who bond during a tumultuous time in their lives. Ms. Gerwig's acting style, which A.O. Scott lauded for its "apparent absence of any method," is employed in this intimate, primarily two-character study.

The New York Times announced a plan on Thursday to begin charging the most frequent users of its Web site $15 a month. Under the plan, which will begin on March 28, visitors to NYTimes.com will be able to read 20 articles a month free. The most frequent users will pay $15 a month; print subscribers will have unlimited access.

Even before Merce Cunningham died, in 2009, plans were being made to ensure the choreographer's legacy. They included his company's farewell tour, which comes to the Joyce next week, and a new box set of music composed for his dances. Now the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis has acquired a trove of material that major 20th-century artists like Robert Rauschenberg and Andy Warhol made for Cunningham performances. The collection covers some 150 props, costumes, backdrops and other objects. Among them are a Rauschenberg combine and his costumes for the 1958 dance "Antic Meet," Frank Stella set pieces for "Scramble" (1967) and silver-colored pillows that Warhol contributed to "RainForest" (1968), as well as work by Jasper Johns. A spokesman for the museum would not comment on how much the Walker paid for the material. Some of the objects will go on display in November when the Merce Cunningham Dance Company's Legacy Tour reaches Minneapolis.

Making dips and spreads - the subject of this week's magazine column - is mostly about intensifying flavors. Since they're usually served in smallish dollops on relatively bland, starchy foods (like bread, chips, and crackers), dips should taste punchier than the kind of thing you eat by the forkful.

UNESCO is planning to send a delegation to Egypt early next week to assess the conditions at Egypt's archaeological sites and monuments, Ahram Online reported. Egypt's former antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, was invited to attend a UNESCO seminar in Paris this week marking the 40th anniversary of the UNESCO convention that seeks to prevent the illicit trade of cultural property, but could not attend; instead, he sent a message asking the international community for help in finding objects that have been looted from Egypt's museums and archaeological sites since that country's revolution began in January. On Wednesday, Egypt's Supreme Council of Antiquities released an illustrated list of 54 objects missing from the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, which was looted on Jan. 28. The list is much longer than the list of 18 missing objects that Mr. Hawass released on Feb. 13. Mr. Hawass originally claimed that nothing was missing from the museum.
