This week Home Fires is publishing "Still in the Fight," a three-part series by the Marine combat artist Michael D. Fay, recounting his visit to McGuire Veterans Administration Hospital in Richmond, Va., where he spent two days with wounded Marines in rehabilitation. Fay, along with his fellow combat artist Richard Johnson, is a member of the International Society of War Artists (ISWA), and in co-operation with the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History's Armed Forces History Division, set out to record a few days in the lives of wounded Marines in rehabilitation. In "Still in the Fight," Fay offers both a written and visual account of time spent with three soldier and their families, on the mend.Though "Still in the Fight" deals with Marines wounded in Afghanistan, the series may be seen as a sequel to "Drawing Fire," a five-part account published in 2010 that recounts in detail several weeks of Operation Steel Curtain in 2005 in Iraq. The conflicts in question are different, but both read in conjunction offer an inside view of the before, during and after of war.

The best part of writing for this blog is getting to talk to lots of successful business owners. Recently, I was reflecting on the companies who really capture my imagination and heart. They have in common an important ingredient for successful companies, large and small. It's not nice packaging or a good product at a good price or passion or exceptional service -- although those things are all important. It's that they all have a company story, told well.

You can't read Lady Gaga's poker face, and you can't hear her single "Born This Way" as the provocative pop singer intended on radio stations in Malaysia, where broadcasters are playing the song but obscuring lyrics that they feel encourage acceptance of homosexuality, The Associated Press reported. "Born This Way," whose chorus proclaims "I'm beautiful in my way / 'Cause God makes no mistakes," would already seem a tough fit in Malaysia, where last year the singer Adam Lambert had a concert protested by the Pan Malaysian Islamic Party, which said his shows promote "gay culture." And while radio stations there are playing the song, they have been garbling a lyric that says, "No matter gay, straight or bi, lesbian, transgendered life, I'm on the right track, baby," for fear that it violates Malaysian indecency laws. The Malaysian broadcaster AMP Radio Networks told The A.P. that those lyrics "may be considered as offensive when viewed against Malaysia's social and religious observances," adding that being gay or bisexual is "still considered as a 'taboo' by general Malaysians."

In our weekly "Poetry Pairing" series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem's themes. MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

It has been almost one week since the devastating earthquake and tsunami struck Japan. If, like me, you love design, you probably have a favorite Japanese designer in fashion, architecture, graphic design or ceramics. Japan is a country that has always nurtured design, from handcraft to industrially produced goods; as a result, good design has become synonymous with Japanese design. Many of the country's designers have been affected by the disaster, which continues to unfold in ways that are unfathomable to most of us. In Kasama and Mashiko, centers of ceramic production that are about halfway between Tokyo and Sendai, potters were hard hit by the quake when brick kilns collapsed and years' worth of production shattered in minutes. Moved by the desire to support their fellow artists, three enterprising women in the United States have organized Handmade for Japan, an online auction of handmade work donated by Japanese artists and American artists with ties to Japan. Ayumi Horie, a Japanese-American potter who lives in Hudson, N.Y., recruited her friends Kathryn Pombriant Manzella and Ai Kanazawa Cheung to solicit donations and set up the auction, while the illustrator David Gordon designed a logo overnight. Offers of support, in-kind donations and handmade goods have poured in via Twitter, Facebook and e-mail. And artists including the illustrator Lisa Congdon, the textile designer Kaoru Oka and the ceramists Jun Kaneko, Justin Rothshank, Kathy Erteman and Diana Fayt, to name a few, have contributed paintings, shawls and, of course, pottery. The auction will go live on eBay on March 24 and will run through March 27. Through GlobalGiving, 100 percent of the auction proceeds will support relief efforts in Japan. To see more, check out Handmade for Japan's Facebook page and Twitter feed.

AUSTIN, Tex. - "The FP," which screened in the SXFantastic sidebar of South by Southwest, may be the only full-length feature film in existence that combines Jerry Bruckheimer-esque action tropes with life-or-death duels played out on a game similar to Dance Dance Revolution. This comedic hybrid of styles and ideas comes from the minds of Jason Trost (who also stars in the film) and Brandon Trost, making their directing debut. "The FP," shot in the brothers' hometown of Frazier Park, Calif., celebrates its outlandishness while its performers play it straight. In this video interview, they discuss their collaboration.

AUSTIN, Tex. -- By the time I arrived at this year's South By Southwest music festival, on Wednesday, the din on East Sixth Street, where a strip of clubs runs block after block, was already rising. It was the din of live music and recordings, of come-ons and conversations, of pitches and pickup lines, of excited giggles and male banter, of tentative connections and of fortuitous reunions and, as the day goes on, of drunken bonhomie or befuddlement, of strategies being worked and of pure chaotic happenstance. It's the din of business meeting pleasure, which is what has now sustained SXSW into its 25th year.
In the last 17 years, I acquired in-laws who still live in Tokyo, and I have spent maybe a year of my life there. So the earthquake and everything else since then has a heavy immediacy.

ALBANY - For state lawmakers, Tuesday was one of the busiest days so far this year. Hundreds of New Yorkers converged here to lobby them for relief from budget cuts. Both houses of the Legislature passed separate spending plans, and their leaders held their first budget negotiating session. Yet amid the news conferences, floor debates and shouting protesters, one figure was absent: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

Riccardo Muti, the Italian maestro who is the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, has been awarded the $1 million Birgit Nilsson Prize for his ''extraordinary contributions'' to the music world, The Associated Press reported. The prize was awarded by the Birgit Nilsson Foundation, established after the death of Nilsson, the renowned Wagnerian soprano, in 2005. The only previous winner, Plácido Domingo, was chosen by Ms. Nilsson before her death; Mr. Muti was chosen, as subsequent winners will be, by the foundation and a jury of at least five members. Mr. Muti, 69, who had surgery last month for facial injuries sustained in a fall from the podium during a rehearsal, was back at work last week conducting Verdi's ''Nabucco'' at the Teatro dell'Opera in Rome. Mr. Muti's fall was related to fainting because of a heart-rhythm disturbance; he subsequently received a pacemaker.

Despite looking a lot like a kitchen-variety vegetable slicer, Discovery Bay Games new Duo ($40) has a very different function. It sits on your iPad screen for use with specially designed, multiple-choice style apps. The first app, called Yoomi (promounced ''you me'') can be downloaded now; a second, based on Smithsonian facts, is due next month. Both are free but remember-they are useless without the Duo. Yoomi contains hundreds of personal preference questions, like ''would you rather ride a bike or a horse?'' Like casting a secret vote, you touch your preference on the iPad screen, hidden from view by Duo's shield. The cards then flip around toward the other players, who try to guess your choice by placing one of their colored tokens on the associated holding bowl.

The grand jury prize for the best narrative feature film at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., went to ''Natural Selection'' on Tuesday night. The film, written and directed by Robbie Pickering, is a comedy about a woman who gets to know the eldest son of her husband, who has been a regular sperm bank donor. The grand jury prize for a documentary went to ''Dragonslayer,'' directed by Tristan Patterson and about the life and love of a skateboarder in Fullerton, a Southern California suburb. ''Natural Selection'' also received prizes for performances by Rachael Harris and Matt O'Leary, above, and for its script, editing and score, setting it up as the big winner at a festival that focused heavily on low-budget films with small, personal stories. On Wednesday, by contrast, Jodie Foster was set to appear with ''The Beaver,'' from Summit Entertainment. That film, which she directed and in which she performs, stars Mel Gibson as a troubled toy executive who sorts out his life with the help of a beaver hand puppet. Mr. Gibson, who pleaded no contest on Friday to a misdemeanor count of battering a former girlfriend, Oksana Grigorieva, is not expected to attend the film's Wednesday-night premiere. The South by Southwest festival continues through Sunday.
To the Editor:

Muammar el-Qaddafi claimed minor victories in some of their last footholds as they battled to hold off the Qaddafi forces' superior firepower. After days of retreat, the rebels appeared to be fighting for time in the hope of obtaining some form of international aid.

SPORTS An article on Feb. 26 about the emergence of Jimmer Fredette and the Brigham Young men's basketball team erroneously included a New York student on a list of high school players whom Fredette said he recalled watching while growing up. Kenny Anderson, who played at Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens and went on to be a guard in the N.B.A., was not one of them. (Fredette was born just a few months before Anderson graduated from high school, in 1989.)

On Tuesday, our 6-year-old daughter saw the above photo, which appeared very large on the front page of The Times, and asked my wife what was going on. ''It's a movie for grown-ups,'' my wife said. As a reporter, I'm not sure I would have said the same thing - maybe go for a scaled-back version of the truth, like, ''There was an earthquake in Japan and people got hurt''? But I was not about to contradict her after the fact. These what-to-tell-young-children decisions are happening all over the place, I suspect, as they do whenever there is a major catastrophe in the news.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Saturday about Jean Dinning, who wrote the hit song ''Teen Angel,'' included several errors. The city where she and her sisters Lou and Ginger had a 15-minute radio show was Enid, Okla., not Enid, Kan. The singer who died in a plane crash along with Buddy Holly and the Big Bopper was Ritchie Valens, not Richie. And the group that performed ''Teen Angel'' at Woodstock was Sha Na Na, not Shah-Na-Na.

While the MagicJack, a device that lets you make phone calls over the Internet, is well known thanks to its inescapable infomercials, it's not the only device of its kind. EastKentucky ended Cornell's tournament run in the Round of 16 last season. This year, the fourth-seeded Wildcats have another date with an Ivy League champion. On Thursday, they will face No. 13 Princeton in Tampa, Fla. The Tigers could pull off an upset, but as the former Kentucky player DeMarcus Cousins said before the game against Cornell last year, ''It's not a spelling bee.'' Also in Tampa, fifth-seeded West Virginia faces a trivia answer: No. 12 Clemson, the first winner of an at-large play-in game (or, as the N.C.A.A. refers to it, the First Four) in tournament history. WestAt first glance, it's an obvious matchup: No. 7 Temple against No. 10 Penn State, an in-state rival. The twist comes when you realize that the Owls and the Nittany Lions had to travel to Tucson for their opening game. No. 2 San Diego State is much closer to home and will take on No. 15 Northern Colorado. In Washington, No. 11 Missouri's frenetic style makes it a trendy upset pick against No. 6 Cincinnati. Bucknell faces No. 3 Connecticut and is dangerous in that position. In 2005, also as a 14 seed, the Bison upset Kansas.

GEORGE--Donny. The Department of Ancient Near Eastern Art at The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourns with profound sadness the loss of esteemed colleague Donny George Youkhanna, who was a superb archaeologist, curator, scholar, and friend. Donny lectured many times at the Museum and was a vital, creative force on our Visiting Committee. He was a wise and generous advisor on the cultural heritage of Iraq and on future plans for its protection, conservation, and presentation. Donny will be sorely missed and we extend heartfelt sympathy to his family.

9:15 P.M. (TCM) RIFIFI (1955) ''Do you want to see a tough gangster picture?,'' Bosley Crowther asked in The New York Times when he reviewed this Jules Dassin movie. ''Do you want to see a crime film that makes the characters of Mickey Spillane seem like sissies and, at the same time, gives you the thrill of being an inside participant in a terrific Parisian robbery?'' In what its fans consider to be the quintessential heist film, Jean Servais plays Tony le Stéphanois, a thief fresh from prison who took the fall to protect his young protégé, Jo le Suedois (Carl Mohner). But old habits die hard, and soon he is persuaded to join Jo, an Italian pimp (Robert Manuel) and a womanizing safecracker (Mr. Dassin, under the name of Perlo Vita, above right, with Mr. Servais) to rob a jewelry store in Paris in a scene staged ''like a ballet,'' Mr. Crowther wrote. There is a poetry about the film, ''and a poetic justice too,'' he added. ''Mr. Dassin has got the tender beauty of Paris at dawn, when there is no one stirring but milkmen, street cleaners, gendarmes -- and thieves. And he has ended his film with a feeling for the pathos of the comédie humaine that would do justice to a story with a more exalting theme.'' 7 P.M. (Syfy) DESTINATION TRUTH: LIVE FROM IRELAND -- THE SEARCH FOR THE BANSHEE GHOST In this four-hour St. Patrick's Day special Josh Gates and his team journey to Duckett's Grove Castle in Carlow, Ireland, seeking a banshee, a supernatural being said to wail outside a house before someone inside dies. Viewers can put their sleuthing skills to work during the broadcast at syfy.com/destination truth.

FRONT PAGE An article on March 4 about the possible effect on 30-year mortgages if the government were to shut down the housing finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac overstated the proportion of loans guaranteed by the companies that had down payments of less than 10 percent. Those loans made up 9 percent -- not two-thirds -- of all loans guaranteed between 2001 and 2008.

When Ivan Nova pitched for the Yankees late last season, his slider grip unleashed a pitch that acted like a flat curveball. After Toronto's Jose Bautista bashed it for a home run, Nova scrapped the grip. But he never gave up on the pitch, and on Wednesday it helped his bid to land a spot in the starting rotation. Using a new grip he learned from the pitching specialist Billy Connors, Nova's slider baffled the Baltimore Orioles for six no-hit innings in a 10-0 victory at Steinbrenner Field in Tampa, Fla.

The Up Close column on March 3 about the barber Martial Vivot referred incorrectly to his career in the United States. He worked for two salons before opening his own in 2008; he did not open a salon immediately after moving from France in 1999.

A play about Bernard L. Madoff that was slated for production at a Jewish theater company in Washington last summer but was canceled after a legal threat from the author and Holocaust survivor Elie Wiesel, who was depicted as a character, will now go on at that theater in a revised version, The Washington City Paper reported. The play, ''Imagining Madoff'' by Deborah Margolin, originally depicted a close relationship between Mr. Madoff and Mr. Wiesel, who in real life lost all his and his wife's savings and $15.2 million of his charitable foundation's assets in Mr. Madoff's Ponzi scheme. Before the premiere at Theater J in Washington, Ms. Margolin sent Mr. Wiesel a copy of the script, hoping he would like it. Instead, he threatened to have his lawyer halt the production. Ms. Margolin agreed to revise the play, but when Theater J's artistic director, Ari Roth, volunteered to show the revised script to Mr. Wiesel's foundation, she backed out of the production. She took the rewritten version -- with Mr. Wiesel's character replaced by a fictional Holocaust survivor and poet named Solomon Galkin -- to Stageworks/Hudson, a small theater company in Hudson, N.Y., where it was performed last summer. Mr. Roth saw the play there and renewed a discussion with Ms. Margolin about producing it at Theater J. The play will run from Aug. 31 to Sept. 25.

N.C.A.A. tournament games between the No. 1 seed and the No. 16 seed aren't normally worth watching. No men's 16th seed has ever beaten a No. 1, and that doesn't figure to change this year. But when Duke plays Hampton on Friday afternoon, the game will be worth keeping an eye on for something other than the final score: whether Duke's spectacular freshman point guard, Kyrie Irving, gets on the floor.

The 2011-12 season for the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., will include world premieres by John Guare, Danai Gurira (''Eclipsed'') and the Irish playwright Marina Carr, along with productions of Tom Stoppard's ''Travesties'' and a new musical directed by John Doyle and based on the songs of Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, Playbill reported. The season will open with Mr. Doyle's musical ''Ten Cents a Dance,'' a co-production with the Williamstown Theater Festival, in which the cast doubles as the orchestra. It will be followed by Ms. Carr's ''Phaedra,'' an adaptation of that classical myth. Next up is ''The Convert,'' by Ms. Gurira, a playwright and actress who was one of the creators and stars of ''In the Continuum,'' about women living with AIDS in Africa and Los Angeles. ''The Convert'' is set in 1895 amid uprisings against colonialism in southern Africa. After ''Travesties,'' the season will close with Mr. Guare's new play, ''Are You There, McPhee?''

The singers of ''Glee'' performed original songs for the first time on Tuesday as that hit musical-comedy on Fox topped the ratings on the night with the highest results among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen's estimates. Although Fox led the night over all in that age group, the 10.8 million total viewers for ''Glee'' at 8 p.m. was fewer than the 12.5 million who watched reruns of CBS's procedurals ''NCIS'' and ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' at 8 and 9.

Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said decisively on Wednesday that she would not serve in a second term if President Obama is re-elected and repeated her assertion that she would not run for president in 2012 or 2016. Asked by CNN's Wolf Blitzer whether she would serve a second four-year stint as secretary of state, Ms. Clinton was blunt. ''No,'' she said, according to a transcript on the network's Web site.

''The Fab Five,'' an ESPN film about the Michigan basketball careers of Jalen Rose, Juwan Howard, Chris Webber, Jimmy King and Ray Jackson from 1991 to 1993, was broadcast for the first time Sunday night. In the show, Rose, the show's executive producer, stated that Duke recruited only black players he considered to be ''Uncle Toms.'' Grant Hill, a player on the Duke team that beat Michigan in the 1992 Final Four, reflected on Rose's comments. I am a fan, friend and longtime competitor of the Fab Five. I have competed against Jalen Rose and Chris Webber since the age of 13. At Michigan, the Fab Five represented a cultural phenomenon that impacted the country in a permanent and positive way. The very idea of the Fab Five elicited pride and promise in much the same way the Georgetown teams did in the mid-1980s when I was in high school and idolized them. Their journey from youthful icons to successful men today is a road map for so many young, black men (and women) who saw their journey through the powerful documentary, ''The Fab Five.''

No one would have blamed the Boston Symphony Orchestra for feeling demoralized when it appeared at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. This was the first of three programs at the hall that its music director, James Levine, was to have conducted. But early this month, coping with a lingering back pain and related health issues, Mr. Levine withdrew from the rest of the Boston Symphony season and, as expected, resigned as music director effective Sept. 1, leaving the orchestra in a leadership crisis.

Cuomo in a letter, posted below, on Wednesday to press for extending and tightening the state's rent regulation laws as part of the budget deal he is negotiating with the Legislature. The state budget is due at the end of March. The rent regulations, which limit the rent that landlords can charge on more than one million apartments in New York City and its suburbs, are set to expire on June 15, raising fears that hundreds of thousands of tenants will face substantial rent increases and be forced to move.

Another week and yet another new occupant atop the Billboard record charts. ''Laser,'' by Lupe Fiasco, below, made its debut at No. 1, pushing aside Adele's ''21'' and continuing a pattern of volatility at the top of the albums chart. But initial sales were strong: 204,000 copies of ''Laser'' were sold in its first week, continuing a recent recovery from slow sales at the start of the year that was also evident in the performance of ''21'': 133,000 copies sold, down a modest 21 percent from the week before. Katy Perry continued the strong run of hits from her ''Teenage Dream'' album, with ''E. T.'' (a track that features Kanye West) rising from No. 5 to the top slot among digital songs, with sales of 216,000, up 30 percent over last week. ''E. T.'' is the fourth song from that album to reach No. 1 on the digital list, and it barely edged out Jennifer Lopez's ''On the Floor,'' with 215,000 downloads.

They say there's no such thing as a small role, but then what do you call a performance in a short film? The 60 short films selected for the 2011 Tribeca Film Festival include turns by actors as, well, big as Campbell Scott, Anthony LaPaglia and Colin Quinn, right. And some of the animated shorts feature the voices of David Duchovny,Joseph Fiennes and Ian McKellen. The films were chosen out of 2,862 submissions; they represent 20 countries and include 22 world premieres. Documentary subjects include a Haitian community that joins together to build a movie theater, a rock musician who decides to have transgender surgery and a motivational speaker privately battling bipolar disorder. The narrative films include one in which a character tries to atone for a car accident that left a girl in a vegetative state; one about a man seeking justice after he thinks his son has been sexually assaulted; and -- for those in search of lighter fare -- a film titled ''Mr. Stache'' and described as ''the awesome adventures of a man and his mustache.'' The short films will compete for three awards -- Best Narrative Short, Best Documentary Short and the Student Visionary Award -- with combined cash and value-in-kind prizes totaling more than $15,000. The winner of Best Narrative Short will qualify for consideration in the short-film category of the Academy Awards without the standard theatrical run. The Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 20 to May 1.

Brandon Prust's name is not on the Rangers' injured list. The N.H.L. is not like the N.F.L., which documents every bruise and strain in daily reports. Cal Ripken has seamlessly handled the transition from playing (he retired in 2001 after 21 years as an infielder with the Baltimore Orioles) to life as chairman and chief executive of Ripken Baseball, a grass-roots organization that oversees leagues for players ages 5 to 12; operates a youth academy in Aberdeen, Md.; and owns several minor-league teams. Ripken has added a new title: children's book author. "Hothead," Ripken's new book, written with The Baltimore Sun's Kevin Cowherd and published by Disney-Hyperion, chronicles the tribulations of 12-year-old Connor Sullivan, a talented player whose temper is as uncontrollable as his power, and threatens his all-star career. Ripken, 50, has said the tale is somewhat autobiographical.

A true flâneur, the artist José Parlá records his observations of the streets of cities like Havana, Istanbul, New York and Tokyo, collecting posters, taking photographs and writings on the wall, turning them into a visual diary. Consisting of memories written in calligraphic script layered on fragments of reconstructed city walls, Parlá's paintings capture bits and pieces of his encounters. Born in Miami in 1973 to Cuban émigrés, and now a resident of Brooklyn, Parlá's work has evolved into highly complex collages that emulate the various cityscapes he has visited. The Moment recently caught up with the artist to talk about his show "Walls, Diaries and Paintings," which is at New York's Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery until April 16.

Gratitude is also a nice feature of human nature. In the Journal of Happiness Studies a research team led by Jeffrey Froh studied surveys of high school students that were designed to measure levels of materialism, gratitude, envy, depression, social integration and self-absorption. They found that high gratitude scores powerfully predict higher grades, better social integration and lower envy and depression levels. Students with more materialistic attitudes earned lower grades.

For six days only - March 25-30 - what promises to be an extraordinary exhibition will fill the Wade Thompson Drill Hall at the Park Avenue Armory. "Infinite Variety: Three Centuries of Red and White Quilts," which was organized by the American Folk Art Museum, will present 650 red and white quilts - no two of which are alike - from the collection of Joanna S. Rose (who will donate 50 of them to the museum when the exhibition ends). The largest quilt exhibition ever mounted under one roof in New York City, it will fill the 55,000- square-foot drill hall to a height of 45 feet with a series of "rooms" defined by quilts that will be suspended on cardboard tubes. In the center of the installation, which was designed by the New York firm Thinc Design, a group of quilts will hang in a spiral formation that the designers liken to a tornado, above a circle of chairs that alludes to the social - and female-dominated - nature of quilting. Organized by Elizabeth V. Warren, a guest curator who is also a trustee of the museum, and Stacy C. Hollander, a senior curator at the museum, the exhibition will be free to the public and will include a cafe and shop. Even if you won't be able to buy the quilts, the postcards should be terrific.

The seaside town of Margate, England, a thriving summer playground until its decline in the 1970s, is counting on the Turner Contemporary to revive its fortunes. Opening April 16, this striking museum - designed by David Chipperfield and named for the painter J. M. W. Turner, one of Margate's famous visitors - has already spurred new galleries, pubs and cafes, as well as the restoration of Dreamland, a 1920s amusement park down the road. And it has inspired a lyrical new work by Tracey Emin, who grew up in Margate. Her pink neon sculpture "I Never Stopped Loving You" hangs adjacent to the museum. (Hundreds of people showed up to cheer its installation last year.) "There is more of an appetite for contemporary art here than you might imagine," says Victoria Pomery, the Turner's founding director. The inaugural show presents six artists whose works relate to a little-known Turner canvas depicting the Soufrière volcano on St. Vincent. "We want to help audiences get a better sense of the contemporary through the historical," Pomery says. "And we will always have a Turner presence." Adds Emin, "The other nice thing about the Turner is that it will have a really beautiful cafe, so people like my 82-year-old mum can go and look out at the sea and have a nice cup of tea."

Think of all that Elvis Presley has given you over the years: hours of memorable music; a couple of half-decent movies; the inspiration to decorate the jungle room of your home with floor-to-ceiling shag carpet. What could you possibly give the King in return as a key anniversary in his career approaches? Elvis Presley Enterprises, the company that manages that rock legend's licensing, publishing and merchandising, is hoping it can entice you to create some Elvis-oriented art, in return for a shot at a Presley-themed prize package. To mark the 55 years since 1956, the fateful year when Presley released his single "Heartbreak Hotel," his album "Elvis Presley" and his movie "Love Me Tender," the company said in a news release that it is seeking a "a work of art that symbolizes Elvis' revolution in 1956." Entries can be provided in just about any medium (which would seem to include velvet paintings) and must be submitted in .jpeg or .pdf format at Elvis.com/revolution by April 28. The finalists will be chosen by a panel of judges, and the artist whose work received the most "likes" on Facebook (how very 1956!) will receive a prize package that includes a trip to Memphis, Tenn., during Elvis Week 2011; tickets to Cirque du Soleil's "Viva Elvis" show in Las Vegas; and a cabin on the 2012 Elvis Cruise (does it go to "Blue Hawaii"?). Any contestants who draw comparisons between Elvis Presley and Justin Bieber are disqualified in our book.

Orpheus, that muse with the tunes so beautiful that he convinced Hades to release his serpent-bit wife from the underworld, knows a thing or two about loss. As he led his wife, Eurydice, back to the surface, he was forbidden to look back, which of course he did, casting her back to the nether zone forever with, essentially, a look that killed. "Orpheus says she did / not perish," reports the narrator of Terrance Hayes's poem "Cocktails With Orpheus." Take it from Orpheus - he's been to hell and back. They sit at a bar, in the dark, imagining worlds that could have been.

Statistics can be used for benevolent purposes or for evil ones. Then there's the middle ground, which is where this column resides. Once each month, I'll suggest ways in which you can exploit data to improve your lot in everyday life. I won't advocate that you do anything illegal or (in my opinion) immoral. But statistical analysis is being used, and not always to your benefit, by everyone from your cable company to your real estate broker. Consider this your chance to fight back. I had the honor of lunching on Wednesday with Gary Hart, the former Colorado senator, who is both a seriously insightful political observer and a central character in my next book. (More on that when I actually get around to writing the thing.) Senator Hart reminded me that, as chairman of a Senate subcommittee on nuclear regulation in 1979, he led an investigation into the near-disaster at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant. He told me we were much closer to a Fukushima in this country than most Americans ever realized. (I don't know about you, but I was 10 at the time, and my only real memory of that moment is of Dan Akroyd dressed up as a giant, irradiated Jimmy Carter on "Saturday Night Live," peering into high-rises like King Kong.)

While closers are easily the most unpredictable aspect of fantasy baseball, catchers also provide quite a bit of variance because of the grueling nature of the position, but that can be mitigated by league specifics. I've already stated why I think catchers should be mostly ignored in deep "only" leagues, which may seem counterintuitive. In reality, the scarcest position actually matters most in the shallowest league. That is, the higher the replacement value, the tougher it becomes to gain an advantage per specific position.

JOHNSON--Frank A.,Jr., (Bud), on March 16, 2011 at a young 88. Survived by his beloved wife of 69 years, Evelyne. Loving father of Barry (Bobbie Congress). Adored grandfather of Deborah Johnson Rothenberg, Katie Congress, Susanne Congress and Elana Congress. Cherished by Jackson the wondercat. Dear uncle of Bredine, Cheryl and Roger. Decorated WWII Veteran with active service throughout Central and South America. 40 years of additional service to America as the Regional Director, appointed by President Kennedy to the NDER organization under the U.S. Coast Guard. He was an active and Past Master of Maimonides Lodge F & AM. A polo player, professional dancer with a stellar professional career in executive sales management, the last 40 years working hand in hand with his adored wife Evelyne. Service 11:15am today at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

UNESCO is planning to send a delegation to Egypt early next week to assess the conditions at Egypt's archaeological sites and monuments, Ahram Online reported. Egypt's former antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, was invited to attend a UNESCO seminar in Paris this week marking the 40th anniversary of the UNESCO convention that seeks to prevent the illicit trade of cultural property, but could not attend; instead, he sent a message asking the international community for help in finding objects that have been looted from Egypt's museums and archaeological sites since that country's revolution began in January. On Wednesday, Egypt's Supreme Council of Antiquities released an illustrated list of 54 objects missing from the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, which was looted on Jan. 28. The list is much longer than the list of 18 missing objects that Mr. Hawass released on Feb. 13. Mr. Hawass originally claimed that nothing was missing from the museum. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

New Yorkers are eating twice as much salt as they should, mostly from prepackaged sources, according to a study released Thursday by the city's health department. The average New Yorker consumes 3,150 milligrams of sodium a day, which is in line with the national average, but about twice the recommended limit of 1,500 milligrams for the majority of adults, the study found.

CHWASKY--Milton, died on Sunday, March 13, 2011 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital in his 80th year, after a long and difficult struggle with cancer. He never complained and did all that was asked of him with dignity and humanity. His wife, Suzy Carija Chwasky, was his champion and shepherded him through the sorrow of sickness and the underbelly of the health care system. Suzy brought sunshine into the last 14 years of Milton's life and they were enormously happy together in sickness and in health. He is also survived by his three children from a previous marriage, Robert, Jennifer, and Michael, his son-in-law Niles and his grandchildren Jordana and Lauren and his beloved uncle Herb and aunt Rita. Milton was born in Brooklyn and raised in the Bronx in poverty. His father, Benny, delivered seltzer bottles to walkups. Milton went to the Bronx High School of Science (1944-48) where he was the 5'10" power forward of a team that won one game per season but never stopped trying. After a short career in real estate he got his law degree from NYU after attending night classes. He worked for Alexander H. Cohen, the Broadway impresario, during the sixties, as production associate on IVANOV with John Gielgud and Vivien Leigh and THE DEVILS starring Ann Bancroft and Jason Robards, and handling negotiations with Marlene Dietrich. In 1978 the attorneys for Muhammad Ali asked him to fill in as the attorney for Ali's next opponent Leon Spinks. Spinks unexpectedly won, and Milton's career as "Boxing's Barrister" was launched. He became lawyer and adviser for numerous boxers, boxing promoters, managers and casinos. He was renowned as the honest and reliable stalwart in a field where few such were to be found. His charm and quick wit served him well. Milton loved to play tennis. Taking pictures and listening to jazz were also his pleasures. During his illness he made many 'girlfriends' of the wonderful women who cared for him both at home and in the hospital. He was loved by many and will be missed greatly. In lieu of flowers it is asked that a donation be made in his name to the Southern Poverty Law Center at splcenter.org. Funeral services will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 11:45am on Sunday, March 20th, 2011.

In 1949, the African-American painters Charles Alston and Hale Woodruff covered the lobby walls at a Los Angeles insurance company headquarters - a trapezoidal Moderne building designed by the African-American architect Paul Williams - with murals of early black Californians including explorers, cowboys and oil riggers. Now the original owner, the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company, is being liquidated, and the Smithsonian's National Museum of African American History and Culture is planning to buy the works for $750,000 and remove them from the lobby. (They have been appraised for up to $5 million.) Preservationists have filed objections, to be aired at a public hearing on March 28, and the Los Angeles Conservancy has requested city landmark protections for the building and the murals. The state's Conservation and Liquidation Office has rebuffed philanthropists' offers to buy the paintings and keep them in the lobby, said Joshua Solomon, the interim executive director of the Golden State Mutual Legacy Foundation and a former consultant to the liquidation office. Scott Pearce, a senior estate trust officer at the liquidation office, said that it would welcome bidders with substantive counter-offers to the Smithsonian proposal. ''If they're prepared to write a check, they can have the murals,'' he said.

YANOS--Theodore, M.D.,beloved husband, father and grandfather, passed away yesterday at the age of 87. He leaves behind his wife, Constantina, his children Alexander (wife Susan Cersovsky) and Philip (wife Victoria Frye) and five grandchildren: Claudia, Athan, Naomi, Theodore and Alexander. Dr. Yanos was a beloved psychiatrist and a graduate of the Johannes Gutenberg University of Mainz, Germany. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Friday 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Services Saturday March 19, 2011 at Holy Trinity Cathedral, 319 E74th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Yanos Scholarship of the Kastorian Society. Omonoia.

Funeral services in Florida on March 20, 2011 at noon. For information, please call Star of David, North Lauderdale, FL, 954-722-9000. McCLINTOCK--Elizabeth Starr (Libby), 66, of Millerton, NY, died on March 2, 2011, following a riding accident in Colombia, South America. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Church, Salisbury, CT on Saturday March 19 at 2:00pm.

East As it begins its N.C.A.A. tournament run in Cleveland, OHIO STATE has been deemed the No. 1 overall seed. The Buckeyes, of course, want to remain at the top when the tournament ends. Their game against No. 16 TEXAS-SAN ANTONIO won't be much of a stumbling block. No. 8 GEORGE MASON is clearly a dangerous team in the tournament (see 2006). Will the Patriots begin another run with a victory over struggling VILLANOVA, seeded ninth? After missing the tournament last season, No. 2 NORTH CAROLINA is back again and playing in the friendly environs of Charlotte against No. 15 LONG ISLAND UNIVERSITY, which owns the nation's longest current winning streak at 13 games. Charlotte is not as friendly to No. 7 WASHINGTON, which won the Pacific-10 tournament and then had to travel roughly 2,800 miles for its game against No. 10 GEORGIA. West No. 4 TEXAS struggled at the end of the season, losing four of its final eight games. Coach Rick Barnes also has a troubling history in the tournament, with his teams often going out much earlier than expected. But the main reason that No. 13 OAKLAND has some thinking upset in Tulsa, Okla., is Keith Benson, a 6-foot-11 senior who averages 18 points and 10.1 rebounds a game and could impress N.B.A. scouts with a strong showing. No. 1 DUKE does not expect much trouble from No. 16 HAMPTON, but the Blue Devils will get some playing time for the freshman point guard Kyrie Irving, out most of the season with a toe injury.

An obituary on Wednesday about the painter and critic Gabriel Laderman included several errors. Mr. Laderman died of heart failure, not cancer. One of the artists with whom he studied was Alfred Russell, not Alfred Leslie. And the title of one of Mr. Laderman's paintings is ''The House of Death and Life,'' not ''The Dance of Death and Life.''
8:56 p.m. | Updated On Oct. 7, 2008, PeopleSupport, an outsourcing company, announced that its sale to another company might be delayed, prompting its shares to plummet nearly 20 percent.

ANDREWS--Duncan (11 May 1935 - 17 March 2011), bookman, poet, and scholar, died today in Manhattan after a protracted illness. Mr. Andrews, a former advertising executive and a past president of DKE, formed important collections of the manuscripts and writings of Sir John Betjeman (now at Yale); on foxhunting ("Tally Ho! Four Hundred Years of Foxhunting", exhibited at the Grolier Club in New York City in 1976); and of the English engraver Stephen Gooden (1892-1955), whose biography and catalogue raisonne he wrote. He had a second career as an antiquarian bookseller associated with the firm of James Cummins Bookseller in New York City. His friends and former colleagues salute the memory of this most convivial of gentlemen.

ROMAN--Eric. The employees of WDF Inc. celebrate the life of one of their own, Eric Roman. Eric came to this country from Vienna to escape the Nazi's. He sailed here with his mother and sister and they didn't have a penny between them. Through various friends and charities they were able to survive on the Lower Eastside. Eric took up his first job at age 14 as a furrier, and he attended classes at night. He was married in 1949 and entered the plumbing business of his father-in-law. Through a series of happenstance, he ended up founding R&C Corporation in 1962. His love and the focus of his business, was to install plumbing in schools. His dream was for his two sons, Steve and Larry, to join him and his wife in business. That dream was fulfilled in 1975. After some very tough years, the business began to blossom in the early 1980's. It was sold in 1988 to JWP, a public company (and renamed WDF Inc.). Eric left for a few years and returned to the business he loved in the late 1990's. He continued to work there until his 80th birthday in 2008. Throughout his decades in the plumbing business, he made hundreds of friends due to his friendliness and his extraordinary generosity. The only thing he loved more than his business was his family, Steve, Larry, Julia, Kathy, Mark, Amy, Carly, Jordanna, Brian, Lizzy, and his friends. His constant desire was to be a burden to no one. We will all sorely miss our friend who inspired the wonderful Company we have grown to be.

GOFFNER--Arlene. The Board of Governors and the members of the Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our beloved member Arlene Goffner. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her husband Ralph and family. Jack Irushalmi, President

CBS usually waits until after the nets have been cut down following the national championship game to show its annual N.C.A.A. tournament highlight reel, ''One Shining Moment.'' The network could have shown it Thursday if it wanted to. There was certainly enough material. Some of the moments will live for years. It was hard to watch Morehead State's Kenneth Faried blocking a last-second attempt by Louisville without leaving his feet and not think back to 1993 when Santa Clara sealed an upset against second-seeded Arizona and introduced the country to a stringy-haired guard named Steve Nash. For Princeton, seeing its season end in the final seconds against mighty Kentucky must have felt uncomfortably close to when the 1989 Tigers, seeded 16th, came so close to felling No. 1 Georgetown, a team led by Alonzo Mourning.

Latin American Arts Festival (Saturday): Preserving the traditional music of the Andes is the personal mission of Guillermo Guerrero, the founder and one of the six Andean musicians who make up the ensemble Tahuantinsuyo, which is among those performing at the American Museum of Natural History for this festival. Trained as an engineer, the Peruvian-born Mr. Guerrero (far left above, last year at the museum) has been the group's driving force since its inception in the early 1970s, even making some of the instruments -- including the large sikus, or panpipes -- as well as teaching music workshops, participating in museum exhibitions and encouraging others to keep the music of the Incas going. The celebration on Saturday will begin at noon with performances and art displays in the Grand Gallery, and there will be workshops and performances all day. Tahuantinsuyo will lead a procession at 3:45 p.m. from the Hall of Mexico to the Hall of South American Peoples, where the group will give the day's last performance, at 4:15 p.m. Warning: Spectators may experience an irresistible urge to sing and dance. Central Park West and 79th Street; suggested admission, $16; $12 for 60+; $9 for those 2 to 12; free for under 2 and members; (212) 769-5100; amnh.org. (Anne Mancuso)

Schedule information on Thursday with an article about Patricio Guzmán's film ''Nostalgia for the Light,'' which opens today at the IFC Center in Greenwich Village, misstated the center's phone number. It is (212) 924-7771.

In a letter sent to every N.F.L. player, Commissioner Roger Goodell asks the players to press their leaders to return to negotiations. The sides are not expected to meet until at least after an April 6 hearing in federal court on the players' request for an injunction to lift the lockout. Goodell's letter is his first direct communication with rank-and-file players since talks toward a new agreement broke off, the union decertified and owners locked the players out. More on nytimes.com/sports.

KELLY--Margaret V. "Peggy," nee Carney, on March 15, 2011, age 87. Beloved wife of the late Francis X. Kelly. Devoted mother Elizabeth Warehime, Michael, Patricia, Margaret and Marian. Cherished grandmother of Clare Walsh, Anne Warehime, Jack, Caroline and Patrick Drake and Grace Kelly. Adored great-grandmother of Madeline and Ella Walsh. Honored graduate of St. Joseph's, Brooklyn. Loyal employee of the American Stock Exchange, 1942-1951. Officer of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Bank, 1964-1989. Member of the Georgetown University Parents Committee, 1974-1982. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Friday, 6:30-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, 10am, St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th St. Interment to follow at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

If you were looking forward to Dane Cook's Broadway debut you'll have to wait a bit longer. And if you weren't, you've just been handed a reprieve: producers for the coming Broadway production of ''Fat Pig'' said on Thursday that they were postponing the show's opening until the 2011-2012 season after losing a ''key investment.'' ''Fat Pig,'' the Neil LaBute play about a man who dates a woman who his friends deem overweight, was to begin previews at the Belasco Theater on April 12 and open on April 26. The production, whose cast includes Josh Hamilton, Julia Stiles, Heather Jane Rolff and Mr. Cook, the popular if polarizing comedian, was to mark the Broadway directing debut of Mr. LaBute.

KNAPPMAN--Edward W. On March 10, Edward W. Knappman of Connecticut died of MRSA. Knappman, 67, was president of New England Publishing Associates. He and his wife had just retired after selling their business. Prior to 1990, Knappman had been publisher and executive vice president of Facts On File, New York. He was the author of eight books. Knappman is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Frost-Knappman, and daughter, Amanda Lee Frost Knappman.

Scott Burgess, the automotive critic for The Detroit News, resigned on Wednesday after a local Chrysler dealer complained about his review of the Chrysler 200 -- the centerpiece of the company's ''Imported from Detroit'' advertising campaign. Mr. Burgess was subsequently directed by editors to amend the online version of his story, which he did on March 11, the day after the article appeared in the print edition. In a telephone interview, Mr. Burgess, who said he technically remained on staff, confirmed that he had been instructed to soften what was generally a scathing assessment of the 200, the successor to the midsize Chrysler Sebring sedan.

BERRAH--Dr. Ghoulem. It is with a saddened heart that Mrs. Marguerite Berrah and Family announces the death of his Excellency, Dr. Ghoulem Berrah; Who departed this earth on the evening of Friday, March 4, 2011 in Miami, FL. Dr. Berrah was a professor at Yale School of Medicine where he was called upon for the post of Special Assistant to President Houphouet Boigny of Ivory Coast and appointed Ambassador At Large. He was a member of the New York Academy of Sciences as well as the American Men of Sciences. He will be missed by family, friends and all who knew his kind and generous heart.

The Bolshoi Ballet, with a major tour to Paris planed for the spring and the opening of its theater set for the fall after a long renovation, is facing leadership turmoil. Its artistic director, Yuri Burlaka, left after his contract expired on Tuesday, according to Reuters, and no successor was named. Also on Tuesday, Gennady Yanin, the company director, abruptly resigned; on Wednesday, a 37-year-old Bolshoi soloist, Yan Godovsky, was named director in his place. News reports, referring to an article in the Russian daily Izvestia, said Mr. Yanin resigned after an e-mail with a link showing erotic pictures of someone who resembled him was sent to hundreds of people. Efforts to reach Mr. Yanin on Thursday were unsuccessful. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

BOFFA--Dr. Michelle Elizabeth. 75, clinical psychologist/psychotherapist, passed away peacefully at Connecticut Hospice on March 15, 2011. The cause was uterine cancer. Michelle graduated from the New Lincoln School in Manhattan, had a B.A. from Cornell University, and a PhD. from New York University. She was on the faculty of Hunter College in New York from 1970 to 1972 and in private practice in Los Angeles from 1972 to 1992. Michelle was born in Vienna, Austria on March 15, 1936 and came to the United States in 1938. She lived in Manhattan, Los Angeles, and, most recently, in South Salem, NY. She was a remarkable woman, a loving wife, mother, and grandmother and a generous and beloved friend. She was an astute and caring therapist, an avid fan of the arts and travel, a passionate gardener, an ardent supporter of social justice and an eternal optimist whose special spirit touched countless lives. A private burial will take place on March 19th with a memorial service to be held later this spring. She is survived by her husband Robert; son Jeffrey; daughter Lynn Fiellin (Sullivan); daughter-in-law Michele Campbell; son-in-law David Fiellin; brothers John and Michael Striker; sister-in-law and brother-in-law Joan and Stuart Gaul; seven grandchildren Colin Sullivan, Riane Sullivan, Liam Sullivan, Jack Boffa, William Boffa, Maya Fiellin, and Nina Fiellin and others, too numerous to mention, who dearly loved her. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent to Planned Parenthood.

The coming movie ''The Wolverine'' may appear to have an extraneous article in its title, but for the time being it lacks a director. On Thursday, Darren Aronofsky, the filmmaker responsible for ''Black Swan'' and ''Requiem for a Dream,'' said he was withdrawing from the Marvel comic-book project, which is set to star Hugh Jackman as the mutant superhero more commonly referred to as Wolverine. Mr. Aronofsky said in a statement: ''As I talked more about the film with my collaborators at Fox, it became clear that the production of 'The Wolverine' would keep me out of the country for almost a year. I was not comfortable being away from my family for that length of time. I am sad that I won't be able to see the project through, as it is a terrific script and I was very much looking forward to working with my friend, Hugh Jackman, again.''

The dream of the 1990s is not alive only in Portland: it's also flourishing on MTV, which on Thursday morning announced that it was resurrecting ''120 Minutes,'' the musical showcase that introduced insomniacs (and viewers who recorded it on their VCRs and watched it the next day after school) to many memorable acts from the age of Nirvana. Though the original ''120 Minutes'' was shown on MTV from 1986 to 2000 and had several hosts in that time, the show is most closely associated with the loquacious and enthusiastic Matt Pinfield, whose tenure ran from 1995 to 1999, and who will host the new monthly ''120 Minutes'' on MTV2 as well as an online companion series, ''120 Seconds,'' on the mtvhive.com Web site.

An article last Friday about problems at the Cook County Juvenile Temporary Detention Center misstated the process for eliminating the position of Earl Dunlap, the transitional administrator at the facility. A court ruling could eliminate his position, not Frank H. Easterbrook, a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

8 P.M. (ABC) SUPERNANNY In this 117th episode and series finale, Jo Frost, right, travels to Houston to work with the family of a woman who died of breast cancer a year earlier; Ms. Frost lost her own mother to that illness. ''To me, this is the end of the world,'' says Michael, 6, who is devastated by his mother's death and feels his memories of her slipping away. His father, Gary, is doing his best to raise Michael and his brothers, Sean, 4, and Dylan, 3, but is overwhelmed and can't bring himself to enforce the rules his wife established for the boys. Dylan still isn't potty trained, and he and his brothers prefer candy bars to healthy food. In her ultimate mission Ms. Frost tries to help this grieving family find peace. 8 P.M. (TCM) STARRING JEANNE MOREAU Intelligent and offbeat, sensuous and austere, Ms. Moreau was a favorite of the New Wave directors François Truffaut and Louis Malle, first rising to prominence in ''Elevator to the Gallows'' (1958) and ''The Lovers'' (1958). But it was her free-spirited performance as Catherine, a tempestuous beauty who comes between college friends (Henri Serre and Oskar Werner, from left above, with Ms. Moreau) in Truffaut's ''Jules and Jim'' (1962), that sealed her stardom. That film will be shown at 12:15 a.m. as part of a three-movie tribute to Ms. Moreau. The evening begins with William A. Fraker's ''Monte Walsh'' (1970), with Ms. Moreau as the mistress of an aging cowboy (Lee Marvin) in the 1880s Wild West. Malle's ''Viva Maria!'' (1965) follows at 10, with Ms. Moreau as Maria I and Brigitte Bardot as Maria II, traveling performers who invent the striptease in Central America in 1910 and end up involved in a revolution.

BUDGET REQUEST Gary Gensler, below, the top regulator of the derivatives industry, told lawmakers on Thursday that his agency needed more money to help prevent another financial crisis. In testimony before a House appropriations subcommittee, Mr. Gensler called the Commodity Futures Trading Commission ''a good investment for the American public, overseeing vast markets with a relatively small staff.'' Although the White House agrees with Mr. Gensler, Congressional Republicans are weighing severe cuts to the agency's budget. BEN PROTESS

LIBYA The United Nations Security Council voted to authorize military action, including airstrikes against Libyan tanks and heavy artillery and a no-fly zone, a risky foreign intervention aimed at averting a bloody rout of rebels by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Meanwhile, Colonel Qaddafi warned residents of the rebel-held city of Benghazi that an attack was imminent. BAHRAIN The crackdown against the predominantly Shiite reform movement by the Sunni-led government continued, with the authorities arresting six opposition leaders. Troops and tanks surrounded the main hospital in Manama, the capital, and a nighttime curfew was imposed on the center of the city. YEMEN Security forces in the central city of Taiz used tear gas and fired live ammunition into the air to break up clashes between protesters and government supporters, witnesses said. More than 100 people were injured.

For Jason Adler, it doesn't matter whether the market goes up. Or down. What matters is that it goes. While other investors have been getting whipsawed by the roller-coaster action in global markets since the earthquake struck Japan a week ago, there are rich pickings these days for Mr. Adler, who runs a $275 million hedge fund that bets on volatility.

A New Zealand entrepreneur seemed to have everything lined up for the start of his social networking venture in the United States. He had raised $430,000, hired 14 employees and leased an office just a few miles away from the famed Sand Hill Road in Silicon Valley. He had everything - except a visa. With his application still pending in December, he had to leave the country. Since then, many of his employees have quit, and his money has been depleted.

TATOR--William H. The Officers, Directors and Staff of Parkside Memorial Chapels, Inc. mark with profound sorrow the sudden passing of our dear friend and esteemed "Manager", Bill Tator. Bill was truly a most respected and caring funeral director whose career spanned more than 40 years with Parkside Chapels. His dedication to the families we serve will be sorely missed by all. Our deepest condolences are extended to his beloved daughter Kerry, his son-in-law Gil Hom, and his loving grandchildren Jack, Harry, Cooper and Lola Grace, whom he adored. We will miss you Billy! Edward S. Goldstein, President David E. Goldstein, Vice-President Ruth V. Risani, Treasurer

KREIZBERG--Yakov. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The New School and Mannes College The New School for Music mourn the untimely passing of alumnus Yakov Kreizberg. His artistry shone forth throughout his distinguished conducting career, including being General Music Director of the Komische Oper Berlin and principal conductor of the Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra, as well as two Grammy nominations this year for his recordings with the Vienna Symphony Orchestra. He will be missed by all who knew him. David E. Van Zandt, President, The New School Michael J. Johnston, Chair, Board of Trustees Joel Lester, Dean, Mannes College The New School for Music Linda Rappaport, Chair, Board of Governors, Mannes College The New School for Music

CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- As Duke begins its defense of the N.C.A.A. tournament title, Coach Mike Krzyzewski has chosen not to defend the Blue Devils' recruiting practices amid accusations that his program discriminates against some African-Americans. Krzyzewski, a four-time N.C.A.A. champion in his 31st year as Duke's coach, declined to comment Thursday when asked about a statement made by the former Michigan guard Jalen Rose on Sunday in the ESPN documentary ''The Fab Five'' about the famed recruiting class at Michigan in the early 1990s.

SCHLOESSER--Lynne D.,83, died on March 12 at her home in Nyack, NY. Born Joan Lynne Davis in Philadelphia on August 22, 1927, she graduated from Swarthmore College in 1949, and in 1964 earned a Master's degree there, in philosophy. She was married to the late Edward B. Mifflin, a Pennsylvania state representative, and then to V. Valle Schloesser, a pioneering jet propulsion engineer, from 1975 until his death in 2001. From 1968 to 1975, she was director of financial aid at Swarthmore College, and from 1975 to 1978, she was associate dean of admissions and advisor to foreign students. Lynne and Valle Schloesser lived in San Diego; Toulouse, France, and Kennett Square, PA, as well as Swarthmore. In 2002, Mrs. Schloesser moved to Nyack, where her daughter Margot Mifflin and family live. In addition to Margot, she is survived by her daughters Lawrie Mifflin, of Brooklyn, and Elizabeth (Lize) Mifflin, of Zurich; her sons Fred Mifflin, of Silver Spring, MD, and Bill Mifflin, of Atlanta; her stepchildren, V.V. Schloesser, Jr., and Donna Kochis, and 13 grandchildren. A devoted Quaker, she asked that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made in her honor to the American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry St., Philadelphia, 19102.

Students at the nerdier extremities of American history know that The Times was founded by Henry J. Raymond, a Republican stalwart of the 1850s, and they also know that the original Republican party - a fairly radical anti-slavery party - bears little in common with the modern GOP. But these early relationships are worth probing, for they show that The Times and Lincoln were helpful to each other on their way up, and that newspapers were anything but gray ladies as the conflict drew closer. It also shows that their symbiotic relationship was seriously strained in the weeks between the inaugural on March 4 and the outbreak of war on April 12. Like so many presidents since then, Lincoln found that The Times was getting on his nerves.

AUSTIN, Tex. - There were gigs in parking lots, the noise carried off on dusty winds. There were lakeside gigs lighted by fireworks. Gigs in big theaters, at an old power plant, in a "death metal" pizza joint. Gigs - parades, funky drummers, ukulele serenades - in the middle of Sixth Street, the always-mobbed party thoroughfare here. And, of course, there were gigs within, outside and above bars all over downtown.

My sunday column looks at the way Japan has pulled together in the aftermath of its earthquake/tsunami/nuclear crisis and argues that we Americans could learn a thing or two from that reaction. The backdrop is the distress I've felt in the last few months as it has become apparent that in budget battles the tendency is to throw the weakest and most vulnerable sectors (i.e. children) overboard. In contrast, Japan seems to me to offer an example where stress knits a country more tightly together and where there has been a certain tendency for people to look after each other. (If you've come to this blog to see how to weigh in on my Win-a-Trip finalists, check out this post.)

One question that comes up occasionally in comments is, what would make me change my mind about how the economy works? Associated with this is the question of whether I have ever changed my views drastically in the face of events.

Henry Farrell has an interesting "model" -- as he says, more of a sketch than a fully-worked-out thesis, but provocative all the same -- of disagreement among economists. The core of it is that when there are powerful political interests that want certain economic conclusions, and which believe that voters will be influenced by what economists say, economists who are politically aligned with one faction or another get suborned into providing analysis that backs that position.

Joe Nocera has a good piece about the demonization of Elizabeth Warren; it's something remarkable to watch. In a sane world, Warren -- who warned about consumer debt before it was fashionable, and in particular warned about the abusive lending practices that played a significant role in the buildup of that debt -- would be an icon of reform. But to listen to the GOP, she's a power-mad usurper of individual rights, a threat to the solvency of our financial system.

LIBYA President Obama told Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to implement a cease-fire immediately and stop all attacks on Libyan civilians or face military action from the United States and its allies in Europe and the Arab world. It remained unclear whether Colonel Qaddafi would stop his forces from advancing on the remaining rebel strongholds. A spokesman for the rebels said forces loyal to Colonel Qaddafi were continuing to advance on Benghazi, and people fleeing the town of Ajdabiya said government forces were still bombing and conducting assaults late in the afternoon. YEMEN Yemen's pro-democracy protests exploded into violence, when government supporters opened fire on demonstrators in Sana, the capital, killing at least 45 people and wounding more than 200. The bloodshed failed to disperse the angry throng of tens of thousands of protesters, the largest in a month of demonstrations against the government. President Ali Abdullah Saleh declared a state of emergency shortly after the shootings.

MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands -- Museum directors, curators and donors generally come to art fairs to look, and occasionally to buy. But auctions are where museums most often decide to sell works of art, because public sales are widely considered the most transparent method of deaccessioning. So when the doors to the annual European Fine Art Fair here opened for an invitation-only-preview on Thursday afternoon, one of the most talked-about paintings on view was ''Woman Picking Flowers,'' a Renoir from 1874-1875 that is being sold by the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass. The canvas, which is hanging as a centerpiece at the booth of Dickinson, a London gallery, depicts Camille Monet, the first wife of Renoir's friend and colleague Claude Monet, standing in a field and holding a bunch of flowers. Sterling Clark bought the painting from Durand-Ruel, the Paris dealer, in 1933. But since the Clark owns 32 other works by the artist, it is selling this one--with a price tag of $15 million--to raise money for future acquisitions.

Have no fear that Superman will grow up not knowing how to hit and field a baseball, how to wield a bow and arrow or how to rid Prohibition-era Chicago of organized crime: he's now got Kevin Costner for an adoptive father. Warner Brothers Pictures announced on Thursday evening that Mr. Costner, the star of ''Field of Dreams,'' ''Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves'' and ''The Untouchables,'' will play Jonathan Kent, one of two human parents who take in the Kryptonian baby Kal-El and raise him as their son, Clark, in the new Superman movie being prepared by the director Zack Snyder (the ''Watchmen'' and ''Sucker Punch'' filmmaker). It was previously announced that Henry Cavill (of ''The Tudors) will play Superman and Diane Lanewill play Jonathan's wife, Martha. In previous incarnations, Jonathan Kent has been something of a tragic figure in Superman's life, having died of a heart attack in Richard Donner's 1978 ''Superman'' film, the CW television series ''Smallville'' and the recent Superman comics. (Whereas it only sometimes seems like Mr. Costner rode off into the sunset after winning a boatload of Oscars for ''Dances With Wolves.'')

A former Goldman Sachs computer programmer convicted of stealing source code from the firm was sentenced on Friday to more than eight years in prison, capping a case that had shone a rare spotlight on the world of lightning-fast computer-driven trading. A federal jury in Manhattan in December found the programmer, Sergey Aleynikov, guilty of stealing proprietary code that places trades using computer algorithms that spot tiny discrepancies in stock prices. Such trading earned Goldman about $300 million in 2009.

In the five years since members of the Blue Man Group theatrical troupe founded an alternative pre-K and elementary school in Lower Manhattan, the institution has been its own gypsy, moving from one location to the next. Now the so-called Blue School is getting a permanent home in the former Seamen's Church Institute building at 241 Water Street. ''You know in your body if a space feels right,'' said Renee Rolleri, a founder of the Blue School, along with her husband, Matt Goldman, an original member of Blue Man Group. ''If you think of the environment as the third teacher, it felt instantly right to us.''

Think of all that Elvis Presley has given you over the years: hours of memorable music; a couple of half-decentmovies; the inspiration to decorate the jungle room of your home with floor-to-ceiling shag carpet. What could you possibly give the King in return as a key anniversary in his career approaches? Elvis Presley Enterprises, the company that manages that rock legend's licensing, publishing and merchandising, is hoping it can entice you to create some Elvis-oriented art, in return for a shot at a Presley-themed prize package. To mark the 55 years since 1956, the fateful year when Presley released his single ''Heartbreak Hotel,'' his album ''Elvis Presley'' and his movie ''Love Me Tender,'' the company said in a news release that it is seeking a ''a work of art that symbolizes Elvis' revolution in 1956.'' Entries can be provided in just about any medium (which would seem to include velvet paintings) and must be submitted in .jpeg or .pdf format at Elvis.com/revolution by April 28. The finalists will be chosen by a panel of judges, and the artist whose work received the most ''likes'' on Facebook (how very 1956!) will receive a prize package that includes a trip to Memphis, Tenn., during Elvis Week 2011; tickets to Cirque du Soleil's ''Viva Elvis'' show in Las Vegas; and a cabin on the 2012 Elvis Cruise (does it go to ''Blue Hawaii''?). Any contestants who draw comparisons between Elvis Presley and Justin Bieber are disqualified in our book. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SILVERMAN--Sandra. Beloved sister of Marvin and Barbara Silverman and cherished aunt, cousin and friend. Sandy's loving arms enfolded family and friends from New York to Chicago to St. Louis to Florida and Israel. The loss of her warmth, her contagious laugh, her absolute integrity will leave an empty space for the rest of our lives. New York City, Democratic politics and women's reproductive freedom have lost a passionate advocate. Sandy's devotion to Jewish tradition and ethics informed every aspect of her life. Richard Brautigan, the poet and novelist, who died in 1984, loved dates, sometimes incorporating them into poems with titles like ''September 3 (The Dr. William Carlos Williams Mistake)'' and ''Yeah, There Was Always Going to Be A June 5, 1968.'' His collection ''Loading Mercury With a Pitchfork,'' published in 1976, includes a poem that appears to commemorate an event that took place in New York on this date 30-something or 40-something years ago: it snowed.

An article on Thursday about lawmakers who are appealing directly to federal agencies for money for projects instead of using earmarks referred incorrectly to the president of Taxpayers for Common Sense, who said lawmakers were placing unwarranted political pressure on agency officials. The president, Ryan Alexander, is a woman.

An art column in the special Museums section on Thursday about Maxwell K. Hearn, the new head of the Asian art department at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misidentified the 2010 exhibition in which the delivery of some items came ''right down to the wire.'' It was ''The World of Khubilai Khan: Chinese Art in the Yuan Dynasty'' -- not ''The Yuan Revolution: Art and Dynastic Change.'' (That exhibition was held in conjunction with ''The World of Khubilai Khan.'')

SILVERMAN--Sandra. The Board and staff of the Scherman Foundation are deeply saddened by the death of our former President. A proud daughter of Chicago, she embraced her adopted home of New York with characteristic passion and energy. Beginning in the Lindsay administration, she served the city in numerous capacities including: press secretary of the 1975 Charter Revision Commission, member of the 1992 Democratic Convention Host Committee; and member of the Taxi and Limousine Commission. In addition to a distinguished career in public relations (M. Booth, Soref and Silverman, etc.) she was the founding executive director of the Citizens Committee of New York City, the city's leader in supporting block associations and neighborhood revitalization. She joined the Foundation's board in 1984 and its staff in 1993, serving as President until 2009. Her dedicated and dynamic leadership increased both the effectiveness of our giving and the visibility of the Foundation. She played a particularly significant role in the reproductive rights field, leading funder groups and inspiring frontline organizations. Meetings with grantees were defined by her generosity and warmth, as well as her genuine curiosity. She loved politics, she loved do-gooders, and she deeply loved her colleagues and her gang of friends, who will all desperately miss her warmth and intelligence. We extend our love and condolences to her brother Marvin and sister-in-law Barbara of Jerusalem as well her many nieces, nephews and other family members whom she loved so much.

10 P.M. (HBO) THE PEE-WEE HERMAN SHOW ON BROADWAY Those sounds that filled the Stephen Sondheim Theater on West 43rd Street? They were ''the happy gurglings and raucous cheers of a thousand reborn inner children romping around a favorite playground,'' Charles Isherwood wrote when reviewing this production in November for The New York Times. ''Pee-wee is back, boys and girls!'' Basically an extended episode of ''Pee-wee's Playhouse,'' the children's television series that hit the airwaves in 1986, the show, Mr. Isherwood said, ''is nothing more and nothing less than a bubble bath of nostalgia for the many adoring fans of Pee-wee, the sweet 'n' snickery alter ego of the comic actor Paul Reubens,'' above. Three of the series's original members reprise their roles: John Moody as Mailman Mike, John Paragon as Jambi and Lynne Marie Stewart as Miss Yvonne. The cast is rounded out by Jesse Garcia as Sergio, Phil LaMarr as Cowboy Curtis, Lance Roberts as the King of Cartoons, Drew Powell as the Bear and Josh Meyers as the Firefighter. With the series's main ingredient -- Pee-wee himself -- still intact after all these years, ''it's yummier than chocolate!,'' Mr. Isherwood added. 3 P.M. It almost sounds too good to be true: Getting the savings of shopping at Costco, without the hassle of getting to the store. Yet Michael Eberstadt says he's for real, and that's just what he offers to Manhattanites on his Web site, MonsterSavings.com. Two weeks ago in his Your Money column, Ron Lieber compared Costco with Amazon.com's ''subscribe and save'' discount service, which gives customers lower prices for regular deliveries of nonperishables like toilet paper and paper towels.

COUGHLAN--Dr. Philippa Mathieu, 75, a clinical psychologist, the founder and for 40 years the Director of the Office of Behavioral Health for Students at Wesleyan University, passed away peacefully at Middlesex Hospital in Connecticut, on March 17, 2011. She was a resident of Middletown, Connecticut, and had a home in Newport, Rhode Island. Philippa was born in Boston, Massachusetts, graduated from Boston University, where she was President of the Newman Society for three years, and received a Ph.D. from University of Wisconsin-Madison, where she worked with Carl Rogers. At Wisconsin, she was a principal in the post-Vatican II transformation of the University Catholic Center. In addition to her long professional career at Wesleyan, Philippa taught in the Psychiatry Department of the Yale School of Medicine, served for eight years as Chair of the Connecticut State Board of Mental Health and was a Governor's Appointee to the Community Health Strategy Board. In her youth Philippa was an accomplished figure skater with the Skating Club of Boston and later a respected judge for the US Figure Skating Association. She was a pioneer in the field of behavioral health for college students and spent a lifetime making a positive difference in young people's lives. Philippa was a loving wife, mother, and grandmother, and she was a generous friend. She is survived by her husband Neil and son John, daughter-in-law Karen and grandson Patrick (to whom she is "Pippa"), brother-in-law Paul, sister-in-law Tina, nieces Nicole and Monica. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:30am on Monday, March 21 at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, New York City, preceded at 9:30 am by a viewing in the church. There will be a noon reception for friends and family at the New York Athletic Club, 180 Central Park South. Philippa will be buried in a private family service at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

TUCSON -- The chatter that surrounded Kansas State's Jacob Pullen in recent days recalled 2002, when the Lakers' Kobe Bryant got sick from a cheeseburger during that year's Western-Conference finals and fans worried if he would be able to play. But, Pullen, who missed Wednesday's practice with an illness and the 100-plus fever that came with it, satisfied any concerns by playing in Kansas State's win over Utah State on Thursday in a West Region game. Pullen, a 21-year-old senior who received intravenous treatment at a local hospital, said he was feeling better, though, and his appetite is as strong as ever considering Wisconsin is the next opponent.
