JOHNSON--Frank A.,Jr., (Bud), on March 16, 2011 at a young 88. Survived by his beloved wife of 69 years, Evelyne. Loving father of Barry (Bobbie Congress). Adored grandfather of Deborah Johnson Rothenberg, Katie Congress, Susanne Congress and Elana Congress. Cherished by Jackson the wondercat. Dear uncle of Bredine, Cheryl and Roger. Decorated WWII Veteran with active service throughout Central and South America. 40 years of additional service to America as the Regional Director, appointed by President Kennedy to the NDER organization under the U.S. Coast Guard. He was an active and Past Master of Maimonides Lodge F & AM. A polo player, professional dancer with a stellar professional career in executive sales management, the last 40 years working hand in hand with his adored wife Evelyne.
An article on Page 24 this weekend about Mike Tyson misidentifies a boxer with whom he posed for photographs. It was Rocky Graziano, not Rocky Marciano.

ROTHSCHILD--Edmund O.,M.D., died on March 16, 2011, surrounded by his family. Beloved husband of Kathy Lonergan; wonderfully devoted father of Emily, Sarah, Anna, Oliver, and the late Joshua and Adam; loving brother of Charles; father-in-law of Josh and Tara. A life-long New York City resident, Ed graduated from Bronx Science High School, NYU University College, Cornell University Medical School. His lengthy and full career began as a Research Fellow, Associate and Attending physician at MSKCC. He served as the Senior Vice President of Affiliation Contracts at NYCHHC, Director of Community Medicine Queens Hospital Center, Vice President Professional and Academic Affairs at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center, Senior Vice President Medical Affairs at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, NJ. Most recently, he served as Medical Director at NRI in New York City. Ed served on many volunteer boards and committees, including NYCHHC, Red Cross of GNY, NYCDOH Lead Poisoning Advisory Committee, NYS Office of Professional Medical Conduct, NYDOH Block Grant Committee. He was an Honorary NYC Police Surgeon, an Honorary Medical Officer of NYCFD and the Medical Director of the Honor Emergency Fund. He was a loyal community supporter and activist. On City Island, he was a member of the Board of Temple Beth-El. He served proudly as the co-President of the PTA and co-Chair of the SLT of PS 175 of City Island, and organized substance abuse education programs for its students. Ed loved his two islands; he loved the ocean, and, more than anything, he loved his family and his friends. He will remain a huge part of us forever. Services will be Monday at 9:30 at The Riverside at 76th & Amsterdam Ave. Donations in Ed's honor can be made to The PS 175 Ed Rothschild Fund for Substance Abuse Education and Scholarship, PS 175, 200 City Island Ave, City Island, NY 10464

CHICAGO -- There weren't many of them, but the Virginia Commonwealth fans were loud and proud as the seconds ticked down on the Rams' 74-56 victory over Georgetown on Friday. ''Jay Bilas,'' they chanted, putting a single face on the many who did not think the Rams deserved an at-large berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament field.

EastBefore Saturday's game between Connecticut and Cincinnati, no teams from the same conference had ever played each other in the Round of 32. On Sunday in Cleveland, it will happen again. Third-seeded SYRACUSE will take on a Big East foe, No. 11 MARQUETTE. The Orange relies on a 2-3 zone to confuse teams in the tournament. Will that strategy work against a team that sees it every year? Marquette beat Syracuse, 76-70, in their lone meeting this season. No. 8 GEORGE MASON was the higher-seeded team when it beat Villanova in its opener, but any time the Patriots win in the tournament, it makes fans think about upsets. It would be a monumental surprise if George Mason managed to topple No. 1 OHIO STATE, the No. 1 overall seed. No. 7 WASHINGTON is a long way from home in Charlotte, which won't make things any easier against No. 2 NORTH CAROLINA. WestThe last two games fifth-seeded ARIZONA has played have ended with the score 77-75. The Wildcats lost the first, in overtime to Washington in the Pac-10 tournament championship. The next, they won, against Memphis in their opening game in Tulsa, Okla. It remains to be seen what the score will be when Arizona plays No. 4 TEXAS. The Longhorns stumbled a bit at the end of the regular season, but Rick Barnes has his team on the brink of reaching the Round of 16 for the sixth time in 10 years. In Charlotte, N.C., top-seeded DUKE will renew a rivalry with No. 8 MICHIGAN. The matchup picked up some sizzle with the recent controversy over the former Michigan star Jalen Rose's comments about the Blue Devils.

CECERE--Lucy, on March 19, 2011. Beloved wife of Leonard. Devoted mother of Francine and Leonard. Dear grandmother of Clare. Loving sister of Betty and Flora. She is also survived by her nieces Frances, Carol, Debbie and Patty. Lucy Cecere has dedicated her life to advocating for and assisting her neighbors in Greenwich Village and Lower Manhattan. In 1973, she co-founded The Caring Community, a social service organization, committed to serving the frail, elderly "in a manner that fosters independence, dignity and respect." She has never stopped working for the people the agency serves. She was a recipient of many community awards. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., New York City. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, 10:30am, Our Lady of Pompei R.C. Church. Entombment: St. John's Cemetery. Friends may call Monday and Tuesday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Caring Community would be appreciated. For online condolences, visit us at: perazzofuneralhome.com

Coming out of the Miu Miu show on the last day of the Paris collections, I had the feeling I was connecting again with ordinary life. Energized by the early spring weather, or maybe the thought of going home, everybody had lightened up, retracted their claws. I thought about going for a drink or a manicure. Instead I went to Eric Kayser, bought my umpteenth cafe au lait, and took it back to my hotel room and started a review. Around 8:30 p.m., I went to Azzedine Alaia's place in the Marais. This has become almost a ritual, the late-night, last-day stop at Mr. Alaia's to see what he has been making. He doesn't have shows anymore. Sometimes I wedge in a studio visit during the collections, just as I do with other designers, but this time the Galliano-Dior business had kept me busy. I think it wore everyone down in the end - the disgust, the disappointment, the blitz of stories. Things were out of control, though the unraveling hardly began with a drunken rant by a designer in a bar. Strange to say, but I think this feeling of the industry operating under extreme pressure, like a valve, will be the condition and not the exception.

The name of Samcheong-dong, one of Seoul's most rapidly evolving neighborhoods, means ''three pure things.'' Originally, that referred to clean water, beautiful mountains and good citizens. Today, though, it might as well stand for organic coffee bars, Italian restaurants and art galleries. For those who equate Seoul with a sprawling metropolis of skyscrapers and malls, the intimate scale of Samcheong-dong is a pleasant surprise. Much of this old-monied neighborhood, in the north of the city, is a hilltop maze of one-story hanoks, small traditional courtyard houses with pagoda-style black slate roofs. In recent years, some of those hanoks have become galleries, Italian- and American-style cafes and wine bars. The latest word is that the Korean National Museum of Contemporary Art will open a satellite in 2013 in the area.

KOLBER--Kate Rudes, of Boca Raton, FL, on March 16, 2011, at age 98. Beloved wife of the late Sam Kolber, cherished mother of Fred, Mark and Phil; loving grandmother of Samantha Berman, Francesca Warren, Michael, Anna and Carl; great-grandmother of seven; fond sister of the late Stan Rudes and aunt of Terry Davis and Jerry Rudes. She was a long time resident of Hewlett Bay Park before moving to Boca Raton 30 years ago. Kate was devoted to her family and adored by her large circle of friends. She had many interests, including bridge and golf, and was especially proud of her first hole-in-one at 91. She will be missed.

SILVERMAN--Sandra. Beloved sister of Marvin and Barbara Silverman and cherished aunt, cousin and friend. Sandy's loving arms enfolded family and friends from New York to Chicago to St. Louis to Florida and Israel. The loss of her warmth, her contagious laugh, her absolute integrity will leave an empty space for the rest of our lives. New York City, Democratic politics and women's reproductive freedom have lost a passionate advocate. Sandy's devotion to Jewish tradition and ethics informed every aspect of her life. She will be buried in Israel, as she wished. Family and friends gathering at 140 E. 81st St on Sunday, March 20, 2-8pm. Memorial service later this spring. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the THANC Foundation, 10 Union Sq. East, Ste. 5B, NY, NY. 10003, attn: Erika Markowitz.

The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the new Ralph Lauren store at the intersection of Madison Avenue and 72nd Street, misstated the street number on 72nd where a high-stoop brownstone with a conical tower once stood. It was at No. 12, not No. 14.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Hit in Montreal Sends Shudders Throughout the N.H.L.,'' March 11: I commend Air Canada for threatening to cancel its sponsorship of the N.H.L. The airline wants ''serious suspensions'' to be handed down to those who cause life-threatening injuries during the game. The N.H.L. should enforce more safety regulations and punish the perpetrators who break the rules with suspensions.

CAHME--Merrilie, founder of Epigraph Studios Inc.,a multi-disciplinary design studio, has died on Tuesday, March 8, 2011, at Beth Israel Hospice. She was 65. A long time resident of Greenwich Village, she is survived by her son Brett, daughter-in-law Nicole, two grandchildren Olivia and Jean-Paul, sister Estelle, and many beloved cousins and other family members. She was a visionary, a true creative, a wonderful soul and an inspiration. Merrilie gave so much back to the community with her work at Visions, an organization for the Blind, as well as working with the Mayor's office to help rebuild Lower Manhattan after 9/11. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. Friends and Family have started a scholarship fund in Merrilie's name at The Institute of Fashion Technology. www.fitnyc.edu/merrilie

Realizing that sellers and shoppers might want to see data about a used vehicle's fuel efficiency, the Environmental Protection Agency now offers an online tool to generate a do-it-yourself window sticker. At the agency's Web site, a seller lists the year, make, model and engine-transmission configuration of the vehicle, which generates a printable PDF with the vehicle's city, highway, combined fuel economy rating and a generic photo of the vehicle.

MASON--Richard G.,of Pawling, NY, died on March 17th at age 81 of multiple myeloma, predeceased by his partner John Herget. His parents were Ricca and Gabriel Mason, the principal of Abraham Lincoln High School, Brooklyn, NY and founder of Camp Greylock. Mr. Mason graduated from Swarthmore College in 1950 and received an MFA from Yale in 1953, where he studied theater design under Donald Oenslager. He retired from the University of Hawaii in 1985, where he had been Professor of Theater Arts, designing many stage productions of theater and opera. He will be deeply missed by numerous friends, especially his college roommates Dick Smith and Philip Brickner, by Patty Robson, and the design students he mentored.
Theater Charles Isherwood

THE NEWS The United Nations Security Council authorized member nations to take military action in Libya, including airstrikes and the establishment of a no-flight zone. BEHIND THE NEWS The resolution, which passed 10-0 with five abstentions, came after weeks of debate over what to do about Libya, where protests gave way to an all-out civil war. Though the rebels once seemed about to topple Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, his forces counterattacked brutally with tanks and airstrikes, put the rebels to rout and were poised to seal off Benghazi, the rebels' capital, when the council acted.
International TIME OF RESPONSE

SILVERMAN--Sandra. The Board and staff of the Scherman Foundation are deeply saddened by the death of our former President. A proud daughter of Chicago, she embraced her adopted home of New York with characteristic passion and energy. Beginning in the Lindsay administration, she served the city in numerous capacities including: press secretary of the 1975 Charter Revision Commission, member of the 1992 Democratic Convention Host Committee; and member of the Taxi and Limousine Commission. In addition to a distinguished career in public relations (M. Booth, Soref and Silverman, etc.) she was the founding executive director of the Citizens Committee of New York City, the city's leader in supporting block associations and neighborhood revitalization. She joined the Foundation's board in 1984 and its staff in 1993, serving as President until 2009. Her dedicated and dynamic leadership increased both the effectiveness of our giving and the visibility of the Foundation. She played a particularly significant role in the reproductive rights field, leading funder groups and inspiring frontline organizations. Meetings with grantees were defined by her generosity and warmth, as well as her genuine curiosity. She loved politics, she loved do-gooders, and she deeply loved her colleagues and her gang of friends, who will all desperately miss her warmth and intelligence. We extend our love and condolences to her brother Marvin and sister-in-law Barbara of Jerusalem as well her many nieces, nephews and other family members whom she loved so much.

MARK MORRISROE'S biography has all the earmarks of tragedy. A teenage prostitute, he made it to the School of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston before moving to New York in the mid-'80s, where he pursued a brief yet scintillating career as a photographer and artist, dying of AIDS at 30. Now, his critically neglected oeuvre is receiving some attention, with a new monograph and show at Artists Space, at 38 Greene Street. One of its curators, Richard Birkett, emphasizes the ''materiality'' in Morrisroe's work, how his hands-on manipulations created ''layers and illusions'' that add romance to his dark, intimate portraiture. Until May 1. MATT McCANN Above, ''Baby Steffenelli (John S.),'' circa 1985.

Tweeting Since July 2010Followers 2,500Twitter Bio HAVE NICE DAY! It figures that within the more than 200 million Twitter users lurk some who tweet as the Incredible Hulk, in a loud voice devoid of pronouns, articles and forms of the verb ''to be.'' @GRAMMARHULK, who plays the part of a boorish grammarian and prefers to be called by the genderless ''Hulk,'' is joined by @FEMINISTHULK,@BUDDHISTHULK,@DRUNKHULK,@LONELY--HULK, among others. ''Each hulk have own purview,'' explained @GRAMMARHULK in an e-mail in all-caps - a set style among the Hulks, if not always easy on the eyes. But the world of tweeting Hulks is relatively small. When @GRAMMARHULK's human persona, a 30-something editor living in Manhattan, ''came out'' to a friend, the friend revealed that he was @SKEPTICHULK. ''Hulk suspect Hulk also know alter ego of @EDITORHULK, but it seem rude to ask,'' @GRAMMARHULK said.

Singapore has a bauble to add to its collection: the ArtScience Museum, which opened last month in a building designed by Moshe Safdie. The museum adds a brainy element to the Las Vegas-style Marina Bay Sands development, which includes a casino, 2,561-room hotel, seven restaurants from big-name chefs and a park on the roof. Some design features are a tribute to the museum's content. For example, the lotus-blossom-shaped building funnels rainwater from the roof via a 115-foot waterfall through the central atrium to a lily pond in the lobby and, later, the restrooms.

Total cost to build terminal: $12 million. Number of workers: 14 engineers, 150 craftsmen. hours spent pouring concrete dome: 120. Cost to build JetBlue's 2008 addition to terminal: $743 million. When the T.W.A. Flight Center opened in 1962, at what would be renamed John F. Kennedy International Airport the next year, Eero Saarinen's building instantly took its place in the vanguard of modern design. But the terminal's functional qualities were not so cutting-edge. Once the airline halted operations in 2001, the terminal was closed as well. Then, three years ago, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey began a $20 million renovation of the facility; now that the work is done, the agency is specifically looking for a hotel to occupy the space.

Layover in Seoul, With Children We have a 14-hour layover at Seoul Incheon airport later this month. We'll be traveling with our three children, ages 6 to 13. Can we see anything of Seoul during that time? We'd consider a resort. -- Karen Snyder, West Vancouver, British Columbia

SILVERMAN--Sandra. The Osborne Association mourns the death of Sandra Silverman, whose leadership and compassion changed the communities and lives of the incarcerated individuals and their families whom we serve.

THAT there were 1,200 miles and several states between us meant constant motion: planes, taxis, buses, trams. And a lot of sitting around waiting -- in airports, for cabs, for one of us to pick up the other. Over time, the states between us grew emotional as well as physical: not only Tennessee and Arkansas but also anxiety, longing and anger at cancellations or delays and irritation at those who haunt airport gates all over America yelling into their cellphones (''We're here!'' or ''I had Quiznos for lunch!'') Or worse, detailing the specifics of their vocation, which, sadly, is never sex therapist.

But we can't stand idly by when a tyrant tells his people that there will be no mercy.'' PRESIDENT OBAMA, on the American decision to use military force against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya.

Travelers in search of great jazz usually flock to clubs in cities like New Orleans or New York, or attend festivals in Montreal or Montreux, Switzerland. But from May 12 to 15, Port Denarau, Fiji, will be the unlikely host of a celebration of jazz, blues and soul. The Fiji 2011 International Jazz and Blues Festival, presented by Air Pacific and Tourism Fiji, will feature more than 100 musicians from around the world. Local bands will perform, along with musicians from Canada, New Zealand, Australia, England, American Samoa and the United States.

BURTON--Dr. Irving F.,Huntington Woods, MI, March 10, 2011 at 93. Pediatrician 42 years. Married 52 years to Doris Hyman Burton. He was President, Archives of American Art, Smithsonian; Life Trustee, Detroit Institute of Arts. Survived by children, Stephen (Loren) Burton, Carol (Joseph Pickrell) Burton, Bonnie (Richard) Firestone; grandchildren Jeffrey (Sarah) Firestone, Elana (Kelly) Shea, Lindsay Firestone, Andrew Burton, Jason Burton, Aaron Burton; brother Russell (Britt) Burton; sisters-in-law Elaine Hyman, Evelyn Burton.

JACOBSON--Louis Biel, 95, died quietly at his home in Pacific Palisades, Los Angeles, March 2, 2011. Born in New York City, February 14, 1916, the third generation of F. Jacobson Company, shirt manufacturers, Lou graduated from Horace Mann School, where he was a star soccer player, and Wesleyan University. He joined the family business in 1938 but in 1942 left for the Army. As First Lieutenant he commanded a motor pool in Canosa di Puglia in Italy. Following the war, while senior officer at the US Army base at Forteleza, Brazil, he met soprano Jane Shelby, then performing with a USO troupe. They married in New York in 1949, then moved in 1952 to Pacific Palisades. With architect Paul Hoag, Lou rebuilt their Umeo Road residence and went on to become a successful building contractor. The couple entertained friends with musical evenings at which Jane performed. They traveled widely and contributed generously to charities and liberal causes. Lou was preceded in death by his parents, Joseph C. and Annette Biel Jacobson, and two brothers, Seth Jacobson of Miami, Florida, and writer Nicholas Biel Jacobson of Norwich, Vermont. Jane passed away in 2005; Lou's love for her was a hallmark of his life. An amiable, genial man, always fond of a joke, he is survived by numerous nieces, nephews and cousins, and his devoted caregivers. Contributions in Lou's memory may be made to Save the Children, 54 Wilton Road, Westport, CT 06880.

MARCY DOLIN: I'm lying on my bed, smoking a joint. I smoke about eight a day, and eat a marijuana cookie before I go to sleep at night. I like the peanut-butter ones. I've been using marijuana for about 35 years, ever since I was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. It takes the pain and muscle spasms away. Without it, I would be living on morphine and other horrible drugs. I couldn't do that to my family. That's no life, and I would have ended it. That's the truth. I used to take a drug called Neurontin, and I just never stopped crying. I was in a fog, totally depressed. I told my doctor that I was going back to just marijuana; he said he would have me arrested if he could. What are they going to do? I'm 71 years old. Are they going to put me in jail? I'm not hurting anybody. It's just here in my own house.

In the past months we have witnessed uprisings against oppressive regimes across the Middle East, from Tunisia to Egypt, Bahrain, Iran and Libya. In all these nations, young protesters have been central in demanding reform. As spring arrives, so too do the seeds of a new era for the Muslim world. This image is a still from my video featuring Umm Kulthum, the singer known as the Mother of Egypt, which can be found on nytimes.com/opinion. At her death in 1975, she was widely regarded as the most significant Muslim artist of the 20th century. She sang about earthly and spiritual love, as well as the struggle for justice. Her music is still a tribute to those who risk their lives to make this season better than the last.

MOND--Corinne Hanley. You have been an incredible spirit. Your joy for life touched us all. Your celebration of the creative mind and soul and of literature and art guided and encouraged us to follow our hearts. Our lives will be forever filled with your bright light. A loving mother to Julie and Josh, a devoted sister to Jeanne, Donna and Margie, an inspiring teacher to all of her students and a compassionate friend to so many. Our lives will be forever changed and we will always love you.

They had just moved back to Britain from Japan, and for several days, the British marathon star Mara Yamauchi and her Japanese husband watched coverage of the developing catastrophe and felt moved beyond words, yet powerless. Then their friend, the British marathon coach Martin Yelling, called with the right idea. Yelling and some of his colleagues wanted to help relief efforts by mobilizing the global running community, asking people to dedicate one of their runs to Japan with a corresponding donation.

TULAS, Okla. -- It looks like a mental mismatch, not to mention a talent mismatch. Kansas and its twin big men, Marcus and Markieff Morris, against Illinois, which has been portrayed as timid by some because of so many close losses this season. Demetri McCamey, a senior guard for Illinois, can just imagine the talking that Kansas forward Marcus Morris will do on Sunday when the teams meet in the Round of 32 in the Southwest Region. McCamey suggested his teammates do not bark back, but that was exactly what the senior forward Mike Davis said he planned to do.

EICHHORN--Ruth, of Great Neck NY, formerly of Brooklyn, passed away on March 14, 2011 at the age of 93. She was married to the late Harry Eichhorn. Ruth was devoted to her family above all else. She leaves three sons, Marvin and his wife Linda, Robert and his wife Lorraine, and Gary and his wife Joan. She cared very deeply for her six grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.

LOWIN--George. A celebration of George's life will be held on Sunday, March 27 at 11am at the Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 199 Bleecker St., between 6th Ave. and MacDougal St., New York, NY 10012. For directions or parking information, call 212-431-6712. Luncheon to follow.

BROWN--Michael Lamer, born November 11, 1931 in Anna, IL to Roy and Ellen (Lamer) died peacefully on March 11, 2011. A graduate of Northwestern University and a veteran of the Korean Conflict, Michael was a longtime associate of the Wally Findlay Galleries in Chicago, New York and Palm Beach, retiring in 2000. Predeceased by his sister, Patricia, survivors include his niece, nephew, cousins and their families.

In Paris, fashion is going in many directions; there is even a new Colette shop that encourages customers to mix Chanel staples with inexpensive contemporary pieces like T-shirts. The palette ranges from somber goth hues to joyful light colors that suggest the first breath of spring, seen in short skirts, long skirts, trousers and -- in some cases -- the shirt, lengthened to a minidress. (One version had three cuffs on each sleeve.) Businesswomen attending the recent fashion shows wore interesting white blouses to enliven severe suits, whether skirts or pants. Some things remain the same: on weekends, browsers explore the book and poster stalls along the Seine. And on the Pont des Arts, lovers by the thousands continue to attach padlocks with their names on them to a fence.

LIBYA American and European forces began strikes against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's forces, unleashing warplanes and missiles in the largest international military intervention in the Arab world since the invasion of Iraq. The mission is designed to impose a no-fly zone and keep Colonel Qaddafi from using airpower against rebel forces in the east. SYRIA The Syrian police sealed off the city of Dara'a after security forces killed at least five protesters there on Friday in the first sign that the Arab world's pro-democracy push was seeping into one of the region's most repressive places, The Associated Press said. President Bashar al-Assad was said to have sent delegates to Dara'a to offer his condolences to victims' families.

BYRNE--Capt. John Anthony Jr.,USN, Retired Died March 7, 2011. Born September 15, 1930, Brooklyn, NY to John A. Byrne, Sr. and Elizabeth Clark Byrne. "Jack" graduated Fordham Preparatory School 1948, Fordham Univ., USN Post Graduate School, USN War College, Pepperdine Univ. and Jefferson School of Law. Naval career had ship commands USS Floyd County LST 725 and USS Patterson FF 1061, Legion of Merit Award on DOD Navy Personnel Legislation and Meritorious Service Medal as COS CMDR Training Pacific Fleet, after retiring 1984 was Chairman of HRM, National Univ. until 1991. A member of USO, Fordham Alumni Assn., Naval Institute, Military Officers Assn. of America, Maritime Museum and patron of La Jolla Playhouse and Old Globe Theater. Pastimes were writing memoirs, reading The New Yorker 60 years and grandchildren's school, NCAA sports. Survived by wife of 54 years Lois Welton Byrne, brother Paul (Martha) Byrne of Canadian Lakes, MI, Tucson, AZ, son Chris Byrne (Karen Pyles) of Carlsbad, CA, daughter Grace (Thomas) McGovern of Escondido CA, grandchildren Lucy, Claire, and Jack McGovern. Jack's 1978 dream orders were San Diego and there at Fort Rosecrans will be his Military Funeral Honors. Holy Mass at St. Thomas More Catholic Church, Oceanside, CA March 24, 2011.

MINSKY--Joseph. (Broadway Joe) died peacefully on March 17 at the age of 102. Beloved husband of the late Helene. Loving father of Marion and Lee Morgenstein, Roz (Bobrow) and Howard Hahn. Special granddad of Susan and Pete, James, Marc and Kim, Rachel and David, Stephen and Gabby. Great-grandfather of eight. Joe was a proud WWII veteran, spent his career in the NYC garment district. Funeral will be private. Shiva will be in West Hartford, CT. In gratitude to the Veterans Administration, any donations may be made to VAMC, mailed to: VA-NYHHS, attn: voluntary service 135, 423 East 23rd Street, New York, New York 10010.

ALEXANDER WANG is still flying high from the opening of his flagship store in SoHo. To keep the momentum going, the designer has introduced an all-leather collection of some of his favorite styles from the past. ''We wanted to create special product for the store,'' Mr. Wang said, ''that felt very classic and representative of our DNA.'' The six reinvented pieces include a fishtail parka, a tank bra, an aviator jacket and a pair of tailored shorts. The skillful deployment of leather, the placement of smooth patched pockets and asymmetrical buckles, and the contour seaming reaffirm the young designer's uncanny eye for subtlety. $625 and up at Alexander Wang, 103 Grand Street; (212) 977-9683. RACHEL WALDMAN

JANIS--Peter Josef, 51, died peacefully March 17. Director of Programs for PWC and Theatre Designer. Alumnae of Rumsey Hall, Bennington College, and F.I.T. Survived by his loving family, mother Lenore Janis, brother John, sister-in-law Lisa and children Rachel and Matthew. A Memorial Service will be held on March 29.

Perhaps it was the prospect of a statue of Michael Jackson that is soon to be erected outside Craven Cottage. Perhaps it was nothing of the sort. To a growing list of distinction during his career in the English Premier League, Clint Dempsey added one more Saturday in Liverpool. His goal during Fulham's 2-1 loss to Everton makes him the first American to score 10 goals in perhaps the best soccer league in the world.

The veteran Hong Kong filmmakers Johnnie To and Wai Ka-fai are known for their collaboration on action thrillers, but their entry for the 35th Hong Kong International Film Festival takes a lighter touch: their film ''Don't Go Breaking My Heart,'' a romantic comedy starring the Chinese actress Gao Yuanyuan as the love interest of both Louis Koo and Daniel Wu, will open this year's festival. The festival, which runs from March 20 to April 5 and offers more than 300 films from 56 countries, will also honor Mr. Wai with screenings of 11 of his movies. In addtion, he will speak at the Hong Kong Cultural Center on April 4.

LUBIN--Martin I.,M.D. on March 17, age, 81. Retired chief of psychiatry at New York Hospital-Queens. Survived by his wife of 44 years, Jane; children Julie and Robert, daughter-in-law, Jennifer; brother Norman (Phyllis) and four grandchildren. Dr. Lubin began his career in forensic psychiatry on the Bellevue Prison Service. His book, "Good Guys, Bad Guys, From Bellevue to Berkowitz" recounted his experiences there and as an expert in many high profile criminal cases. He founded the Department of Psychiatry at Booth Memorial Hospital (NYHQ) in 1971 and ran the Department until its demise in 2000. Friends and colleagues will remember his outstanding devotion to ethical practices in medicine and psychiatry and in living his life. Donations to a charity of the donor's choice would be greatly appreciated.

ZANGAS--Thomas C.,of New York, NY, passed away quietly at home on March 10, 2011, after a heroic two year battle with lung cancer, a non-smoker. He graduated from Hofstra University, New York University and Gallaudet University in Washington, D.C. with a Ph.D. in clinical psychology---specializing in working in the deaf community. He worked at St. Joseph's School for the Deaf, the New York City public school system as well as having a private practice. He is survived by his partner, Manny Kalamaras, his father, Leonard Zangas, stepmother, Penelope Zangas, sisters Yelena Zangas and Melissa Krahn, brother-in-law Thomas Krahn, niece Catherine, nephew Ethan and step-grandmother, Irene Candemeres. He will be remembered for his loving, warm, compassionate and generous personality. Donations in his memory may be made to the Lung Cancer Alliance.
MAGAZINE An article on Page 24 this weekend about Mike Tyson misidentifies a boxer with whom he posed for photographs. It was Rocky Graziano, not Rocky Marciano.

BERRAH--Dr. Ghoulem. It is with a saddened heart that Mrs. Marguerite Berrah and Family announces the death of his Excellency, Dr. Ghoulem Berrah; Who departed this earth on the evening of Friday, March 4, 2011 in Miami, FL. Dr. Berrah was a professor at Yale School of Medicine where he was called upon for the post of Special Assistant to President Houphouet Boigny of Ivory Coast and appointed Ambassador At Large. He was a member of the New York Academy of Sciences as well as the American Men of Sciences. He will be missed by family, friends and all who knew his kind and generous heart.

WHEN Vanessa Traina agreed to be the face of Maje's fall campaign, she never anticipated she would also be designing her first capsule collection. Does the match shock anyone, though? Known for gracing countless best-dressed lists and working alongside the stylist Marie-Amélie Sauvé, as well as styling for T: The New York Times Style Magazine, Ms. Traina has an approach to chic that appears enviously effortless. BLUEWATER PRODUCTIONS has already made a name for itself in the biographical comic book business. Its series ''Female Force and Fame'' has featured Sarah Palin, Lady Gaga, the cast of ''Twilight'' and more. ''Infamous,'' its newest line, will be inaugurated by Charlie Sheen, whose recent troubles will be chronicled by Marc Shapiro, himself a comic book fan. No stranger to celebrity biographies, Mr. Shapiro is the author of ''J. K. Rowling: The Wizard Behind Harry Potter'' and ''Justin Bieber: The Fever!'' In April, his biography of Kathy Griffin will arrive in stores, followed by comics on John Lennon and Cher. While his work on Mr. Sheen is basically done, he said that he's holding the final two pages until the last possible minute. ''Something wacky seems to happen every day,'' he said. ''You want to keep that door open just a crack, just in case.'' ''Infamous: Charlie Sheen'' will be available in June for $3.99. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

Al Morgan, a novelist, screenwriter, playwright and television producer who was probably best known for writing ''The Great Man,'' a 1955 novel that became the basis of a movie of the same name, died on March 3 at his home in Brattleboro, Vt. He was 91. His daughter Joey Morgan confirmed his death.

CLEVELAND -- Syracuse guard Scoop Jardine, who finished Friday's 77-60 victory over Indiana State on the bench with ice on his left wrist after a second-half tumble, said it would not keep him from facing Marquette on Sunday. ''I'm fine,'' he said Saturday. ''I was fine yesterday. Like I said, if we play today, I'd be playing.''

WHAT YOU GET FOR $700,000 NEW YORK LIST PRICE: $699,000 BEDROOMS: 0 BATHROOMS: 1 INTERIOR: 550sq.ft.LOT SIZE: N/A RENOVATED: 2005 This studio apartment in Greenwich Village was designed by AvroKO -- a group of young Manhattan architects -- to make the most of a narrow loft with 13-foot ceilings. There are two Murphy beds and a sliding wall that can create a small guest bedroom; an interior staircase ascends to a platform that can be used as an office.The building has a rooftop deck.

COUGHLAN--Dr. Philippa Mathieu, 75, a clinical psychologist, the founder and for 40 years the Director of the Office of Behavioral Health for Students at Wesleyan University, passed away peacefully at Middlesex Hospital in Connecticut, on March 17, 2011. She was a resident of Middletown, Connecticut, and had a home in Newport, Rhode Island. Philippa was born in Boston, Massachusetts, graduated from Boston University, where she was President of the Newman Society for three years, and received a Ph.D. from University of Wisconsin-Madison, where she worked with Carl Rogers. At Wisconsin, she was a principal in the post-Vatican II transformation of the University Catholic Center. In addition to her long professional career at Wesleyan, Philippa taught in the Psychiatry Department of the Yale School of Medicine, served for eight years as Chair of the Connecticut State Board of Mental Health and was a Governor's Appointee to the Community Health Strategy Board. In her youth Philippa was an accomplished figure skater with the Skating Club of Boston and later a respected judge for the US Figure Skating Association. She was a pioneer in the field of behavioral health for college students and spent a lifetime making a positive difference in young people's lives. Philippa was a loving wife, mother, and grandmother, and she was a generous friend. She is survived by her husband Neil and son John, daughter-in-law Karen and grandson Patrick (to whom she is "Pippa"), brother-in-law Paul, sister-in-law Tina, nieces Nicole and Monica. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:30am on Monday, March 21 at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, New York City, preceded at 9:30 am by a viewing in the church. There will be a noon reception for friends and family at the New York Athletic Club, 180 Central Park South. Philippa will be buried in a private family service at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.
MILLER--Jason, M.D.,1 year has passed - will miss your intellect and humor always. Love, Corinne

Hank Aaron was the major league career home run leader from 1974 until 2007. Now 77, he has served since 1998 as the senior vice president of the Atlanta Braves. He is helping Topps commemorate its 60th anniversary with a Diamond Dig promotion. Special code cards are inserted in packs of 2011 Topps Baseball Series 1. Fans who enter the codes online at DiamondTopps.com receive vintage cards and a chance to win other prizes. VINCENT M. MALLOZZI Q. KLEINE--Paula M.,(nee Stein), 80, passed away peacefully at home on March 8, 2011. Paula was born in Washington, D.C., and resided in Fairfield, CT for the past nine years. The devoted and loving wife of Herman, mother of Joseph and Michael, grandmother of Suzanne, Sarah, Daniel, and Harold, sister of Jacob, Orren, and the late Ralph. A talented painter, she graduated with a B.A. in Fine Arts from The George Washington University. Paula loved animals, was an avid reader, and had a wonderful sense of humor. A woman of valor, she will be greatly missed. Donations in her name may be made to the Connecticut Humane Society (www.CTHumane.org).

SCHLOESSER--Lynne D.,83, died on March 12 at her home in Nyack, NY. Born Joan Lynne Davis in Philadelphia on August 22, 1927, she graduated from Swarthmore College in 1949, and in 1964 earned a Master's degree there, in philosophy. She was married to the late Edward B. Mifflin, a Pennsylvania state representative, and then to V. Valle Schloesser, a pioneering jet propulsion engineer, from 1975 until his death in 2001. From 1968 to 1975, she was director of financial aid at Swarthmore College, and from 1975 to 1978, she was associate dean of admissions and advisor to foreign students. Lynne and Valle Schloesser lived in San Diego; Toulouse, France, and Kennett Square, PA, as well as Swarthmore. In 2002, Mrs. Schloesser moved to Nyack, where her daughter Margot Mifflin and family live. In addition to Margot, she is survived by her daughters Lawrie Mifflin, of Brooklyn, and Elizabeth (Lize) Mifflin, of Zurich; her sons Fred Mifflin, of Silver Spring, MD, and Bill Mifflin, of Atlanta; her stepchildren, V.V. Schloesser, Jr., and Donna Kochis, and 13 grandchildren. A devoted Quaker, she asked that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made in her honor to the American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry St., Philadelphia, 19102.

Sean Parker, a co-founder of Napster and the founding president of Facebook, has expressed sardonic irritation at his portrayal as a hard-partying playboy in the film ''The Social Network.'' ''I'm definitely not having as much fun as the press likes to claim,'' he said in an interview via e-mail, ''but it's probably for the better. However, when I do have a party I will do it right.''

I used to love eating out; I don't anymore. Even though the smokers have been moved outside and the food is more likely to be from some local, free-range, organic farm, and I can finally afford the ''better'' places, I would rather stay home - because I am tired of the noise. I arrived at this conclusion after a particularly ear-splitting week. I went out three times for lunch with friends on the Upper West Side and a dinner in Turtle Bay. Each occasion started with our entering a wall of sound surpassing Phil Spector's - the standard decibel level of restaurants in New York City. From there, it was a game of vociferous one-upmanship. As the places filled up (I got to each early), the diners worked harder to be heard, increasing the overall din as their voices struggled to rise above it.

Hewlett-Packard, Google, Apple and Medtronic all have thousands of employees who work in shiny corporate offices. But it wasn't always that way. In fact, all four companies got their start in humble garages. Steve Jobs, for one, worked in his parents' garage to build the very first Apple computer. Was it something about the garage environment itself that caused these four companies to thrive? Could be. After all, when you work in a garage, operating costs are low, tinkering is encouraged, and it's O.K. to get your hands dirty -- three important factors that lead to entrepreneurial success, and to outgrowing the garage.

(Fuse) THE 2011 ROCK AND ROLL HALL OF FAME INDUCTION CEREMONY A bumper crop of venerable rockers -- Alice Cooper (with snake in tow), Neil Diamond, Dr. John (above), Darlene Love, Leon Russell and Tom Waits -- as well as two record company founders, Jac Holzman of Elektra Records and Art Rupe of Specialty Records, were celebrated at this 27th-annual event, held on Monday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan. Rob Zombie, Paul Simon, John Legend, Bette Midler, Neil Young, John Densmore, Lloyd Price and Elton John paid tribute to the honorees before joining them and guests, including Bruce Springsteen, John Mayer and Lloyd Price, in musical collaborations on hits like ''Get Behind the Mule,'' ''Such a Night,'' ''He's a Rebel'' and ''Da Doo Ron Ron.'' He will appear also on ''This Week With Christiane Amanpour,'' at 10 on ABC; ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS; and ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

LAWNHURST--Richard "DICK" 1911-2011, residing in Roslyn NY, West Palm Beach and Denver. Passed away peacefully March 9, 2011. He was a gentleman whose patience and generosity touched many. He leaves wife Leila (married 68 years), four children, many grandchildren, great-grandchildren and friends.

ROTHSCHILD--Edmund O.,M.D., died on March 16, 2011, surrounded by his family. Beloved husband of Kathy Lonergan; wonderfully devoted father of Emily, Sarah, Anna, Oliver, and the late Joshua and Adam; loving brother of Charles; father-in-law of Josh and Tara. A life-long New York City resident, Ed graduated from Bronx Science High School, NYU University College, Cornell University Medical School. His lengthy and full career began as a Research Fellow, Associate and Attending physician at MSKCC. He served as the Senior Vice President of Affiliation Contracts at NYCHHC, Director of Community Medicine Queens Hospital Center, Vice President Professional and Academic Affairs at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center, Senior Vice President Medical Affairs at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, NJ. Most recently, he served as Medical Director at NRI in New York City. Ed served on many volunteer boards and committees, including NYCHHC, Red Cross of GNY, NYCDOH Lead Poisoning Advisory Committee, NYS Office of Professional Medical Conduct, NYDOH Block Grant Committee. He was an Honorary NYC Police Surgeon, an Honorary Medical Officer of NYCFD and the Medical Director of the Honor Emergency Fund. He was a loyal community supporter and activist. On City Island, he was a member of the Board of Temple Beth-El. He served proudly as the co-President of the PTA and co-Chair of the SLT of PS 175 of City Island, and organized substance abuse education programs for its students. Ed loved his two islands; he loved the ocean, and, more than anything, he loved his family and his friends. He will remain a huge part of us forever. Services will be Monday at 9:30 at The Riverside at 76th & Amsterdam Ave. Donations in Ed's honor can be made to The PS 175 Ed Rothschild Fund for Substance Abuse Education and Scholarship, PS 175, 200 City Island Ave, City Island, NY 10464

''I GREW up with this story, and I've always wanted to do something about it,'' Ruth Sergel said. ''It's like a black hole in your heart.'' In 2004, Ms. Sergel started doing something about the story she grew up with: the Triangle Waist Company fire, which killed 146 garment workers in 1911, almost all of them Jewish and Italian immigrants. She had just read a book about the fire, to distract herself from worrying about the premiere of a short film she had directed at the the Tribeca Film Festival.

Beloved husband of Michele Urvater, adored father of Alessia Cook, cherished brother of Sophie Cook, and loved brother-in-law of Ronald Urvater. Michael was a dedicated educator for 40 years at The Bank Street School for Children, loved, respected and admired by his colleagues, present and former students. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Michael's honor to The Bank Street School for Children. A tribue to his life will take place on Sunday, March 20, 2011, from 3-5pm at the Bank Street School for Children.

JOHNSON--Frank A.,Jr., (Bud), on March 16, 2011 at a young 88. Survived by his beloved wife of 69 years, Evelyne. Loving father of Barry (Bobbie Congress). Adored grandfather of Deborah Johnson Rothenberg, Katie Congress, Susanne Congress and Elana Congress. Cherished by Jackson the wondercat. Dear uncle of Bredine, Cheryl and Roger. Decorated WWII Veteran with active service throughout Central and South America. 40 years of additional service to America as the Regional Director, appointed by President Kennedy to the NDER organization under the U.S. Coast Guard. He was an active and Past Master of Maimonides Lodge F & AM. A polo player, professional dancer with a stellar professional career in executive sales management, the last 40 years working hand in hand with his adored wife Evelyne.

SPORTS Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Princeton's 63-62 victory over Harvard in an Ivy League men's basketball playoff on Saturday, March 12, erroneously attributed Princeton's record to Harvard in one instance. Princeton was 25-6; Harvard was 23-6.

While there are certainly some things to applaud in your magazine's new layout (the cover page is a definite improvement), the aim of making ''everything sharper, clearer'' seems to have gotten lost in the attempt to make the pages look more like they belong on the Web than in print. The contents page is laid out like a jigsaw puzzle, requiring Page 19 to be listed ahead of 18. Moreover, I believe that those who are current or prospective readers have no interest in Internet gossip, whether on Twitter or Facebook. Over all, the attempt to modernize has many successes, but you must remember that your readers are just that: people with attention spans longer than a tweet! --ARTHUR D. APTOWITZ, Forest Hills, N.Y., e-mail Good work on the new design. It finally looks like The New York Times. --JEFF JANK, Los Angeles, e-mail

The cover story on March 6 about Bahia Bustamante, a sheep farm in Argentine Patagonia where hundreds of species coexist, misstated the proper names of two of them. Among the animals and birds seen there are elephant seals and rheas -- not sea elephants and ostriches, which are colloquial names. The article also misstated the months when the farm, which takes guests, is open to visitors. As a listing correctly noted, it is August to May, not September through May.

BOFFA--Dr. Michelle Elizabeth. 75, clinical psychologist/psychotherapist, passed away peacefully at Connecticut Hospice on March 15, 2011. The cause was uterine cancer. Michelle graduated from the New Lincoln School in Manhattan, had a B.A. from Cornell University, and a PhD. from New York University. She was on the faculty of Hunter College in New York from 1970 to 1972 and in private practice in Los Angeles from 1972 to 1992. Michelle was born in Vienna, Austria on March 15, 1936 and came to the United States in 1938. She lived in Manhattan, Los Angeles, and, most recently, in South Salem, NY. She was a remarkable woman, a loving wife, mother, and grandmother and a generous and beloved friend. She was an astute and caring therapist, an avid fan of the arts and travel, a passionate gardener, an ardent supporter of social justice and an eternal optimist whose special spirit touched countless lives. A private burial took place on March 19th with a memorial service to be held later this spring. She is survived by her husband Robert; son Jeffrey; daughter Lynn Fiellin (Sullivan); daughter-in-law Michele Campbell; son-in-law David Fiellin; brothers John and Michael Striker; sister-in-law and brother-in-law Joan and Stuart Gaul; seven grandchildren Colin Sullivan, Riane Sullivan, Liam Sullivan, Jack Boffa, William Boffa, Maya Fiellin, and Nina Fiellin and others, too numerous to mention, who dearly loved her. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent to Planned Parenthood.

SO you think you're too young to wear your mother's jewelry? It's all a matter of how you wear it, says Theresa Bruno, who designs Jordan Alexander's fine jewelry collection, a mélange of lustrous Tahitian pearls, twisted strands of quartz and diamond-encrusted ornaments, with unexpected touches like macramé and prayer beads all strung together with leather or silk. Ms. Bruno, an Alabama native, credits her mother and her grandmother for her inspiration. ''They wore serious pearls,'' she said. ''I wanted jewelry that looked beautiful like theirs.'' But obviously, with her own free spirit. Left, Jordan Alexander pavé diamond earrings, $2,920. At Fragments, 116 Prince Street; (212) 334-9588. MADISON SHIMODA

Before Diddy and his missing Mercedes-Benz S-Class, before Eminem and his imported-from-Detroit Chrysler 200, even before Funkmaster Flex and his special-edition Ford Expedition, there was the Jay-Z Jeep Commander. You would be forgiven, however, for not remembering the commercials. In an unauthorized biography released today, the Forbes magazine editor Zack O'Malley Greenburg relates the tale of a cross-promotional deal gone sour, in which Jay-Z, the multiplatinum hip-hop artist and entrepreneur, was ready to lend his name to a special-edition Jeep Commander, until Chrysler executives became apprehensive about the rapper's criminal past and let the collaboration languish in the boardroom.

FRIEDMAN--John M.,66 years old, a lawyer, woodworker, and mathematician, died on March 17, 2011, in Connecticut, after a long and courageous struggle with pulmonary fibrosis. He lived in Roxbury, CT. Friedman graduated from Princeton University in 1966, and received a masters degree from University of Sussex and a law degree from the University of Chicago in 1970. He was a partner in the law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, where he spent 25 years. In 1996 he retired and became a full time resident of Litchfield County, CT. Over the next 15 years he served as Chairman of the Board of The Washington Montessori School, Chairman of the Federation Foundation of the Jewish Communities of Western Connecticut, Vice President of the Federation and served on various community boards. Friedman was multi-dimensional: he wrote a math column for The Litchfield County Times, was an avid fly fisherman and took great pride in his woodworking. Friedman is survived by his wife, Judith, his sons David and Michael, his daughter Julia and his sister Tonni. The funeral will be held on Monday, March 21, 2011 at 11am at B'nai Israel, Southbury, CT. Please send donations to John Friedman Memorial, Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation, 811 West Evergreen Avenue, Chicago, IL 60642.

The month of March, 1861, found the once sleepy riverside town of Montgomery, Ala., suddenly awake with the efforts to build the new Confederate government. Delegates from the seceding states had gathered there in February, and they had already written a constitution for the Confederate States of America and elected Jefferson Davis as president. Now the new Congress was busy with more routine matters like the postal service, liquor regulations and the salary of members. Cannons saluted arriving dignitaries and receptions, dinners and plays were regularly held. One delegate wrote his wife that "cheers, enthusiasm, and waving handkerchiefs" went along with "the work of bringing a nation into existence."

At Fixes, our focus is typically on implementing new or underutilized ideas to help those in need. But sometimes it's just as important to protect institutions that are already working well. Which is why I'm writing today about the Grameen Bank, the Bangladeshi organization that won the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize, along with its founder Muhammad Yunus, for its work extending microloans to some of the world's poorest, and has been crucial in global efforts to lift millions of people out of poverty.

While a debate rages over the safety and utility of new bike lanes in Manhattan and Brooklyn, statistics show that cycling-related fatalities and overall pedestrian injuries have fallen in recent years, even as the number of cyclists on New York streets has grown. It had a fairy tale beginning and it was supposed to have a fairy tale ending. Jennifer was everything I could have asked for in a woman. Our paths crossed for the first time this past fall. We immediately fell in love. In fact, she said the words first. Her confidence inspired me. I knew the dangers of taking a girlfriend into a deployment. I tried it during my last deployment to Iraq in 2005, and it was an epic failure. The problems with that relationship began before I even got on a plane, and continued throughout my time overseas. This time, as I prepared to return to Iraq, I felt a lot better about things, even though Jennifer and I had only been together a few months. She told me it would work, that the deployment wasn't that long of a time. I jumped in both feet first. I thought she jumped in with me.

Enormous suitcases, a digital camera and fashion-pack friends like Hamish Bowles and Christian Louboutin are constant companions for the on-the-dash textile designer Carolina Irving, whose finds in souks and museums inspire her delicately patterned, vintage-looking pastels. Born in Miami to Venezuelan parents and raised in Paris, she developed a passion for antique textile design in college. "My fabrics look old, hand printed, vegetable dyed," Irving says. "A modern twist isn't me at all." Go to interactive >>

Spring has arrived on Broadway, with many musicals and a relatively large number of plays performing solidly at the box office last week. Several plays earned at least 50 percent of their maximum possible gross amounts, an indicator that each was in the black for the week. They were "Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo," with a healthy $637,756 in its first full week of previews; "Driving Miss Daisy"; "Good People"; "Ghetto Klown"; and "War Horse," which also had a strong showing of $653,919 for its first seven performances. Also above 50 percent was the week's top-grossing play, "That Championship Season," at $698,853, as well as "Arcadia" and "The Importance of Being Earnest." The musical "Wicked" was the top-grossing show, as usual, at $1.67 million; others that earned more than $1 million were "The Lion King," "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark," "Jersey Boys" and "Mary Poppins." Broadway shows earned $22.2 million over all last week, according to the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

There have been a host of efforts to describe Japan's earthquake and nuclear emergency, ranging from volumes of helpful graphics generated by The Times and other media to freelance efforts, including the "sonification" of a month of earthquake activity surrounding the great quake off Japan by Paul May and a chart by Randall Munroe comparing human radiation exposure from an array of sources -- ranging from a banana to a mammogram to a leaking nuclear plant and "A Layman's Intro to Radiation" by Ellen McManis, who operates a research reactor at Reed College.

George W. Bush had a movie, "W," made about him. Now Dick Cheney may be getting one as well, though for smaller screens. HBO confirmed on Monday that it was developing a miniseries about the political life of Mr. Cheney, the former vice president, emphasizing his decades-long effort to give more power to the executive branch of government. The untitled project is based on two nonfiction sources, the "Frontline" documentary "The Dark Side" and the best-selling book "Angler: The Cheney Vice Presidency," by Barton Gellman. Deadline.com reported that one executive producer was Paula Weinstein, who produced "Recount," about the presidential vote counting in Florida in 2000.

Love and hate do battle in Charles Laughton's eerie 1955 film "The Night of the Hunter," starring Robert Mitchum as a preacher harboring demons of his own. In his discussion of the film, A. O. Scott called it "a hybrid of a folk tale and a film noir, but true to its own vivid and haunting reality." The film was the first and only one directed by Mr. Laughton, who found inspiration in German Expressionism. "You can analyze it from a distance, which might bring some comfort," Mr. Scott says, "but while you're watching this movie, you're like a child in the grip of a nightmare."

A century after 146 garment workers died in a fire at the Triangle shirtwaist factory, new immigrants still try to sew their way to the American dream.  But these days, especially in New York, garment work is hard to come by.  Safe working conditions and living wages in unionized factories are a legacy of the Triangle fire, but in other factories, day laborers from Latin America say they are treated poorly, paid less than minimum wage, or not paid at all.  That is, if they can find work.

Twyla Tharp turns 70 this summer, but the choreographer isn't slowing down any time soon. Atlanta Ballet and the Royal Winnipeg Ballet have announced that Ms. Tharp will collaborate with the two companies on a new evening-length ballet for next season. The ballet will be produced by the two companies and will have its premiere in Atlanta in February 2012, followed by a Canadian premiere in the fall of 2012.

Brad DeLong, in writing about the dubious state of economics as a discipline (at least in some quarters), offers a useful set of quotes and links from freshwater economists who were shocked, shocked at the idea that anyone imagined that fiscal expansion might be expansionary. Brad stresses these economists' ignorance of intellectual tradition. But they were and still are amazingly ignorant of what contemporary economists who don't happen to be part of their hermetic world have been doing.

Seven years after the debut of her Indian-inspired jewelry collaboration with H. Stern, Diane von Furstenberg has added eight new gem-inlaid yellow gold pieces to the Sutras collection. Rock crystals and diamonds are organically incorporated into the designs, using techniques employed by the Mughal Empire of Jaipur, India. "Gold embraces a gemstone and assumes its form," says von Furstenberg of eye-catching pieces like the undulating teardrop crystal rings. "The movement within the gold alludes to sensuality and natural feminine forms." Inspirational inscriptions, like love, laughter, harmony and freedom, are engraved on the back of each pendant, earring droplet and ring, a tribute to the power von Furstenberg sees in both words and gold. (Prices range from $3,200 to $8,200). "The combination not only adds beauty, but strength and empowerment as well," she explains. Indeed, the collection displays a majestic embodiment of the literal translation of "sutra" from Sanskrit: a line that holds objects together.

Sometimes, passing underground through Union Square or Times Square, you hear snatches of good music: the well-scratched washboard of the Ebony Hillbillies or the sonic eruption of the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, who upset commuters boroughwide when they made the understandable if regrettable decision not long ago to move into the light. Riders are divided in their response to the single-minded intensity of Alice Tan Ridley, whose many renditions of "I Will Survive" are almost too authentic. Ridley, by the way, is Gabourey Sidibe's mother (Sidibe played Precious in the movie of the same name a couple of years ago), and when the conversation turns to subway music, she is the first person many locals mention, rarely by name, almost always as "the woman who sings 'I Will Survive' for hours on end." Ridley taught special ed before she hit the platforms, and after reaching the semifinals of "America's Got Talent" last year, she has become perhaps our best-known subway performer.

Amanda Hocking, the darling of the self-publishing world, has been shopping a four-book series to major publishers, attracting bids of well over $1 million for world English rights, two publishing executives said.

We all have an image of the politicians who started out in the log cabin or the farm and rose to greatness. It turns out this doesn't happen very often. James Gimpel, Francis Lee and Rebecca Thorpe published a study in Political Geography finding that candidates and nominees for statewide office rarely come from rural parts of their states. Instead, these candidates and nominees come from the most populous counties-in numbers significantly out of proportion to these counties' share of their state population. Gimpel, Lee and Thorpe argue that dense population fosters political ambition and provides candidates with the resources they need to pursue their ambition. The upshot is that rural areas are under-represented in state governments.

We know that the nuclear situation in Japan is critical. But how bad is it? Japan's nuclear safety agency on Friday raised the rating of the crisis at Fukushima from 4 to 5 on the 7-step international scale. On one hand, this is scary: another Level 5 nuclear crisis was at Three Mile Island in 1979. (Chernobyl was a 7.) On the other hand, as a scientist friend pointed out to me this morning, the new rating means that the situation in Fukushima is 1/100 as bad as the Chernobyl accident.

As the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament rages on, the spectacle of competitive sports seems more surreal than usual. In a country barely wobbling out of the recession, how can so much energy, ambition and money be channeled into this? Should we Americans be proud, or a little ashamed? It's hardly just basketball and football. The freakiest detail to catch my attention over the weekend came from the unlikely realm of long-distance running, in a Wall Street Journal profile of the former marathon champ Alberto Salazar, who now works for Nike. Salazar is obsessed with restoring American runners, long displaced by Africans and others, to a position of greatness in the world. How obsessed? The poor man could be mistaken for one of those screaming college basketball coaches:

If, somehow, you have not heard of 13-year-old Rebecca Black, let me back up for a moment. The eighth grader wants to be a pop star, and her parents paid $2,000 to the Ark Music Factory to turn her simple song "Friday," about looking forward to a weekend party, into an Internet-ready video. It went viral, but not entirely in the way Rebecca and her family had hoped. She received nearly 30 million YouTube hits, and that became license for countless strangers to pummel her online. They called her "the worst singer in the world" and -- in the comment she says hurt the most -- said, "I hope you'll get an eating disorder so you'll be pretty."

Downtown is a state of mind for the art impresarios Aaron Bondaroff and Al Moran, whether they're selling Statue of Liberty figurines by Kembra Pfahler at a pop-up shop in Athens, Greece, or recreating the Ludlow Street watering hole Max Fish at a bar in Miami (bar staff included). After descending upon Los Angeles last year with a one-night-only Halloween Neckface show that drew 5,000 people, this weekend the two introduced the new L.A. home of their OHWOW gallery. Opening Saturday in a 4,000-square-foot, ivy-covered former Laundromat on La Cienega Boulevard in West Hollywood, OHWOW presented "Noblesse Oblige," the first L.A. exhibition from Scott Campbell, who is as well known for the work he's inked into the flesh of Marc Jacobs, Terry Richardson and others as he is for the intricate 3-D pieces he cuts into sheets of United States currency. "Noblesse Oblige" - an ironic battle cry for Campbell's backwoods Louisiana kin and a phrase he has tattooed on his neck - also finds the artist working with neon, etching onto 24-karat gold plates, and drawing on the insides of ostrich eggs. We caught up with Bondaroff and Moran in the Rafael de Cardenas-designed space to discuss the bigger picture.

"The Divine Sister," Charles Busch's Off Broadway love letter to Hollywood movies about nuns, will end its run on May 1 after nearly eight months of performances at the Soho Playhouse. The producers, Daryl Roth and Bob Boyett, said this weekend that the critically acclaimed comedy would close because of the previous commitments of several cast members. One of them, Alison Fraser, had already announced plans to leave next month to join the cast of the coming Off Broadway production of "The School for Lies." Mr. Busch dons a nun's wimple to star as Mother Superior, his latest drag role in a celebrated career in New York theater, where he is best known for his works "Vampire Lesbians of Sodom" and "Die Mommie Die!" His foray onto Broadway as a playwright also yielded a hit in 2000, "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife." Directed by Carl Andress, "The Divine Sister" also stars Julie Halston, Amy Rutberg, Jennifer Van Dyck and Jonathan Walker. It began preview performances on Sept. 12 and opened on Sept. 22.

Dostoyevsky wrote about the magic of a change of place. And as Adan Jodorowsky can attest, it doesn't hurt to change your name and your language while you're at it. In 2004, in a cheap hotel in Mexico City, the 31-year-old singer (and the son of the cult filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky) was reborn as Adanowsky after taking part in a shamanic ritual. But it wasn't until he left his native Paris for Chile and translated his lyrics from French to Spanish that he and his career started to go places. Lately, he splits his time between Mexico City, Los Angeles, Paris and anywhere the tour for his melancholy new album, "Amador," takes him. Catch him if you can.

Last month Inc. magazine ran a fascinating article by Leigh Buchanan called "How Entrepreneurs Think." Corporate leaders, Buchanan wrote, are often good at causal reasoning. They set a goal and diligently find the best way to achieve it. Entrepreneurs are often good at effectual reasoning. They start without concrete goals but constantly improvise and react creatively to contingencies.

Oh, and business surveys show that poor sales, not any imagined threat from government, are the reason for low investment.

9 P.M. (13) NO TOMORROW (2011) In May 2005 PBS broadcast the documentary ''Aging Out,'' directed by Roger Weisberg and Vanessa Roth, about the challenges facing older teenagers who were forced to leave the foster care system and learn to fend for themselves. One subject was Risa Bejarano, above, who was abused and molested as a child and shuttled among foster homes in Los Angeles for six years. After becoming the first member of her family to graduate from high school and receiving scholarships for college, she eventually found herself battling drug addiction. By June 2004 she was living on the street. That month she was fatally shot by Juan Jose Chavez, who wanted to prevent her from talking to the police about two gang killings she might have witnessed. He was ultimately sentenced to death. In this new documentary Mr. Weisberg and Ms. Roth follow up on Ms. Bejarano's murder and the unexpected role that ''Aging Out'' played in the trial of her killer. 8 P.M. (ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS As a wide receiver for the Pittsburgh Steelers, Hines Ward (left, with his dancing partner Kym Johnson) uses deft footwork to help the team keep the ball moving, so much so that some odds makers are predicting he will win this Season 11 competition. Joining him on the ballroom floor are the actors Kirstie Alley, Chelsea Kane and Ralph Macchio; the radio personality Mick Catherwood, a k a Psycho Mike; Chris Jericho, a World Wrestling Entertainment world champion and the lead singer of the rock band Fozzy; the former boxer Sugar Ray Leonard; the model Petra Nemcova; the rapper Romeo; Kendra Wilkinson, formerly of ''The Girls Next Door''; and the talk-show host Wendy Williams.

SILVERMAN--Sandra. The Board and staff of the Community Service Society of New York mourn the loss of a friend and advocate for social justice, civil liberty and human rights. Her leadership and contributions to the people of New York have inspired many. Our deepest sympathy goes to her family. David R. Jones, Esq., President & CEO Community Service Society of New York

From her colleagues and friends at the firm; Margaret Booth, President; Brad Rodney, Managing Partner.

The weeks between the announcement of a Grammy nomination and the awards show offer cachet, exposure and sales. In the album of the year category, even a well-known artist like Katy Perry took in a substantial portion of total sales for her ''Teenage Dream'' during that period. After the awards, the winner benefits: ''The Suburbs'' by Arcade Fire tallied 15 percent of its total after the ceremonies (compared with 9 percent for ''Teenage Dream''). In the best new artist category, Justin Bieber (album sales of 4.4 million) and Drake (3.3 million) did not lack exposure. Esperanza Spalding, above, the category's winner, sold 11 percent of her 170,000 albums after her nomination and 29 percent after the win.

OPPENHEIMER--Bertram Jay, M.D. March 10, 1922March 18, 2011. Dr. Bertram Jay Oppenheimer served the Yonkers community faithfully for more than 40 years; Rotarian; graduate of Yonkers High, Cornell and Washington University Medical School, Army Air Corp. Veteran. Preceded in death by first wife, Elaine. Survived by children Martin, George, Betty and Joseph; wife Leatryce and her children V. Michelle, Cleveland and Gregory; and grandchildren Zorah and Jordan. View full obituary: www.flynnmemorial home.com. Service Thursday, March 24, 6-8pm at Flynn Memorial Home, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers. Memorial gifts to the American Cancer Society.

The former North Carolina State coach Jim Valvano's famous mantra about the N.C.A.A. tournament was ''survive and advance.'' For the teams that have made it to the Round of 16, close calls will be long forgotten. There is no looking back, only forward to Houston and the Final Four. The Southeast Region was pegged as the most unpredictable when the bracket was announced, and it did not disappoint. On Thursday in New Orleans, FLORIDA, which some felt did not deserve a No. 2 seed, will face No. 3 seed BRIGHAM YOUNG, which many dismissed with the suspension of Brandon Davies. No. 8 BUTLER has continued its charmed tournament existence with two last-second victories -- the second on one of the most bizarre endings in tournament history. Up next for the Bulldogs is No. 4 WISCONSIN.

Toshiko Takaezu, a Japanese-American ceramist whose closed pots and torpedolike cylinders, derived from natural forms, helped elevate ceramics from the production of functional vessels to a fine art, died on March 9 in Honolulu. She was 88. Her death was confirmed by Scott Ashley, the associate director of the Perimeter Gallery in Chicago.
