SAN FRANCISCO -- Barry Bonds will walk into United States District Court here on Monday ready for a contest likely to be tougher than any baseball game or home run race he ever took part in. Nearly four years after his initial indictment, Bonds will be tried on charges that he lied to a federal grand jury in 2003 when he testified that he had never knowingly used steroids. His legacy as baseball's home run king is at stake, as is his freedom.

AUSTIN, Texas -- Angry Birds, the wildly popular game for mobile devices that challenges players to sling grumpy birds at complex formations of smirking pigs, has close to 100 million downloads and a flourishing line of merchandise like cute plush toys. So why did Rovio, the Finnish firm behind the game, raise a $42 million round of venture financing from Accel Partners and Atomic Ventures?

KOLBER--Kate Rudes, of Boca Raton, FL, on March 16, 2011, at age 98. Beloved wife of the late Sam Kolber, cherished mother of Fred, Mark and Phil; loving grandmother of Samantha Berman, Francesca Warren, Michael, Anna and Carl; great-grandmother of seven; fond sister of the late Stan Rudes and aunt of Terry Davis and Jerry Rudes. She was a long time resident of Hewlett Bay Park before moving to Boca Raton 30 years ago. Kate was devoted to her family and adored by her large circle of friends. She had many interests, including bridge and golf, and was especially proud of her first hole-in-one at 91. She will be missed.

You've probably heard the adage ''birds of a feather ock together.'' A new research paper with the catchy title, ''Happiness is assortative in online social networks,'' has found another example of this maxim. The paper says that people who use Twitter congregate online according to their mood, not just by age or similar interests. For example, the research, which was led by Johan Bollen of the University of Indiana, found that people who send Twitter messages that include the word ''loneliness'' also tend to flock together on Twitter.

GERMAIN--Lawrence. In loving memory of my dear husband Lawrence who passed away March 21, 1991. To me You Were Someone Special, Someone set apart. Your Memory will live forever. Engraved within my heart. You gave me years of happiness Then sorrow came with tears. You left me lovely memories. I will treasure through the years. I remember the day I met you and the day God made you mine, I remember the day I lost you and will until the end of time I dream of a beautiful garden by the gate my Lawrence stands, one day that gate will open and Lawrence will take my hand. Sadly remembered by your loving Wife, Sheila

CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- The last time Duke and Michigan played in the N.C.A.A. tournament was the 1992 championship game, won by Duke for its second consecutive title. The Blue Devils are once again on a quest to win a second consecutive championship. And Michigan stood in their way this time, too. Not anymore.

FRIEDMAN--John M.,66 years old, a lawyer, woodworker, and mathematician, died on March 17, 2011, in Connecticut, after a long and courageous struggle with pulmonary fibrosis. He lived in Roxbury, CT. Friedman graduated from Princeton University in 1966, and received a masters degree from University of Sussex and a law degree from the University of Chicago in 1970. He was a partner in the law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, where he spent 25 years. In 1996 he retired and became a full time resident of Litchfield County, CT. Over the next 15 years he served as Chairman of the Board of The Washington Montessori School, Chairman of the Federation Foundation of the Jewish Communities of Western Connecticut, Vice President of the Federation and served on various community boards. Friedman was multi-dimensional: he wrote a math column for The Litchfield County Times, was an avid fly fisherman and took great pride in his woodworking. Friedman is survived by his wife, Judith, his sons David and Michael, his daughter Julia and his sister Tonni. The funeral will be held on Monday, March 21, 2011 at 11am at B'nai Israel, Southbury, CT. Please send donations to John Friedman Memorial, Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation, 811 West Evergreen Avenue, Chicago, IL 60642.

PETERS--Virginia Frank, lived 87 wonderful years before dying suddenly on March 14, 2011 in Florida. Ginny loved her family, friends and fun. She was very charitable and devoted herself to volunteer work in hospitals, schools, churches and community clubs. She will be greatly missed by her two daughters, Susan and Sally, son-in-law, grandchildren and many friends. A memorial service we be held on Friday, April 15th at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Delray Beach, FL at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Thomas Hartman Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Inc., 72 West Main St., E. Islip, NY 11730

With AT&T agreeing to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, the future of Sprint Nextel just got fuzzier. Over the past several months, Sprint had held its own talks with Deutsche Telekom, the owner of T-Mobile, over a potential deal, as part of an effort to gain sorely needed scale and wireless spectrum, according to people with knowledge of the talks, which were intended to be private. But Telekom's discussions with AT&T moved more quickly this month, and the two reached a preliminary agreement last week, one of these people said.

LOS ANGELES - Ask executives at Disney Publishing to explain why they are trying to build a children's subscription magazine business in the United States, and the answer will involve marketplace analysis this and business model that. It boils down to this explanation, offered by Aparna Pande, Disney's general manager for American magazines: ''Kids want them, and moms will pay for them.'' On Tuesday, Disney plans to announce the introduction of a cluster of new subscription magazines - an effort to replicate in the United States what is a robust business in Europe. Phineas and Ferb, a print companion to the animated television series of the same name, will be a 52-page bimonthly available at retail outlets for $4.99 and via annual subscription for $23.95.

GOFFNER--Arlene, on March 17, 2011. Beloved wife of Ralph. Loving mother of Lori and Doug, Gary and Jennifer and Karen. Cherished grandmother of Matthew, Perry and Amanda. Her warmth and love will remain in our hearts and thoughts forever. May she rest in peace with her daughter Karen. The family is asking that any kind of donation that you might be considering may be made to: The Wyckoff Hospital Foundation, The Arlene Goffner Fund, Attn: Anna Roggio, 374 Stockholm Street, Brooklyn, NY 11237, Phone: 718-963-7272.

NASH--Selma B. Passed away peacefully on March 19 at age 96. Adoring wife of the late Joseph J. Nash, mother of Ronnie and William Potter, grandmother of Geoffrey Potter, Melissa Potter and Pamela Potter-Osit. Grandmama to her seven great-grandchildren. We will miss her unwavering devotion and her daily advise. Funeral private.

LIBYA American and European forces stepped up their air and sea barrage against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's forces. Rebel forces in the east seemed to consolidate their hold on Benghazi after heavy fighting on Saturday, and they began moving back to the west, advancing past government vehicles destroyed by allied airstrikes. EGYPT Voters overwhelming approved constitutional changes to usher in rapid elections to replace the Mubarak government. Results underscored the strength of established political organizations, like the Muslim Brotherhood and remnants of the National Democratic Party, and the weakness of new liberal groups. The Muslim Brotherhood said it embraced a swift return to civilian rule, but the liberal groups said early elections would lead to a constitution that centralizes power much like the old one.
GOFFNER--Arlene. We mourn our esteemed member's passing and send heartfelt sympathy to her family. Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre

SILVERMAN--Sandra. Symphony Space notes with great sadness the death of our esteemed board member, Sandy Silverman. As chair of our 30th Anniversary, among other roles, she was a wonderful presence. Steven M. Alden, Chair Cynthia Elliott, President and CEO

Think of Washington's initial 2011 budget fights as spring training - for a season about to open in a hailstorm. Twice, Congress and the Obama White House have agreed on temporary spending bills that trim spending and keep the government open. Last week's version averted a shutdown, at least until April 8.

Two hundred years ago, New York's street commissioners certified Manhattan's 90-degree street grid. An interactive map shows the 1811 street grid, its development over time, and some obscure facts. nytimes.com/nyregion

The Rangers have gotten hot when they needed to. They won their fourth game in a row and sixth in their last seven with a 5-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins on Sunday. The result also gave the seventhplace Rangers a big boost in the tight Eastern Conference playoff race. But the game may be better remembered for the gratuitous elbow the Penguins' Matt Cooke threw at the head of Rangers defenseman Ryan McDonagh -- flagrant enough that it earned Cooke a five-minute major and a game misconduct, as well as a public rebuke from his coach. It will also probably cost Cooke a substantial suspension from the N.H.L.

WEIL--Mabel S. (nee Selig), 80, at home on March 19, 2011, with her family by her side, after a long illness. Cherished wife of Leon J. for 59 years, devoted mother of Jerry, Katie and Cary, proud mother-in-law of Gigi, Stuart and Rick, adored grandmother of Ben, Harry, Lilly, Charlotte, Jackson, Victoria and Emma. Daughter of the late Ivan and Mabel Selig, sister of Ivan M. and Leon M. Selig; predeceased by her sister Mary Jane Mullen, whose five children she loved as her own. Born and raised in New Rochelle, NY, she lived in New York City her entire married life, except for three years in Kathmandu, Nepal, during her husband's appointment there as US Ambassador. It was an experience she relished. A graduate of Wheaton College and Hunter College Master of Urban Planning Program, she worked six years on the staff of US Senator James L. Buckley. From 1989 until the end of her life, she proudly worked for the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, primarily as program director. Longtime board member of the National Dance Institute, Himalayan Healthcare and the Kathmandu Valley Preservation Trust, causes close to her heart. Avid swimmer, skier and tennis player almost until the end. A cancer survivor for 12 years, she faced her final illness with grace, dignity and humor. Her endless curiosity, unbridled enthusiasm for life and unfailing interest in others will be dearly missed by her family, many friends, co-workers and close knit extended family. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison at 81st, on Wednesday March 23 at 3:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her honor to the National Dance Institute or to the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research.

GRUBERG--Steve, 69, Brooklyn born and Manhattan dweller, died March 19, 2011 after a long, well fought battle with cancer. He was surrounded by family and friends. Best known by Manhattan Cable TV viewers for his popular weekly call in show "The Grube Tube" running for over 35 years, he was an original and a true pioneer in cable access television. Steve's powerful personality, love of comedy, fishing and fierce dedication to friends and family, made him a uniquely memorable husband, brother, son and friend. He was loved by many and will be missed. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife Adrienne, and brother Mitchell. He was the son of the late Harold and Sylvia Gruberg. Services, Monday 11am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

KAYLIE--Tess Aranowitz. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our most dedicated benefactor, Harvey Kaylie, eponym of the Kaylie Center and the Aranowitz Library. Harvey, your magnanimous efforts on behalf of the Jewish people are a lasting tribute to your mother's cherished legacy. Our heartfelt sympathy to Harvey, Gloria, and to the entire family. May her memory always be a source of blessing and inspiration. Rabbi Marc Schneier Morris Tuchman, President Seymour Siegel, Treasurer

GOLDSTEIN--Bruce, 80, died on March 13, 2011. He was a resident of Sun Lakes in Chandler, AZ for the past five years. Before his retirement, Mr. Goldstein practiced law in Manhattan for 40 years. He was originally from the Bronx is survived by his loving wife, Tudie Yanuck Goldstein.

A delicate French pastry is trying to take over New York, one mouth at a time. On Sunday, more than a dozen bakeries sent thousands of brightly colored, bite-size macarons onto the streets, offering them free of charge to curious passers-by. The celebration even had a name, Macaron Day. Organized by the baker François Payard, it was inspired by a similar event in Paris the same day (created by the French pastry chef Pierre Hermé).

An editorial on Saturday about the death penalty incorrectly described the drug protocols used in Texas and Oklahoma. Both states are using pentobarbital as a substitute for sodium thipental in a three-drug protocol. They are not using a one-drug protocol.

GOLDBERG--Neal, a leader in the retail sector, died on Thursday, March 17th. He was 51. He will be remembered as a loving father, caring husband and philanthropist. He is survived by his wife Denise, and his two sons Zachary and Max, his stepchildren Marinna and Michael and his mother Rita and sister Meryl.

COLLEGEVILLE, Pa. -- For years, officials at Ursinus College had been trying to figure out how to capitalize on the fact that J. D. Salinger had spent one semester there in the fall of 1938. They were hoping to attract publicity for Ursinus and tried everything they could think of to lure Salinger from the secluded world he'd lived in for his final 50 years. They offered to make him a guest lecturer; to build a literary festival around him; to award him an honorary degree. ''No response,'' said Richard DiFeliciantonio, the vice president for enrollment at the small liberal arts college here. ''Absolutely nothing.''

WNET, the parent company of New York City-area public broadcasters WNET Channel 13 and WLIW Channel 21, is going into the local news business, starting on the Web around Memorial Day. The new venture, named ''MetroFocus,'' is envisioned as a half-hour television show and, eventually, a mobile application as well. The expansion to television specials or a monthly or weekly show, to show on both television stations, could come as soon as the fall, with expectation for a daily version to follow later.

ROSS--Lord Robert. The Board of Governors and Members of Falls Golf and Country Club, Lake Worth, FL, acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Lord Robert Ross. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Lady Anne and their family. Gerald Fineberg, President

12:16 a.m. | Updated AT&T announced on Sunday that it had agreed to buy T-Mobile USA from Deutsche Telekom for $39 billion, in a deal that would create the largest carrier in the nation and promised to reshape the industry. The transaction - one of the largest since the onset of the financial crisis - is expected to start a fierce battle in Washington as regulators scrutinize the impact of the deal on competition and consumers. The deal would leave just three major cellular companies in the country: AT&T, Verizon and the much smaller Sprint Nextel.

ROSS--Robert, (New York City/Palm Beach) passed away March 19th after a long and courageous battle with cancer. At the age of 92, Dr. Ross has achieved more than most people can dream of. He is survived by his devoted wife of 40 years, Anne, and his children: Nancy Ross, Carole Walker, Bryan Ross, Warren Ross, and Anne's children, Marlene Hummel, Janis Adler; and 13 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Dr. Robert Ross is best known as a pioneer in medical education--as he founded and led Ross University, one of the largest and most successful Caribbean medical and veterinary schools from 1979 to 2000. His reputation for developing academic institutions and dedication to excellence is known worldwide. Thousands of his graduates are now licensed and practicing throughout the United States. After selling his schools in 2000, Dr. Ross followed his passion to address the shortage of nurses and physicians in the United States and Canada by founding the International University of Nursing (IUON) and the University of Medicine and Health Sciences... A state of the art medical and nursing school that compares to the best schools in the United States. In addition to his many contributions to humanity, Dr. Ross also proudly served his country in World War II, assigned to the 69th Infantry Division. Funeral services will take place at the Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY (212-362-6600) on March 22nd, at 10am. Following the service the procession will move to the final burial site located at the New Montefiore Jewish Cemetery (631-249-7000) at 1180 Wellwood Ave., West Babylon, NY.

9:48 a.m. | Updated Mitch Daniels, the governor of Indiana, may not run for president. But if he does, the controversies of his governorship will follow him. He took some heat for aggressive plans to privatize parts of state government but urged lawmakers to delay passing controversial right-to-work legislation. Now, there's a contentious legal battle with I.B.M., which is being sued by the governor over a canceled $1.3 billion contract to modernize the state's welfare system. In blunt language, a company lawyer charges Mr. Daniels with hypocrisy for claiming to run a "transparent" government but refusing to release documents or be deposed in the case. A lawyer for the state says there are many others who can testify besides the governor. A spokeswoman for Mr. Daniels declined to comment for an article in The Indianapolis Star.

Governments cannot create or even know what will be the next great entrepreneurial success. The Web's latest hits show the pitfalls of such efforts.

I got a call yesterday morning from David Wilson, the general manager of Quorn in the United States. Quorn is a British enterprise that has been moving into the American market with a line of meatless products that approximate the taste of meat but are, in fact, developed from a mycoprotein that comes from Fusarium venenatum, "which was originally discovered growing in a field in Buckinghamshire, England," as I learned from the Quorn Web site.

There's this story in Haruki Murakami's "after the quake" (according to Jay Rubin, the book's translator, Murakami insisted that the title be lowercase) called "Super-Frog Saves Tokyo." The book is a collection of short stories about the psychic aftershocks of the '95 Kobe earthquake. (Here's a fascinating conversation between Murakami and Jonathan Lethem, plus audio of Murakami reading "Super-Frog.") Five of the six stories are more or less straight-up realism, but "Super-Frog" is from the land of Kafka. A slightly overwhelmed and depressive banker named Katagiri comes home one day to find a huge Dostoyevsky-quoting frog in his house. The frog tells Katagiri that he needs his help defeating the monstrous Worm that's raging beneath the streets of Tokyo. (Worm, by the way, is a version of the catfish of Japanese mythology, which my colleague Harvey Dickson wrote about.)

At first glance, the photographs in Miru Kim's new show, "The Pig That Therefore I Am," opening this Thursday at the Doosan Gallery in New York, seem like abstract studies of female skin. But as your eye moves to take in the big picture, you are surprised and perhaps a bit horrified to discover that most of the flesh in these intimate compositions is not human. A nude female (the 30-year-old artist herself) lies in filth with hundreds of caged hogs in industrial farms. The impulse is to recoil in disgust, but you are easily drawn back by the stillness, the almost transcendental quality of the images.

Wildlife was another casualty of the March 10-11 tsunami, and the federal Fish and Wildlife Service has been tallying the toll on birds at the Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge, including an estimated 110,000 albatross chicks and 2,000 adult albatrosses. On Tuesday the agency reported that Wisdom, an albatross thought to be the world's oldest bird in the wild, had survived and returned to her nesting place. Leslie Kaufman reported in a post here two weeks ago that Wisdom, believed to be at least 60, was still breeding.

There's a lot that goes into opening a new school in New York City. For the Department of Education, the process demands several layers of discussions and decisions that include finding a place for the school, fine-tuning its academic mission and, especially in the case of high schools, settling on a name that will make it stand out in a crowded, competitive field.

After several months out of the spotlight, Chris Brown has the nation's attention again, though surely not for the reason he intended. On Tuesday, the first day of release for his new album, "F.A.M.E.," Mr. Brown reportedly left behind a dressing room strewn with broken glass at ABC's "Good Morning America" after giving an uncomfortable interview to the "G.M.A." co-anchor Robin Roberts. In the interview, Ms. Roberts asked Mr. Brown about a 2009 incident involving his ex-companion, the pop singer Rihanna, after which Mr. Brown pleaded guilty to a charge of felonious assault and was sentenced to five years of probation and six months of community labor. After Mr. Brown said that a restraining order against him had recently been relaxed, Ms. Roberts asked if he and Rihanna still saw each other; Mr. Brown replied, "I mean, not really," and he avoided follow-up questions. Mr. Brown then performed a song from his new album and returned to his dressing room, where the "G.M.A." morning staff members said they heard loud noises that prompted a call to security, according to a report on the ABC News Web site. It was later found that a window in the dressing room had been broken, leaving glass in the room and on the street outside ABC's studio in Times Square, and that Mr. Brown and his representatives had left the building.

The youthfully exuberant Julia Haltigan performed a free set recently at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's upstairs cafe. With 7 minutes 26 seconds remaining in Monday's Celtics-Knicks game, Chauncey Billups converted a 4-point play that gave the Knicks a 9-point lead over the Celtics. Everything seemed to be working for the Knicks; the ball was moving, shots were falling and the Celtics were struggling offensively. Unfortunately for the Knicks, they were outscored, 23-4, after Billups's 4-point play, and managed only one field goal in the final seven minutes of the game.

James Gandolfini may be a man of few words, but when he returns to the cable channel that made him, it's worth devoting a few words to. HBO said on Tuesday that Mr. Gandolfini was planning to star in a new made-for-cable film that would return him to the network that gave us "The Sopranos," as well as the state that gave us the Bada Bing! club. The film will be adapted from "Eating With the Enemy: How I Waged Peace With North Korea From My BBQ Shack in Hackensack," a nonfiction book by Robert Egan and Kurt Pitzer, in which Mr. Egan recounts how he used his barbecue restaurant to build friendships with diplomats from Vietnam and North Korea, and became an unlikely liaison between North Korea and the United States. Mr. Gandolfini, who has also produced the HBO documentaries "Alive Day: Home from Iraq" and "Wartorn: 1861-2010," is attached as a star and would also be an executive producer of the new film, which will be produced by his Attaboy Productions company and Tribeca Productions, though neither a start date for production nor a broadcast date on HBO have been announced.

An Australian play about four people from a small town trying to build new lives after a violent crime has won the 2011 Yale Drama Series award for an emerging playwright. John Guare, the acclaimed stage writer ("The House of Blue Leaves," "Six Degrees of Separation") and judge for the series, announced on Tuesday that Shannon Murdoch had won for "New Light Shine." Ms. Murdoch, who is a legal assistant and writer living near Melbourne, will receive $10,000 from the David Charles Horn Foundation, and there will be a staged reading of the play at the Yale Repertory Theater on Sept. 12. Yale University Press will also publish the play.

Judging from my inbox, many readers interpreted this week's column, which examines the perils inherent in the liberal interventionist style of warfare, as an implicit defense of the Bush administration's rather different approach to the invasion of Iraq. (There were hints of a similar critique from Adam Serwer and Andrew Sullivan as well.) This was not my intention at all: As I've suggested before, I think that the Iraq War was a mistake in its conception and a botch in its execution, and I wouldn't be supportive of our Libya intervention if it were being undertaken à la Rumsfeld (or John Bolton) rather than à la Samantha Power. My point, rather, was to push back against the conceit that the form of a war can vindicate its strategy - that what matters most in warfare is whether you're "part of U.N. Security Council approved action" and whether the Arab League gives you the go-ahead, and that merely invoking the Obama White House's multilateralism is sufficient to prove that our Libyan venture is far more responsible than the invasion of Iraq. Too many liberal Libya hawks (the president included) seem bent on persuading themselves that a strategically dubious intervention is justified so long as its goals are sufficiently high-minded and the French and the United Nations are on board. But the history of such interventions doesn't bear their logic out.

Roubaix, France, an old textile town near Lille, has stitched its fabric-driven past to the fashion-driven present. As part of its Maisons de Mode initiative, the regional government recently helped turn a disused cinder block warehouse into Le Vestiaire (right; 27 rue de l'Espérance; maisonsdemode.com), a complex of shops and ateliers for emerging designers. Stéphane Martello, a k a Mister Crochet, knits Etsy-chic pieces like a tiered turtleneck capelet. The dapper designer Eric Garde at Sakal does a wide range of sleek overcoats for men and women in everything from fine wool to faux-fur pile. The shop Mercredi (Wednesday, a half day for many happy French schoolchildren) has tot-size flannel shirts and pinafore dresses. And at Rhum Raisins (in a separate Maisons de Mode cluster at 101-107 avenue Jean Lebas), the three lovely Vermeulen sisters make pretty, structured clothes like a navy crepe dress with an empire waist and pleated skirt, and a sleeveless faux-fur patchwork minicoat with a stole collar.

An actor portraying Hamlet in an Irish production of that Shakespeare play sustained a palpable and frightening hit during a performance on Monday, resulting in his hospitalization, The Associated Press reported. Conor Madden, who is portraying the melancholy Danish prince in the Second Age Theater Company's production of "Hamlet" being presented at the Everyman Palace Theater in Cork, Ireland, was wounded during a sword fight. The A.P. said that Mr. Madden sustained a cut beneath his eye and collapsed on stage, requiring the theater company's artistic director, Alan Stanford, to go to the stage and explain to stunned audience members that this was not part of the play: the actor had been injured, and the play could not continue. Mr. Madden was treated and released. He will miss two performances scheduled for Tuesday but could return to the production as soon as Wednesday.

AHERN--Patrick V.,Bishop: Born in New York City, on March 8, 1919 to the late Patrick and Margaret (nee Flood). He was predeceased by his brother, Daniel. Bishop Ahern was a former Episcopal Vicar of the Bronx, Staten Island, and Vicar for Development for the Archdiocese of New York. STANFORD, Calif. -- Although it was far from a flawless performance, Stanford's 75-49 victory against St. John's on Monday in the second round of the N.C.A.A. women's basketball tournament spelled perfection for its upperclassmen. With the victory, the seniors finished their careers with a record of 63-0 at Maples Pavilion. It was the first meeting between the teams, but the Cardinal, seeded No. 1 in the Spokane Region, had seen the St. John's type before: a young, hungry, scrappy squad playing as if it had nothing to lose. Four years ago, Florida State upset the Cardinal at Maples in a second-round game, a result that no doubt flashed before the eyes of the Cardinal faithful when the ninth-seeded Red Storm (22-11) jumped out to a 22-14 lead after 10 minutes 15 seconds.

It is ''The Collapse of American Criminal Justice'' -- not ''Fighting Crime: Race, Crime, and Democracy in America,'' which had been a tentative title.

A federal judge in Manhattan has ruled against the artist Richard Prince in a closely watched copyright case, finding that Mr. Prince - who is well known for appropriating imagery created by others - violated the law by using photographs from a book about Rastafarians to create a series of collages and paintings. The decision, handed down on Friday by Judge Deborah A. Batts, found in favor of Patrick Cariou, a photographer whose book ''Yes Rasta,'' featuring portraits he took during several months in Jamaica, was published in 2000. According to the suit, Mr. Prince used 41 or more of the pictures from the book as the basis for a body of work he called ''Canal Zone,'' which was shown in St. Barts and in a 2008 exhibition at the Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea. A gallery that was planning to show Mr. Cariou's photographs canceled that exhibition after learning that Mr. Prince had already created works based on the photographs.

When my wife, Ruth, learned she had breast cancer, friends told us not to worry. After all, they said, a lot of progress has been made. As a cancer researcher and a doctor at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, where she was being treated, I knew this was true. Progress has indeed been made. Throughout my career, death rates from breast cancer in the United States have steadily declined by 1 percent to 2 percent a year.

MANNUCCI--Nancy Stingley, March 17, 2011 in New York City. Beloved wife of Mannuccio, adoring mother of Valerie, dear sister of Charles Stingley, caring stepmother of Mark (Stephanie) and Anthony (Katherine), doting Nonna of Libby, Matthew, Nico, Nam and My, loving aunt of Dianne (Mark), Chris (Brooke), Devin, Jack. Loved her visits to Rome and will be missed by sister-in-law Alba, her extended Italian family and numerous friends. Raised in Cincinnati, attended Walnut Hills High School and University of Michigan, Ann Arbor where she studied Art and Interior Design. Professional career in NYC: Interior Designer for over four decades, member American Society of Interior Designers, longtime member and past president of the Decorators Club. Advocate of Universal Design that is not only functional but beautiful. Her exquisite taste and standard of perfection have enriched the lives of many. Donations in Nancy's honor may be made to the Central Park Conservancy. Details for a memorial service will be announced.

WEIL--Mabel. Our dear friend and colleague, Mabel Weil, passed away this weekend after a courageous battle with cancer. We extend our condolences to her family -- her husband, the Hon. Leon Weil, and their three children Kate, Jerry, and Carrie, and their families. A dedicated conservative and proud American, Mabel started as a 'Goldwater girl,' campaigned and worked for Sen. Jim Buckley, and accompanied her husband to Nepal where he served as ambassador during the Reagan administration. She joined the Manhattan Institute in 1989, and demonstrated a Midas touch on her many and varied projects -- she was a strategic planner, exhibited superior policy judgment, and was the perfect ambassador for our work. While Mabel wore many hats at MI, her role as friend and confidant is the one her colleagues will miss the most. She was a mentor and inspiration to us all.

Twyla Tharp turns 70 this summer, but the choreographer isn't slowing down any time soon. Atlanta Ballet and the Royal Winnipeg Ballet have announced that Ms. Tharp will collaborate with the two companies on a new evening-length ballet for next season. The work, which will be based on the writings of the Scottish author George MacDonald, will feature music based on Schubert and arranged by Richard Burke. The ballet will be produced by the two companies and will have its premiere in Atlanta in February 2012, followed by a Canadian premiere in the fall of 2012. Ms. Tharp will begin choreographing the work on Atlanta Ballet this summer, and The Twyla Project, the name Atlanta Ballet has given to the collaboration, will include a series of preview events. At a news conference in Atlanta last week, Andre Lewis, artistic director of the Royal Winnipeg Ballet, said, ''This co-production represents a rare opportunity for artists from Canada, the United States and around the world to work together under the leadership of one of the world's most influential choreographers. We are honored to be working with Ms. Tharp.''

Stuart Holden's breakout season in the English Premier League has come to a premature end. On Monday, Bolton Wanderers announced that Holden, their American midfielder, would be sidelined for six months after sustaining a knee injury in Saturday's 1-0 loss to Manchester United. The crafty and competitive Holden, 25, was injured when Jonny Evans's studs-up sliding tackle left Holden with a gash that required 26 stitches to close. Evans was shown a red card; Holden was taken off the field on a stretcher.

Spring has arrived on Broadway, with many musicals and a relatively large number of plays performing solidly at the box office last week. Several plays earned at least 50 percent of their maximum possible gross amounts, an indicator that each was in the black for the week. They were ''Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,'' with a healthy $637,756 in its first full week of previews; ''Driving Miss Daisy''; ''Good People''; ''Ghetto Klown''; and ''War Horse.'' Also above 50 percent was the week's top-grossing play, ''That Championship Season,'' at $698,853, as well as ''Arcadia'' and ''The Importance of Being Earnest.'' The musical ''Wicked'' was the top-grossing show, as usual, at $1.67 million; others that earned more than $1 million were ''The Lion King,'' ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' ''Jersey Boys'' and ''Mary Poppins.'' Broadway shows earned $22.2 million over all last week, according to the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

But it was not clear when that assessment was made, or whether his condition had since improved. On Monday, a spokeswoman for the hospital, Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn, said only that Kymell was in critical condition.

ROSS--Robert (New York Cityalm Beach) passed away March 19th after a long and courageous battle with cancer. At the age of 92, Dr. Ross has achieved more than most people can dream of. He is survived by his devoted wife of 40 years, Anne, and his children: Nancy Ross, Carole Walker, Bryan Ross, Warren Ross, and Anne's children, Marlene Hummel, Janis Adler; and 13 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Dr. Robert Ross is best known as a pioneer in medical education--as he founded and led Ross University, one of the largest and most successful Caribbean medical and veterinary schools from 1979 to 2000. His reputation for developing academic institutions and dedication to excellence is known worldwide. Thousands of his graduates are now licensed and practicing throughout the United States. After selling his schools in 2000, Dr. Ross followed his passion to address the shortage of nurses and physicians in the United States and Canada by founding the International University of Nursing (IUON) and the University of Medicine and Health Sciences... A state of the art medical and nursing school that compares to the best schools in the United States. In addition to his many contributions to humanity, Dr. Ross also proudly served his country in World War II, assigned to the 69th Infantry Division. Funeral services will take place at the Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY (212-362-6600) on March 22nd, at 10am. CRICHTON-BRIGHAM--Zula passed peacefully on March 2, 2011, in Connecticut. Born in Colorado, she graduated from Northwestern University in Chicago with a degree in Music in 1940. Her love of music infused every aspect of her rich, long life. Later that year she married her childhood sweetheart, John Henderson Crichton, an advertising man. Mr. Crichton, then President of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, died in 1977. A gifted pianist, she tirelessly advocated for creative arts education in public schools and the improvement of libraries. She served as a Trustee of the Bryant Library in Roslyn, Long Island, and a Board member of the New Canaan Library; appropriate for a lifelong bibliophile. In her sixties she became an enthusiastic volunteer teacher of English as a second language and worked to reduce adult illiteracy. She was always dashing off to a lecture or a study group. A resident of New Canaan, Connecticut for more than fifty years, she served as an Elder of the First Presbyterian Church. She and Georges Brigham, a technical consultant and the founder and chairman of the APL Group, were joyously married there on December 6, 1997. She is survived by her sister, Mrs. Jean Sayre; her husband, Georges Brigham; three children, Kimberly, Douglas and Catherine Crichton; five grandchildren and two great-grandsons. Her eldest son, the author Michael Crichton, died in 2008. Her birthday this year, April 24, 2011, is Easter Sunday. Peace. A Memorial Service will be held for Zula Crichton-Brigham on Saturday, March 26, at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, at 2:00pm, followed by a reception at Bliss House. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to UNICEF, at US Fund for UNICEF, 125 Maiden Lane, 11th Flr., New York, NY 10038.

MUSEUMS An article in the special Museums section on Thursday about the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, N.Y., misspelled the surname of an adjunct curator. He is Klaus Ottmann, not Ottman. The article also misstated the date of the SITE Santa Fe Biennial that Mr. Ottmann organized. It was in 2006, not 2007.

LIBYA An American-led military campaign to destroy Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's air defenses and establish a no-fly zone over Libya has nearly accomplished its initial objectives, but the firepower of Tomahawk cruise missiles and attacks by allied warplanes have not yet succeeded in forcing Colonel Qaddafi to cease all attacks against civilians. SYRIA Protesters gathered on the streets of the southern city of Dara'a for a fourth consecutive day, witnesses said. The army entered the city for the first time to support the police, setting up checkpoints in the center of Dara'a and on the city's outskirts, according to a witness. The police fired live ammunition on a funeral procession for someone who died during a demonstration on Sunday. In addition, an 11-year-old boy died of injuries he suffered from the firing of tear gas on Sunday, according to a human rights activist.

An obituary on Saturday about the psychologist David E. Rumelhart misstated the year that the book ''Parallel Distributed Processing,'' which he wrote with Jay McClelland, was published. It was 1986, not 1987.

REEM-KAYDEN--Gabrielle H. M.D.,died peacefully on March 20, 2011. Survived by husband Herbert J. Kayden, M.D., son David S. Kayden, M.D., daughter-in-law Debbie Young Kayden, daughter Joelle M. Kayden and grandchildren Philip Samuel Killian and Eleanor Kayden Killian. Funeral private.

They say that even the longest journey begins with a single step, and Peter Jackson has finally reached that step on his movie adaptations of ''The Hobbit'' where cameras are (metaphorically) rolling, actors are performing their parts and footage is being gathered that will someday arrive in your local cinema. Warner Brothersannounced on Monday that production had begun in Wellington, New Zealand, on Mr. Jackson's two-film version of J. R. R. Tolkien's ''Hobbit'' novel, a project that has previously been stalled by the loss of the directorGuillermo del Toro; a battle between Mr. Jackson and labor unions in New Zealand and Australia over hiring practices for the films; and, just when things finally seemed to be getting on track, an emergency surgery for Mr. Jackson to repair a perforated ulcer. In a statement, Warner Brothers said that the ''Hobbit'' movies ''will be shot consecutively in digital 3-D using the latest camera and stereo technology'' and that filming ''will take place at Stone Street Studios, Wellington, and on location around New Zealand.'' The movies, which are being jointly produced by New Line Cinema and MGM, are planned for release in 2012 and 2013, though if history is any indication, there's no need to start camping outside your theater for tickets just yet.

An art review in some editions on Friday about the catalog of the German chocolate maker and art collector Peter Ludwig misstated the location of Specific Object, where the work is on display. It is on West 26th Street in Chelsea, not on 25th Street.

After the month that Jon Cryer just lived through, you'd think he'd had his fill of toxic bachelors. Instead, Mr. Cryer will spend some time away from ''Two and a Half Men,'' the CBS comedy on which he stars (starred?) with Charlie Sheen, in a semistaged production of ''Company'' for the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Cryer will play the role of David, a pot-puffing chum of the perennially single protagonist, Robert, who will be portrayed by his CBS colleague Neil Patrick Harris, representatives for the Philharmonic said on Monday. Also joining these ''Company'' performances, which will run from April 7 through 9, are Christina Hendricks, an Emmy Award nominee for ''Mad Men,'' who will be trading in her role as a tough-as-nails office manager to play the airhead flight attendant, April; Katie Finneran, a Tony Award-winner for ''Promises, Promises,'' who will play the motor-mouthed bride-to-be, Amy; and Craig Bierko (''The Music Man'') as Peter, one of Robert's amorous married friends. The cast will be rounded out by Aaron Lazar as Paul; Jill Paice (''The 39 Steps'') as Susan; Jennifer Laura Thompson (''Lend Me a Tenor'') as Jenny; and Chryssie Whitehead (''A Chorus Line'') as Kathy.
ENGEL--Betsy. Beautiful... brave, with a true zest for life. We miss you. Love and hugs from your Banyan buddies

An obituary on March 6 about the Czech author Arnost Lustig misstated the surname of the Czech director whose first feature film, ''Diamonds of the Night,'' was based on one of Mr. Lustig's stories. He is Jan Nemec, not Nimec.

CHRISTOPHER--Warren. The Council on Foreign Relations (CFR) mourns the passing of Warren Christopher. Secretary Christopher led a long and distinguished career as a statesman, diplomat, and lawyer. A dedicated member of CFR for close to 40 years, Secretary Christopher served on the Board of Directors from 1982 to 1991 and as vice chairman from 1987 to 1991, and in recent years was active in CFR's West Coast activities. We are truly grateful for his service to the Council, his community, and most importantly, to his country. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Marie, and other members of his family. Carla A. Hills, Co-Chairman Robert E. Rubin, Co-Chairman Richard N. Haass, President

Updated 9:00 p.m. | State Senator Kevin S. Parker, who faced as much as two years in prison for his role in attacking a staff photographer from The New York Post, was sentenced on Monday to three years' probation. Prosecutors had sought to put Mr. Parker behind bars for 30 days, followed by 30 days of supervised release.
GOFFNER--Arlene. The Board of Directors of Queens Plaza and Electric Realty Companies mourn the passing of Arlene Goffner, a longtime friend and shareholder of both companies.

10 P.M. (Syfy) MARCEL'S QUANTUM KITCHEN Marcel Vigneron (above with the caterer Robyn Wilson), a contestant on ''Top Chef All-Stars'' and the former head chef of Bar 210 in Los Angeles, is known for combining technology and tools, like canisters of liquid nitrogen, with food preparation, in a style of cooking known as molecular gastronomy. In this new series he sets off on the next phase of his career as the head of a catering and event company charged with turning clients' dreams into reality. His team, chefs all, includes Ms. Wilson, the mixologist Devon Espinosa and the artist Jarrid Masse. Their first assignment: to cater an elaborate party that will raise awareness of the Wildlife Waystation, an animal refuge and sanctuary in Southern California. The menu will feature an edible map and Himalayan Tiger's Breath, a dessert made with liquid nitrogen. 9 P.M. (ABC) BEST IN FILM: THE GREATEST MOVIES OF OUR TIMES Tom Bergeron and Cynthia McFadden reveal favorite films as voted on by fans in this collaboration between ABC News and People magazine. The special includes interviews with Harrison Ford, Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Newton-John and movie outtakes, screen tests and behind-the-scenes footage. Best-film categories include sci-fi, musical, action, horror, chick flick, comedy, animated, suspense/thriller, western, political/historical and overall.

George W. Bush had a movie, ''W,'' made about him. Now Dick Cheney may be getting one as well, though for smaller screens. HBO confirmed on Monday that it was developing a mini-series about the political life of Mr. Cheney, the former vice president, emphasizing his decades-long effort to give more power to the executive branch of government. The untitled project is based on two nonfiction sources, the ''Frontline'' documentary ''The Dark Side'' and the best-selling book ''Angler: The Cheney Vice Presidency,'' by Barton Gellman. Deadline.com reported that one executive producer was Paula Weinstein, who produced ''Recount,'' about the presidential vote counting in Florida in 2000. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

To the Editor: Your March 15 issue on animals was short on science and long on sentimental anecdotes about dogs and cats. The often negative effects of pets on neighbors, fellow walkers and the environment were given short shrift.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Friday with an art review about the annual Association of International Photography Art Dealers show at the Park Avenue Armory misspelled the surname of a photographer whose work was being shown by the Weinstein Gallery. GOTTLIEB--Martin, of Boca Raton, FL and Quogue, NY, on Sunday, March 20th. Devoted husband to his adoring wife, Evelyn for 63 years on this day. Every day-anytime of the day-an amazing Dad, adored by his children Stacey, Russ, Jonathan and Annie-lucky to have him this long with us. His seven grandchildren Cris, Sean, Sydney, Skylar, Sabrina, Julian, Cody - blessed with a grandpa that was unselfish, loving, and active in their lives. He was so proud of all of them. A great friend, someone you could count on and lucky to have in your life. An extraordinary man, whom everyone loved--with a smile that lit up the room and a warm heart that made everyone feel good. We will miss you daddy. The funeral will be held on Wednesday, March 23 at 9:30am: Jewish Community Center of Harrison, 130 Union Avenue, Harrison, NY 10528 (914) 835-2850.

''The Divine Sister,'' Charles Busch's Off Broadway love letter to Hollywood movies about nuns, will end its run on May 1 after nearly eight months of performances at the Soho Playhouse. The producers, Daryl Roth and Bob Boyett, said this weekend that the critically acclaimed comedy would close because of the previous commitments of several cast members. One of them, Alison Fraser, had already announced plans to leave next month to join the cast of the coming Off Broadway production of ''The School for Lies.'' Mr. Busch dons a nun's wimple to star as Mother Superior, his latest drag role in a celebrated career in New York theater, where he is best known for his works ''Vampire Lesbians of Sodom'' and ''Die Mommie Die!'' His foray onto Broadway as a playwright also yielded a hit in 2000, ''The Tale of the Allergist's Wife.'' Directed by Carl Andress, ''The Divine Sister'' also stars Julie Halston, Amy Rutberg, Jennifer Van Dyck and Jonathan Walker. It began preview performances on Sept. 12 and opened on Sept. 22. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

8:24 p.m. | Updated Just two years ago Citigroup stood on the brink of collapse. Its stock price was measured in cents, not dollars. But on Monday, the bank announced that it would reinstate a dividend and engineer a reverse split to lift its stock out of the single digits.

ROSS--Alan Gordon Alan, it's been 10 years, far too long. Always on our minds and in our hearts - always. Love you, Mom, Dad and Chris

TAMPA, Fla. - Call it a slurve, a cutter, a slider - Phil Hughes does not care. The new pitch he unveiled Wednesday night generated several swings-and-misses and six of his seven strikeouts against Toronto. With additional refinement, Hughes said it could be an asset during the season.

On Thursday, the mad scramble that is the opening week of the N.C.A.A. tournament makes way for a more orderly Round of 16: eight games in two nights to whittle the field to eight teams. But don't be fooled. There is plenty of opportunity for the unexpected. While spunky underdogs often face up to the reality that they are out of their depth in this round, teams with bushels of talent can ill afford to be caught looking ahead.

Most people keep their New Year's resolutions simple: exercise, save money, volunteer. Mya Henry and Eric Werner took on something more challenging - they made a pact to leave New York and open a restaurant in Tulum, Mexico. Last December, after seven months of planning, building and traveling around the country in search of antiques, they opened Hartwood, which they describe as "Mexican farmhouse rustic." Werner, who cooked at Peasant in Manhattan and Vinegar Hill House in Brooklyn, helms the kitchen, while Henry, who worked for the Soho Grand Hotel, runs the front of the house. Henry blames her naïveté for fueling their project. "I've never worked so hard in my life - despite being in this paradise." Go to interactive feature >>

That clever video of a Times Square billboard being hacked that you and thousands of other people passed around? It was an ad, designed to go viral. Bettina Edelstein talks to Tanzina Vega, a Times media reporter who followed a small team as they created a video in Times Square. Edited to look authentically amateur, the video was actually a promotion for a movie and it got nearly a million views in just a few days. For advertisers, this kind of viral marketing is a new direction, Ms. Vega says.

The former Giants star Lawrence Taylor was matter-of-fact Tuesday about his involvement with  prostitutes. On "Studio B with Shepard Smith" on Fox News, he said that "I'm not saying it's right but it's the oldest profession in the world" and that the only person he had "to answer to" was his wife.

Coverage of the Triangle Waist Company factory fire in 1911 by a corps of photojournalists - armed most likely with hand-held Press Graflex cameras - was one of the earliest such graphic, public, inescapable and almost instantaneous media assaults on genteel sensibility and certainly helped enshrine the tragedy. City Room takes a look at the newspapers that published the chilling pictures, in "Triangle Fire: A Frontier in Photojournalism," part of its overall centennial presentation this week, "The 1911 Triangle Fire."

A video created by a Democratic state legislator in Minnesota captures Tim Pawlenty, the former Republican governor and a 2012 presidential candidate, repeatedly calling for a cap-and-trade program for carbon dioxide emissions to fight climate change. The video was aired during a hearing on a Republican bill to lift restrictions on coal-fired power plants. Mr. Pawlenty now describes his past support for cap-and-trade as "stupid." [MinnPost]

Aaron Carroll has a very good takedown of an op-ed article by Senator Ron Johnson, who basically exploits his infant daughter's medical experience to make an incoherent attack on the Affordable Care Act. His daughter received excellent treatment, and he asserts that she wouldn't have received that kind of treatment under universal health insurance, because .... well, he doesn't explain.

If you're in the market for a home, you may want to consider some advice from academics before sealing the deal. Research papers on the subject of negotiation offer numerous tips to help potential home buyers better navigate the home-buying process, as I recently learned when I wrote a paper for my business school negotiation class on the subject. This post is part of a series on some of the findings that I thought were worth sharing. These are my earlier posts: "The True Value of a Home to a Seller," "Keeping Your Top House Price to Yourself" and "Why to Know What a Home Seller Paid."

This administration's Libya policy has grown steadily more baffling with every day that we've spent at war. On the one hand, it's clear that the Obama White House desires nothing more than to hand responsibility for this military operation over to France and Britain posthaste, and that the president has absolutely no intention of committing American ground forces to the shores of Tripoli. On the other hand, it's also clear that it may well take more than an air bombardment to remove Qaddafi's regime from power, which is the outcome that France is more or less explicitly pursuing, and that Britain and the United States are informally committed to as well. So where does this leave us? Adam Garfinkle minces no words:

A memorial to the youngest victim of the shooting rampage in Tucson, a 9-year-old girl who was born on 9/11, will include a five-foot length of steel from the World Trade Center.A statue of an angel, which will incorporate the steel, will memorialize the girl, Christina-Taylor Green. It is to be erected in the outfield of her Little League softball field in a Tucson suburb.Workers at Kennedy Airport's Hangar 17, where the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey stores debris from 9/11, removed a 272-pound beam on Wednesday; it is to be trucked to Arizona. Similar pieces have been sent to cities and towns and other countries for use in memorials.

CBS's Tuesday night block of procedurals lifted the network to No. 1 in the ratings, as "NCIS" delivered the largest audience in prime time with 19.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. "NCIS: Los Angeles" was close behind at 9 p.m. with 16.5 million viewers, while "The Good Wife," at 10, delivered 11.6 million to win its time slot ahead of its network competitors. ABC and NBC finished in a virtual tie for second place over all, with ABC broadcasting a two-hour special, "Best in Film: The Greatest Movies of Our Time" (7.1 million). Fox ranked fourth with mostly repeats.

In the age of YouTube, Pandora and Spotify, fans can watch millions of videos or listen to endless hours of music for free. But do those services make significant money for artists and record companies? Those questions became all the more interesting last week with "Friday," a song by Rebecca Black, a 13-year-old amateur from California whose YouTube video became a viral sensation. With heavily Auto-Tuned vocals and lines like "Tomorrow is Saturday/And Sunday comes afterwards," critics abhorred it. Yet it had racked up more than 38.5 million views by Wednesday afternoon, and the single was slowly climbing iTunes's posted popularity charts.

Top Senate Democrats defended the administration's handling of the crisis in Libya on Wednesday and predicted that President Obama would win bipartisan backing for the military intervention there if it comes to a Congressional vote.

The pianist Maurizio Pollini has canceled a United States recital tour because of illness, Carnegie Hall said in a statement on Wednesday. Mr. Pollini was to have played at Carnegie on Sunday and on April 4. The pianist Jeremy Denk will perform in his place on Sunday; a substitute has yet to be named for the April 4 concert. Mr. Pollini also had stops in Princeton, N.J., and Chicago. He previously canceled appearances this month with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Boston and at Carnegie. A hall spokesman said he did not know the nature of Mr. Pollini's illness, and the pianist's New York-based manager did not immediately return a phone call. Mr. Denk will play Charles Ives's Piano Sonata No. 2 ( "Concord") and Bach's "Goldberg" Variations, which he performed just last month at Carnegie's smaller Zankel Hall.

When I do TV pundit shows, I am usually placed on the right facing the host so when I turn to speak with my more liberal partner, I end up exposing my right cheek to the camera. I never really thought about the significance of this. But in the journal Laterality: Assymetries of the Body, Brain & Cognition, Annukka Lindell and Nicola Savill point out that the face expresses emotion asymmetrically. The left cheek is more emotionally expressive whereas the right cheek is more passive.

Many moviegoers watched Elizabeth Taylor grow up on screen. She made her first film, "There's One Born Every Minute," at age 9 and became a child star after appearing in 1944's "National Velvet." Ms. Taylor grew into a more mature artist in the 1950s and at age 19 starred with Montgomery Clift in George Stevens's 1951 drama "A Place in the Sun," the second screen adaptation of Theodore Dreiser's novel. The film features Mr. Clift as a factory worker who falls for a socialite (Ms. Taylor). This party scene shows the moment, as they dance together, that their romance blossoms.

Ian Frazier doesn't need me to help him sell his book "Travels in Siberia." In fact, after reading an excerpt in The New Yorker, I thought: I get it; it's long and cold. I don't need a whole book. But there it was at the Morningside Heights library. And I was hooked, especially when he reminded me of the importance of Kamchatka in the game Risk. Frazier, like me, apparently spent many high-school hours in someone's basement in the 1970s, trying to dominate the world on the game's map. Like me, he may have wondered why no girls ever wanted to play this fascinating board game with us.

A.P.C. does not, as far as we know, stand for A Prairie (Home) Companion, but the 25-year-old brand's latest edition of quilts has us wondering. The seven styles - made from 50 collections' worth of unused tweed, wool, corduroy and printed cotton scrap fabric - are at once graphically modern and sentimentally nostalgic. "My mother made me a log cabin quilt from leftover fabric that we were given while I was working at Kenzo," says the A.P.C. founder Jean Touitou. "So, the idea came quite naturally." And while quilts are very of the moment - think Rodarte's prairie-inspired collection for fall 2011 - according to Touitou, these are pieces that are designed to last. "What's important is passing on culture, it's like blues or cooking," he says. "Perhaps it will fix some memories for people. Or simply they'll have a hell of a graceful piece of popular art where they live."

Jimmy Fallon recently demonstrated that it was possible to extricate a few unscripted words from Robert De Niro, at least within the context of a "Late Night" recreation of the game show "Password." Next, Mr. Fallon's NBC colleague Brian Williams will attempt to coax further spontaneous utterances out of Mr. De Niro, the soft-spoken screen actor and co-founder of the Tribeca Film Festival, at a one-on-one discussion that will be held as part of the festival's Tribeca Talks panel series, its organizers said on Wednesday. In addition to Mr. Williams's interview of Mr. De Niro, which will take place on April 23 at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, other announced events include a conversation between Doug Liman, the "Bourne Identity" director, and Alec Baldwin, the "30 Rock" star; a discussion between the director Martin Scorsese and the Malian filmmaker Souleymane Cissé; and a 10th-anniversary screening of "A Beautiful Mind" that will be followed by a conversation with that film's director, Ron Howard, producer Brian Grazer, and the screenwriter, Akiva Goldsman. The film's math consultant, Dave Bayer, Sylvia Nasar, the author of the book "A Beautiful Mind," and Brian Greene, the theoretical physicist and mathematician will also participate. The Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 20 to May 1, and more information about its screenings and events can be found at tribecafilm.com.

There's a pro football team in Washington whose name rhymes - sort of - with "wineskins." It's probably best to refer to it this way for now, because the team recently cracked down and made The Washington Post drop the real name from the title of one of its blogs. The rationale seems to be that some other entity, in this case the paper, might be making some unauthorized money by appropriating a brand that belongs to someone else, in this case the team's owner, Daniel Snyder. No doubt he has the right to do so, but does that mean he's right to do so? Is it a smart business decision? You'd think that such vigorous policing of a brand's use in a case like this would threaten to make the brand less appealing to the fans who make that brand valuable in the first place. Apparently not. Snyder has a history of antagonisms - start here, then check out his current lawsuit against The Washington City Paper - and still his is the fourth-most valuable sports team in the world.

Elizabeth Taylor, who died of congestive heart failure today at 79, was synonymous with jewelry and fragrance. (She famously owned the Cartier and Krupp diamonds, and made a fortune from her various lifestyle perfume concerns.) But Elizabeth Taylor Hilton Wilding Todd Fisher Burton Burton Warner Fortensky was also the embodiment of modern celebrity glamour. Whether being snapped by the ever-present paparazzi or lighting up the screen in her turban-wearing turn as the divinely decadent Sissy Goforth in "Boom!", she more than looked the part. A lot has been written about the exotic allure she exuded as Cleopatra in 1963, but we have a soft spot for the carnal outfits she wore in her Oscar-winning performance as the call girl Gloria Wandrous in "Butterfield 8," pictured. What was your favorite Liz Taylor look? Leave your suggestions in the comments below.

Just a thought on market movements: you often see news stories confidently asserting that factor X was responsible for any given market movement. Serious observers rightly make fun of such stories; after all, how do they know? And it goes beyond funny to downright harmful when the stories assert supposed facts that actually serve some policy agenda. Lately we've seen that with regard to interest rates: again and again, upticks in US interest rates are asserted to be the result of debt fears, as evidence that the bond vigilantes have arrived.

Maharam Digital Projects - the mural-scaled wallpaper collection from the forward-thinking textile company Maharam - includes work by designers like Marian Bantjes, and artists like James Welling and Marilyn Minter. The fashion icon Paul Smith, who has designed fabrics for Maharam, has also contributed wallpapers. These have tended toward the abstract, but Smith's latest, Stamp World Map, is a richly detailed collage of letters and stamps from what he calls his "amazing mailbag," adding that "I love the emphasis and character you can put into handwriting." People around the world write to Smith, and he answers them all, although he has no idea how to reply to the anonymous American whose fan mail includes actual objects - like a surfboard or a bright pink plastic mannequin - that arrive at Smith's London studio unboxed and covered with stamps. With the correct postage, of course. Available at Moroso, 146 Greene Street.

I have some odd interests. Two are the Sun Ra Arkestra (the legendary jazz commune/band) and East Germany (the former country). I was reminded that these two interests once intersected by the Ra blog Adventure-Equation last weekend. In trying to sort out the band's (often label-less) records and tapes that were sold at its shows, the blog mentioned a 1986 performance that was "also broadcast, unedited, on East German TV in 1988, as two 45-minute shows." That merry band of space pranksters? Broadcast to the East Germans before the Berlin Wall opened? Hilarious! AHERN--Patrick V.,Bishop: Born in New York City, on March 8, 1919 to the late Patrick and Margaret (nee Flood). He was predeceased by his brother, Daniel. Patrick was ordained to the Priesthood in the Diocese of New York on January 29, 1945, and ordained an Auxiliary Bishop on March 19, 1970. Bishop Ahern was a former Episcopal Vicar of the Bronx, Staten Island, and Vicar for Development for the Archdiocese of New York. He was instrumental in the creation of the Seton Foundation for Learning, in Staten Island, NY. Bishop Ahern was also influential in Pope John Paul II's Declaration of the Doctorate of Saint Therese of Lisieux in 1997. Reposing Wednesday, from 2-7pm at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave. A Mass of The Holy Eucharist will follow at Mary Manning Walsh Chapel on Wednesday at 7:30pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Thursday at 11am, at The Cathedral of Saint Patrick, 5th Avenue at 51st Street. Interment to follow at the Cemetery of the Gate of Heaven, Valhalla, NY. A Memorial Mass will take place on Tuesday, March 29, at 6pm at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Seton Foundation for Learning, 315 Arlene Street, Staten Island, N.Y. 10314. For further information, please contact Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, (212) 288-3500.

For much of her life, Rita Margules knew practically nothing about how her mother, Clara Lemlich Shavelson, had changed the world a century ago. ''It never came up,'' Ms. Margules said. ''My mother was not one to say, 'Oh, you know what I did as a young girl?' '' This week, as the centennial of the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire is commemorated, Clara Lemlich is being recognized as a leading voice of working women in the early 20th century, a clarion force braided into the history of change that came before and after the fire. A new award, named for her, was given on Monday to 30 women activists, many in their 80s and 90s. Some Lemlich descendants plan to gather Friday evening, the anniversary of the fire, in the Great Hall at Cooper Union.

LIBYA Allied fighters struck targets in Tripoli on a fourth day of airstrikes, but forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi showed no signs of ending their sieges of cities held by rebels. Attacks by pro-Qaddafi forces were particularly intense in the western cities of Zintan and Misurata, where snipers and artillery killed 40 people, a rebel spokesman said. YEMEN President Ali Abdullah Saleh clung to power despite continuing antigovernment demonstrations. There were also signs of fragmentation among the nation's main military units. EGYPT After thousands of police officers demanding higher wages and the resignation of a new interior minister protested in Cairo, the upper floors of a building in the Interior Ministry compound became engulfed in flames. At least eight people were injured, security officials said, and 12 protesters were arrested on suspicion of arson.

PRITCHETT--James Turner. Passed quietly at home in New York on March 15 at the age of 88. Mr. Pritchett was born in Lenoir, NC where he briefly practiced law before beginning a long and rich life in the theatre. Notably, Mr. Pritchett portrayed Dr. Matt Powers on the daytime serial "The Doctors" from 1963-1982, for which he won a Best Actor Emmy in 1978. On Broadway, he starred in "Two For the Seesaw" in 1959 and appeared "Sail Away" in 1961-62. He appeared in national tours of "Auntie Mame" with Sylvia Sydney in 1958 and "Other Peoples Money" with Tony LoBianco in 1991. He began his television career on the daytime serial "The Secret Storm" and then "As The World Turns" before his 19 year run on "The Doctors." He also worked extensively in regional theatre throughout his life, and appeared in numerous television commercials and film. Mr. Pritchett served in World War II where he earned a degree in meteorology. He met his wife Cynthia as they starred together in a production of "Guys and Dolls" in her home state of Michigan. He was a devoted family man, sharing with his family his zeal for travel, and love of nature and sports. He will be remembered by many for his playful nature and sharp wit. He will be deeply missed by his loving family, wife Cynthia, daughter Laura, son-in-law Priest Dimitri, daughter Shelley, son Kyle, daughter-in-law Claudia, and grandchildren Yevgraf, Vassily and Theodora. Mr. Pritchett will be laid to rest in a private service in upstate New York where he and his family enjoyed many happy years.

It's not as transformative as something Norman Osborn might try, but add DNA testing to the measures being taken to speed the recovery of Christopher Tierney, the actor who was hurt when he fell during a December performance of ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.'' Mr. Tierney wants to return to doing aerial stunts in the show and as part of his recovery the show's trainer, Edythe Heus, has arranged for the testing. The test can highlight traits like a tendency to low levels of certain vitamins and Ms. Heus, who has worked with Olympic athletes and Hollywood stuntmen, said it will help her fine-tune Mr. Tierney's diet.

NEW YORK An article on Saturday about Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo's relationship with Catholicism gave the incorrect context for a quotation by Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan. When the archbishop said, ''It was a bit of a tempest in a teapot,'' he was referring to news media coverage of a scheduling conflict involving a meeting between Mr. Cuomo and a group of bishops. He was not referring to the issue of whether Mr. Cuomo, who is divorced and living with his girlfriend, should be allowed to receive holy communion. (The archbishop has said that that issue is a private pastoral matter, and not an appropriate subject to address in the news media.)

In his book ''The Biographical Dictionary of Film,'' David Thomson explained what knocked him out about James Agee's film criticism during the 1940s. Agee wrote, Mr. Thompson said, ''like someone who had not just viewed the movie but been in it -- out with it, as if it were a girl; drinking with it; driving in the night with it.'' That's not a bad description, as it happens, of what's so winning about Geoff Dyer's skinny and genre-blurring books. Mr. Dyer doesn't exactly drive in the night with his subjects, but he tests them in other ways. It's as if he'd been out at a rave with them, dancing ecstatically, ingesting some mildly illegal drugs with them, no thought of sleeping. When Mr. Dyer stares at something, that thing -- on the page, anyway -- begins to glow.

Penguins forward Matt Cooke expressed contrition Tuesday for the elbow he threw at Rangers defenseman Ryan McDonagh during a game on Sunday afternoon in Pittsburgh. ''I realize and understand more so now than ever that I need to change,'' Cooke said. ''I'm fortunate that Ryan McDonagh wasn't hurt. I don't want to hurt anybody. That's not my intention. I know that I can be better.'' Cooke said that at an N.H.L. disciplinary hearing Monday in Toronto, he did not try to defend his actions, which resulted in his suspension for the rest of the regular season and the first round of the playoffs. ''In the past, I've been very defensive and have argued my point,'' Cooke said, but he acknowledged this time that he had made a mistake.

The Our Towns column on Thursday, about the Indian Point nuclear power station, referred imprecisely to the distance between the plant and New York City. The plant is about 25 miles -- not 35 miles -- from New York City, with the nearest point being the Bronx. (It is Midtown Manhattan that is about 35 miles from the plant.)

SCIENCE TIMES An article on Tuesday about the challenges of accurately estimating seismic hazards described incorrectly the Java trench in the Indian Ocean, where few earthquakes occur. The ocean plate there is relatively old, not young, and therefore, as the article noted, is less likely to produce a great quake, according to a theory held by some scientists.

CRICHTON-BRIGHAM--Zula passed peacefully on March 2, 2011, in Connecticut. Born in Colorado, she graduated from Northwestern University in Chicago with a degree in Music in 1940. Her love of music infused every aspect of her rich, long life. Later that year she married her childhood sweetheart, John Henderson Crichton, an advertising man. Mr. Crichton, then President of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, died in 1977. A gifted pianist, she tirelessly advocated for creative arts education in public schools and the improvement of libraries. She served as a Trustee of the Bryant Library in Roslyn, Long Island, and a Board member of the New Canaan Library; appropriate for a lifelong bibliophile. In her sixties she became an enthusiastic volunteer teacher of English as a second language and worked to reduce adult illiteracy. She was always dashing off to a lecture or a study group. A resident of New Canaan, Connecticut for more than fifty years, she served as an Elder of the First Presbyterian Church. She and Georges Brigham, a technical consultant and the founder and chairman of the APL Group, were joyously married there on December 6, 1997. She is survived by her sister, Mrs. Jean Sayre; her husband, Georges Brigham; three children, Kimberly, Douglas and Catherine Crichton; five grandchildren and two great-grandsons. Her eldest son, the author Michael Crichton, died in 2008. Her birthday this year, April 24, 2011, is Easter Sunday. Peace. A Memorial Service will be held for Zula Crichton-Brigham on Saturday, March 26, at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, at 2:00pm, followed by a reception at Bliss House. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to UNICEF, at US Fund for UNICEF, 125 Maiden Lane, 11th Flr., New York, NY 10038.

SCHNEIDER--Eleanor F.,nee Kokol. Ellie, beloved wife of Melvin for 60 years, passed away on March 20, 2011. BLAU--Ronald M.,of Boca Raton, Florida passed away in his home on 21 March 2011, taken by cancer at age 75. Mr. Blau is survived by his children Steven, Carol, and Helene. Raised in Rockville Centre, New York, Mr. Blau attended Southside High School. From there he went to Cornell University, eventually earning a Doctor of Law degree. The integrity and class with which he lived his life were always in evidence in his business dealings at Gompers and Blau, the accounting firm he took over from his father and company co-founder Maurice. Aside from his family, Mr. Blau's first love was contract bridge. In 1968, he and his partner won the then-largest-ever pairs tournament and nine years later he represented the US at Israel's Maccabiah Games. In later years, he and his wife Honey turned to philanthropy; they have endowed a need-based scholarship at Cornell and have generously supported Boca Raton's medical and art institutions.

An Australian play about four people from a small town trying to build new lives after a violent crime has won the 2011 Yale Drama Series award for an emerging playwright. John Guare, the acclaimed stage writer (''The House of Blue Leaves,'' ''Six Degrees of Separation'') and judge for the series, announced on Tuesday that Shannon Murdoch had won for ''New Light Shine.'' Ms. Murdoch, who is a legal assistant and writer living near Melbourne, will receive $10,000 from the David Charles Horn Foundation, and there will be a staged reading of the play at the Yale Repertory Theater on Sept. 12. Yale University Press will also publish the play. The runners-up in the annual international competition were Laura Marks for ''Bethany'' and Mary Elizabeth Hamilton for ''We Three.'' This is the fifth time the prize has been awarded. Probably the best-known winner is Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig, whose ''Lidless'' has been staged in Philadelphia; Edinburgh; Austin, Tex.; and at the Contemporary American Theater Festival in West Virginia.

FRONT PAGE Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the joint American-European military attacks on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's forces in Libya referred incorrectly to Amr Moussa, a prominent Egyptian statesman-politician whose support for the international agreement that laid the groundwork for the attacks was considered crucial. Mr. Moussa is the current top official of the Arab League, not the former top official. Also because of an editing error, the article misstated his official title. It is secretary general, not chairman.

James Gandolfini may be a man of few words, but when he returns to the cable channel that made him, it's worth devoting a few words to. HBO said on Tuesday that Mr. Gandolfini was planning to star in a new made-for-cable film that would return him to the network that gave us ''The Sopranos,'' as well as the state that gave us the Bada Bing! club. The film will be adapted from ''Eating With the Enemy: How I Waged Peace With North Korea From My BBQ Shack in Hackensack,'' a nonfiction book by Robert Egan and Kurt Pitzer, in which Mr. Egan recounts how he used his barbecue restaurant to build friendships with diplomats from Vietnam and North Korea, and became an unlikely liaison between North Korea and the United States. Mr. Gandolfini, who has also produced the HBO documentaries ''Alive Day: Home from Iraq'' and ''Wartorn: 1861-2010,'' is attached as a star and would also be an executive producer of the new film, which will be produced by his Attaboy Productions company and Tribeca Productions, though neither a start date for production nor a broadcast date on HBO have been announced. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
