After several months out of the spotlight, Chris Brown has the nation's attention again, though surely not for the reason he intended. On Tuesday, the first day of release for his new album, ''F.A.M.E.,'' Mr. Brown reportedly left behind a dressing room strewn with broken glass at ABC's ''Good Morning America'' after giving an uncomfortable interview to the ''G.M.A.'' co-anchor Robin Roberts. In the interview, Ms. Roberts asked Mr. Brown about a 2009 incident involving his ex-companion, the pop singer Rihanna, after which Mr. Brown pleaded guilty to a charge of felonious assault and was sentenced to five years of probation and six months of community labor. After Mr. Brown said that a restraining order against him had recently been relaxed, Ms. Roberts asked if he and Rihanna still saw each other; Mr. Brown replied, ''I mean, not really,'' and he avoided follow-up questions. Mr. Brown then performed a song from his new album and returned to his dressing room, where the ''G.M.A.'' morning staff members said they heard loud noises that prompted a call to security, according to a report on the ABC News Web site. It was later found that a window in the dressing room had been broken, leaving glass in the room and on the street outside ABC's studio in Times Square, and that Mr. Brown and his representatives had left the building. ABC declined to comment on the incident, beyond a statement from ABC News that said, ''As always, we ask questions that are relevant and newsworthy, and that's what we did in this interview with Mr. Brown.'' A telephone call to Jive Records, which released ''F.A.M.E.,'' went unanswered on Tuesday afternoon.

There will be plenty of new blood and young performers on stage this summer at the Newport Jazz Festival, whose 2011 schedule was announced on Tuesday. The bassist and singer Esperanza Spalding, who last month won the Grammy for best new artist, will perform on two of the festival's three days of shows, which begin on Friday, Aug. 5, in Newport, R.I., where the festival was first held in 1954. Besides Ms. Spalding, 26, the festival will feature the saxophonist Rudresh Mahanthappa, who has been voted ''a rising star'' by Downbeat magazine in recent years, in a duo with the veteran horn player Bunky Green. Also performing will be the trumpet player Ambrose Akinmusire, 28, whose career got off to a flying start in 2007, when he won the Thelonious Monk International Jazz Competition.

The financier Sanford I. Weill and his wife, Joan, have given a $12 million gift to Sonoma State University - the largest cash gift in the university's history - for the completion of a concert hall at the Green Music Center, the university announced on Tuesday. The opening is scheduled for fall 2012. ''I think it's going to be an incredible destination,'' Mr. Weill said in a telephone interview. The Weills learned about the project shortly after buying a home in Sonoma's wine country, and Mr. Weill asked to visit the center, which he said had been in the works for 12 years at a cost of $100 million. ''I saw this hall and what they were doing,'' Mr. Weill said. ''I thought it was absolutely beautiful and to my ear the sound sounded terrific.''

LAMBERT--Louisa Garnsey, of Pennington, NJ, and Grand Lake, CO, died at home in Pennington on Saturday, March 19, at the age of 71. She was the daughter of the late Louisa Herrick Garnsey and the late Colorado State Senator William S. Garnsey III, and step-daughter of former Colorado State Senator Roseanne Ball Garnsey. She was born in Denver and grew up in Greeley, CO. She graduated from the Master's School in Dobbs Ferry, NY, Bennett Jr. College in Millbrook, NY, and the University of Colorado at Boulder. A dedicated gardener, Weezie was a member and past president of the Garden Club of Princeton and obtained her N.J. Master of Gardening degree. A member of the Women's Fly Fisher Club, she was an enthusiastic angler who fished many streams and lakes in the American West, Quebec, Alaska, and Russia, as well as the Beaverkill and Neversink rivers and other eastern streams. Weezie was also president of the Parents Association at Princeton Day School, and as such an ex-officio member of the Board of Trustees. She was also a member of the Balsam Lake Club in New York, the Grand Lake (CO) Yacht Club, and the Bedens Brook Club. Weezie was a devoted alumna of the Master's School, serving on the Board of Trustees for thirteen years, and was named a Trustee Emerita. She also served on the board of the Losam Fund, a private foundation that she began with her former husband, Samuel W. Lambert III. Weezie is survived by her three children, Louisa Kelly Lambert Walker of Marion, MA, Samuel William Lambert of Bath, ME, and Sarah Hamill Lambert Dolan of Studio City, CA, their spouses, and nine grandchildren. A memorial service has been scheduled for Saturday, March 26, at 3:00pm at Trinity Episcopal Church, Princeton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Master's School, 49 Clinton Ave., Dobbs Ferry, NY 10522-2201 or to the Stony Brook Millstone Watershed Association, 31 Titus Mill Road, Pennington, NJ 08534.

On the night before William Howard Russell left London for New York, he dined at the Garrick Club with William Makepeace Thackeray. Charles Dickens, Anthony Trollope and many other leading lights of English culture and society also belonged to the private establishment. Although admitted to the Bar, it was as a correspondent for The Times of London that Russell established his reputation. His fame came from his dogged coverage of the Crimean War and, at its conclusion in 1856, he returned a hero. His dispatches brought the war home to readers. He wrote with clarity and vitality about the grandeur and the horror of battle. He followed that with an equally vivid account of the Sepoy Rebellion in India. People called him a "war correspondent," perhaps the first, but he rejected the label and departed on March 3 for the brewing conflict in America as "special correspondent" for The Times.

As March Madness begins another four-day run tonight, I suspect that I will once again find Dan Shanoff's Quickish.com to be - well, not exactly an essential resource, but a delightfully inessential one. Quickish compiles the best insights - from ESPN.com, from SI.com, from Yahoo Sports, sometimes even from the Twitter feeds of certain denizens of The New York Times Magazine - into a real-time feed of instant tournament analysis. "American Idol" remained dominant in the ratings on Wednesday as 23.5 million viewers tuned in for two hours of performances from the remaining competitors on the Fox reality show, according to Nielsen's estimates. CBS ranked a distant runner-up for the night, earning decent results opposite "Idol" with "Survivor: Redemption Island" at 8 (10.8 million) and a rerun of "Criminal Minds" at 9 (8.7 million). CBS's "Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior" led the 10 p.m. time slot with 8.9 million viewers, edging past NBC's "Law & Order: SVU" (8.7 million) and easily beating ABC's "Off the Map" (4.5 million) in the hour. ABC and its comedy line-up finished in third place over all, benefiting largely from solid ratings for "Modern Family" at 9 (10.8 million). NBC was fourth with "Minute to Win It" at 8 (4.2 million) and a repeat of "Law & Order: SVU" at 9 (4 million).

"Color Me Obsessed" is just about the perfect title for a new documentary about the Replacements. The movie's tag line is also promising: "The potentially true story of the last best band." And yet I was a little surprised to learn that the Replacements themselves are not really in the film. Instead, the movie is a parade of 40-something (and older) ex-rockers and critics reminiscing ecstatically about the glory days. (Those would be the years 1981 to 1987.) A colleague (and huge 'Mats fan) objected, "If I want to hear a bunch of guys talk about how great the Replacements were, I'll go hang out in a record store!" He paused as the realization sunk in: there are no more record stores. "Color Me Obsessed" will have to do.

Overview | Why have journalists throughout history risked death to bring us living history? What stories are worth risking one's life for? In this lesson, students perform monologues excerpted from first-person accounts by New York Times journalists who have experienced perilous situations in their pursuit of news. They then analyze photographs taken by photojournalists covering war and other dangers, and discuss why some journalists risk danger and whether the value of what they report is worth that risk.

The Wall Street Journal on Thursday offered a look inside the fund-raising efforts of Mitt Romney, reporting that the former governor of Massachusetts is expected to meet as many as 100 wealthy donors in New York City as he prepares a fund-raising network in advance of a presidential run. Mr. Romney, a wealthy former businessman, spent $45 million of his own fortune in his losing bid for the 2008 Republican presidential nomination. But he also proved to be a successful fund-raiser, collecting close to $60 million for that race. Mr. Romney's status as the likely front-runner in the field of potential 2012 contenders is heavily dependent on the assumption that he has the best chance of raising large sums of money, especially early on in the contest.

On Wednesday, the conservative fund-raising powerhouse Crossroads GPS started a Web site called wikicountability.org, aimed at pressuring the Obama administration to be better at releasing requests filed under the Freedom of Information Act. The committee's site,  wikipocrisy.org, presents visitors with a button to view the group's donors. What comes back are the words: "ERROR: No donors disclosed" in flashing large type.

Wednesday night's shindig (nice word mmm ) for Vanessa Traina and her Maje collaboration was relaxed and fun. I didn't need to go to the hairdresser, after all. It started on the seventh floor of Barneys, with a D.J., and the arrivals of Ashley and Mary-Kate Olsen, in a great-looking fur jacket, though I liked the look of Ashley's broad-shoulder beige coat over a long black Row dress; then the designers Alexander Wang, Joseph Altuzarra and Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler. People were talking about Elizabeth Taylor, Carine Roitfeld's appointment as a guest editor/stylist for Barneys and places they had recently been (other than fashion shows), and eyeing a Maje blazer with satin lapels, as if to say, "Should I or shouldn't I?" Ms. Traina, whose sisters Victoria and Samantha also attended, had on a blazer and skinny pants, with a cutaway Balenciaga top that draped in the front. Dinner was down the slushy street, at Caprice.

Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, made a pretty convincing Senator John McCain when he appeared as himself in "Wedding Crashers" and on "Saturday Night Live," but HBO Films has decided to go a different route in casting for its coming television-movie "Game Change." On Wednesday evening HBO said that it had chosen Ed Harris, the Academy Award-nominated star of "Apollo 13," "Pollock," "The Truman Show" and "The Hours," to play Mr. McCain in the film, which is adapted from the book of the same title by John Heilemann and Mark Halperin. The film will chronicle Mr. McCain's 2008 presidential campaign starting with his selection of Sarah Palin as his running mate. HBO previously announced that Julianne Moore (of "The Kids Are All Right") would play Ms. Palin in the film, which will be directed by Jay Roach ("Dinner for Schmucks") and written by Danny Strong. Mr. Roach and Mr. Strong previously collaborated on the HBO movie "Recount," about the backroom battles that followed the 2000 presidential election. A broadcast date for "Game Change" has not yet been announced.

For anyone looking to know more about rowing after watching the acclaimed "Henley sequence" from "The Social Network," a good place to begin is the Xchanging Boat Race on the Thames River on Saturday. First held in 1829 and an annual event since 1856 (with the exception of the two World Wars),  it pits the Oxford University Boat Club against the Cambridge University Boat Club. They compete on a four-and-a-quarter-mile course that follows the tidal stretch of the river that extends through central London to the open sea. Winners last year, Cambridge currently leads the series 80 to 75.

The center of Minamisanriku, a fishing port on Japan's northeastern coast, has disappeared. It was completely washed away by the tsunami that devastated the country on March 11. As I looked down from a hilltop while on assignment there last week, it was hard for me to imagine that a town had really existed, that people had had lives there.

Blankfein, testified on Wednesday in the insider-trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam, who before his arrest in 2009 was among the most powerful hedge fund managers on Wall Street. It was a unusual role for the Goldman chief executive, who has had audiences with presidents, foreign leaders and chieftains of the world's largest companies. But on Wednesday, he was addressing a jury of New Yorkers - including teachers, transit workers and the unemployed - all of whom said they had never heard of Mr. Blankfein during the jury selection process.

Robert Ross, a gung-ho entrepreneur who juggled global deals in things like fertilizer, pantyhose, steel and antisnoring medicine, then made his big mark by starting for-profit medical, veterinary and nursing schools in the Caribbean, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92. The cause was cancer of the urethra, his son Warren said.

If the devious Dwight Schrute doesn't have the inside scoop on the comings and goings at Dunder Mifflin, does anybody? It's now an open secret that, as EW.com reported and NBC has since confirmed, the May 19 season finale of ''The Office'' will be overstocked with special guest stars, including Ricky Gervais, a co-creator and star of the original British ''Office'' (who turned up on the U.S. series for a nanosecond in January) and Will Arnett, the ''Arrested Development'' star whose wife, Amy Poehler, lives just down the NBC block on ''Parks and Recreation.''

A new movie event is aiming to bring the real jungle to the concrete one. Starting in April 2012, the New York Wild Film Festival will present a roster of movies and filmmaker panels in four categories: adventure, environmental, wildlife documentaries and shorts. Nancy Rosenthal, a former documentarian for National Geographic who is the festival's founder and director, said the goal was to ''inspire appreciation for the planet.'' The Wild festival will be sponsored by the Open Space Institute, a New York conservancy organization. Promotional partners will include Clif Bar, World Wildlife Fund, National Geographic and Enterprise Rent-A-Car. Ms. Rosenthal plans to unveil her plans for the festival at a gala event on April 7 at Tribeca Cinemas that will include screenings, like ''The Krill is Gone,'' that are emblematic of her mission.

MANILA -- He has been chided for an easygoing work ethic and for his flashy new Porsche, but more than eight months into his presidency, Benigno S. Aquino III still carries with him a glow of hope, much of it inherited along with his family name. In a nation where pedigree is a prime political asset, Mr. Aquino's credentials are unmatched. When he recently put his signature to a new 500 peso bill, he signed beneath the twin portraits of his parents, former President Corazon C. Aquino and her husband, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., who became a national icon when he was assassinated in 1983.

Q.Facebook keeps sending me e-mail messages to notifying me of comments and photos posted to my wall, but the alerts are not coming to the e-mail account I use with Facebook. Is someone impersonating me? A.Impersonation on Facebook is a possibility. But unless you clicked a confirmation link at one point to acknowledge you set up a Facebook account linked to that e-mail address, it is more likely that you are getting fraudulent Facebook messages. (If you received no confirmation message and someone is trying to use your address to set up a Facebook account, that account will only be active for a short time because Facebook deactivates unconfirmed accounts after three days.)

For those who love nothing better than unearthing lost musical gems, ''A Tree Grows in Brooklyn'' is a dangerous temptation. This classic story of a soulful, alcoholic husband who dreams of making it big as a singer is blessed with a lovely score by Arthur Schwartz and Dorothy Fields from the golden age of Broadway. It surely has appeal also for the legions interested in the dynamic history of New York neighborhoods. Trees still grow in Williamsburg, of course, though now you are more likely to hear about the birth of boutiques with exposed brick. But the problem is that this is an awfully challenging musical to mount: a mix of peppy, melting-pot comedy and pitch-black tragedy, with a large cast. Like so many adaptations of novels, the show, which had its premiere in 1951, moves very quickly through time and plot. To make sense of this sprawling work, you need a firm hand.

When Bill Nguyen was in kindergarten, he probably got top marks for sharing. Mr. Nguyen was the lead person behind Lala, a music-sharing service that was acquired by Apple in 2009. After spending about a year at his new parent company, Mr. Nguyen left to found a new start-up, Color, which introduces its first application on Thursday.

Q.I have a collection of CDs containing vacation pictures. How can I adapt the discs to play a slide show on my TV through the attached CD/DVD player? A.If your CD/DVD player does not recognize the photo discs when you try to play them, you probably need to create a picture slide show and burn it to a DVD so it plays like a movie disc. Several companies make photo slide show software to do just that and these programs usually cost less than $50; Magix PhotoStory and Corel Digital Studio are two of the many examples.

QUINN--John Joseph, Jr. John (Jack) Joseph, Jr. passed away Tuesday, March 22, 2011, in New York City. A loving and devoted husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife of 32 years Corinne Quinn, his five children, daughters Kelli Nagel, Jeanette Honigsbaum and Susan Quinn; and sons John Quinn IV, and James Quinn; grandchildren Olivia and Max Honigsbaum of London, England; and his sister Nan Chezek of Ohio. Born in 1934 in the Bronx, NY, to his parents John and Jean Quinn. He attended Fordham Preparatory School in The Bronx, class of '52 where he ran track and set several NYC records, one of which still stands today. Graduated Fordham University, B.S. School of Business., 1956. Served his country with honor, as a Captain in US Air Force 1956-1959. 1956 joined Arthur Young & Company, New York, where he began a long and distinguished career as a CPA. He was one of the youngest members of the firm to make Partner in 1970 at the age of 36. Member of the AICPA and New York State Society of CPA's. He retired as a Partner from Ernst & Young, New York, in 1994. A loving, generous man with a big heart and great sense of humor, some of Jack's favorite moments were spent at his summer house in Long Beach Island, NJ, with his wife Corinne, his children and grandchildren. A lifelong fan of the New York Yankees and New York Football Giants. He will be remembered as a great man who was always there for his wife, children and friends. We love you and will miss you always. Friends may call Thursday and Friday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, March 26, 2011 at 10am at Our Saviour Church, Park Ave at 38 St, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Fordham University, Development and University Relations, 888 Seventh Ave, Seventh Floor, New York, NY 10019.

You have to be one serious klutz to need the Ballistic HC iPhone case. This chunky Humvee of a case encloses the iPhone in a hard shell that includes a clear screen cover, which is then wrapped in a silicon bumper, which is then inserted into a hard holster. The manufacturer said the case is tested to military specifications. That is an ambiguous claim. There are military specifications for dozens of aspects of a product, from susceptibility to solar radiation to damage from gunfire vibration, with specific test procedures for each. So a consumer product that claims to be ''Mil-Spec'' need only have passed one test-say, resistance to fungus.

In the theatrical trailer for ''Butterfield 8,'' the deep-voiced announcer declared: ''She's not like anyone. That's for sure.'' He was talking about the character Gloria Wandrous, but the same seven words could describe the actress who played Gloria, Elizabeth Taylor, who died on Wednesday at 79. After all, both were larger-than-life types whose Manhattan was stylish, and filled with not a little drama. But Gloria Wandrous's New York was not Elizabeth Taylor's New York.

FURTH--Valerie Jakober, 85, passed away at home on March 23. She is survived by her sons, Mark (Lola) and Peter (Susan) and grandchildren Michael, Edward, Shoshana, Melanie and Joshua. Valerie's indomitable spirit inspired all who knew her. She was born in Munkacs, Czechoslovakia. Deported to Auschwitz in 1944, she was liberated in April 1945. She emigrated to New York in 1948 and married her devoted Frank in 1949. They were together for 52 years. Valerie studied with Louise Nevelson and became an accomplished painter and sculptor. In the mid-1970s she began a series of paintings and sculptures from her Holocaust experiences. She then published a book, Cabbages and Geraniums, and told her story in schools and communities. Valerie and Frank were Benefactors of the Museum of Jewish Heritage. Funeral services will be held Friday, March 25 at 11:30am at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 E. 51st St. Donations can be made to Sutton Place Synagogue designated for the Valerie and Frank Furth Shoah Fund; the Museum of Jewish Heritage; or the University of Rochester designated for the Valerie and Frank Furth Fund.

I recently joined an amateur music group whose members set up a Facebook group. Two days into the project, one member panicked. ''All my friends can see everything we're talking about,'' she wrote us via e-mail. ''I don't want them to even know I'm doing this. We need to go back to e-mail.'' You don't. Facebook has a privacy setting for groups that allows you to hide not only the group's activity, but its very existence. To set it, you need to be configured as an admin for the group. By default, the only admin for a group is the Facebook member who created it.

Wednesday, March 23, 2:09 p.m. | Updated The Staten Island Museum on Wednesday broke ground on its new $25 million home in Building A, a landmark on the campus of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center. In the age of YouTube, Pandora and Spotify, fans can watch millions of videos or listen to endless hours of music for free. But do those services make significant money for artists and record companies? Those questions became all the more interesting last week with ''Friday,'' a song by Rebecca Black, a 13-year-old amateur from California whose YouTube video became a viral sensation. With heavily Auto-Tuned vocals and lines like ''Tomorrow is Saturday/And Sunday comes afterwards,'' critics abhorred it. Yet it had racked up more than 38.5 million views by Wednesday afternoon, and the single was slowly climbing iTunes's posted popularity charts. What does all of that attention mean in dollars and cents? Forbes jumped in quickly, estimating that the song had generated ''a few hundred thousand downloads'' and would earn Ms. Black millions. But music industry number-crunchers soon threw cold water on that assessment. Billboard, triangulating through the song's iTunes chart position, guessed that it had less than 40,000 downloads; adding in possible revenue from YouTube, and adjusting for royalties, it yielded a back-of-the-envelope total of about $40,000 for the week. ''The start of a great college fund,'' Billboard said, but not mega-millions. But if there is money earned, who keeps it is unclear. Ark Music Factory, the company that produced the songs -- the company specializes in ready-to-made pop songs for tweens, with parental payment made up front -- did not respond to a request for comment.

If you use an RSA SecurID keyfob or card for stricter security than a user name and password provides, you may have just become a last line of defense. RSA Security, a division of EMC Corporation, said on Thursday that it suffered a sophisticated hacker attack that resulted in the theft of sensitive information related to its popular SecurID two-factor authentication products.

Edward I. Koch is many things to many people: larger-than-life mayor, cantankerous commentator, amateur movie critic. Now he will be a bridge. The City Council voted 38 to 12 on Wednesday to rename the Queensboro Bridge after Mr. Koch, who led New York City from 1978 to 1989 and emerged as one of its most familiar faces. The city is expected to officially christen the bridge the Ed Koch Queensboro Bridge next month.

On Thursday, the mad scramble that is the opening week of the N.C.A.A. tournament makes way for a more orderly Round of 16: eight games in two nights to whittle the field to eight teams. But don't be fooled. There is plenty of opportunity for the unexpected. While spunky underdogs often face up to the reality that they are out of their depth in this round, teams with bushels of talent can ill afford to be caught looking ahead. WestThe Round of 16 is new territory for second-seeded San Diego State, but it is a trip down memory lane for Coach Steve Fisher. He led Michigan to the 1989 national championship as an interim coach and later returned to the Final Four twice with the Fab Five. Standing in the Aztecs' way in Anaheim, Calif., is No. 3 Connecticut. The Huskies have spent the past two weeks defying expectations. They won an unprecedented five games in five days to win the Big East tournament, then dismissed any thoughts that they would be tired from that feat by winning their first two games of the N.C.A.A. tournament. Their reward? They get to fly across the country to face a team that has lost twice this season.

(NBC) COMMUNITY Jeff (Joel McHale) plans a surprise birthday party for Abed (Danny Pudi), incorporating the birthday boy's love of movies and pop culture. In the nearly eight years that he has led the Nasdaq OMX Group, Robert Greifeld has made his name as a deal maker, cleaning house at the market operator and expanding its size. That reputation faces its biggest challenge yet as analysts and investors await his response to the rapid-fire consolidation of exchanges, one that analysts say could leave his company weakened and alone.

''All Chestnut Trees Here Are Doomed'' read the headline in The New York Times. The year was 1911, ''here'' was greater New York, and the great chestnut blight, which was first discovered in the Bronx Zoo in 1904, was well on its way to wiping out four billion of the trees that once made up a quarter of the Northeast's hardwoods.

NATIONAL An article on March 15 about three prominent Mormon politicians -- Senator Orrin G. Hatch and former Govs. Mitt Romney and Jon M. Huntsman Jr. -- who are facing varying degrees of revolt in Utah from Mormon Tea Party members misstated the position of one Tea Party leader, David Kirkham. While Mr. Kirkham noted that many Tea Party members oppose all three politicians, he did not say that was his personal position. (He said he was undecided about whether to support Mr. Hatch's re-election bid next year.)

TAYLOR--Elizabeth. amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research, mourns the loss of its Founding International Chairman and cherished friend, Dame Elizabeth Taylor. As one of the earliest and most passionate advocates for people living with HIV/AIDS, Dame Elizabeth drew worldwide attention to the epidemic and helped raise millions of dollars for AIDS research. Spurred by anger at official inaction, undeterred by the stigma attached to AIDS, and above all motivated by her boundless compassion for those who were suffering, she did more in the early years of the epidemic than any other prominent figure to change the world's view of AIDS and those affected by it. Much of Dame Elizabeth's early work with amfAR involved speaking out about the realities of HIV/AIDS and lobbying aggressively for increased federal funds for research, education, treatment, and care. "I will not be silenced and I will not give up and I will not be ignored," she once declared, and her determination brought hope to millions. Whether she was visiting patients in the hospital, headlining an amfAR benefit, or addressing the United Nations on the need for worldwide action, Dame Elizabeth always impressed those around her with her grace, dignity, and intelligence. For more than two decades she remained an active and visible leader in the fight against AIDS, chairing many of amfAR's successful Cinema Against AIDS benefits. While we grieve her passing, the board of trustees and staff of amfAR will remember and honor Elizabeth Taylor for inspiring us to continue working for an end to this devastating epidemic. We extend our deepest sympathy to Dame Elizabeth's family. Kenneth Cole, Chairman of the Board Mathilde Krim, Ph.D., Founding Chairman Kevin Robert Frost, CEO amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research

A memorial to the youngest victim of the shooting rampage in Tucson, a 9-year-old girl who was born on 9/11, will include a five-foot length of steel from the World Trade Center.A statue of an angel, which will incorporate the steel, will memorialize the girl, Christina-Taylor Green. It is to be erected in the outfield of her Little League softball field in a Tucson suburb.Workers at Kennedy Airport's Hangar 17, where the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey stores debris from 9/11, removed a 272-pound beam on Wednesday; it is to be trucked to Arizona. Similar pieces have been sent to cities and towns and other countries for use in memorials. Christina-Taylor's connection to Sept. 11, 2001, followed her death in the rampage on Jan. 8, in which 5 other people were killed and 13 were wounded, including Representative Gabrielle Giffords. The National 9/11 Flag, which was salvaged from ground zero and has traveled the country for years, was flown at her funeral, a gesture that inspired the statue.

FOREIGN A news analysis article on Friday about relations between the United States and Saudi Arabia misstated Saudi Arabia's current ranking among top oil suppliers to the United States. It is the third, not the second, largest foreign supplier. (Canada is first, and Mexico second.)

A report in the National Briefing column on Wednesday about an Interior Department report that faulted a National Park Service scientist's use of photographs to help make her case that an oyster farm at Point Reyes National Seashore was harming harbor seals referred incorrectly to the report's references to the scientist and one of her superiors involved in the controversy. Their identities had been obtained independently by The New York Times and other news organizations; the report did not identify them by name.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia -- Like a vast majority of Muslims in Malaysia, Mohammad Shah was raised according to the Sunni school of Islam. But when he was about 30, he said, he came to believe that Sunni teachings did not answer all of his questions about Islam. He began reading about the Shiite school of thought, the world's second-largest Islamic branch, and decided that ''Sunni was not right for me.'' ''I consider myself the new generation of Malaysian Shia,'' said Mr. Mohammad, 33. ''My father is Sunni, my mother is Sunni. They are aware that I'm practicing a different school of thought. It's no problem at all.''

NEW YORK An article on Monday about the 200th anniversary of the Manhattan street grid misspelled the surname of one of the street commissioners who certified the plan. He is John Rutherfurd, not Rutherford.

Jimmy Fallon recently demonstrated that it was possible to extricate a few unscripted words from Robert De Niro, at least within the context of a ''Late Night'' recreation of the game show ''Password.'' Next, Mr. Fallon's NBC colleague Brian Williams will attempt to coax further spontaneous utterances out of Mr. De Niro, the soft-spoken screen actor and co-founder of the Tribeca Film Festival, at a one-on-one discussion that will be held as part of the festival's Tribeca Talks panel series, its organizers said on Wednesday. In addition to Mr. Williams's interview of Mr. De Niro, which will take place on April 23 at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, other announced events include a conversation between Doug Liman, the ''Bourne Identity'' director, and Alec Baldwin, the ''30 Rock'' star; a discussion between the director Martin Scorsese and the Malian filmmaker Souleymane Cisse; and a 10th-anniversary screening of ''A Beautiful Mind'' that will be followed by a conversation with that film's director, Ron Howard, producer Brian Grazer, and the screenwriter, Akiva Goldsman. The film's math consultant, Dave Bayer, Sylvia Nasar, the author of the book ''A Beautiful Mind,'' and Brian Greene, the theoretical physicist and mathematician will also participate. The Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 20 to May 1, and more information about its screenings and events can be found at tribecafilm.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

KAYLIE--Tess. Our hearts go out to our good friend Harvey Kaylie, his dear wife Gloria and his family on the passing of his beloved mother Tess. We cherish his friendship, his guidance and his service on the City College 21st Century Foundation Board, and we treasure the Mini-Circuits Scholarship Program and the Kaylie Prize for Entrepreneurship, which will enable Grove School of Engineering students to follow in Harvey's illustrious footsteps forever. Lisa Staiano-Coico, President The City College of New York

LIBYA Having all but destroyed the Libyan Air Force and air defenses, the allies turned their firepower on the military units loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi that are besieging rebel-held cities. Loyalist forces have surrounded two rebel-held cities in the west, Zintan and Misurata, and the eastern city of Ajdabiya. SYRIA Syrian security forces continued their crackdown on protests in the southern city of Dara'a, with reports that they had fired on demonstrators after the funeral of a prominent doctor, Ali al-Mahameed. Witnesses said he had been shot while tending to the injured during shootings earlier in the day. The death toll was unclear, with reports ranging from 6 to 15. The official SANA news agency reported that a ''gang'' had killed a doctor, a medical worker and a driver in an ambulance and that ''security forces faced down those aggressors.''

The pianist Maurizio Pollini has canceled a United States recital tour because of illness, Carnegie Hall said in a statement on Wednesday. Mr. Pollini was to have played at Carnegie on Sunday and on April 4. The pianist Jeremy Denk will perform in his place on Sunday; a substitute has yet to be named for the April 4 concert. Mr. Pollini also had stops in Princeton, N.J., and Chicago. He previously canceled appearances this month with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Boston and at Carnegie. A hall spokesman said he did not know the nature of Mr. Pollini's illness, and the pianist's New York-based manager did not immediately return a phone call. Mr. Denk will play Charles Ives's Piano Sonata No. 2 ( ''Concord'') and Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations, which he performed just last month at Carnegie's smaller Zankel Hall. The Sultanate of Oman occupies the corner of the Arabian Peninsula nearest India, and lies between Dubai and Yemen. In broad strokes, this is a fair social description as well as geographical. The ancient city of Muscat is picturesquely nestled among a craggy collection of low mountains that run right into the sea. The bare rocky massifs yield occasionally to sandy beaches and the deep natural harbors that have made the city a hub of Indian Ocean trade for thousands of years.

ABC placed second for the night, earning its best ratings at 9 for "Grey's Anatomy" (10.1 million). The latest Spring Travel issue of T magazine heads to Haiti with the actor Sean Penn, who spent most of the last year in the country coordinating a remarkably effective relief effort. Zoë Heller's profile helps us see the beauty beneath the devastation and the generosity behind the usually guarded star. The writer Wells Tower also takes a timely journey, this one through Humboldt County, the cannabis-growing hub of California (much in the news recently) with a lovably cantankerous local culture and an impossibly gorgeous landscape. Nature is also the lure in Newfoundland, Canada, which, as Mark Schatzker learns, is perhaps the best place to catch and eat a wild Atlantic salmon, a fish most of us have only eaten farmed. Elsewhere in the issue are more cerebral pleasures, as in Trieste, a legendary Italian redoubt for thinkers and flâneurs, and Beirut, Lebanon, where Joumana Haddad is creating a stir with her erotic writing - as well as plenty of sybaritic pursuits: a luxurious new boot-camp spa in Laguna, Calif.; a revived, post-recession London filled with new restaurants, shops and bars; and a lively music scene revolves around the beer halls and nightclubs of Hamburg, Germany, a playground forever enshrined by the Beatles.

None of us is looking to sustain a serious head injury, but Janelle Jones and some colleagues conducted a survey of 630 people who had sustained serious injuries with the help of Headway UK. She found that survivors of serious head injuries are much more satisfied with their lives than others. They seem to regard themselves as survivors. They tell stories about their lives that emphasize resilience and bouncing back. What's more, they relied on strong social support networks to get through their injuries. The write up of the study in Psychology and Health carries the apt title: "That Which Doesn't Kill Us Can Make Us Stronger."

Add another entry to the growing publishing genre of Twitter lit. Scribner has acquired the rights to publish a book based on the profanity-laced Twitter feed written by a fake Rahm Emanuel, later revealed to be Dan Sinker. Mr. Sinker, the founding editor of the culture magazine "Punk Planet" and an assistant professor at Columbia College in Chicago, was anonymously behind the much-followed Twitter feed until he revealed his identity in The Atlantic last month. The book will "compile the tweets, annotate them and include Sinker's first-person account of the phenomenon that has attracted legions of followers and media attention," his publisher said in a statement on Friday. Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, plans to release the book - with a foreword by Biz Stone, a founder of Twitter - later this year.

There are many different explanations for the global obesity epidemic, but here's one I hadn't come across. Petra Jansen and others studied obese children for a forthcoming issue of Appetite and found that these children performed poorly on what is called chronometric mental rotation test, which measures spatial ability. Maybe some people are less astute at judging portion sizes or even their own body mass.

The sights of Humboldt County, Calif., can be hard for the rational mind to reconcile. Its hysterical shifts in landscape and weather conspire to make you feel, in the most pleasurable way possible, that you are going out of your head. A day's drive in Humboldt carried me past what appeared to be: a Hawaiian beach, an Icelandic coastal flat, a swath of rustic Switzerland, an elk-thronged Montana prairie, a street in San Francisco, the Ewok moon of Endor, a prop village from a musical about the Gold Rush, and Allentown, Pa. The dawn brought blue skies, which turned to brilliant sunlit rain, then hail, then sleet, then driving snow, then back to full sun refracting into a huge rainbow that seemed like the meteorological equivalent of a crazy person's laugh.

Six letters by Frédéric Chopin went on display this week at the Chopin museum in Warsaw after having been lost from view since the early years of World War II. The missives date from 1845 to 1848, a year before Chopin's death, and were written from Paris and Nohant in central France -- the childhood home of George Sand, Chopin's lover - to the composer's family in Warsaw. It was a time of considerable turmoil in the Chopin-Sand domestic arrangement. The letters were in the hands of Laura Ciechomska, a grandniece of Chopin, until at least 1939, a museum curator, Alicja Knast, said, according to The Associated Press. They resurfaced in 2003, and the museum later acquired them, The Associated Press said.

Today is the 100th anniversary of the Triangle Waist Company factory fire, a tragedy in Lower Manhattan that claimed the lives of 146 people, all but 23 of whom were young women. One of the landmark disasters in American history, it eventually inspired important shifts in the nation's laws, particularly those protecting the rights of workers and the safety of buildings.

One morning, about a century ago, the poet Rainer Maria Rilke was visiting his friend, Princess Marie von Thurn und Taxis-Hohenlohe, in her seaside castle at Duino, just west of Trieste. He was 36, broke, blocked, disconsolate and sickly, a saturnine man contemplating his fears and failures. Perhaps the princess had business elsewhere; perhaps she understood a poet's need for solitude; perhaps he was merely bad company. In any case, she left the castle, while Rilke remained, watched over by a staff who must have found him odd, at best. It was January, and Trieste's furious Bora wind was blowing; nevertheless, he liked to walk along the cliffs overlooking the Adriatic. On one such occasion, he was brooding about money, as writers will, when his thoughts were interrupted by a voice emerging from the gale: "Who, if I cried, would hear me among the Dominions of Angels?"

The Times's Bucks blog is hosting a timely discussion on the merits of taking on student loan debt for a four-year college versus paying the relatively inexpensive tuition of community college, perhaps with an eye on transferring later. As its jumping-off point, the blog post uses an article about "an 18-year-old high school senior with a choice to make. Should he go into at least $6,500 in debt each year to attend a private college or university like Juniata or Clark, or is he better off working part time and attending community college for two years before transferring to one of those colleges?"

Reunited and it feels so good: four members of the vintage-1990s rock band Hole, which never got along as smoothly as any Peaches & Herb song, are planning to reconvene on Monday at the New Directors/New Films series to see a documentary about the former Hole drummer Patty Schemel, the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center said. A screening at MoMA of "Hit So Hard," directed by P. David Ebersole, is set to be visited by its subject, Ms. Schemel, as well as the guitarist Eric Erlandson and the bassist Melissa Auf der Maur, not to mention a certain idiosyncratic front woman and fashion plate named Courtney Love. If we sound a little surprised by the gathering (which the film series organizers say is the first time these four musicians have been together at a public event in 13 years), consider such past events in the history of Hole as: Ms. Schemel's departure from the group in 1998 and the band's dissolution in 2002; Ms. Love's announcement of a Hole reunion in 2009 that seemed to surprise Ms. Auf der Mar; Mr. Erlandson's remarks that "there is no Hole without me" and Ms. Love's online reply that Hole is "MY Band" and "MY name." A Q. and A. with Mr. Ebersole and the band members is set to follow the screening; there was no mention of whether it would be conducted from within a steel cage.

It was never the famous "meet-me-under-the-clock" clock at the old Biltmore Hotel. Nor is it the gilded four-faced centerpiece in the concourse of Grand Central Terminal. It was just a plain workaday clock that spent most of its life in a lower-profile nook at Grand Central answering one of two questions: Can I make the train, for people sprinting to catch one, or how late was it, for people sprinting off a train that had finally arrived.

In the autumn of 2006, NBC found itself with a surfeit of shows (which is to say, two) with numerically themed titles that were set backstage at fictional television sketch programs. The first, "30 Rock," created by Tina Fey, was a rapid-fire sitcom containing zany shenanigans, wacky hijinks and roughly 100 jokes per minute. The second, "Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip," created by Aaron Sorkin, was an hour-long drama about philosophical and aesthetic debates, the pioneering satire of Gilbert and Sullivan and, somehow, the delicacy of hostage negotiations during wartime. Guess which one survived its freshman season?

Marietta Ladies', Men's and Children's Wear has been part of my neighborhood in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, for over half a century. Hand-lettered signs fill the display window ("Heavy sox, $1.50 a pair"). Inside, the walls are lined with honey-colored wooden drawers stuffed with bras and pajamas. Two elderly brothers run the shop, which they inherited from their mother. I often go in to buy T-shirts (rung up on a cash register that, like the brothers, is old but still working).

The imperiled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan dates from the 1960s. Forty-plus years may not be a long time when it comes to radioactive decay - 300 years to go for the Switzerland-size contaminated area around Chernobyl - but it can feel like close to forever when you think about the engineering and technological advances since the pre-moon-landing days. Steven Chu, the secretary of energy, says that the 23 American reactors (more than 20 percent of our reactor fleet, by the way) built according to the same design as the Fukushima Daiichi station are continually "upgraded" to ensure their safety. But still. As one of our contributing writers, Jon Gertner, put it a few years ago, "Nuclear power plants are arguably the most complicated machines in the history of civilization." Even as that partly hints at why their failures can be so catastrophic, it also prompts the question: Shouldn't we have more than upgrades by now? Shouldn't we have much more advanced nuclear "machines" already?

As expected, many Agenda readers took us to task for a post last week that considered the burden small businesses would bear if the expanded 1099 reporting requirements embedded in the health care overhaul are not repealed. She recorded them describing the incident, then set it to this re-enactment complete with crazy white wig.

Whereas my colleague Jeff Erickson recently ranked closers, I'd like to take a step further and look over relievers who could end up factoring in your league's save category this season. Closers-in-waiting have become increasingly overpriced in recent years, which is a mistake, given how volatile relief pitching is year-to-year. Nevertheless, 20 to 30 percent of a typical fantasy league's saves during the season come off the waiver wire, so this aspect can't be ignored. Just let your own league dictate which middle relievers to grab. I'm not ranking the following for a reason - all are similar, so you might as well take those who come cheapest.

LEAVE A MESSAGE Some people say it with flowers. Others prefer e-mail. Lloyd C. Blankfein, left, once a BlackBerry aficionado, says voice mail is now his chosen method of communication. In court on Wednesday, testifying at the insider trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam, Mr. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, told jurors that he sometimes did not read his e-mail, preferring instead to listen to voice mail. He testified that he typically digested the day's daily profit and loss statement via voice mail.

He touched the lives of many and will be sadly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Mona, to their children, and to the entire family. Mary E. D'Alton, MD, New York-Presbyterian Sloane Hospital for Women, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, Chair Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology.

While MTV executives plot how to extend the shelf life of their two biggest hits, ''Jersey Shore'' and ''Teen Mom,'' they have one show that seems not to have an expiration date: ''The Real World.'' The network announced on Tuesday that it had ordered two more seasons of the 19-year-old ''Real World,'' which inspired much of the reality programming that came along later, like ''Jersey Shore.'' The show's 25th season, set in Las Vegas, had its debut this month. MTV noted in a news release that it ranked No. 1 among all programs in its Wednesday night time slot among 12- to 34-year-olds. The 26th season is being cast now, and the renewal will take it through Season 28.

FAUPEL--Leonard Brigham. Leonard Brigham Faupel, 90, of Sea Girt, NJ passed away on March 22, 2011. Born in Irvington, NJ on June 24, 1920, Mr. Faupel graduated from Irvington High School in 1937. At the outbreak of WWII, he enlisted in the Army Air Force and served in Intelligence for the 8th Air Force, earning a Bronze Star, a Presidential Citation (Division Award) and three campaign ribbons. Returning from the war in 1945, he went to work at P. Ballantine & Sons Brewery in Newark. There, Len fell in love with and married Jacqueline Kuett in 1947. The couple settled in Maplewood, NJ. Mr. Faupel's professional career in marketing and advertising spanned 40 years. At Ballantine, Len became Advertising and Public Relations Director. He oversaw Ballantine's sponsorship of the Yankees and football Giants, and helped pioneer the explosive growth of televised sporting events we take for granted today. From Ballantine, Mr. Faupel was hired as Senior Vice President at William Esty Co. in New York City. His creative talents promoted brands including Mastercard, Seagram, Colgate, Genesee Beer and SAS Airlines. Len was a dedicated family man and community servant. He chaired the Maplewood Recreation Committee for ten years and was President of the Maplewood Little Club. After retiring in 1985, Mr. Faupel moved with Jacqueline to Sea Girt where he served on the Planning Board. An avid craftsman, he and Mrs. Faupel built two homes in Sea Girt. Active and engaged all his life, Mr. Faupel directed considerable time and energy to organizations dedicated to special needs individuals; in particular, the Bancroft School, where he was a member of the Board of Trustees, Chair of the Board of Rehabilitation Services, and a member of several other boards. In recent years, Len served as a board member of Plan/New Jersey, an organization whose mission is to ensure lifetime good care for individuals with special needs. In addition to his beloved wife, Jacqueline, Len is survived by sons Mark and John, daughter Caroline Keating, granddaughters Erinn and Jessica, grandsons Matthew Devlin and Sean, sister Nancy Benner and family, and many more beloved extended family members and treasured friends. Visitation will take place at O'Brien Funeral Home, 2028 Hwy. 35, Wall, NJ, on Saturday, March 26, 2011, from 2-5pm. A service will take place at the funeral home at 5pm. Cremation will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Bancroft Foundation, to Plan/New Jersey, or to other special needs charities. For further information or to send condolences to the family, please visit: www.obrienfuneralhome.com.

Dear stepfather of Jonathan, Carolyn, Cheryl and Cynthia. Funeral Service is Today at 12 noon at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY 10538. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, New York.

WEINGLASS--Leonard. The Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR) deeply mourns the passing of Leonard Weinglass, one of the great progressive trial lawyers of the last fifty years. Len was co-counsel with CCR founder Bill Kunstler in the renowned Chicago 8 case, fought to obtain a fair trial for the Cuban 5, and was a true inspiration and mentor to young lawyers. We will miss Lenny terribly and offer our love and sincere condolences to his family.

The Bolzano Journal article on March 17, about an autonomous region of Italy and divisions in the country on the 150th anniversary of its unification, referred imprecisely to a treaty with Austria that made the region part of Italy. While Italy signed the treaty, it was not the only country to do so. The pact was signed by all of the victorious allies in World War I, which included Italy. The article also referred incorrectly to the excommunication of Italian kings for their role in the Catholic Church's loss of its temporal powers. It predated the establishment of the Italian republic in 1946; it was not for the kings' allowing the ''nascent republic'' to remove those powers.

The Advertising column on Monday, about ConAgra's efforts to focus attention on child hunger, misstated the age of a boy featured in a program financed by the company and hosted by Al Roker of the ''Today'' show on NBC. The boy, who says ''I eat less so my sisters can have another meal,'' is 15, not 8.

Updated: Walgreen's announcement today that it plans to purchase the Web business drugstore.com for $409 million highlights the radically different business strategies of the nation's two leading drugstore chains. Walgreen, with about 7,600 stores, is focused on retail sales. Just two weeks ago, it announced it was selling its pharmacy benefits management business for $525 million. The purchase of drugstore.com means Walgreen will essentially flip the benefit management money into Web retail expansion.

DAVIS--Ruth, 1917-2011. Wife, mother, teacher and bridge player extraordinaire, Ruth faced life's challenges with spunk and intelligence. She will be missed. Survived by Joyce Davis of Belmont, MA.

Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, made a pretty convincing Senator John McCain when he appeared as himself in ''Wedding Crashers'' and on ''Saturday Night Live,'' but HBO Films has decided to go a different route in casting for its television movie ''Game Change.'' On Wednesday night HBO said it had picked Ed Harris, right, the Oscar-nominated star of ''Apollo 13'' and ''Pollock,'' to play Mr. McCain in the film, which is adapted from the book of the same title by John Heilemann and Mark Halperin. ''Game Change'' will chronicle Mr. McCain's 2008 presidential campaign, starting with his selection of Sarah Palin, who was the governor of Alaska at the time, as his running mate. HBO previously announced that Julianne Moore would play Ms. Palin in the film, which will be directed by Jay Roach (''Dinner for Schmucks'') and written by Danny Strong. A broadcast date has not been announced.

ARNEL--Lloyd, 82, of New Preston, Connecticut, died suddenly March 22, 2011. Cherished husband of Laurette for 56 years. True friend and devoted father to Ross and his wife Chris, and Lisa Arnel Marti. Adoring grandfather of Michelle and Samantha Arnel. Loving brother to Carol Greenberg and the late Robert Arnel. Lloyd, an executive in the life insurance industry, CLU, ChFC, member of the New York, Estate Planning Council, Lifetime member of the Million Dollar Roundtable, qualified for the National Quality Industry award. He was a Board member of the Lake Waramaug Association. A lover of Broadway music, he was a great sports fan-especially for the Mets, Giants, and Knicks. He was handsome, witty, an avid tennis player, eclectic reader, wise friend, and sidekick of his shih tzu, Saki. He made us all feel safe, warm, treasured. Shiva on Sunday March 27, 3:30-8:00pm and Monday, March 28, 5:30-8pm at the home of Ross and Chris Arnel, 103 Clive Street, Edison, New Jersey, 08820.

NICHOLSON--Jean Baptiste, O.S.U.,Educator Sister Jean Baptiste Nicholson, principal of The Ursuline School in New Rochelle, NY from 1974 and president from 2005 to 2009, died at White Plains Hospital on March 23, 2011. She was 75 years old. Jean Baptiste, known as JB, brought strong leadership to The Ursuline School, a private Catholic school for girls grades 6-12. It was honored three times as a National Blue Ribbon School of Excellence. She increased enrollment and diversity, enriched academic programs, athletics, programs for students' personal development. She held BA in classics from College of New Rochelle and MA in Latin and Greek from The Catholic University of America. She taught at Ursuline Academy in Bethesda, MD and at St. Joseph's Academy in Malone, NY. Principal at The Urusline School in 1973 until 2009, with title President Emerita. Active in local community and on Board of Trustees of the College of New Rochelle. Born in New York to Helene and John Nicholson in 1936. Predeceased by one brother.Survived by three sisters and nephews and nieces. Wake at Ursuline Provincialate, 1338 North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY, on Thursday, March 24 from 7 to 9pm and on Friday, March 25 from 3 to 8pm. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, March 26, at College of New Rochelle. Burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Ursuline Sisters Retirement Fund or to The Ursuline School. www.LloydMaxcy.com

8 P.M. (National Geographic) FISH WARRIOR The adventure angler Jakub Vagner travels to the Trinity River in Texas in search of the alligator gar, above, with Mr. Vagner. With what resembles the body of a fish and the head of an alligator, the gar is known for its bony skull, armorlike scales and piercing teeth. But those defenses don't protect it from overfishing and environmental changes. Mr. Vagner helps scientists tag several fish for tracking and research. He also wants to catch and release a huge gar for the fun of it and manages to land one that stretches six feet and weighs 125 pounds. At 9 p.m., on ''Beast Hunter,'' the host, Pat Spain, who tries to uncover the truth behind mythical creatures, travels to the Gobi Desert in Mongolia to look for the so-called death worm. This creature is rumored to spray acid, send out electric shocks and explode when threatened. A woman who claims to have seen it says her family members were so frightened when they spotted one on their land that they moved the next day. 7:30 P.M. (21) CONSUELO MACK WEALTHTRACK The financial historian Niall Ferguson, left, is interviewed and discusses diminishing Western economic and political power and what the United States could do to prevent further loss of influence. The topic is covered in Mr. Ferguson's latest book, ''Civilization: The West and the Rest.''

An article last Friday about President Obama's planned meetings with Brazil's new president, Dilma Rousseff, during his trip to Latin America this past week misstated her trade policy regarding China. Like Mr. Obama, Ms. Rousseff has been pressing China to raise the value of the Chinese currency, not lower it. (A more expensive Chinese currency would make China's goods more expensive in both the United States and Brazil, where manufacturers complain that cheap Chinese imports are hurting them.)

In an appearance on Wednesday on BET's ''106 & Park,'' the singer Chris Brown, above, apologized for his actions on Tuesday during a visit to ABC's ''Good Morning America,'' which resulted in a broken window in his dressing room. In an interview with Mr. Brown on Tuesday, Robin Roberts, one of the show's co-anchors, asked about his relationship with the pop star Rihanna, whom Mr. Brown pleaded guilty to assaulting in 2009. Mr. Brown replied that a restraining order against him had been relaxed and avoided Ms. Roberts's follow-up questions. After Mr. Brown left the studio, staff members discovered the broken window. On ''106 & Park,'' Mr. Brown said he apologized ''to anybody who was startled in the office, anybody who was offended or really disappointed in my actions, because I was disappointed in the way I acted.'' He added that when he gives interviews, he and his representatives are usually shown ''a talking-points sheet,'' and if they feel they cannot ''equally accomplish a goal,'' then ''we usually kind of back out.'' Mr. Brown said he was ''thrown off by'' his interview. He continued: ''I felt like, it was like, O.K., you told us this just so they could get us on the show to exploit me.'' ABC said in a statement at ABCNews.com that Mr. Brown was invited ''to perform and to be interviewed. There were no talking points offered.''

PFLASTER ROSNER--Claire. The management, brokers and staff of Warburg Realty mourn the unexpected loss of our beloved colleague Claire Rosner. Claire was unique. First and foremost a sculptor, Claire had a long career as an agent - a job at which she excelled when she put her mind to it. Impervious to technology, funny, quirky, head strong, warm and charming, she will be impossible to replace in our office and our hearts. We extend all our sympathy to her husband Felix Pflaster, her son David, daughter Victoria and her grandson Judah whom she lovingly referred to as "Mushkie". The world will be a less fun and interesting place without Claire in it.

FURTH--Valerie Jakober, 85, passed away at home on March 23. She is survived by her sons, Mark (Lola) and Peter (Susan) and grandchildren Michael, Edward, Shoshana, Melanie and Joshua. Valerie's indomitable spirit inspired all who knew her. She was born in Munkacs, Czechoslovakia. Deported to Auschwitz in 1944, she was liberated in April 1945. She emigrated to New York in 1948 and married her devoted Frank in 1949. They were together for 52 years. Valerie studied with Louise Nevelson and became an accomplished painter and sculptor. In the mid-1970s she began a series of paintings and sculptures from her Holocaust experiences. She then published a book, Cabbages and Geraniums, and told her story in schools and communities. Valerie and Frank were Benefactors of the Museum of Jewish Heritage. Funeral services will be held Friday, March 25 at 11:30am at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 E. 51st St. Donations can be made to Sutton Place Synagogue designated for the Valerie and Frank Furth Shoah Fund; the Museum of Jewish Heritage; or the University of Rochester designated for the Valerie and Frank Furth Fund.

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Path to Peace Foundation, 25 East 39th Street, New York, NY 10016.

LIBYA Prominent members of NATO reached a tentative agreement to separate the political and military leadership of the Libyan air campaign, as allied warplanes delivered a ferocious round of airstrikes on Libyan ground forces, tanks and artillery. YEMEN As antigovernment demonstrators planned a new round of rallies on Friday, President Ali Abdullah Saleh was engaged in serious negotiations with leaders of the protest movement over the timing and conditions for him to end his 32-year rule, Yemeni and American officials said. But no deal had been reached. SYRIA The government of President Bashar al-Assad announced a series of reforms, including greater freedom for the media and political parties and a reconsideration of the emergency law that has been in effect for 48 years. The announcement came as thousands of demonstrators massed again in the southern city of Dara'a, demanding democratic reforms and protesting the death of scores of people who were shot by security forces this week. JORDAN More than 1,000 pro-democracy demonstrators set up a tent camp in the center of Amman, the capital, in a deliberate imitation of Tahrir Square in Cairo. They said they would remain until they saw real change, including an end to corruption, greater economic equality and an end to autocratic rule.

Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers. So it is with some Knick fans, who seem convinced that their team is on the brink of an epic collapse that would keep them out of the postseason.
Arthur Ross Architecture Gallery Buell Hall, Columbia University

The Weinstein Company said on Thursday that it would release a PG-13 version of ''The King's Speech,'' its Academy Award-winning film about King George VI (played by Colin Firth, below) and the speech therapist (Geoffrey Rush) who helped him tame his stammer. The film, which also won Oscars for best director (Tom Hooper), actor (Mr. Firth) and original screenplay (David Seidler), was originally released with an R rating. The Weinstein Company did not immediately explain what changes it was making, but presumably some un-regal language will be toned down. In a statement, ErikLomis, the Weinstein Company's president for theatrical distribution and home entertainment, thanked the Motion Picture Association of America for its ''wisdom and swift action.'' He added: ''The action enables those to whom it speaks most directly -- young people who are troubled by stuttering, bullying and similar trials -- to see it.'' The PG-13 version will be shown starting April 1, and will be the only version available in theaters at that time, at least until someone figures out how to make it into an animated G-rated film.

East OHIO STATE, the No. 1 overall seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament field, has played like it so far. The Buckeyes won their first two games by an average of 30.5 points, but in Newark they face a much tougher test in No. 4 KENTUCKY. Everyone expected No. 2 NORTH CAROLINA to advance to the Round of 16. Not many expected the same of No. 11 MARQUETTE. Now the Golden Eagles have the unenviable task of trying to salvage the reputation of the Big East. That won't be an easy feat in this region, which features some of the most tradition-rich programs in college basketball. Southwest One of these teams is not like the others. The odd one out is, surprisingly, No. 1 KANSAS, the lone single-digit seed in San Antonio. The Jayhawks' opponent, No. 12 RICHMOND, is a significant underdog. No. 11 VIRGINIA COMMONWEALTH has come a long way since Selection Sunday, when the Rams' inclusion in the field was derided by some bracket observers. V.C.U. proved its worth with emphatic victories over Georgetown and Purdue. Its next hurdle is No. 10 FLORIDA STATE, which used a stifling defense to dominate No. 2 seed Notre Dame and advance to the Round of 16.
Edward Thorp Gallery 210 11th Avenue, at 25th Street

ROTHSTEIN--Paula, died March 23, 2011 at the Classic Residence in Teaneck, New Jersey. She was 91 years old and had previously resided in Englewood Cliffs for over forty years. Paula was born in Vienna, Austria in 1920, the daughter of Sabine and Samuel Youngerman and the sister of Henry Youngerman. She came to New York in 1938 and worked in the publishing business until 1945, when she married Norbert Rothstein, who predeceased her. Paula had two sons, Kenneth and Peter, before returning to school and completing her B.S., M.A. and Ph.D. degrees at New York University. She subsequently taught German language and literature at several local colleges. Paula was an accomplished pianist, who also loved opera and traveled extensively. She had a sharp sense of humor and was not afraid to express her opinions. In addition to her two sons, Paula is survived by her loving daughter-in-law Carole Haber and her two grandchildren, Emma and Noah Rothstein. In addition, she is survived by her beloved nieces and nephews Caroline Altschuler, Sharon (Jose) Camacho, Susan (Andrew) Needelman, Sylvia (Harold) Nudelman, Andrew (Joyce Wasserman) Rothstein and Barry Youngerman. The family wishes to express its thanks to the staff of the Classic Residence for the kindness and compassion that they showed Paula during the last years of her life. In addition, we offer a special thank you to Paula's loyal aides, Bibi Edun and Danielle Jones, who were her constant and loving companions during the closing chapter of Paula's long and active life. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the New York Public Library, where Paula spent countless hours in preparation of her dissertation. Service 2pm Sunday at Gutterman & Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. May her memory be for a blessing.

He blessed us for many years with his presence, with his inspiration, consolation, counsel and good humor. He is greatly missed. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated in the Parish Church, 65 East 89 Street, on Tuesday, March 29, at 6pm.

A headline in the National Briefing column on Thursday misidentified the state that was the subject of the report, on a legislative stalemate. As the report correctly noted, progress has been made in ending an impasse in the legislature in Indiana -- not in Illinois, the state to which Democratic legislators from Indiana fled to delay votes on Republican-backed education- and labor-related bills.

WEINGLASS--Len. The National Lawyers Guild deeply mourns the death of our beloved colleague, friend and stalwart member, Len Weinglass. Others may recall his brilliant legal career, but for us the loss is deeply personal. He was an inspiration and a model whose passing leaves a gaping hole in the front lines of the fight for freedom and justice that cannot be quickly or easily filled. His memory and example, however, will renew for the entire Guild our commitment and dedication to the causes that Len fought for so bravely and passionately until his last breath.

John Kander, 84, who with Fred Ebb spent four decades creating some of musical theater's greatest shows, including ''Cabaret'' and ''Chicago,'' is teaming up with a 32-year-old playwright and fiction writer, Gregory Pierce, on Mr. Kander's first full new theater collaboration with another writer since Ebb's death in 2004. Douglas Aibel, artistic director of the Off Broadway Vineyard Theater, said on Thursday that it was developing that work: three one-act musicals that are linked by the same theme, about characters confronting what it means to get what they think they want. The Vineyard recently held a private workshop on the first one-act, ''Andra,'' short for Andromeda. Mr. Kander, the composer, said he met Mr. Pierce years ago through their Oberlin College alumni network. In the last year or two, Mr. Kander said, he began talking to Mr. Pierce about doing an intimate musical project, and Mr. Pierce, a published short-story writer, suggested ideas. ''Greg and I started playing the old game 'What if?' that Fred and I used to develop plot lines,'' Mr. Kander said. ''I sort of assumed I would be writing the lyrics, but it turned out that Greg is a terrific lyricist.''

Curtis, Executive Director of Bellevue Hospital Center and member of the GNYHA Board of Governors. We send our deepest sympathies to Lynda and the entire Curtis family. Pamela Brier Chair, GNYHA Kenneth E. Raske, President, GNYHA

GIN--David Y. The staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center note with sadness the untimely death of our esteemed colleague David Y. Gin, a brilliant and talented chemist who joined the Sloan-Kettering Institute's Molecular Pharmacology and Chemistry Program in 2006. Dr. Gin was working at the nexus of synthetic chemistry, clinical trials, and research to develop new, safer, and more-potent immunological and therapeutic agents for cancer and infectious diseases. He was a gentle, kind, good-humored, and remarkable human being who will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Mary; his children, Duncan and Laura; and his entire family. David A. Scheinberg, MD, PhD Chair, Molecular Pharmacology and Chemistry Program Thomas J. Kelly, MD, PhD Director, Sloan-Kettering Institute Craig B. Thompson, MD President & CEO, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

6:43 p.m. | Updated Doug Hampton, the former senior aide to Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada, was indicted on Thursday for violating a one-year lobbying ban, an unexpected development in a case that only became a subject of a federal criminal investigation after Mr. Hampton himself accused his former boss of instructing him to ignore the lobbying ban. Mr. Hampton is accused of repeatedly contacting Mr. Ensign's office in 2008 and early 2009 to seek assistance for two Nevada companies that the senator had helped him get lobbying jobs with, after Mr. Ensign was caught having an affair with Mr. Hampton's wife.

'Infinite Variety: Three Centuries of Red and White Quilts' (through Wednesday) Viewing just a few quilts, with their intricacies of color, pattern and theme, can be a feast for the eyes. Taking in a display of 650 quilts from a private collection can be an out-of-body experience. Presented at the Seventh Regiment Armory by the American Folk Art Museum as part of its Year of the Quilt, the exhibition -- which organizers say is one of the largest of its kind under one roof -- features examples from the past 300 years, all using a traditional red-and-white color scheme and each with a different design. (Above, a rendering of the show, which was being installed this week.) Some quilts depict objects, like airplanes; some have symmetrical designs and optical illusions. Special exhibition events include a lecture by the show's designers (Friday at 6 p.m.); a panel discussion about contemporary quilt-making (Saturday at 4 p.m.); and a talk on the history of red-and-white quilts (Sunday at 2 p.m.). 643 Park Avenue, at 67th Street; (212) 616-3930, folkartmuseum.org/infinitevariety. The display is free, but event tickets range from $20 to $30 ($15 to $25 for museum members and students). Viewing hours are 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. on Friday, Saturday, Monday and Tuesday, and 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Sunday and Wednesday. You may never again think of a quilt as just something to throw over a bed. (Anne Mancuso)

QUINN--John Joseph, Jr. John (Jack) Joseph, Jr. passed away Tuesday, March 22, 2011, in New York City. A loving and devoted husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife of 32 years Corinne Quinn, his five children, daughters Kelli Nagel, Jeanette Honigsbaum and Susan Quinn; and sons John Quinn IV, and James Quinn; grandchildren Olivia and Max Honigsbaum of London, England; and his sister Nan Chezek of Ohio. Born in 1934 in the Bronx, NY, to his parents John and Jean Quinn. He attended Fordham Preparatory School in The Bronx, class of '52 where he ran track and set several NYC records, one of which still stands today. Graduated Fordham University, B.S. School of Business., 1956. Served his country with honor, as a Captain in US Air Force 1956-1959. 1956 joined Arthur Young & Company, New York, where he began a long and distinguished career as a CPA. He was one of the youngest members of the firm to make Partner in 1970 at the age of 36. Member of the AICPA and New York State Society of CPA's. He retired as a Partner from Ernst & Young, New York, in 1994. A loving, generous man with a big heart and great sense of humor, some of Jack's favorite moments were spent at his summer house in Long Beach Island, NJ, with his wife Corinne, his children and grandchildren. A lifelong fan of the New York Yankees and New York Football Giants. He will be remembered as a great man who was always there for his wife, children and friends. We love you and will miss you always. Friends may call Thursday and Friday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, March 26, 2011 at 10am at Our Saviour Church, Park Ave at 38 St, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Fordham University, Development and University Relations, 888 Seventh Ave, Seventh Floor, New York, NY 10019.

STENBORG HUGHES--Helen, died Tuesday evening March 22 at her home in Manhattan. A Tony-nominated, Drama Desk and Obie-Award winning Actress, she was married for fifty six years to the late Tony-Award winning actor Barnard Hughes. Born January 24, 1925 in Minneapolis, MN, she is survived by her son Doug, her daughter Laura and her grandson Sam. A funeral service will be held on Monday April 4th at 10:30am at The Church of The Transfiguration, also known as The Little Church Around The Corner-1 East 29th St. between Fifth and Madison. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg hasn't seen ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' but he's planning to join the cultural crush of sketch comedy lampooning that problem-plagued musical. For Saturday night's annual Inner Circle benefit dinner, which will feature skits by the City Hall press corps and the mayor, Mr. Bloomberg is planning to work some elements from ''Spider-Man'' into his act -- including, if the technical elements jell, Hizzoner flying through the Hilton New York's grand ballroom, according to two people who work on ''Spider-Man'' and have been briefed on the mayor's plans. The two people would speak only on condition of anonymity because Mr. Bloomberg has insisted on keeping the nature of his performance a secret. The mayor's office hasn't sought flying advice from the ''Spider-Man'' production, nor has he borrowed a costume, the two people said, and it was not clear Thursday if he would appear in Spidey's red, white and blue outfit. The mayor's spokesman, Stu Loeser, declined to comment. A spokesman for ''Spider-Man,'' Rick Miramontez, said in response to questions on Thursday: ''If he were to don the Spidey outfit, everyone at 'Spider-Man' would be delighted, of course. And we know he'd look good in tights.'' The Inner Circle, which donates money to charities, was formed in 1922 by New York newspaper reporters covering City Hall.

My Sunday column is about the way Mubarakism is continuing in Egypt, even without Mubarak. I tell this largely through the story of a young woman who was arrested this month by the army for her political activism, then beaten, given electric shocks, and subjected to a forced "virginity exam" as a way to humiliate and punish her. These extrajudicial tools of torture and military detention reflect the efforts of the Egyptian armed forces to intimidate democracy activists and prevent the democratic revolution from chipping away at army control.
