''He signed up for the Navy when he was 13.'' He came back to New York to work as a firefighter with Engine 20 on Lafayette Street in Lower Manhattan. A century ago, he watched from near the corner of Greene Street and Washington Place as young women and men dropped from the sky, escaping fire on the ninth floor of the Triangle shirtwaist factory. Standing outside the building on Friday morning, young women, dressed as they would have been for work on March 25, 1911, sang out the names of the girls and the streets they had left early that morning, making their ways to the shirtwaist factory.East Third Street,Ida Pearl,East Fourth Street,Violet Schochep, Morris Bernstein and Mary Herman.

The cover article this weekend about the actor Sean Penn and his charitable efforts in Haiti refers incorrectly to his relief group. It is known legally as J/P Haitian Relief Organization, not Jenkins/Penn Haitian Relief Organization. (When the group first came together, the J referred to Diana Jenkins, a philanthropist and entrepreneur, a co-founder.)
A book excerpt on March 13 about the life of Yuri Gagarin, a Soviet astronaut, misspelled the name of a luxury resort where he and other astronauts stayed in 1961. It is Tesseli, not Kisseli.

SCHORR--Norman A.,age 91, will be greatly missed by his wife of 56 years, Thelma; daughters Susan, Margie and Betsy; sons-in-law Joe Gurvets and Eric Grossman; grandchildren Nina, Simon, Alex, Rebecca and Josh; sister, Lillian Soson and her family; and his many friends and admirers. He will be remembered for his compassion, dry wit, intelligence, strength, integrity and passionate commitment to doing right. He loved his family, his friends, freedom of the press, Reconstructionist Judaism, democracy, theater and the University of Michigan. We loved him. Services Sunday 11am at SAJ, 15 West 86th St.

An article on Tuesday about Chinese censorship of digital communications began with a description of two interrupted cellphone calls, which were cited as possible examples of ''a host of evidence over the past several weeks'' that the authorities were increasing their monitoring efforts out of concern that antigovernment sentiment might spread from Arab countries. In one call, a Beijing entrepreneur lost his cellphone connection after he used the English word ''protest'' twice. In the second, a call was lost after the speaker twice used the Chinese term for protest. The article did not point out that in both cases, the recipients of the calls were in the Beijing bureau of The New York Times. Because scrutiny of press communications could easily be higher than for those of the public at large, the calls could not be assumed to represent a broader trend; therefore, those examples should not have been given such prominence in the article.

An article on Thursday about the popularity of the Philippines president, Benigno S. Aquino III, eight months into his tenure, misstated the year that his father, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., an opponent of the dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos, was assassinated. It was 1983, not 1985.

Melvin Sparks, a guitarist whose brightly sinewy style made him an in-demand session player during the soul-jazz boom of the late 1960s and early '70s, a touchstone during the acid-jazz trend of the '90s and a wise elder on the jam-band scene of the last decade, died on March 13 at his home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 64. His wife, Judy Hassan, confirmed his death and said that he had diabetes and high blood pressure.
An obituary on Friday about the playwright Lanford Wilson misstated, in some copies, the day he died. It was Thursday, not Wednesday.

Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libya leader, misspelled the surname of a member of the exiled Libyan royal family, who described how Colonel Qaddafi and his relatives had established bank accounts around the world in the names of members of Libyan tribes that remained loyal to his government. The exiled royal is Idris Abdulla Abed al-Senussi, not al-Sonosi.

With fighter planes darting around at a cost of $13,000 an hour, and Tomahawk missiles worth $1.4 million apiece, lawmakers have been concerned about how much the intervention in Libya could cost the Pentagon. But the easy destruction of Libya's air defenses, and the success in shifting much of the mission to allied forces, have probably limited the initial expenses to several hundred million dollars, analysts said.

They speak of his friends, the troubled composition of his Cello Sonata, his favorite hot chocolate. Six letters by Frédéric Chopin went on display this week at the Chopin Museum in Warsaw after having been hidden from view since World War II. The missives date from 1845 to 1848, a year before Chopin's death, and were written from Paris and Nohant in central France -- the childhood home of George Sand, Chopin's lover -- to the composer's family. It was a time of considerable turmoil in the Chopin-Sand domestic arrangement. The letters were held by Laura Ciechomska, a grandniece of Chopin, until at least 1939, a museum curator, Alicja Knast, said, according to The Associated Press. They resurfaced in 2003, and the museum later acquired them, The A.P. reported. Above, an envelope from the collection.

COOPER--William C.,M.D. We mourn the passing of our colleague, friend, and former director division of Ophthalmology, William C. Cooper, M.D. Dr. Cooper was a member of the New York Hospital Queens' medical staff for more than 17 years, prior to his retirement last fall. He was the first director of the Queens Eye Center and was instrumental in modernizing and expanding the NYHQ Eye Service. He also served as Professor of Ophthalmology at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University. During his tenure at the Queens Eye Center, he treated thousands of community members to help preserve and protect the gift of their eyesight. As a generous, gifted scholar and clinician, he taught countless medical students and residents to do the same. A number of his former students currently serve in clinical leadership positions around the country. On behalf of our trustees, administration, employees and medical staff, as well as the dedicated physicians and staff of the NYHQ Eye Center, we offer our deepest condolences to his wife Elizabeth Cooper, his two daughters and his grandchildren. In memory of his lifelong passion for teaching, the Dr. William C. Cooper NYHQ Eye Center Education Fund has been established. Donations may be made via www.nyhq.org/ways--to--give. George F. Heinrich, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees Stephen S. Mills, President & Chief Executive Officer John E. Sciortino, Senior Vice President & Chief Operating Officer Stephen Rimar, M.D., Senior Vice President & Chief Medical Officer William G. Wolff, M.D., Chairman, Medical Board Jack M. Mann, M.D., President, Medical Staff Society James W. Turner, M.D., Chairman, Department of Surgery Mary Godfrey, RN, Vice President, Professional Services Anthony A. Somogyi, Chairman, Ambulatory Care Maureen Buglino, RN, Vice President, Ambulatory Care Sangwoo Lee, M.D., Director, Ophthalmology

Richard Leacock, a filmmaker who helped create the documentary style known as direct camera or cinéma vérité, and who played a pivotal role in making some of the most innovative documentaries of the 1960s, died on Wednesday at his home in Paris. He was 89. His death was confirmed by his daughter Victoria Leacock Hoffman.

Add another entry to the growing publishing genre of Twitter lit. Scribner has acquired the rights to publish a book based on the profanity-laced Twitter feed written by a fake Rahm Emanuel, later revealed to be Dan Sinker. Mr. Sinker, the founding editor of the culture magazine ''Punk Planet'' and an assistant professor at Columbia College in Chicago, was anonymously behind the much-followed Twitter feed until he revealed his identity in The Atlantic last month. The book will ''compile the tweets, annotate them and include Sinker's first-person account of the phenomenon that has attracted legions of followers and media attention,'' his publisher said in a statement on Friday. Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, plans to release the book - with a foreword by Biz Stone, a founder of Twitter - later this year. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday, suggesting personal technology devices and services to eliminate, misstated the price of CoPilot Live, a GPS app that might replace a stand-alone GPS device. It is $19.99, not $35.

Reunited and it feels so good: four members of the vintage-1990s rock band Hole, which never got along as smoothly as any Peaches & Herb song, are planning to reconvene on Monday at the New Directors/New Films series to see a documentary about the former Hole drummer Patty Schemel, the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center said. A screening at MoMA of ''Hit So Hard,'' directed by P. David Ebersole, is set to be visited by its subject, Ms. Schemel, as well as the guitarist Eric Erlandson and the bassist Melissa Auf der Maur, not to mention a certain idiosyncratic front woman and fashion plate named Courtney Love. If we sound a little surprised by the gathering (which the film series organizers say is the first time these four musicians have been together at a public event in 13 years), consider such past events in the history of Hole as: Ms. Schemel's departure from the group in 1998 and the band's dissolution in 2002; Ms. Love's announcement of a Hole reunion in 2009 that seemed to surprise Ms. Auf der Mar; Mr. Erlandson's remarks that ''there is no Hole without me'' and Ms. Love's online reply that Hole is ''MY Band'' and ''MY name.'' A Q. and A. with Mr. Ebersole and the band members is set to follow the screening; there was no mention of whether it would be conducted from within a steel cage. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

NICHOLSON--Sr. Jean Baptiste, OSU. The College of New Rochelle Community records with sadness the death of Sr. Jean Baptiste. Long-standing trustee, immediate past chair, class of 1960 and recipient, Doctor of Humane Letters 2004. Teacher and educational leader of enviable reputation, she put her considerable gifts in faith-filled service, touching and transforming generations. Her generous, wise counsel immeasurably strengthened the College whose mission she so passionately embraced. We mourn her loss and celebrate her life. Stephen J. Sweeny, Ph.D. President Michael Ambler, Esq. Chair, Board of Trustees

NEW DELHI - The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett capped off a weeklong visit to India by doing one of the things he does best, after investing - doling out folksy sayings and sensible advice to an appreciative crowd. While Mr. Buffett's first trip to India comes years, or even decades, after many Western investors and businesses have put down roots in this country, the delay does not seem to have dampened his reception. In recent days, he traveled from the technology hub of Bangalore to New Delhi, meeting with students, politicians, businesspeople and India's wealthy, and seeming to win new admirers everywhere he went.

Coming off another season of critically acclaimed work, Playwrights Horizons on Thursday announced five of the six productions in its 2011-12 lineup, including a world premiere from Gina Gionfriddo (a Pulitzer Prize finalist for ''Becky Shaw''). The season will begin in August with Pam MacKinnon's production of ''Completeness,'' by Itamar Moses (''The Four of Us''), a comedy about a computer scientist who falls for a molecular biologist. Next will be ''Milk Like Sugar,'' a co-production with the Women's Project theater company about an inner-city teenager in a pregnancy pact, written by Kirsten Greenidge (''Bossa Nova'') and directed by Rebecca Taichman (''Orlando''). Ms. Gionfriddo's new play, ''Rapture, Blister, Burn,'' will follow, directed by Peter DuBois (''Becky Shaw''). According to a news release, the play is ''an unflinching look at gender politics in the wake of 20th-century feminist ideals,'' centering on two friends who pursued different careers and start dangerously coveting the other's life. Leslye Headland, whose play ''Bachelorette'' was an Off Broadway hit, will reunite with her director on that dark comedy, Trip Cullman, for her new satire, ''Assistance,'' about young assistants suffering humiliations working for a powerful magnate. And Sam Gold will direct ''The Big Meal,'' a love story that spans 80 years, written by Dan LeFranc (''Sixty Miles to Silver Lake'').

One of the articles in our special section on Money Through the Ages (produced in partnership with the public radio program Marketplace Money) is about an 18-year-old high school senior with a choice to make. Should he go into at least $6,500 in debt each year to attend a private college or university like Juniata or Clark, or is he better off working part time and attending community college for two years before transferring to one of those colleges? Zac Bissonnette, the author of Debt-Free U and a senior in college himself, encourages students and families to take on as little debt as possible. He urged the subject of our profile, Mino Caulton of Shutesbury, Mass., to consider the University of Massachusetts, though Mr. Caulton was worried that he wouldn't get enough individual attention there.

ALEXANDER--Marilyn Lois, of Oakland Gardens, NY. Born October 22, 1937, passed away March 20, 2011. Predeceased by parents Phoenix and Beatrice Morris and brother Bert. Survived by an abundance of friends and Snowy. Graduate of City College, master of arts and educator for 32 years. A world traveler, patron of the arts, supporter of woman's rights, fashionista, a long standing member of Temple Israel of Great Neck, NY and a friend to so many. Big hug Marilyn! You have left footprints in our hearts. Donations to: American Cancer Society.

Novak Djokovic has not quite won everything this season. There was that doubles match in Indian Wells, Calif., that exhibition match against Rafael Nadal in the high altitude of Bogotá and that charity soccer match Wednesday night in Florida in which Djokovic and his A.T.P. brethren were beaten by a professional club, the Fort Lauderdale Strikers. But in the singles matches that define and redefine order in his court, Djokovic has been unbeatable in 2011. His 19-0 singles record represents the best start by a male player since Ivan Lendl in 1986, and Djokovic has done it by defeating the best of this remarkable era: Andy Murray once, Rafael Nadal once and Roger Federer three times (on three continents).

The little boy on the pony is 92 now, but he does not need a black-and-white film to remember the October afternoon in 1927 when Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig came to his family's backyard in Sioux City, Iowa. ''The whole neighborhood wanted to see Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig,'' said Phil Donohue, who was 9 years old on that day he will never forget. He is the only person in the footage who is still alive, and now lives in Sioux Falls, S.D.

SYRIA Military forces opened fire on protesters in the south of Syria, according to news reports quoting witnesses. It was unclear how many people may have died or been injured, but human rights groups said that since the antigovernment demonstrations began in the country a week ago, at least 38 people have been killed by the security forces. JORDAN Riot police officers stormed a pro-democracy rally in Amman, the capital, leaving one man dead and scores of people injured. Witnesses said the violence -- the worst since demonstrations began in Jordan in January -- came after 200 pro-government supporters used sticks and rocks to attack the pro-democracy demonstrators, who fought back. Riot police officers broke up the fighting and then used water cannons to disperse a 1,000-person tent camp that had been set up on Thursday. Muammar el-Qaddafi's forces, senior NATO officials said, while the allied effort won rare military commitments in the Arab world when a Qatari fighter jet flew on patrol and the United Arab Emirates said it would send warplanes.

HUSAMI--Nabil M.D. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and the New York-Presbyterian Sloane Hospital for Women mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague Dr. Nabil Husami. SCHORR--Norman. As a news correspondent and later as a publicist, Norman swam in a lofty mix of important world events, deadlines and wordsmithing with an urbanity that was the hallmark of the journalist giants of the 20th Century. He lived an acutely civilized life, always with style, sharing a no-matter-what gimlet with his beloved Thelma every evening. Throughout, he remained a Reconstructionist Jew and, again with his accomplished Thelma, raised three original thinkers. It is now to them and their families, and of course to Thelma herself, that West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation, sends our love.

6:30 P.M. (FX) YOU DON'T MESS WITH THE ZOHAN (2008) Adam Sandler, above, stars in this comedy as Zohan, an Israeli special agent who wants out of the violent life. He fakes his death after an encounter with a Palestinian superterrorist (John Turturro) and heads to New York to become a hairstylist. A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times that the movie was ''the finest post-Zionist action-hairdressing sex comedy I have ever seen. That it is the only one I have ever seen -- and why is that? what cultural deficiency or ideological conspiracy has prevented this genre from flourishing? -- does not much detract from my judgment.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND David Owen, the former British foreign secretary and a physician, discusses the ''hubris syndrome'' in world leaders, past and present, and the theory that it might be an acquired personality disorder. He also recalls what Lord Acton famously wrote in an 1887 letter: ''Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely.''

WILSON--Lanford. The Dramatists Guild Council mourns the death of Lanford Wilson, our honored colleague and friend. We greatly admired his work and celebrated him with the Guild's Lifetime Achievement Award in 2009. Lanford was one of the trailblazers of the Off-Off and Off-Broadway movements; a whole generation of playwrights owes him an enormous debt of gratitude. We will miss Lanford's lyric poetry and dynamic theatricality. Our deepest sympathies to his family, friends and loved ones at this time. Stephen Schwartz, President The Dramatists Guild of America

Fans will have another chance to see James Murphy, above, the LCD Soundsystem frontman and white T-shirt devotee, croon his paean to ''Drunk Girls.'' The group's sold-out final concert, on April 2 at Madison Square Garden, will be streamed live by Pitchfork, the music site announced on Friday. LCD Soundsystem, the venerable New York dance-punk act, has promised that the farewell show will last nearly three hours and be stocked with special moments: ''lcd looking for a 12 to 16 (or more) part men's chorus to help us with... something...'' was a recent post on the band's Twitter account. Tickets to the Madison Square Garden show sold out so quickly -- and, the band complained, to too many scalpers -- that additional lead-up shows were added at Terminal 5 (those also sold out). It adds up to nearly a week of LCD goodbyes, but the final concert will be broadcast only once, Pitchfork said.

An article and a picture caption on Wednesday about footage of Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig on a barnstorming tour in 1927 erroneously attributed a distinction to the film clip. While the reel of this scene was a ''recent discovery,'' the clip itself was not. At least one other copy of that footage already existed and had been shown publicly before, including in two baseball documentaries broadcast by HBO in the 1990s. A corrective article appears today on Page B12.

Cast members of ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' held their first organized reading on Friday of the Broadway musical's new script, which jettisons the directorJulie Taymor's Geek Chorus of narrators and reduces her villainess Arachne to a supporting character, according to two members of the production who attended the reading. The new script beefs up the role of another villain, the Green Goblin (near right, played by Patrick Page, battling Reeve Carney as Peter Parker/Spider-Man), who proved popular with focus groups that the producers convened after the onslaught of negative reviews by theater critics. Most of the changes will be implemented during the show's hiatus, which starts April 19, according to the two production members, who would only speak anonymously because the producers do not want the changes discussed publicly. On Thursday, the producers said that the choreographer Chase Brock would stage new musical numbers. Mr. Brock, 27, is best known for his choreography on a popular video game, the Broadway Experience. He takes over from Daniel Ezralow. The producers ousted Ms. Taymor this month; Mr. Ezralow said at the time that he was directly assured that he would continue with the show. Ben Brantley, the chief theater critic of The New York Times, wrote in February that the musical may ''rank among the worst'' in Broadway history and that Mr. Ezralow's choreography was ''pure vintage MTV.''

McLEAN--Robert Ludlow, age 79, died peacefully at home on March 22, 2011. Colonel McLean graduated from Princeton University in 1952, and earned his MBA from New York University. He served in the army as a guided missile officer, and remained in the Army Reserves for over 30 years. After his active military duty, he was an engineer at the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory's thermonuclear fusion experiment, followed by a distinguished career in finance for 40 years. He was Chairman of the Alumni and Friends of Princeton University ROTC, Chairman of Squadron A, governor of The St. Andrews Society, the Robert Burns Society, and the Association of the U.S. Army. He is survived by his wife, Linda Durfee McLean, two daughters, Elissa McLean and Maggie McLean Suniewick, and three grandchildren. Memorial Service at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street, Tuesday, March 29, 2011 at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in his memory to Cure PSP, 30 E. Padonia Road, Suite 201, Timonium, MD 21093, or at CurePSP.org

It was never the famous ''meet-me-under-the-clock'' clock at the old Biltmore Hotel. Nor is it the gilded four-faced centerpiece in the concourse of Grand Central Terminal. It was just a plain workaday clock that spent most of its life in a lower-profile nook at Grand Central answering one of two questions: Can I make the train, for people sprinting to catch one, or how late was it, for people sprinting off a train that had finally arrived. Now it has a new home. It has been moved downstairs, to the dining concourse on the lower level. It is on the ceiling near the gates to Tracks 108 and 109.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - Making a debut as a crossword constructor in The New York Times is a pretty nifty thing. I personally hyperventilated when I got my first acceptance from Will Shortz, and even his rejections are so kind that I've had to read them through more than once to make sure I'd actually been rejected. Add to that the admiration and amazement of friends and family, as you regale them over and over with tales of construction woes and punny challenges, and it's enough to keep your head swelled long after these same people have stopped taking your phone calls.
